law.shorttitle: CONSOLIDATION OF MUNICIPAL WITH COUNTY SCHOOL MANAGEMENT IN CERTAIN COUNTIES; REFERENDUM.
law.fulltitle: An Act to provide the duties, rights, and powers of county boards of education, and for the management and control of public schools and educational matters, and for the consolidation of school management, to be effective only in counties of this State wherein is now or hereafter situated wholly or in greater territorial part a city of more than 200,000 population; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted, that this Act shall apply wherever there now is or shall hereafter be within this State a county wherein is situated wholly or in greater territorial part a city of more than 200,000 population, according to the latest U. S. Census, as taken from time to time. Act applicable to counties with city of more than 200,000 population.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that the word city or cities as used herein shall include any municipal corporation or other political subdivision the major territorial portion of whose territorial limits lie in said county at the time this Act goes into force therein. City in more than one county.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted that all public schools of such county, including all the public schools of any such city, shall, upon this Act going into force therein, be under the consolidated management and jurisdiction of the county board of education of said county; and all the duties, powers, rights, titles, and jurisdictions existing by law, local, general, or special, in the local school authorities of said city, at that time, shall pass to and vest in the county board of education. All provisions in force in said city or cities, by virtue of charter or other laws for the imposing of taxes or the appropriation of revenues to the public schools or for the purpose of education in the public schools of said city, shall remain of force, but the funds shall be turned over to the county board of education, or its authorized representative, for expenditure. As far as may be practical and constitutional, the schools of the county shall be managed as one consolidated system, due regard being had, in the expenditure of funds, to the sources from which derived. All public schools in county to be under management of county board of education.Laws as to taxes and use of revenue for city schools to remain of force; funds go to county board.Expenditure of funds.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, that this Act shall go into effect in any county of the class stated in section 1. Before this Act shall go into effect so as to consolidate the schools of any city with the county school system, with the consolidated management as stated, an election shall be held with vote favorable thereto in such city, said election to be called and held as follows: Whenever the county board of education shall so request of the city authorities of such city, said city authorities shall call an election to be held not less than 20 nor more than 40 days from the date of such request being filed, and shall give notice thereof in the newspaper in such county in which sheriff's sales are advertised, at which election a vote shall be taken as to
whether this Act shall go into effect. All voters residing in said city and lawfully qualified to vote therein shall be entitled to vote at such election. Those desiring to vote in favor of the Act to go into effect shall in substance have on their ballots the words in favor of Act consolidating school management. Those opposed to the same shall in substance have on their ballots the words against consolidated school management. The election shall be held in general conformity to the rules governing elections for mayor or other office corresponding to mayor in such city, and returns shall be made to the city authorities of said city, who shall declare the result. If the result be in favor of the Act going into force by a majority vote of those voting on the subject, this Act shall go into force on the first day of January next succeeding such election. If the result be unfavorable, no new election on the subject shall be called within one year of the date of the election last held hereunder. Referendum in city.Act effective January 1st after election.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: GEORGIA NORMAL SCHOOL; NAME CHANGED, ETC.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend An Act to establish, organize, and maintain, as a branch of the University of Georgia, a Normal School or Teachers' College, to be located at Statesboro, Georgia, and to be known as the Georgia Normal School, and to include theirin the organization plant and equipment of the First District Agricultural and Mechanical School; to provide for courses of study therein; to provide for a Board of Trustees therefor; and for other purposes, by striking from the caption
of said Act and wherever same occurs in said Act the words Georgia Normal School, and substituting therefor the words South Georgia Teachers' College; also by striking from said Act section 8, and substituting therefor a new section as section 8; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act, the Act approved August 18, 1924, establishing the Georgia Normal School at Statesboro, be and the same is hereby amended by striking from the caption of said Act and wherever the same occurs in said Act the words Georgia Normal School, and substituting therefore the words South Georgia Teachers' College. Ga. L. 1924, p. 165, amended.Name changed to South Georgia Teachers' College.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that section 8 of said Act be stricken, and be substituted therefor section 8, which shall read: Section 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said school shall have the authority to give diplomas, degrees, and certificates, and such other evidences of work done as may be authorized by law and conferred and given by other schools of like character and standing. Diplomas, degrees, etc.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, that all powers and authority given to the Board of Trustees, and all the provisions of the charter of Georgia Normal School, except where inconsistent with the powers therein given, shall be and are given to South Georgia Teachers' College, and the trustees of Georgia Normal School are hereby made the trustees of South Georgia Teachers' College until their respective terms shall expire; and all appropriations given to said Georgia Normal School are hereby expressly made available to said South Georgia Teachers' College.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: INSTRUCTION IN ANIMAL, BIRD, AND FISH LIFE.
law.fulltitle: An Act to provide a course of instructions in the public schools of Georgia for the encouragement and promotion of protection to and conservation of birds, animals, and fish, forest and any and all other forms of useful wild life, and to require the principals or teachers of every school to certify in his or her report that such instruction has been given in the schools in or under his or her control; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of same, that for the purposes of lessening crime and raising the standard of good citizenship and inculcating in the minds of the children of this State a spirit of thrift, economy, and kindness therefor, by including in the curriculum of all public schools in the State of Georgia a course of training to teach, promote, and encourage the conservation and protection of birds, animals, fish, forest, and any and all other forms of useful wild life. Purpose of Act.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that in every public school of this State a period of not less than twenty-five minutes of each week during the entire school term shall be devoted to teaching the pupils thereof the practical value of conserving and protecting birds, animals, fish, forest, and other forms of wild life; also the humane treatment and protection of our domestic birds and animals, as well as the part they fulfill in the economy of nature. It may be optional with the teacher whether this period shall be a consecutive twenty-five minutes or be divided into shorter periods during the week; and it shall also be within the discretion of the teacher as to the method of instruction to be employed. The instruction herein prescribed shall constitute a definite purpose of the curriculum of study in all the public schools of this State. Public-school instruction in bird, animal, fish, forest life, etc., 25 minutes each week of term.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that each and every teacher in the schools of this State shall certify in his or her reports that the instruction provided for has been in accordance with the provisions of this Act.
Sec. 4. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of law in conflict with the provisions of this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: INSURANCE FOR TEACHERS AND EMPLOYEES IN CERTAIN COUNTIES.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the boards of education of all counties in the State of Georgia, having a population of not less than 200,000 of the 1920 census, to insure the lives and health of all teachers and other employees of such boards of education, and authorizing such boards of education to pay the premiums to maintain such insurance; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the board of education of each county of the State of Georgia, which may hereafter have a population of not less than 200,000 of the 1920 census, is hereby authorized in its discretion to insure the lives and health of all teachers of the said county employed by the said board of education and of all other employees of the said board of education such insurance to be for the benefit of any beneficiary designated by such insured person; and each such board of education is further authorized to provide appropriations for the payment of premiums on such policies. Insurance for teachers and employees of board of education in counties of 200,000 population; payment of premiums by board.

law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act entitled an Act to incorporate the Menlo School District, Chattooga County, Georgia, to fix its boundaries, to establish therein a system of free schools, with trustees and other officers, with the right to pass rules and by laws to govern same and provide for the support and maintenance of said schools by local tax, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that an Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved August 22nd, 1905, with the above and foregoing caption and incorporating the Menlo School District in Chattooga County, Georgia, providing to establish a system of public schools therein with trustees and other officers, with the right to pass by laws to govern the same and provide for the support and maintenance of said schools by local tax, and for other purposes, be and the same is hereby repealed; however, subject to the condition that this Act shall not affect any legal contract or other obligation heretofore entered into by the proper officers of said school, nor any debt lawfully created, nor in any way affect the present status and title of the school property in said district nor any obligation or lien thereon lawfully established. Repeal of Act to incorporate Menlo School District, etc.Repeal not to affect existing contract on status of school property.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that upon the passage of this Act the said school district as created shall no longer exist under said repealed Act, and shall come under the jurisdiction of the board of education of said county as any other school district of said county laid out under the general law of said State in reference to school districts, and the general laws of the State shall be applicable thereto and of force therein in reference to the maintenance of schools, trustees, taxes, and otherwise, and the legal obligations of the board of trustees of said Menlo School District hereby repealed shall be carried out by the board of trustees created under the general law of said State. General laws applicable to district.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: MIDDLE GEORGIA COLLEGE; FIFTH AND SIXTH DISTRICT SCHOOLS; NAMES CHANGED, ETC.
law.fulltitle: An Act to change the name of the Middle Georgia Agricultural and Mechanical Junior College to Middle Georgia College, to provide that all trustees and officials of the Middle Georgia Agricultural and Mechanical Junior College shall constitute the board of trustees and officials of the Middle Georgia College, to provide for the payment of all appropriations made for the support, maintenance, and other purposes to the Middle Georgia Agricultural and Mechanical Junior College for the years 1929, 1930, and 1931, to be made payable to the Middle Georgia College; also to change the name of the Fifth District Agricultural and Mechanical School located at Monroe, Georgia; and also to change the name of the Sixth District Agricultural and Mechanical School located at Barnesville, Georgia; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of same.

Section 1. That an Act approved August 20th, 1927, establishing a Middle Georgia Agricultural and Mechanical Junior College, be and the same is hereby amended to change the name from the Middle Georgia Agricultural and Mechanical Junior College to Middle Georgia College. Middle Georgia College to be name of Middle Ga. Agricultural and Mechanical Junior College.

Sec. 2. That the present Board of Trustees and Officials of the Middle Georgia Agricultural and Mechanical Junior College shall likewise constitute the Board of Trustees and Officials of the Middle Georgia College.

Sec. 3. That all appropriations heretofore made or which may be made during the session of the General Assembly for the year 1929 for support, maintenance, and other purposes of the Middle Georgia Agricultural and Mechanical Junior College, which have not been previously paid to said school, shall be and the same are hereby made available for such purposes for the Middle Georgia College for the years 1929, 1930, and 1931 respectively, and the Governor is hereby authorized and directed to draw his warrants for the same to the Trustees of the University of Georgia for such purposes, and the State Treasurer is hereby authorized and directed to pay said sums to the Trustees of the University of Georgia for the support and maintenance of that college for said years. Appropriations.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, that the name of the Fifth District Agricultural and Mechanical School located at Monroe, Georgia, be and the same is hereby changed to The Georgia Vocational and Trades School, and all diplomas and other documents emanating therefrom shall bear the name The Georgia Vocational and Trades School. The Georgia Vocational and Trades School to be name of Fifth District A. M. School.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, that the name of the Sixth District Agricultural and Mechanical School located at Barnesville, Georgia, be and the same is hereby changed to Georgia Industrial College, and all diplomas and other documents emanating therefrom shall bear the name Georgia Industrial College. Georgia Industrial College to be name of Sixth District A M. School.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, that the courses of study in the said Georgia Vocational and Trades School and the Georgia Industrial College shall be the same as are now taught in the said Fifth District Agricultural and Mechanical School and the Sixth District Agricultural and Mechanical School, except that additional grades, subjects, and courses may be provided as may hereafter be prescribed by the Board of Trustees of the said Georgia Vocational and Trades School and the Georgia Industrial College respectively. Courses of Study.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, that the Boards of Trustees for the management and control of the said Fifth District Agricultural and Mechanical School and the Sixth District Agricultural and Mechanical School shall be and remain the same with reference to appointment, tenure of office, rights and duties for the Georgia Vocational and Trades School and the Georgia Industrial College respectively, as are now provided by law. Trustees.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted that all appropriations, donations, endowments, and properties heretofore authorized by law or heretofore made and hereafter granted to or for the Fifth District Agricultural and Mechanical School shall be for the use and support of the Georgia Vocational and Trades School and shall be paid to said school as is now provided by law. Appropriations.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, that all appropriations, donations, endowments, and properties heretofore authorized by law or heretofore made and hereafter granted to or for the Sixth District Agricultural and Mechanical School shall be for the use and support of the Georgia Industrial College and shall be paid to said college as is now provided by law.
Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: PENSIONS FOR TEACHERS IN CERTAIN COUNTIES.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to authorize the boards of education of all counties in the State of Georgia, having a population of not less than 200,000 of the 1920 census, to create a retirement or pension fund out of which to pay retirement pay or
pensions to teachers and other employees of such boards of education; to authorize such boards of education to appropriate funds therefor, and to prescribe rules and regulations governing the application and use of such funds, and determine the persons entitled to benefit therefrom; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the board of education of each county of the State of Georgia, which may hereafter have a population of not less than 200,000 of the 1920 census, is hereby authorized in its discretion to create a retirement or pension fund which shall be used, when created, for the purpose of paying to all teachers and other employees employed by such board such retirement pay or pensionas the said board may in its discretion fix from time to time; provided, however, that no such retirement pay or pension shall be paid to any such person until he or she has served as such teacher or employee of the said county board of education, or of some other educational system of this State, for a period of time not less than twenty years; and provided further that such board of education shall have authority to provide appropriations for the creation of such fund, and shall have authority to prepare and promulgate rules and regulations relating to the uses of the said fund, by which regulations the said board may, in its discretion, require that each person employed either as a teacher or employee after the adoption of such regulation contribute to the said fund such reasonable sum as may be necessary partially to maintain the said fund, and by which regulations the said board may provide that only such persons as contribute to the said fund out of their pay shall be entitled to participate in the benefits therefrom; provided, however, that such regulations shall be uniform in their application to all persons similarly situated, and that each of the persons thus similarly situated shall have an equal opportunity to participate in the benefits from the said fund. Pensions for teachers in counties of 200,000 population.

law.shorttitle: SOUTH GEORGIA AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE; NAME CHANGED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to establish a College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts, as a branch of the University of Georgia, to be known as the South Georgia Agricultural and Mechanical College, to define its purposes, powers and privileges, to provide for its location, and for other purposes, approved August 18, 1924, and published in Georgia Laws 1924, page 177, so as to change the name of said college to Georgia State College for Men, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that the Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, entitled An Act to establish a College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts, as a branch of the University of Georgia, to be known as the South Georgia Agricultural and Mechanical College, to define its purposes, powers, and privileges, to provide for its location, and for other purposes, approved August 18, 1924, and published in Georgia Laws 1924, page 177, be and the same is hereby amended by striking out the words South Georgia Agricultural and Mechanical College wherever they occur in the caption and in the body of said Act, and by substituting in lieu thereof the words, Georgia State College for Men, so as to change the name of said college from South Georgia Agricultural and Mechanical College to the name Georgia State College for Men. Georgia State College for Men to be name of South Georgia Agricultural and Mechanical College.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: SOUTH GEORGIA JUNIOR STATE COLLEGE; NAME CHANGED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to change the name of the South Georgia Junior State College, located at Douglas, Georgia, to South Georgia State College, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, that the name of South Georgia Junior State College, located at Douglas, Georgia, be changed to that of South Georgia State College. South Georgia State College to be name of South Georgia Junior State College.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

contentslist.title: ACTS.
contentslist.p: Barrow Superior Court Terms; Amending Act.
Griffin Circuit Superior Court Terms (including Fayette, Pike, Spalding and Upson Counties)two Acts.

law.fulltitle: An Act to provide for the holding of three terms of the Superior Court of Atkinson County, Georgia; to prescribe the time for holding the same; to prescribe when and how grand and petit juries shall be required to attend said court; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act there shall be held in each year three terms of the Superior Court of and for the County of Atkinson.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the terms of the said court shall be held on the third Monday in February, third Monday in July, and Fourth Monday in October of each year. Terms begin 3rd Monday in February, 3rd Monday in July, 4th Monday in October.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the judge of said court shall draw grand and petit juries for the October and February terms of said court, and in his discretion, either in term time or in vacation, he may draw grand and petit juries or either of them, as he sees fit and proper, for the July term of said court. Drawing juries.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved August 18, 1923, entitled An Act to provide for holding four terms a year of the Superior Court of Barrow County; to prescribe the time for holding the same; to prescribe when and how grand juries shall be required to attend said court, and for other purposes, by adding to section 2 of said Act the following words, to wit: Provided, however, that for the July term of said court in each year no juries shall be drawn unless the judge of the circuit shall pass an order to be spread upon the minutes of the court, certifying that the public welfare demands that a jury session of the court be held, with the reasons therefor; and in the absence of such order, only such business shall be tried or disposed of by the court during the said July term as may be tried or disposed of by the court without the intervention of a jury, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that the Act approved August 18, 1923, entitled: An Act to provide for holding four terms
a year of the Superior Court of Barrow County; to prescribe the times for holding the same; to prescribe when and how grand juries shall be required to attend said court, and for other purposes, be and the same is hereby amended by adding at the end of section 2 of said Act, after the words in each year, the following words, to wit: Provided, however, that for the July term of said court in each year no juries shall be drawn unless the judge of the circuit shall pass an order to be spread upon the minutes of the court, certifying the public welfare demands that a jury session of the court be held, with the reasons therefor; and in the absence of such order, only such business shall be tried or disposed of by the court during the said July term as may be tried or disposed of by the court without the intervention of a jury, so that said section 2 after being so amended shall read as follows: No jury for July term except by order of judge, giving reasons, etc.

blockquote.p: Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the regular terms of said court shall begin on the third Mondays in January, April, July, and October of each year, and the said regular terms of said court shall be held for two weeks each unless sooner adjourned by the judge in his discretion, so that the regular terms shall cover the two weeks beginning on the third and fourth Mondays in January, April, July, and October in each year; provided, however, that for the July term of said court in each year no juries shall be drawn unless the judge of the circuit shall pass an order to be spread upon the minutes of the court, certifying that the public welfare demands that a jury session of the court be held, with the reasons therefor; and in the absence of such order only such business shall be tried or disposed of by the court during the said July term as may be tried or disposed of by the court without the intervention of a jury. Amended Section.

law.p: Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to provide for holding three terms in each year of the Superior Court of Chattooga County, Georgia; to prescribe the time for holding the same; to designate the spring and fall terms of said court; to fix the terms for drawing a grand jury; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after th passage of this Act there shall be held in each year three terms of the Superior Court of Chattooga County, Georgia.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the terms of said court shall begin on the first Monday in February, fourth Monday in May, and second Monday in September of each year, and that the term beginning the first Monday in February shall be known as the spring term of said court, and the term beginning the second Monday in September shall be known as the fall term thereof. Terms begin 1st Monday in February (spring term), 4th Monday in May, 2nd Monday in September (fall term).

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the judge of said court shall only draw a grand jury for the February and September terms of said court; provided, that the presiding judge of said court in his discretion may, in term time or vacation, draw and require the attendance of a grand jury at the May term of said court. Drawing juries.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all proceedings of every kind and character now pending in or returnable to the superior court of said county shall relate to the terms as changed and fixed by this Act, and the next term of said court as fixed by this Act shall be the return term or trial term as the case may be, and all processes, bonds, or other proceedings whatever shall be and are hereby made returnable to the next term of said
superior court after this Act shall become of force; and that all subpoenas heretofore issued shall be returnable so as to contemplate the changes in the number of terms and the time of holding said court as herein provided, so that the person so summoned shall be and appear at the next term of said court after this Act shall become of force.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to provide for the holding of three terms annually of Fannin County Superior Court, to provide the time for holding the same; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the times of holding the regular terms of Fannin County Superior Court shall be on the second Mondays in April, August, and December of each years, changing the same from two to three terms annually. Terms begin on 2nd Monday in April, August, December.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, that this Act shall go into effect for and at the August term, 1929, of said Superior Court.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, that all civil suits returnable to the May term, 1929, of said superior court, shall be triable at the August term, 1929, of said court. Suits returnable to May term, 1929, triable at August term, 1929.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to fix the regular terms, and the times for holding same, of the superior courts in and for the several counties comprising the Griffin Judicial Circuit; to provide for the return and trial of all pending and new cases, writs, rules, orders, processes, indictments, and other matters to and at said terms of courts; to repeal all conflicting laws; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by said authority, that from and after the first day of January, 1930, the regular terms of the superior courts in and for the several counties comprising the Griffin Judicial Circuit are fixed, and the same shall be held, unless adjourned for some good cause, as follows:
In Spalding County, the weeks beginning on the 1st and 2nd Mondays in February, the 3rd and 4th Mondays in June, and the 1st and 2nd Mondays in October of each year. Terms for Spalding County.

In Pike County, the weeks beginning on the 3rd and 4th Mondays in February, the 1st and 2nd Mondays in August, and the 3rd and 4th Mondays in October of each year. Pike County.See conflicting Act, post.
In Upson County, the weeks beginning on the 3rd and 4th Mondays in March, the 3rd and 4th Mondays in August, and the 1st and 2nd Mondays in November of each year. Upson County.
In Fayette County, the weeks beginning on the 1st and 2nd Mondays in March, and the 1st and 2nd Mondays in September of each year. Fayette County.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by said authority, that all cases, writs, rules, orders, processes, indictments, and other matters pending in said several courts, and undetermined by the first day of January, 1930, shall stand for trial and determination at the next regular term of said courts
as the same has been fixed in and by section 1 of this Act, unless the judge of said courts has adjourned a regular term thereof as now fixed by law, or convenes a special term of said courts, to hear, or try, or determine any such cases, writ, rule, order, process, indictment, or other matter, in which such event same may be tried and determined at such adjourned or special term of court. That all new cases, writs, rules, orders, processes, indictments, or other matters filed in either of the courts of said circuit after the return day of the last regular term of either of said courts as now fixed by law shall be and are hereby made returnable to the next regular term of such court as the same is fixed by this Act, and thereafter same shall be made returnable to the proper term of such court as is provided for by the general laws of this State. Trial term of cases pending January 1, 1930.Return term of new cases.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by said authority, that nothing contained in this Act shall ever be construed to abridge, impair, or deny the discretion, authority, and power of the judge of said Griffin Judicial Circuit to adjourn regular terms of said courts to some other time, or to call special terms thereof, as is now or may hereafter be provided for by the laws of this State, or any other power or discretion vested by law in judges of superior courts. Power to adjourn regular terms, or to call special terms.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by said authority, that upon this Act taking effect and becoming of force as provided in section 5 hereof, all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith, and particularly all laws fixing other and different times for holding the regular terms of said several courts than as provided and fixed in this Act, be and same shall be and are hereby repealed. Repeal of conflicting laws.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by said authority, that this Act shall take effect and be of force on and after January first, one thousand nine hundred and thirty. Effective January 1, 1930.See following Act.

law.fulltitle: An Act to fix the regular terms, and the times for holding same, of the superior courts in and for the several counties comprising the Griffin Judicial Circuit, to provide for the return and trial of all pending and new cases, writs, rules, orders, processes, indictments, and other matters to and at said terms of courts, to repeal all conflicting laws; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by said authority, that from and after the first day of January, 1930, the regular terms of the superior courts in and for the several counties comprising the Griffin Judicial Circuit are fixed, and the same shall be held, unless adjourned for some good cause, as follows:
In Spalding County, the weeks beginning on the 1st and 2nd Mondays in February, the 3rd and 4th Mondays in June, and the 1st and 2nd Mondays in October of each year. Spalding County.

In Pike County, the weeks beginning on the 3rd and 4th Mondays in February, and the 4th Mondays in July, and the 1st Mondays in August, and the 3rd and 4th Mondays in November, of each year. Pike County.
In Upson County, the weeks beginning on the 3rd and 4th Mondays in March, the 3rd and 4th Mondays in August, and the 1st and 2nd Mondays in November of each year. Upson County.
In Fayette County, the weeks beginning on the 1st and 2nd Mondays in March and the 1st and 2nd Mondays in September of each year. Fayette County.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by said authority, that all cases, writs, rules, orders, processes, indictments, and other matters pending in said several courts, and undetermined by the first day of January, 1930, shall stand for trial and
determination at the next regular term of said courts as the same has been fixed in and by section 1 of this Act, unless the judge of said courts has adjourned a regular term thereof, as now fixed by law, or convenes a special term of said courts, to hear, or try, or determine any such case, writ, rule, order, process, indictment, or other matter, in which such event same may be tried and determined at such adjourned or special term of court. That all new cases, writs, rules, orders, processes, indictments, or other matters filed in either of the courts of said circuit after the return day of the last regular term of either of said courts as now fixed by law shall be and are hereby made returnable to the next regular term of such court as the same is fixed by this Act, and thereafter same shall be made returnable to the proper term of such court as is provided for by the general laws of this State. Trial term of cases pending January 1, 1930.Return term of new cases.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by said authority, that nothing contained in this Act shall ever be construed to abridge, impair, or deny the discretion, authority, and power of the Judge of said Griffin Judicial Circuit to adjourn regular terms of said courts to some other time, or to call special terms thereof, as is now or may hereafter be provided for by the laws of this State, or any other power or discretion vested by law in Judges of Superior Courts. Power to adjourn regular terms or to call special terms.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by said authority, that upon this Act taking effect and becoming of force as provided in section 5 hereof, all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith, and particularly all laws fixing other and different times for holding the regular terms of said several courts than as provided and fixed in this Act, be and the same shall be and are hereby repealed. Repeal of other laws.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by said authority, that this Act shall take effect and be of force on and after January first, one thousand nine hundred and thirty.

law.fulltitle: An Act to provide for holding three (3) terms a year of the Superior Court of Houston County, Georgia; to prescribe the time for holding the same, and for other purposes:
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after December 15th, 1929, the terms of the Superior Court of Houston County, Georgia, shall be three (3) in number and shall be held in each year.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the terms of said court shall begin on the third Monday in January, third Monday in May, and the third Monday in September in each year. Terms begin 3rd Monday in January, May, September.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved August 20th, 1927, entitled an Act to provide for the holding of three terms annually of Rabun Superior Court, to provide the time of holding the same, and for other purposes, so as to provide for the holding of the summer term of said court in August of each year, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of same, that the Act approved August 20th, 1927, entitled
an Act to provide for the holding of three terms annually of Rabun Superior Court, to provide the time of holding the same, and for other purposes, be and the same is hereby amended by striking from the fifth line of section 1 of said Act the following word, to wit, June, and by substituting in lieu of said stricken word June the word August, so that said section when so amended shall provide as follows, to wit:

Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is enacted by authority of same that the time of holding the regular terms of Rabun Superior Court shall be on the fourth Mondays in February and August, and the third Monday in November of each year, changing the same thereof from two to three terms annually. Terms begin 4th Mondays in February and August, 3rd Monday in November.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of law in conflict with the provisions of this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to provide for holding two terms a year of the Superior Court in Seminole County (Pataula Circuit), instead of three terms a year, and to prescribe the time for holding same, and to prescribe when and how the grand jury shall be required to attend said court, and to provide that instead of holding the court on the third Mondays in February, June, and October in each year, that said superior court be held the third Monday in April and the third Monday in October of each year; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authorit
of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act there shall be held in each year two terms of the Superior Court of the County of Seminole in the Pataula Circuit.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act that the terms of the Superior Court of Seminole County (Pataula Circuit) shall be held on the third Mondays in April and October in each year. Terms begin 3rd Mondays in April and October.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that there shall not be held in said County of Seminole but two terms of the superior court in said county for each year, and that the holding of the third term of the superior court in said county in said circuit heretofore named is hereby changed and modified to the extent that there shall not be held but two terms of the Superior Court in said County of Seminole.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the Judge of the Superior Court of the Pataula Circuit shall draw a grand jury for the April and October terms of said court as herein provided for, and that he may draw same either in term time or vacation and require the attendance of said grand jury at both terms of said court. Grand juries for each term.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of law in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to change the time for holding the Superior Court of Troup County in the Coweta Circuit, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that an Act entitled an Act to change the time of holding Superior Court of Troup County, same being Acts of 1916, page 69, approved July 21, 1916, be and the same is hereby repealed, to become effective on the adjournment of the July term of said court in 1929.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the time for holding Superior Court of Troup County be and the same is hereby fixed and established as beginning the first Mondays in May and the first Mondays in November of each year following the approval of this Act. The first term of court to be held under this Act being fixed as first Monday in November, 1929. Terms begin 1st Mondays in May and November.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act declaring the 11th day of November of each year, commonly known as Armistice Day, to be a public and legal holiday in this State.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, that from and after the passage of this Act the 11th day of November of each year, commonly known as Armistice Day, be and the same is hereby declared a public and legal holiday in the State of Georgia. Holiday, November 11.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to provide for the appointment by the board of commissioners of roads and revenues, in all those counties of this State which have boards of county commissioners and which counties also have a population, according to the United States Census of 1920, of not more than 25,865 and not less than 25,860, of an auditor for such counties; to prescribe the duties of such county auditor; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act, in all counties of the State of Georgia which have a board of commissioners of roads and revenues and which counties also have a population, according to the United State Census of 1920, of not more than 25,865 and not less than 25,860, the board of commissioners, when they deem it necessary, may appoint an auditor for their respective counties. Auditors for counties of 25,860 to 25,865 population.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that it shall be the duty of such county auditor, under the direction of his respective board of commissioners and in accordance with such rules as may be prescribed by said board, to audit the orders drawn on the county treasurer by the judge of the superior court and the judge of the city court of the county. Duty of auditor.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted that no order drawn by the judge of any court against the treasury of any county having an auditor under the provisions of this Act shall be paid by the treasurer of such county unless the same has been approved by the county auditor. Orders on treasurer not to be paid unless approved by auditor.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted that the term of office of such auditor shall be one year from the date of his appointment, and the county commissioners may discontinue the office of county auditor at any time they may deem best. Term of office.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted that the said county auditor shall be the clerk of the county commissioners and shall receive no additional compensation for his services as county auditor, other than his salary as said clerk of the county commissioners. Auditor to be clerk of county commissioners.
Sec. 6. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to require every person engaged in the business of selling authomobiles to make certain monthly reports to the Secretary of State; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, that from and after the passage of this Act every person, firm, or corporation engaged in the business of selling automobiles shall be required to report in writing monthly to the Secretary of State, either by depositing said report in the United States mails or by sending the same by hand, a description of all cars sold by such dealer during that month, including the make of the machine sold, the number of the machine sold, and the name and address of the purchaser to whom sold, the said report to be sent in not later than the tenth of each month. Monthly reports to Secretary of State, contents and time of.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that any person engaged in the business of selling automobiles who shall violate the provisions of this Act, by failing to send in the report herein required, shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. Violation of Act, a misdemeanor.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize banks chartered under the laws of this State, and having their principal office in a city now or hereafter having a population of not less than eighty thousand nor more than one hundred and twenty-five thousand, to establish branch banks in the city in which its principal office is located, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that banks chartered under the laws of this State, and having their principal office in a city now or hereafter having a population of not less than eighty thousand or more than one hundred and twenty-five thousand, may establish branch banks in the city in which its principal office is located. Branch banks in cities of 80,000 to 125,000 population.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize banks chartered under the laws of Georgia, and having the principal office in a municipality now or hereafter having, a population of not less than 200,000 by the last census of the United States or any future census of the United States, to establish branch banks in the municipality in which its principal office is located; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority
of the same, that banks chartered under the laws of this State, and having their principal office in a municipality now or hereafter having a population of not less than 200,000 according to the last census of the United States or any future census of the United States, may establish branch banks in the municipality in which its principal office is located. Branch banks in cities of 200,000 population.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: CANAL FROM ATLANTIC TO GULF; COMMISSION CREATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to create an Atlantic Ocean to Gulf of Mexico Canal Commission; and for other purposes.
law.p: Whereas from time to time resolutions have been passed and bills enacted by the Georgia Legislature looking to, advocating, and urging the construction of a canal thru Georgia and Florida from Cumberland Sound to some point on the Gulf of Mexico, and Preamble.

Whereas the urgency, expediency, and economy of such a canal as set out in all of said resolutions and acts are recognized and acknowledged by all Georgians who have studied the question or have in any wise become familiar with the subject-matter, and

Whereas an active authorize body should be created to represent Georgia's endorsement and active co-operation in an effort to have the government construct said canal and to appear before committees and officials of the National Government to urge the building of said canal so as to elicit the help and co-operation of States and municipalities to be benefited by the construction of said canal:
Now, therefore, be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of same.

Section 1. That a commission be and is hereby created to urge and advocate the early construction and completion of a canal thru Georgia and Florida from Cumberland Sound to the Gulf of Mexico. Appointment of commission of 12 to advocate construction of canal.

Sec. 2. That said commission shall consist of twelve members, at least six of whom shall be residents of the State of Georgia, nine of whom to be appointed by the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House acting jointly, and three of said commission to be those who compose the membership of the Georgia State Canal and Waterways Commission appointed by the Governor, as same existed before the passage of this Act. The full term of office of the members of this commission to be four years, with an initial appointment designated of four groups of three members to each group, for one, two, three, and four years, so that the term of three members of said commission shall expire every year. All vacancies on said commission are to be filled by a majority vote of the commission itself. The said twelve members shall elect their own chairman and secretary and fix compensation for same. Membership of commission.Term of commissioner.Vacancies.Officers and pay.

Sec. 3. The said commission is hereby authorized to receive and expend such monies as it may hereafter receive by appropriation of this or any other legislative body or from any other public or private source. Authority to receive and expend money.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled: An Act to prescribe the rights, duties, and responsibilities of the Coastal Highway District, a highway paving district to be composed of Chatham, Bryan, Liberty, McIntosh, Glynn and Camden Counties, to prescribe the duties of the commissioners of said district, to provide for the issuance of bonds, the expenditures of funds, and other matters and things relating to the administration of said highway district as created by a constitutional amendment passed by the Legislature of Georgia at its session in 1924 to be ratified at the subsequent general election, and for other purposes, so as to authorize the appointment of a fiscal agent to handle the collection of assessments and payment of bond maturities and interest of the Coastal Highway District bonds, to provide a means of expending the collection of assessments; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act the Board of Commissioners of the Coastal Highway District of Georgia shall have power and authority to employ a fiscal agent at such compensation as may be fixed by the board; and said fiscal agent shall have authority to collect the assessments required for the payment of interest and retirement of bonds of the Coastal Highway District from the counties composing said district, and, from the sums so collected, to pay the interest and retire the bonds. And said fiscal agent shall have such other duties and authority as may be fixed by said board of commissioners, not inconsistent with the law. Fiscal agent for Coastal Highway District; duties.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that any condemnation proceedings instituted by the Coastal Highway District for the purpose of acquiring
additional rights of way or borrow pits may be instituted either under section 5206 et seq. of the Code of Georgia, or under the Acts of 1914, page 92, as codified in section 5246(1) et seq. of Michie's Code of Georgia (1926.) Condemnation proceedings.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to fix the compensation of commissioners of roads and revenues in counties in this State, having a population of two hundred thousand according to the United States Census of 1920 or any future census; to repeal all conflicting laws; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act the compensation of commissioners of roads and revenues in counties in this State having a population of two hundred thousand or more, according to the United States census of 1920 or any future census, be and the same is hereby fixed at the sum of three hundred ($300.00) dollars per month for each commissioner, payable monthly on the first day of each month, out of the county treasury. Salaries of commissioners in counties of 200,000 population, $300 a month.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: CONDEMNATION OF LAND FOR GAS PIPE LINES.
law.fulltitle: An Act to confer the right and powr of eminent domain upon persons who are or may be engaged in constructing or operating pipe-lines for the transportation and/or distribution of natural or artificial gas; and upon persons who are or may be engaged in furnishing natural or artificial gas for heating, lighting, and/or power purposes in the State of Georgia; and to amend section 5235 of the Code of Georgia of 1910, which provides to what the method of condemnation shall apply, by adding thereto the following words: The method herein referred to shall also apply to persons who are or may be engaged in constructing or operating pipe-lines for the transportation and/or distribution of natural or artificial gas for heating, lighting and/or power purposes in the State of Georgia; to make definition of the word persons; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted, by the authority of the same:

Section 1. The power of eminent domain is hereby granted to and conferred upon persons who are or may be engaged in constructing or operating pipe-lines for the transportation and/or distribution of natural or artificial gas; and upon persons who are or may be engaged in furnishing natural or artificial gas for heating, lighting, and/or power purposes in the State of Georgia. Condemnation for gas pipe-lines.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that section 5235 of the present Code of Georgia of 1910 be amended by adding at the end thereof the following words: The method herein referred to shall also apply to persons who are or may be engaged in constructing or operating pipe-lines for the transportation and/or distribution of natural or artificial gas; and upon persons who are or may be engaged in furnishing natural or artificial
gas for heating, lighting, and/or power purposes in the State of Georgia; so that said section when amended shall read as follows: C. C. 5235 amended.

blockquote.p: The method of condemnation of property and assessment of damages hereinbefore provided shall apply to condemnation by cities, counties, railroads, telegraph, canal, mining, and waterworks companies, drainage by counties, tramroads, light-houses, and beacon constructions, and to all persons or corporations having the privilege of exercising the right of eminent domain. The method herein referred to shall also apply to persons who are or may be engaged in constructing or operating pipe-lines for the transportation and/or distribution of natural or artificial gas; and upon persons who are or may be engaged in furnishing natural or artificial gas for lighting, heating and/or power purposes in the State of Georgia.

law.p: Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the word persons as herein used shall include individuals, partnerships, associations, and corporations, domestic or foreign; and shall include the singular as well as the plural. Meaning of persons.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws or parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend An Act to provide for an annual increase of the pensions paid by the State to the Confederate soldiers and their widows, and for other purposes, approved August 16th, 1920, and found in the Acts of the General Assembly for the year 1920, folio 231, so as to add another section to said Act above named
and to be numbered 2-a before the repealing clauses in the Act hereby amended, and to provide that after January 1st, 1930, the annual pensions paid to Confederate soldiers and their widows by the State of Georgia shall be $360.00 per year for the Confederate soldiers and $360.00 per year to be paid to their widows, and to provide that it shall be paid monthly on the first day of each month; and for other purposes; so that said Act when amended shall read as follows:
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the passage of this Act, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that on and after January 1st, 1930, the annual pensions paid to the Confederate soldiers and their widows shall be $360.00 per annum to the Confederate soldiers and $360.00 per annum to their widows, and these amounts are to be paid monthly on the first day of each month; provided, however, that the Confederate soldiers shall not receive the amount named in this Act and the amount that they are now receiving from the State, but are to receive only $360.00 per annum and to be paid this amount in installments of $30.00 per month as provided in this Act; and provided further, that if there are widows of Confederate soldiers who are now drawing a pension under any prior law, that they shall come under this Act; and to provide further, that if there are any widows of Confederate soldiers who are now drawing a pension under any prior law, that they shall not receive any other pension except that provided for, in this Act, but may be increased up to the amount herein named; provided further, that if any portion of this Act is held invalid, then and in that event the portions not so held shall remain of force; and provided further that the amount to be paid the widows shall be paid in installments of $30.00 per month on the first day of each month as herein provided for. Provided further that in order to carry out the provisions of this Act the Pension Commissioner is hereby authorized to employ an additional clerk at a salary of not exceeding fifteen hundred ($1,500.00)
dollars per annum, the same to be paid out of appropriations made to pay pensions. Pensions of Confederate soldiers and widows, $360 per annum, payable $30 a month.Additional clerk of Pension Commissioner, salary $1,500.
Sec. 2. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this bill be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: CO-OPERATIVE MARKETING ASSOCIATIONS; SERVICE FOR NON-MEMBERS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the Co-operative Marketing Act of the State of Georgia, approved August 15, 1921, and amended August 15, 1922, and August 13, 1924, by providing that the association referred to in said Act may deal in or handle the products of both members and non-members; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the Co-operative Marketing Act of the State of Georgia, approved August 15, 1921, be and the same is hereby amended by striking from the said Act the words at the end of paragraph (a), Section four, as follows: No association, however, shall handle the agricultural products of any non-member, and substituting in lieu thereof the following: The association, however, may handle and deal in the agricultural products of non-members equal in value to, but not greater in value than, that handled by it for members. Service for non-members, what allowed.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that said Act be further amended by striking from section five of said Act the following nine words at the end of section five: and shall handle such agricultural products for members only.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that all laws or parts of laws in conflict herewith be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: COUNTY TREASURER'S SALARY IN CERTAIN COUNTIES.
law.fulltitle: An Act to provide for the payment of the salary of county treasurer in counties having a population of not less than 63,690 inhabitants and not more than 63,695 according to 1920 census; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same:

Section 1. That the salary of the county treasurers of counties of this State, having a population according to the Federal Census of 1920 of not less than 63,690 and not more than 63,695, be fixed at thirty-six hundred ($3,600.00) dollars per annum, to be paid in monthly installments of three hundred ($300.00) dollars each out of county funds. Salary in county of 63,690 to 63,695 population.
Sec. 2. That all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to authorize the ordinary or county commissioners, as the case may be, of the several counties of this State, having therein a city with a population of not less than
fifty-two thousand, nine hundred, ninety-five, and not more than eighty thousand, according to the United States Census of 1920, to name depositories for such counties; to fix the terms and conditions under which such depositories shall be named, and to authorize public officials of such counties, or other parties having funds to which the county is presently or ultimately entitled, to deposit such funds in such depository; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the boards of county commissioners, sometimes called boards of roads and revenues, of any county in this State having therein a city with a population of not less than fifty-two thousand, nine hundred, ninety-five, and not more than eighty thousand, according to the United States Census of 1920, or the ordinaries in such counties having no such boards, be and they are hereby authorized to designate one or more banks located in such county as a depository for public funds to which the county is presently or ultimately entitled. Such depository or depositories shall be designated for a term to expire on December 31 next succeding the naming of such depository or depositories, or until the prior order of the authority naming such depository, entered for good cause, revokes such designation. Any such depository or depositories named shall, before entering upon its duties as such depository, enter into bond with security approved by the authority naming such depository, conditioned for the payment to such county of any and all funds received by such depository under such appointment. Any such bond shall cover the fees which may be collected by the sheriff, tax-collector, tax-receiver, clerk of the superior court, ordinary, sheriff or other officer who may be paid a salary in lieu of fees, the county being entitled to fees accruing to the several offices, or any other funds to which the county may be presently or ultimately entitled. County commissioners authorized to name depositories in counties with city of 52,995 to 80,000 population.Term of depository.Bond.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that any depository so qualifying under the terms of this Act shall continue to act until the end of the term herein specified, or prior order of the authority designating it as depository, revoking its authority so to act, or until ten days after written notice by such depository to such appointing power, asking to be relieved as such depository.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, that all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: EDUCATIONAL FUNDS IN CERTAIN COUNTIES, AUTHORITY TO SUPPLEMENT, ETC.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of all counties in the State of Georgia, having a population of not less than 200,000, to supplement the funds of the county board of education from any funds in the treasury of the said county derived from any source other than from taxation, to provide the method by which the said funds shall be handled, and the purpose for which they shall be expended; and for other purposes.
law.p:
The board of commissioners of roads and revenues of each county in the State of Georgia, having a population of not less than 200,000, is hereby authorized to pay over to the county board of education of such county any sums not to exceed $20,000 each month out of any funds in the treasury of the said county, which shall have been derived from any source other than from taxation. Such funds when paid to the county board of education shall become a part of the county school fund, and may be used by the board of education for paying teachers' salaries, buying
or renting lots and buildings for school purposes, purchasing or building school buildings, maintaining school property, or for any other education purpose not inconsistent with the laws of this State. Authority to pay board of education not more than $20,000 a month from funds not derived from taxation in counties of 200,000 population.

law.fulltitle: An Act to provide for the procedure in all contests in all cases when any person is nominated in any primary election by the people for election to any county office in such counties of this State as have a population of not less than 6,458 and not more than 6,462 as determined by the census of the United States of 1920; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act the procedure relative to contests as outlined in subsections or paragraphs numbers two, three, four, five, and seven of section 121, also sections 122 and 123 of Park's Code of Georgia, shall be and the same is hereby made the procedure to contest the nomination of any person nominated in any primary election by the people for election to any county office in such counties of this State as have a population of not less than 6,458 and not more than 6,462, as determined by the census of the United States of 1920. Primary election contests in counties of 6,458 to 6,462 population.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the candidate receiving the highest number of votes as shown by the consolidation of the returns of said primary election shall be deemed the nominee for election to the office as he may have been candidate therefor, and it shall not be necessary for any authority to so declare him as such, as a condition precedent to contesting his nomination for election to such office. Candidate receiving highest vote is deemed nominee.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, that the judgment, order, or finding of the judge of the superior court of such counties, declaring the nominee in any such contests, shall be final.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, that all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: ELECTIONS FOR GENERAL ASSEMBLY IN CERTAIN COUNTIES; NAMING OPPONENT IN PRIMARY.
law.fulltitle: An Act to provide for the nomination or election in primary elections of members of the General Assembly in counties of population of not less than 25,393 and not more than 25,700, requiring specification of incumbent opposed; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, that from and after the passage of this Act candidates for the General Assembly in all counties having more than one representative, and having a population of not less than 25,393 and not more than 25,700 according to the last census of the United States, shall, when qualifying for a primary, specify the particular incumbent which said candidate desires to oppose or succeed, and all ballots shall be prepared accordingly. The candidate receiving a plurality of the votes cast for candidates for such office shall be declared the nominee therefor. Candidate required to specify incumbent opposed, in county of 25,397 to 25,700 population.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the same authority, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to further regulate the sale, inspection and distribution of commercial fertilizer and fertilizer materials in the State of Georgia and fixing additional requirements governing manufacturers, manipulators, jobbers and dealers, to provide a penalty for the punishment of violations of the fertilizer laws; to provide for penalties to be paid by manufacturers and manipulators of fertilizers in certain cases; to authorize the Commissioner of Agriculture to collect such penalties; to extend the commissioner's authorities in inspecting fertilizer; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that in addition to and supplemental to all the present laws governing the sale, manufacture and distribution of fertilizer and fertilizer materials in the State of Georgia:

Section 1. That on and after the passage of this Act every manufacturer and mixer selling or offering for sale within the State any fertilizer or fertilizer material shall first file annually with the Commissioner of Agriculture, upon forms supplied by the commissioner for that purpose, a registration of each brand of fertilizer or fertilizer material to be offered for sale, giving the name and address of the manufacturer or mixer, together with the name of each place at which they may desire to do business in this State, the guaranteed analysis thereof, stating the sources from which the phosphoric acid, nitrogen and potash are derived and giving the percentage of organic nitrogen, the percentage of inorganic nitrogen and the percentage of the total amount of nitrogen, and stating what proportion of the potash is sulphate, if any, and that for the purpose of this Act, organic nitrogen shall be that derived from animal or vegetable matter, and all other nitrogen shall be classed as inorganic. Such application to be accompanied
by a fee of five dollars for each brand of fertilizer or fertilizer material which they may desire to sell. Registration of brands, analysis.Fee of $5 for each brand.

Sec. 2. Every person, before offe1[UNK]ri[UNK]ng any fertilizer or fertilizer material for sale or exchange in the State of Georgia, shall first procure a license from the Commissioner of Agriculture authorizing such person to sell or exchange or deal therein. Such license shall be issued by said Commissioner of Agriculture on payment of fee of $1.00, and shall expire on the 31st day of December of each year. License for sale, etc., fee $1.

Sec. 3. It shall be unlawful for any manufacturer or mixer of commercial fertilizer to use any material as a filler or make-weight which does not comply with the requirements of this law as hereinafter set out as a fertilizer material. Filler.

Sec. 4. Every bag or package of commercial fertilizer sold within the State shall have printed on bag or package, or affixed thereto, a tag containing a legible and plainly printed statement in the English language, the following: Tag.

item.p: 1. Net weight of each bag or package in pounds.
2. Brand name or trade mark.
3. (a) Guaranteed analysis, giving the minimum percentage of available phosphoric acid, and the sources, and within ten per cent. of the amount of each source of available phosphoric acid.

(b) The minimum percentage of total nitrogen and the names of the sources, and within ten per cent. of the total amount of the source in the form of organic materials, and the names of sources, and within ten per cent. of the total amount of the source in the form of inorganic materials.
(c) The minimum percentage of potash and the sources, and within ten per cent. of the amount of each source of potash.
(d) The sources, and pounds of filler.
(e) Total pounds of available plant food.
(f) Name and address of manufacturer, mixer, or importer.
(g) Whenever any fertilizer material is reduced from its original plant-food content, the amount of the filler and source used must also be shown as provided for above.

(h) It shall further be unlawful for any fertilizer manufacturer or mixer to use any foreign or artificial coloring in the manufacture, mixture, or manipulation of any fertilizer or fertilizer material, or to use any substance for supplying an odor not natural to and a part of the material used.

law.p: Sec. 5. It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale any fertilizer material as tankage which shall contain more than two per cent. of inorganic nitrogen, and it shall be unlawful to designate as tankage any material used in a mixed goods which contain more than two per cent. of inorganic nitrogen. It shall also be unlawful to designate as tankage any material which contains hair, hoof, horn or other animal matter in which the nitrogen shows available of less than eighty-five per cent. when determined by the neutral permangate method without a clear statement on the outside of each package of the fact that such material is used. Tankage.

Sec. 6. Where the present law states the percentage of water soluble nitrogen shall be declared, same shall be in terms of water soluble nitrogen, and a variation of ten per cent. shall be construed as false branding and be subject to a penalty of ten per cent. of purchase-price. Penalty for variation from legal percentage of water soluble nitrogen.

Sec. 7. The Commissioner of Agriculture is authorized to use the inspectors provided for by law in inspecting all factories, warehouses, railroad cars and places of business of all manufacturers and mixers of commercial fertilizer, and is authorized to open any and all packages, cars or parcels of fertilizer or fertilizer material or materials which
may be found in and about such places which are unlawful to be used in fertilizer, and to secure samples of the same to be analyzed by the State Chemist as now provided by law. Inspection.Samples.

Sec. 8. All inspections of commercial fertilizer and fertilizer materials as now provided by law shall be in so far as practicable made before delivery into the possession of the consumer. However, the Commissioner of Agriculture is authorized in his discretion to have samples drawn at any time or place of any fertilizer or fertilizer material found within the limits of this State. Same.

Sec. 9. Any fertilizer or fertilizer material sold in this State without compliance with the requirements of the law, any fertilizer which upon analysis by the State Chemist shows a shortage in any one plant food of ten per cent. or more, and any fertilizer which upon analysis under direction of the State Chemist shows a shortage in commercial value below the guarantee of five per cent. or more shall be subject to a penalty of twenty-five per cent. of the purchase-price plus the actual shortage in commercial value. These penalties shall be in lieu of all other penalties now provided by law and shall not be cumulative. Penalties for shortage in plant food or commercial value.

Sec. 10.
