Be it further enacted that there shall be a judge of said courts, who shall not be less than twenty-five years of age, and who shall have resided in such county at least three years immediately preceding his election, and before entering upon the discharge of the duties of his office shall take and subscribe the following oath: I do solemnly swear that I will administer justice, without respect to persons, and do equal justice to the rich and poor alike, and that I will faithfully and impartially discharge and perform all of the duties which may be required of me as judge of such county criminal court, according to the best of my ability and understanding, according to the laws and constitution of the State of Georgia and of the United States, so help me God, and said oath shall be filed and recorded in the office of the ordinary of such county, who may also administer the same. Judge's qualifications, oath.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted that there shall be a solicitor of said court, who shall be not less than twenty-five years of age, a practicing attorney, and who shall have resided in such county immediately preceding his election at least three years, and before entering upon the discharge of the duties of his office shall take and subscribe the following oath: I do swear that I will faithfully and impartially discharge the duties of solicitor of such county criminal court, according to the best of my ability and understanding, according to the laws and constitution of the State of Georgia and of the United States, so help me God. Such oath shall be filed and recorded in the office of the ordinary of such county, who may also administer the same. Solicitor's qualifications, oath.

Sec. 5. Said judge and solicitor shall be elected in the following manner: within ten days after the recommendation of the grand jury establishing said court, it shall be the duty of the ordinary of such county to call a special election for the purpose of electing a judge and solicitor of said court and advertise the same by posting a notice before the court-house door of said county and publishing a notice of the same at least one time fifteen days before said election in the official organ of such county, said election to be held not earlier than fifteen days and not later than twenty-five days from the date of the order calling such election, at which election only the qualified voters of such county shall participate, the returns of said election to be made to the ordinary, who shall consolidate the same and declare the result, and any contest arising from said election shall be heard and determined in the same manner as contests arising over elections for officers of municipal corporations. Election of Judge and Solicitor.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted that no person shall be eligible to either of said offices unless he shall in writing give notice of his candidacy for the same to the ordinary of said county at least ten days before said election. Notice of candidacy.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted that said officers thus elected shall be commissioned by the Governor, upon receipt of a certificate of the results of said election to be forwarded by the ordinary, for a term of office expiring on the 1st day of January following the next general election for county officers of such county, at which said general election for county officers, the successors of said judge and solicitor shall be elected.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted that said judge shall not receive any salary from the treasury of such county, but his compensation for his services shall be as follows: In all civil suits wherein the principal sum claimed is not over one hundred dollars, he shall receive the same fees as now allowed justices of the peace; in all civil suits wherein the principal sum claimed is not over two hundred dollars,
he shall receive one and a half times the fees as now allowed justices of the peace; and in all civil cases wherein the principal sum claimed exceeds two hundred dollars, he shall receive double the fees as now allowed justices of the peace in such county. In all criminal cases disposed of by verdict of guilty or not guilty or plea, said judge shall be entitled to a fee of six dollars, and in case of plea in abatement or nol. pros., three dollars, and these fees shall include any service that he may have rendered in issuing criminal warrants or sitting as a commital court, unless such services are rendered in criminal cases which reach the superior court of said county and are disposed of there, in which case he shall have a claim on the insolvent fund of said superior court for his fees in said matters, which shall be the same as now allowed justices of the peace. Judge's fees.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted that the solicitor of said court shall not receive any salary from the treasury of such county, but compensation for his services shall be as follows: The fee of said solicitor of said court shall be fifteen dollars in each and every case disposed of in said court, whether it be an accusation drawn by said solicitor, or indictment or presentment transferred from the superior court of such county, except where a nolle prosequi is entered on plea of abatement is allowed, and in those cases the fees shall be seven dollars and a half; and for such other services as forfeiting recognizances, confiscations, rules against defaulting witnesses, contempt proceedings, and for each and all services of said solicitor not herein provided for, he shall receive the same fees as are now and hereinafter allowed solicitors-general of this State for similar services; and if for any reason said solicitor shall fail or be disqualified to act in any case, the judge shall have power to appoint a solicitor pro-tem to act in said case. Solicitor's fees.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted that the clerk of the superior court of such counties shall be the clerk of said court, by virtue of his election to the office as clerk of the
superior court of such county, and shall be known as the clerk of the county criminal court. He shall take a similar oath as that required of the solicitor of said court, and shall also give bond in the sum of $1,000.00, payable to the ordinary of said county and conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties as clerk of said court, and which bond, together with said oath, shall be recorded in the office of the ordinary of such county. The fees of the clerk of the county criminal court shall be the same as are now or may hereafter be allowed by law to the clerk of the superior court of such county. Clerk of superior court, ex-officio clerk of criminal court. Fees of clerk.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted that the sheriff of such county shall be the sheriff of the criminal county court, by virtue of his election as sheriff, and shall be known as the sheriff of the county criminal court, and before entering upon the discharge of the duties of his office shall give bond in the sum of $1,000.00, conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties as sheriff of said court. The fees of the sheriff of the criminal county court shall be the same as those now allowed by law to sheriff of the superior court of such county. Sheriff, ex-officio sheriff of criminal court. Fees of sheriff.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted that the judges of such courts shall have the authority to issue criminal warrants, warrants to dispossess tenants holding over, and intruders, to issue distress warrants, to issue attachments and garnishments, to attest deeds and other papers, and to take affidavits anywhere in the State, and said judge, solicitor, sheriff, and clerk shall have power to administer oaths and do all official acts pertaining to the duties of their office as the judge and other officers of the superior courts may in like cases do. Said judge shall also have power to issue writs of habeas corpus, hear and determine the same as judges of the superior courts may do; to take testimony to be used de bene esse and for the purpose of perpetuating testimony within his jurisdiction, and generally to do all acts which the judges of the superior courts of this State are authorized to do, except in those matters where exclusive jurisdiction is vested in judges
of the superior courts, and all the laws relating to and governing judges of the superior court shall apply to the judges of the county criminal courts, so far as the same may be applicable and except as herein provided. Authority of Judge.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted that there shall be held monthly terms of said court for the trial and disposition of all criminal cases and all civil cases wherein the principal sum claimed does not exceed one hundred dollars, and regular quarterly terms for the trial and disposition of all criminal cases and all civil cases where the principal sum claimed is over one hundred dollars and does not exceed five hundred dollars. Terms of court.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted that the monthly and quarterly terms of said court shall be established by the judge, who shall advertise his order fixing the same weekly for two successive weeks in the official organ of such county, and he shall have power to change the same by proper order and similar advertisement. Same.
Sec. 15. Be it further enacted that said court shall be held at the court-house of said county. Place of court.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted that if said judge shall be disqualified from presiding over the trial of any civil case in said court, and should the parties thereto fail or refuse to agree upon a judge pro hac vice, then it shall be the duty of the clerk of court to appoint some attorney practicing in the court to preside in the case and try the same; and should said judge be disqualified from presiding over the trial of any criminal case pending in said court, then it shall be his duty to call in some judge of a superior or city court to try such case, and they are hereby authorized to do the same. Disqualified cases.

Sec. 17. Be it further enacted that the authorities in charge of county affairs, nor other authority of such counties, shall be required to furnish the judge or solicitor of said court with an office; but the clerk of said court is hereby required at such county's expense, to furnish the necessary
dockets, stationery, subpoenas and blank forms as may be necessary for use in said court. County to furnish stationery, etc., not offices of judge and solicitor.

Sec. 18. Be it further enacted that suits in said court shall in all respects be conformable to the mode of pleading and practice in the superior courts, unless otherwise herein provided, and the processes and writs shall be annexed by the clerk of the county criminal court, shall be attested in the name of the judge thereof, and directed to and served by the sheriff of such court or the special baliff hereinafter provided, and all executions issuing from said court shall bear test in the name of the judge, signed by the clerk, and directed to the sheriff or special bailiff of said court, and to all and singular the sheriffs and their deputies of this State. Process.

Sec. 19. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that in all matters pertaining to service, pleading and practice, the laws governing the superior courts, where not inconsistent with this Act, shall be applicable to said criminal county court, and all laws upon the subject of garnishment, attachment, proceedings to make parties, commencement of suits, defenses, set-offs, affidavits of illegality, arbitration, examination of witnesses by interrogatories, or under subpoenas, witnesses and their attendance, continuance in the superior courts of this State, and all matters of a judicial nature within the jurisdictional limits of said superior court, shall be applicable to said county criminal courts, where not inconsistent with this Act. Other laws applicable to court.

Sec. 20. Be it further enacted that said judge shall have the power and authority to appoint at his discretion a special bailiff of the county criminal court, who shall have all the authority in both civil and criminal matters as the sheriff of said county, in the service of all warrants, writs, processes, subpoenas and other papers, and he shall receive the same fees as allowed by law to the sheriffs of this State for similar services, and before entering upon the discharge of his duties shall give a bond in the sum of
$1,000.00, conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties, said bond to be made payable to the ordinary of said county and approved by him and recorded. Special bailiff; bond.

Sec. 21. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that county criminal courts shall be courts of record and have a seal, and the minutes, records, dockets and other books and files that were required by law to be kept by the clerk of the superior courts of such counties shall be kept in and for said county criminal courts and in the same manner, and all laws applicable to the duties of the clerk and the sheriff of the superior court, except where they conflict with the provisions of this Act, shall apply to the county criminal courts. Court of record.Clerk and sheriff.

Sec. 22. Be it further enacted that all laws regulating the enforcement of judgments of the superior courts, whether civil or criminal, shall apply to said county criminal courts, and execution shall issue and be levied and sales be had thereunder under the same rules and regulations as govern in the superior courts. Judgment, execution, levy and sale.

Sec. 22. Be it further enacted that the judge of said county criminal court shall have the same power to enforce his orders, to preserve order, punish for contempt and to enforce all his judgments as is vested by law in judges of the superior court. Contempts.
Sec. 23. Be it further enacted that traverse jurors in the county criminal courts shall be procured in the following manner:

The clerk of said county court shall prepare and file in his office a complete copy of the traverse-jury list of the superior court of the county, as provided from time to time for such superior court. From that copy traverse jurors shall be drawn in the following manner: the clerk shall write upon separate tickets the name of each traverse juror and shall number the same and place it in a box to be prepared for that purpose, and it shall be known as the jury-box of the county criminal court, from which shall
be drawn traverse jurors for service in said court. All laws with reference to the drawing of, selecting and summoning traverse and tales jurors in the superior court shall apply to the county criminal court. Juries.

All laws regulating the qualifications, relations, impanelling, fining, and challenging jurors in the superior courts shall apply to and be observed in the county criminal courts, except when inconsistent with this act. A new list shall be made up in manner and form herein provided immediately after every revision of the traverse jury lists of the superior court of the county.

Sec. 24. Be it further enacted that in all cases, either civil or criminal, where issues are to be tried by a jury, the parties shall be entitled to a panel of twelve jurors from which to strike; in criminal cases the defendant shall have four strikes and the States shall be entitled to two strikes, and the first strike shall be on the defendant, leaving a jury of six to try said case, and in civil cases the parties shall have three strikes each, and it shall never be necessary to make a demand for a jury in said court. Strikes.Demand for jury never required.

Sec. 25. Be it further enacted that with the consent of the parties to any civil case the same may be tried by the judge without a jury, and in all criminal cases, with the consent of the accused, the same may be tried by the judge without a jury, and such county criminal courts shall be open for the trial of such cases and for the purpose of receiving plea of guilt and fixing punishment for offenders at all times. Trial without jury.

Sec. 26. Be it further enacted that all criminal cases tried in the county criminal court, whether at a monthly, quarterly, or special session, shall be upon written accusation, indictment, or presentment, and no defendant or person accused shall have any right to demand an [Illegible Text] by the grand jury of the county. Such accusation shall set forth plainly the offence charged, and shall conform as to matter and substance with the rules of criminal pleadings
which prevail in the superior court of the county; provided, however, that such accusation shall be amendable at a stage of the trial until such accusation shall be legally sufficient and sane shall not be dismissed or quashed upon a mere technicality. Said accusation shall be based upon an affidavit before the judge of said court or before some other competent judicial officer of this State, and same shall be signed by the solicitor of said court, and have endorsed thereon the name of the prosecutor, if any. Accusation.No right to demand indictment.

Sec. 27. Be it further enacted that the judge of the superior court of such county shall by order transmit to the county criminal court, for trial and disposition, all presentments and bills of indictment found by the grand jury of such county for offenses within the jurisdiction of such county criminal court, which may remain undisposed of at the end of each term of the superior court, or in vacation, the order transmitting such cases to be entered on the minutes of both courts. All bonds returnable to the superior court shall follow the cases to the county criminal court when so transferred, and in such cases the defendant shall be bound to appear in said county criminal court, and upon his failure so to do his bond shall be forfeited in the same manner as bonds are forfeited in the superior court, and such defendants shall have notice of such transfer, either by serving them personally with a notice of such transfer to be signed by the clerk of the county criminal court, or by leaving the same at his most notorious place of abode, if a resident of the county, or notice may be given all defendants by publication of the order transferring such cases in the official organ of the county at least ten days before the holding of said county criminal court. Transfer of indictments from superior court.Bonds.

Sec. 28. Be it further enacted that witnesses in civil and criminal cases shall receive the same pay from the same source and in the same manner as the witnesses in the superior court. Pay of witnesses.

Sec. 29. Be it further enacted that jurors in said court shall receive for their services the sum of two dollars per
day, and it shall be the duty of the clerk of the county criminal court at the end of each term of court to issue jurors orders on the county treasurer in payment of their services, and it shall be the duty of the county treasurer or other person or depository to pay said script. Pay of jurors.

Sec. 30. Be it further enacted that in suits to the monthly or quarterly terms of said court the original petition shall be filed with the clerk of the county criminal court twenty days, and service thereof shall be made fifteen days before said session. Time of filing suits.

Sec. 31. Be it further enacted that the judge of said county criminal court shall not have power to grant new trials, in either civil or criminal cases, and there shall be no direct writ of error from said court to either the supreme court of court of appeals of this State, but errors committed by either the judge or a jury in said court in the trial of any case, shall be reviewable by the superior court of the county by writ of certiorari, as hereinafter provided. Judge not empowered to grant new trials; writ of error not lie.

Sec. 32. Be it further enacted that in the trial of any civil case in said court, regardless of the amount involved, if the same be tried by the judge without a jury by consent of the parties, there shall be no appeal to a jury in said court or to any other court, and if the same be tried in the first instance before a jury in said court there shall be no appeal to a jury in any other court, but the sole and exclusive remedy shall be by writ of certiorari to the superior court of said county. No right of appeal.Certiorari.

Sec. 33. Be it further enacted that in the trial of any civil case the writ of certiorari shall lie to the superior court of said county, for the correction of errors committed by the judge or jury in said county criminal court, and the same shall be obtained under the same laws, rules, and regulations provided in the Code of Georgia, for preparing, serving, answering, hearing, and disposing of certioraries from justice's courts, which may be disposed of by the judge of the superior court, in accordance with said rules, in
vacation or at a regular term of the superior court of said county. In disposing of any certiorari in vacation, the judge of the superior court is hereby authorized to pass an order either in term time or vacation fixing the time and place of said hearing, notice of which shall be given both parties at least ten days before the time set. Same.

Sec. 34. Be it further enacted that in the trial of any criminal case in said court, for the correction of errors committed by either the judge or a jury in said case, the writ of certiorari shall lie to the superior court of the county, and the writ shall be obtained under the order and sanction of the judge of the superior court of the county, upon the written petition, duly sworn to, of the defendant, stating the complaint showing sufficient grounds of error, and containing a brief of the material evidence. The writ must be applied for within ten days after the trial, and if the regular judge of the superior court of the county be absent from the circuit at the time, application may be made to the judge of any adjoining circuit, and may be obtained and disposed of either in term time or vacation, and shall be filed in the office of the clerk of the superior court within ten days after the same is sanctioned, and notice of the sanction and time and place of hearing shall be served upon the solicitor-general of the circuit within ten days after the same is filed. If the petition be presented to the judge of the superior court in vacation or term time, he is authorized to set the hearing for a regular term of said superior court or set the time for hearing in vacation. Same.

Sec. 35. The writ shall not be granted, and if granted shall be dismissed, unless the accused shall, at the time of presenting said petition for certiorari, have incorporated in the same an affidavit stating that he has not had a fair trial and has been wrongfully and illegally convicted, and shall also give bond and security, or make affidavit as is required of persons when carrying cases to the supreme court; and the execution and filing of such bond shall operate as a supersedeas of the judgment rendered in said
court for the space of twenty days, and said bond shall be approved by the clerk of the county criminal court and a certified copy of the same shall be attached to said petition when the same is presented. And should the said affidavit in pauperis be filed in lieu of said bond, it shall likewise operate as a supersedeas, but the defendant shall not be set at liberty, and a certified copy of said affidavit shall accompany the petition. Same.

Sec. 36. Be it further enacted that the bond provided for in the preceding section shall be conditioned for the personal appearance of the defendant to answer the final judgment of the county criminal court and of the superior court of said county; and the same, upon a breach of its terms, may be forfeited in either of said courts. Bond.

Sec. 37. Be it further enacted that if said petition be sanctioned by said judge of the superior court, the supersedeas shall continue until final judgment in said certiorari proceeding is had in the superior court of said county, and if the same is decided adversely to said defendant, his bond shall be forfeited should he fail to appear at the next term, either monthly or quarterly, of said county criminal court, without sufficient legal excuse. Same.

Sec. 38. Be it further enacted that if the judge of the superior court, upon the determination of said certiorari, remand said case back for another trial to the county criminal court, upon failure of the defendant to be and appear at the next term, either monthly or quarterly, or said county criminal court, without sufficient legal excuse, said bond shall be forfeited. Same.

Sec. 39. Be it further enacted: If, upon examination, the judge of the superior court considers the petitioner entitled to the writ, he shall sanction the same and order it filed and the writ to issue, and upon the same being filed it shall be the duty of the clerk to issue said writ, directed to the judge of the county criminal court, requiring him to certify and send up to the superior court of said county a
complete and accurate history of the case, which shall be his answer. It is subject to correction and traverse as prescribed in civil cases, except that the superior-court judge shall try and determine the traverse, and may then pass such judgment as, in review of the whole case is consistent with justice and law. Answer to certiorari.

Sec. 40. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all monies arising from fine, forfeitures, and confiscations, or otherwise collected in the county criminal court on account of criminal cases of whatever kind or character, or upon any judgment of said court, in any criminal or contempt case, shall be collected by the clerk of the county criminal court immediately upon the imposing of the same by the court or its authority, and the full amount of all monies so collected shall forthwith be paid by said officer over to the county treasurer, county depository, or to such other person, who by law are in charge of receiving and disbursing county funds, and shall be kept by said treasurer or depository, or other person in charge of county funds, in a separate fund, which shall be known as the criminal county-court fund. The officers of said court shall have a special lien on said fund for their services, and no part thereof shall be paid into the general treasury of the county, until said officials shall have been paid in full their fees and costs. The county criminal-court fund shall be distributed among the officers of the court immediately after each term of said court, or oftener in the discretion of the judge, in the following manner: each officer of said court shall prepare a sworn itemized costs or fee bill of all criminal cases disposed of in said court after each term thereof, and all cases disposed of between terms, stating how and in what manner the cases were disposed of, whether by jury trial, judge without a jury, plea of guilty, verdict of guilty or not guilty, nol, pros., plea in abatement, plea to the jurisdiction, etc., and whether or not the convicted offenders appealed their cases by writ of certiorari, and said bill of costs shall specify what the different items of costs are due for, and forthwith
shall be submitted to the judge of said court, who shall certify whether or not said cases were disposed of in the manner and form as alleged in the affidavit; the costs or fee bills of said officers having been thus certified, shall be presented to the treasurer, depository, or other person having in charge the funds of the county and the criminal county court fund, and said costs bill thus certified shall be his authority to and it shall be his duty to issue his warrant or check on said criminal county fund in payment of said bills. Fines, etc.Bill of costs in criminal cases.

Sec. 41. Be it further enacted that should there be a deficit in said county criminal-court fund at any time or an amount insufficient to pay all the costs bills in full, then and that event the same shall be prorated among said officers according to the amount of their said bills, and the amount thus paid shall be credited on each bill and filed with said treasurer, and it shall be his duty to pay the balance due on said bills prorated as above outlined, as fast as the same is received by him. Payment of costs.

Sec. 42. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid that the officers shall be entitled to their fees and costs in each case whether the same results in a conviction or otherwise in said court, and shall be entitled to receive the same as provided in the preceding sections whether or not the same should be certioraried by the convicted defendant, out of any fund in the county criminal-court fund, and said officers shall at no time have any claim on said county for any fees or costs, but the same must be paid exclusively from said county criminal-court fund. Same.

Sec. 43. The jury-box of said court shall be in the custody of the clerk of said court at all times, and the judge, in the presence of the clerk, shall be authorized at any time, term or vacation, to draw a jury for the next term of court; said box to be divided in two compartments, numbered one and two, and when all of the jurors are drawn from compartment number one the judge shall start drawing from compartment number two, and vice
versa. When a jury is drawn it shall be the duty of the clerk to issue a precept containing the names of the jurors thus drawn, and deliver the same to the sheriff of said court, his deputy, or the special bailiff of said court, who shall cause the persons whose names appear on said precept to be summoned by leaving a subpoena or summons at their most notorious place of abode, or by serving them personally, at least three days before said court. The judge, after drawing the jury, shall cause the box to be locked and sealed, and it shall not be opened by any other person except the judge of said court or some judge presiding in his stead, for the purpose of drawing a jury, or by the clerk, for preparing a new list after the revision of the lists for the superior court. Drawing juries.

Sec. 44. Be it further enacted that in the absence of the judge of said court, from indisposition or otherwise, from any term of court, it shall be the duty of the clerk of said court to open and adjourn such term of court for the term. Absence of judge.

Sec. 45. Be it further enacted that should any clause, provision, section, or any portion of this Act be held illegal or unconstitutional, the illegality or unconstitutionality of same shall not vitiate any other clause, provision, section or the remainder of said Act, but the same shall remain in full force and effect, and those portions which may be held illegal shall be governed thereafter by the laws governing the superior courts of this State in like matters. Invalidity of part of Act not invalidate other part.
Sec. 46. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to establish the City Court of Darien, in and for the County of McIntosh; to define its jurisdiction and
powers; to provide for the appointment of a judge and other officers thereof; to define their powers and duties; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that the City Court of Darien is hereby created and established, with civil and criminal jurisdiction over the whole County of McIntosh. Court created; jurisdiction.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that said City Court of Darien shall have jurisdiction to try and dispose of all civil cases of whatever nature, except in those cases over which exclusive jurisdiction is vested in the superior court by the constitution and laws of the State of Georgia.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted that said City Court of Darien shall have jurisdiction to try and dispose of all criminal cases when the offense has been committed in McIntosh County, Georgia, and where the offender is not subject, upon conviction, to loss of life confinement in the penitentiary.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted that there shall be a judge of said City Court of Darien, who shall be recommended and endorsed to the Governor by the county commissioners of McIntosh County in conjunction with the county attorneys of McIntosh County, and then appointed by the Governor, without the advice or consent of the Senate, for a term of four years; all vacancies in the office of judge shall be filled in the same manner for the unexpired term. The judge of said court shall receive a salary, the same to be fixed by said board of county commissioners, and shall be paid monthly out of the county funds by the proper persons having charge of such county funds. Judges of said court shall hold office until their successors are duly appointed and qualified. Judge, how appointed.Salary fixed by commissioners.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted that any person appointed judge of said court must be at least 25 years of age, a bona fide resident of the State, and residing in the Atlantic
judicial circuit, a practicing attorney, and shall have practiced law at least two years before his appointment. He shall, before entering upon the discharge of his duties, take and subscribe the following oath: I solemnly swear that I will administer justice without respect to persons and do equal rights to the poor and rich, and I will faithfully and impartially discharge and perform all the duties which may be required of me as judge of the City Court of Darien, according to the best of my ability and understanding, agreeably to the laws and constitution of this State and the constitution of the United States, so help me God, and said oath shall immediately thereafter be forwarded to the Governor and filed in the Executive Department. Said judge may practice law in any other court except the court hereby created; he shall have authority to issue criminal warrants, to issue and dispose of distress warrants, and generally to do and perform all the acts which the judges of the county or city courts of this State are authorized to do, unless otherwise provided in this Act. Qualifications and oath of judge.Practice of law by judge.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted that there shall be a solicitor of said City Court of Darien, who shall be appointed in like manner as the judge and who shall hold office for a like term. All vacancies in said office shall be filled in the same manner as vacancies in the office of judge, and shall possess the same qualifications as those provided herein for the judge of said court. The solicitor shall receive as compensation one third of all costs, fines, and forfeitures in criminal proceedings. Solicitor.Vacancy.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted that the clerk and sheriff of the superior court of McIntosh County shall be ex-officio clerk and sheriff of said city court. Their deputies shall likewise be ex-officio deputies in said city court. Said officers shall perform all the duties in said city court which are by law required to be performed in the superior court, so far as the same are applicable. All the officers of said city court shall be amenable to the same processes and penalties as such officers are amenable to in the superior
courts. Before engaging upon the discharge of his duties as clerk of said court the clerk shall give bond and good security, as in the superior court, in the sum of $2,000, for the faithful discharge of the duties of his office. Before entering upon the discharge of his duties in said city court the sheriff shall give bond and good security as in the supeior court, in the sum of $2,000, conditioned upon the faithful discharge of the duties of his office. Upon failure or refusal of either to give such bond and security, the judge of said court shall appoint some suitable and proper person clerk or sheriff as the case may be, who shall give bond and security as aforesaid, and who shall then hold such office until the expiration of the term of office of such clerk or sheriff of the superior court. Pay of solicitor. Clerk and sheriff of superior court ex-office clerk and sheriff for county court.Bond of clerk.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted that the cost in all civil cases in said court, when the amount involved is $100.00 or less, shall be $5.00, and when the amount involved is over $100.00 shall be $10.00, which costs shall be charged against and collected from the party cast in the suit. In criminal cases the costs shall be $18.00. All costs shall be paid to the clerk of said court, and by him divided and paid over as follows: One third of all costs, fines, and forfeitures in all criminal cases shall be paid over to the general fund of the County of McIntosh, and the remaining two thirds shall be divided equally and one part paid to the clerk, one part to the sheriff and one part to the solicitor of said court: In all civil cases the cost shall be paid by said clerk when collected, one third to the general fund of the County of McIntosh, one third to the sheriff, and one third to the clerk as their compensation. Costs.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted that the terms of said City Court of Darien shall be held on the first Monday in January, March, May, July, September, and November of every year. The first terms shall be held on the first Monday of any of the above-named months immediately after this Act becomes effective. The judge of said court shall have power to hold said court in session, and adjourn from
time to time; provided that said court shall finally be adjourned at least five days before the next succeeding term. Said judge shall hold court on the first Mondays in the months of February, April, June, August, October, and December for the purpose of disposing of cases where a jury is not demanded. Terms of court.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted that the judge of said court shall have power to issue writs of habeas corpus, and to hear and dispose of the same in the same way and with the same power as superior courts. Habeas corpus.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted that suits in said city court shall in all respects be conformable to the mode of proceedings in the superior court, except as hereinafter provided; the process to writs shall be annexed by the clerk of said court, be attested in the name of the judge thereof, and be directed and served by the sheriff of the City Court of Darien, or his deputy. Suits, process.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted that in all matters pertaining to service, pleading, and practice, the laws governing the superior court, where not inconsistent with this Act and not otherwise specially provided by this Act, shall be applicable to said city court. The general laws in regard to the commencement of suits, defenses, set-off, affidavits of illegality, arbitration, examination of parties, witnesses by interrogatories or under subpoena, power and rights of parties as to waiver in pleading and procedure, or matters pertaining to the same, continuances, motions, pleas and practice, or other matters of a judicial nature governing in the superior court, are hereby made applicable and shall govern in said city court. Other laws applicable.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted that the judge of said city court shall have power and authority to hear and determine all civil cases in which the said court has jurisdiction and give judgment therein; provided always that either party in any cause shall be entitled to a trial by jury in said court, upon entering a demand therefor, by himself
or his attorney, in writing, on or before the first day of the term of said court, to which the case is returnable; provided the party is entitled to a trial by jury under the constitution and laws of this State. Demand for jury.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted that all judgments obtained in said court shall have the same force and effect as judgments obtained in the superior courts. All executions issued from said court shall be attested in the name of the judge and signed by the clerk, and directed to the sheriff or his deputy of said City Court of Darien, and to all and singular the sheriffs or their deputies, of the State of Georgia. Judgments.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted that said court shall have jurisdiction of all claim cases where personal property is levied on under execution or other process from said court, and such claims shall be tried in the same manner as claims in the superior court. Where the property levied on is real property and claim filed, the same shall be returned to the superior court of the county where the property is situated for trial as provided by law. Claim cases.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted that all laws upon the subject of garnishments and attachments shall be applicable to said city court to the same extent as if named with the superior courts of this State. Attachments in said court or returnable to said court shall be directed to the sheriff or his deputy of the City Court of Darien, and to all and singular the sheriffs and constables of this State; and the judge of said court may, or any justice of the peace or any notary public may issue attachments returnable to said city court, under the same rules that govern the issuing of attachments returnable to the superior court. Garnishment proceedings in said court shall be conformable to the laws of this State applicable to said subject in the superior court. Garnishments, attachments.

Sec. 17. Be it further enacted that scire facias to make parties in any cause in said court shall be had as in the
superior court, but scire facias shall run throughout the State, and may be served by any sheriff, or his deputy, thereof. Scire facias.

Sec. 18. Be it further enacted that the judge of said city court shall have the power to cause testimony to be taken and used de bene esse, and for the purpose of perpetuating testimony within his jurisdiction in all cases according to the general laws of this State, and the judge and all other officers of said city court shall have power respectively to administer all oaths pertaining to their office, as the judge and other officers of the superior court may in like cases do; and said judge shall also have power to attest deeds and other papers, and administer affidavits in all cases anywhere in this State in which, by existing laws, such papers may be attested and the affidavits administered by justices of the peace of this State; and the judge of said court shall have all the power and the authority throughout his jurisdiction as judges of the superior courts, except where by law exclusive power and authority are vested in the judges of the superior courts, and all laws relating to and governing judges of the superior courts shall apply to the judge of said city court, so far as the same may be applicable as herein provided. Testimony de bene esse.

Sec. 19. Be it further enacted that said City Court of Darien shall be a court of record and shall have a seal, minute, record, order and other books and files necessary for the proper conducting of said court, and the same shall be kept in and for said city court in the same manner as the records and other books are required to be kept for the superior court, and all laws applicable to the duties of the clerk and sheriff in said superior court shall apply to them in said city court, except where they conflict with the provisions of this Act. Records.

Sec. 20. Be it further enacted that the laws regulating the enforcement of judgments in the superior court, whether civil or criminal, shall apply to said city court, and executions shall be levied and sales be had thereunder the
same rules and laws regulating the same in the superior court. The judge of said court shall have the same power to enforce his orders, to preserve order, punish for contempt, and enforce all his judgments as is vested by law in the judges of the superior courts. Enforcement of judgments.Contempt.

Sec. 21. Be it further enacted that it shall be the duty of the clerk of said city court to prepare and file in his office a complete copy of the traverse jury list of the superior court of McIntosh County, as provided from time to time for such superior court. From said copy so made, traverse jurors in said city court shall be drawn in the following manner: The clerk of said city court shall write upon separate tickets the names of each traverse juror, and shall number the same, and place the same in a box to be prepared for the purpose, from which shall be drawn all traverse jurors as now required by law in the superior courts. All laws with reference to the drawing of, selecting, and summoning traverse and tales jurors in the superior courts shall apply to the said city court. All laws in reference to the qualifications, relations, impanelling, finding and challenging now of force in this State, or hereafter to be enacted by the General Assembly, regulating the same in the superior courts, shall apply to and be observed in said city court, except where inconsistent with the provisions of this Act. Jury lists.Drawing juries.

Sec. 22. Be it further enacted that the judge at each term of said city court shall draw from said box the names of eighteen persons to serve as jurors at the next term thereafter of said city court, and the eighteen jurors drawn and summoned as above provided shall be impaneled. Twelve jurors shall constitute a panel. In all cases, civil and criminal, trial by a jury of twelve shall be had in said court, when so demanded, but a trial by a jury of twelve may be waived and in that event shall be selected as follows: In civil cases each side shall have three strikes, and in criminal cases, then the jury shall be made up as follows: A list of the 18 jurors shall be furnished, and in
civil cases each side shall have three strikes; and in criminal cases the defendant shall have four strikes and the State two, and the remaining twelve shall constitute the jury. All jurors serving in said court shall receive the sum of $1.50 per day while serving as such, or any sum fixed by proper resolution of the board of county commissioners, to be paid under rules governing payment of superior court jurors. Same.
Sec. 23. Be it further enacted that the judge of said court is authorized to appoint at each term of said court not exceeding two bailiffs as officers of said court. Bailiffs.

Sec. 24. Be it further enacted that the defendants in criminal cases in said City Court of Darien may be tried on written accusations setting forth plainly the offense charged, founded on affidavit made by the prosecutor. Said affidavit shall be made before said judge, or other officer authorized to issue warrants, and said accusation shall be signed by the prosecuting officer of said court. Upon such affidavit and accusation being made and signed and filed in the clerk's office of said court it shall be the duty of the judge of said court to issue a warrant for the apprehension and arrest of the defendant, directed to the sheriff of said City Court of Darien, or his deputy, and to all and singular the sheriff and constables of said State. In all criminal cases within the jurisdiction of said city court the defendant shall not have the right to demand an indictment by the grand jury of the County of McIntosh. The judge of said court may inquire of the defendant whether he demands a trial by jury, and the response of the defendant shall be endorsed on said accusation. A plea to the accusation or indictment shall be a waiver of jury trial, unless jury trial has been demanded in writing. If defendant fails to demand trial by jury or waives the same by pleading, he shall not thereafter have the right to recall such waivers, his failure to demand being hereby declared to be a waiver. If the defendant demands a trial by jury, the judge of said court shall proceed with said
case, if at a regular term of said court, according to the rules and laws of the superior court applicable to the trial of misdemeanors. If the defendant demands a trial by jury and the court is not sitting at a regular term, the judge shall admit the defendant to bail, to appear at the next regular term, or, on defendant's failure to give bond, shall commit him to jail until the regular term of said court. If the defendant waives trial by jury, then the said judge shall proceed to hear and determine such criminal cases conformably to the law governing the superior courts as the same may be applicable; provided that a reasonable time may be granted to the State or the defendant to procure witnesses. Accusations.Demand for jury.Commitment.

Sec. 25. Be it further enacted that the judge of the superior court may by order, in term or in vacation, transmit to said city court all presentments and bills of indictment for misdemeanors, and all civil causes of which said city court has jurisdiction to try, which are now pending in McIntosh Superior Court, or which may hereafter be pending in said superior court; provided, that in civil cases the parties to such cases shall agree that the same be transmitted. All bonds in transmitted cases shall follow the case to the said city court, and the defendant shall be bound to appear to said city court after he or his counsel shall have had notice of such transfer. Transfer of indictments, etc.

Sec. 26. Be it further enacted that it shall be the duty of all justices of the peace and notaries public of McIntosh County to bind over to said city court all persons charged with offenses committed within the limits of McIntosh County, over which said city court has jurisdiction, to answer for said offenses. Binding over.

Sec. 27. Be it further enacted that a writ of error shall be direct from the said city court to the Court of Appeals of Georgia upon a bill of exceptions filed under the same rules and regulations as govern and control the issue of writs of error and filing of bills of exceptions in the superior courts of this State. Writ of error.

Sec. 28. Be it further enacted that the judge of said city court shall have power to grant a new trial in any cause, civil or criminal, in his court upon the same terms and conditions, and under the same laws and regulations, in every respect, governing the granting of new trials in the superior courts. All rules of pleading, practice, and procedure governing motions, rules nisi, and other proceedings in new trials in the superior courts shall apply to and govern the same in said city court. New trials.

Sec. 29. Be it further enacted that all suits against joint obligors, joint promisors, copartners, or joint trespassers, in which any one or more reside in the county of McIntosh, may be brought in said city court, under the same rules and regulations governing such cases in the superior courts, mutatis mutandis, as to copies, second originals, returns, and other matters connected with the suit. Suits against joint defendants.

Sec. 30. Be it further enacted that the solicitor of said court shall for his services in the Court of Appeals be paid out of the treasury of the State, by warrant drawn by the Governor, upon certificate of the clerk of the Court of Appeals as to the performance of such services and the certificate of the clerk of the city court of the insolvency or acquittal of defendant. Solicitor's services in Court of Appeals.

Sec. 31. Be it further enacted that the first term of said court to which a case is brought shall be the appearance or return term, the second term shall be the trial term or judgment term, and all the laws, rules and practice in said court with reference to the terms thereof and to the continuance, pleading, and trial of causes therein, shall be the same as in the superior court, unless otherwise provided in this Act. Second term trial or judgment term.

Sec. 32. Be it further enacted that whenever the judge of said city court is from any cause disqualified from presiding, and the judge of the superior court cannot from any cause preside in said court as provided for in the constitution,
then, upon consent of the parties or upon their failure or refusal to agree, said cause shall be tried by a judge pro-hac vice, selected in the same manner as now provided for in the superior courts. Disqualified cases.

Sec. 33. Be it further enacted that said court shall be held in the court-house of McIntosh County, and the board of county commissioners for the County of McIntosh shall provide the necessary books for keeping the dockets, minutes and records of said city court. Place of court books.

Sec. 34. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that said court may be abolished by a vote of the majority of qualified electors of McIntosh County, at any general election, or at a special election, after twenty days' notice of the question to be voted upon, or by recommendation of the board of county commissioners of McIntosh County. Abolition of court by election.

Sec. 35. Be it further enacted that this Act shall become effective upon resolution to that effect passed by the board of county commissioners or by a majority vote of the electors voting at any general or special election called for said purpose after twenty days' notice of the question be voted. Act effective when.
Sec. 36. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: DOUGLAS CITY COURT; JUDGE'S SALARY; TERMS.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to establish the City Court of Douglas, in Coffee County, Georgia, to define its jurisdiction and powers, to provide for the election of a judge and other and toand to
define their powers and duties, to provide for the granting of new trials and writs of error therefrom, and for other purposes, approved August 19, 1919, so as to increase the salary of the judge of said court, and to change the time of holding said court, and to make all proceedings therein returnable to and legal and binding for the terms of said court as fixed in this Act; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that section 4 of the aforesaid Act approved August 19, 1919, be and the same is hereby amended by striking the words and figures fifteen hundred ($1500.00) dollars which appear immediately after the words salary of in the last sentence of said section, and adding in lieu thereof the words and figures twenty-one hundred ($2100.00) dollars, so that the last sentence of said section 4 of said Act shall read as follows: The judge of said City Court of Douglas shall receive a salary of twentyone hundred ($2100.00) dollars per annum, which shall be paid monthly out of the treasury or depository of the County of Coffee, by the person or persons charged by law with paying out the money of the County of Coffee. Judges salary, $2,100.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that section 16 of the aforesaid Act be and the same is hereby amended by striking the word third in the first sentence of said section and adding in lieu thereof the word fourth; and by striking the word third in the second sentence of said section 16 and adding in lieu thereof the word fourth; so that the first and second sentences of said section shall read as follows: Be it further enacted that the regular jury terms of said court shall be held on the fourth Mondays in February, May, August, and November. In addition to the above sessions there shall be terms for which no jury shall be drawn, on the fourth Mondays in January, March, April, June, July, September, October and December. Terms of court.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted that all suits and actions, criminal cases, bills, writs and summonses, subpoenas, bail bonds, scire facias, notices to blind for attorney's fees, mesne and final processes, and all other proceedings of whatsoever kind or nature, now returnable or pending in said court as the terms are now provided, shall hold good, be legal and binding, and relate to the terms of said court as fixed and provided for in this act. Pending cases.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, and it is hereby enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the provisions of this Act shall become effective and operative from and after the passage of this Act. Effective on passage of Act.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act entitled An Act to establish the City Court of Fairburn in and for the County of Campbell; to define its jurisdiction and powers; to provide for the election of a judge, solicitor and other officers; to define the powers and duties of the judge and other officers thereof and to fix their compensation; to provide for rules of practice and procedure in said court; to provide for new trials and writs of error therefrom; and to provide for the transfer of certain cases to said City Court of Fairburn from the Superior Court of Campbell County, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that an Act entitled An Act to establish the City Court of Fairburn in and for the County of
Campbell; to define its jurisdiction and powers; to provide for the election of a judge, solicitor and other officers; to define the powers and duties of the judge and other officers thereof and to fix their compensation; to provide for rules of practice and procedure in said court; to provide for new trials and writs of error therefrom; and to provide for the transfer of certain cases to said City Court of Fairburn from the Superior Court of Campbell County, and for other purposes, approved July 18, 1923, be and the same is hereby repealed. Repeal of Act creating court.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the provisions of this Act shall take effect immediately upon the approval by the Governor of an Act re-establishing the City Court of Fairburn and not before. Act to take effect on approval of Act re-establishing court.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all business pending in said court at the time of the going into effect of this Act shall be transferred to the newly created City Court of Fairburn, where said cases shall have exactly the same status as they had in the court hereby abolished; all books, papers and proceedings of whatever kind, either civil or criminal shall be turned over to the clerk of the Superior Court of Campbell County and by him delivered to the clerk of the newly created City Court of Fairburn. Transfer of cases.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all writs, processes and executions heretofore issued by said court shall have the same dignity and force as if said court had never been abolished.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to establish the City Court of Fairburn in and for the County of Campbell; to define its jurisdiction and powers; to designate the first judge and solicitor and to provide for the election of a judge and solicitor to succeed said judge and solicitor so designated, and other officers; to define the powers and duties of the judges and other officers thereof and to fix their compensation; to provide for rules of practice and procedure in said court; to provide for new trials and writs of error therefrom; and to provide for the transfer of certain cases to said City Court of Fairburn from the superior court of Campbell County; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that the City Court of Fairburn, to be located in the County of Campbell, in the City of Fairburn, is hereby established and created, with civil and criminal jurisdiction of the whole County of Campbell, concurrent with the superior court, to try and dispose of all civil cases of whatever nature wherein the principal claimed or involved is more than fifty ($50.00) dollars, and does not exceed one thousand ($1,000.00) dollars, except those of which the constitution of this State has given the superior court exclusive jurisdiction; and with criminal jurisdiction to try and dispose of all offenses below the grade of felony committed in the County of Campbell That the jurisdiction herein conferred shall include not only the ordinary suits and proceedings that now or may hereafter be in use in the superior court, either under the common law or statutes, including, among others, attachment and garnishment proceedings, claims to personalty, illegalities, counter-affidavits to any proceedings from said court, statutory awards, proceedings against intruders and tenants holding over, partition of personalty, issues upon distress warrants, trover and bail-trover, foreclosure of all liens
and mortgages on personalty, habeas corpus proceedings, and quo warranto. The judge of said city court shall have power to issue writs of habeas corpus and to hear and dispose of the same in the same way and with the same power as the judge of the superior court. Court created.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that there shall be a judge of said City Court of Fairburn, that the first judge of said city court shall be J. Wilson Parker, who shall be commissioned by the Governor, and whose term of office shall expire on the first day of January, 1933, when his successor is elected and qualified. His successor as judge of said city court shall be elected by the qualified voters of Campbell County at the regular election to be held on Tuesday after the first Monday in November, 1932, or at such other time as the regular election is held for State officers in said year of 1932, and once every four years thereafter, whose term of office shall be for four years and all vacancies in said office of judge of said court shall be filled by appointment of and commissioned by the Governor of said State, whose term shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term. Judge named. Election and term of successor.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the judge of said City Court of Fairburn shall receive a salary of twelve hundred ($1200.00) dollars per annum, and shall be paid monthly out of the funds arising from the fines and forfeitures of said court, as hereinafter provided. The judge of said city court shall as such receive no other compensation, but may practice law in any court, except the City Court of Fairburn, and may hold any other office or offices except those which he is expressly prohibited by law from holding. Judge's salary, $1,200.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that no one shall be eligible for the office of said judgeship unless he shall at the time of qualification be at least twenty-five (25) years old, a resident of Campbell County, Georgia, for at least three years immediately preceding his election or appointment, and must have practiced law at least three
years before his qualification. He shall immediately before entering upon the duties of his office take and subscribe the following oath: I solemnly swear that I will administer justice without respect to persons, and do equal rights to poor and rich, and I will faithfully and impartially discharge all duties which may be required of me as judge of the City Court of Fairburn according to the best of my ability and understanding, agreeable to the laws and constitutions of this State of the United States, so help me God; which oath shall be filed in the executive department. Qualifications and oath of judge

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that there shall be a solicitor of said City Court of Fairburn, that the first solicitor shall be Henry T. Golightly, who shall be commissioned by the Governor and whose term of office shall expire on the 1st day of January, 1933, when his successor is elected and qualified. His successor as solicitor of said court shall be elected by the qualified voters of Campbell County at the regular election to be held on Tuesday after the first Monday in November, 1932, or at such other time as the regular election is held for State officers in said year 1932, and once every four years thereafter, and all vacancies in said office of solicitor of said court shall be fille by appointment of and commissioned by the Governor of the State, whose term shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term. The duties of the solicitor of said city court shall be to prosecute for all offenses cognizable before said city court, and shall perform such other duties as usually pertain to the office. Solicitor named: election and term of successor.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the salary of the solicitor of said city court shall be one thousand ($1,000.00) dollars per annum, and shall be paid monthly out of funds arising from fines and forfeitures of said court as hereinafter provided. Said solicitor shall receive, for representing the State in the appellate courts of the State, the same compensation now paid by the State to solicitor-generals of superior courts for like services, said
fees to be paid by the State in the same manner that the same are now paid solicitor-generals. The solicitor of said city court shall, as such, receive no other compensation, but may practice law in any court or courts and may hold any other office or offices, except those which he is expressly prohibited by law from holding. Solicitor's pay.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that no person shall be eligible for the office of solicitor of said City Court of Fairburn unless he shall have arrived at the age of twenty-one (21) years at the time of his qualification, and shall have been a bona fide resident of Campbell County for at least two years immediately preceding his election or appointment, and shall be actively engaged in the practice of the profession of law. Said solicitor, before entering upon the duties of his office, shall take and subscribe the following oath: I do solemnly swear that I will faithfully and impartially, and without favor or affection, discharge my duties as solicitor of the City Court of Fairburn, so help me God. If for any reasons the solicitor shall be absent or disqualified to act in any case, the court shall appoint a solicitor pro tempore, who shall be paid by the solicitor from his salary. Qualifications and oath of solicitor.Solicitor pro tem.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the clerk of the Superior Court of Campbell County shall be clerk of the City Court of Fairburn, and the said clerk shall, before entering upon the duties of the office, take and subscribe an oath to faithfully and impartially discharge the duties thereof, which oath shall be entered upon the book of minutes of said city court. He shall also have power to appoint a deputy clerk with the consent of the judge of said court. Clerk of superior court ex-officio clerk of city court. Deputy.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the sheriff of Campbell County shall be the sheriff of the City Court of Fairburn. Before entering upon the discharge of his duties of the office of sheriff of said city court, said sheriff shall execute a bond with good security for the sum of two thousand ($2,000.00) dollars for the
faithful discharge of the duties of his office. He shall have power to appoint a deputy or deputies with the consent of the judge of said court. It shall be the duty of the judge of said court to approve the bond given by the sheriff. The bond shall be in the same form as the usual bond given by the sheriff, and shall be filed with the ordinary of said county. Any deputy or deputies that said sheriff may have or may hereafter have shall also be deputy sheriffs of said city court. The sheriff of said city court is authorized, with the approval of the judge of said court, to appoint at each term of court not exceeding two bailiffs as officers of said court, who shall receive for their services the same compensation paid bailiffs in the superior court. Sheriff o county ex-officio sheriff of city court. Bond.Deputies.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all the duties and liabilities attached to the office of clerk of the superior court and to the office of sheriff of the superior court shall attach to the office of the clerk and the sheriff of the City Court of Fairburn, respectively; and that the judge of the City Court of Fairburn is empowered to enforce the same authority over the clerk and sheriff of said city court and their deputies as is exercised by the judge of the superior court over the clerk of the superior court and the sheriff of the superior court of Georgia.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the clerk of the City Court of Fairburn shall be paid the same fees as are allowed the clerks of the superior court for like services, and the sheriff of said city court shall be paid the same fees as are allowed the sheriff of Campbell county for services in the superior court, and the said sheriff and his deputies shall for all services receive the same fees as are allowed by the law for like services in the superior court of said county. Said fees shall be paid monthly out of the funds arising from the fines and forfeitures of said court as hereinafter provided. The said clerk and deputy and said sheriff and deputies shall be amenable to the same process and penalties as are now
amenable to in the superior court, and shall be entitled to the same remedies to enforce the collection of their fees and costs in said city court as they are now entitled to in the superior court. Fees of clerk and sheriff.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the terms of the City Court of Fairburn shall be as follows: The first court to be held the second Monday in October, 1929, and quarterly thereafter on the second Monday in January, April, July, and October of each year thereafter. The judge of said court shall have power to hold said court in session so long as in his judgment the same shall be necessary at each regular adjourned term, and he shall also have power to order and hold adjourned terms of said court when in his judgment it is necessary, and to adjourn his regular term to such time as he shall deem best, and he shall have the same power as to holding adjourned and special terms of his court as judges of the superior courts have. Terms of court.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that suits in said city court shall in all respects be conformable to the mode of procedure in the superior courts, except as hereinafter provided, but process of writs shall be annexed of said city court, be attested in the name of the judge thereof and be directed to and served by the sheriff of the City Court of Fairburn or his deputies. Procedure, process.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that in all matters pertaining to service, pleadings, and practice the laws governing the superior courts, when not inconsistent with the Act and unless otherwise specially provided by this Act, shall be applicable to said city court. Pleading and practice.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all cases, both civil and criminal, over which the court has jurisdiction shall be tried by the judge without a jury, unless one party to the case shall in writing demand a trial by a jury, and in that case a trial shall be had by a jury of six (6) as hereinafter provided, unless always, in any case one of the parties to a case, either civil or criminal
shall be entitled to a jury of twelve by entering a demand therefor in writing on or before the call of the docket at the term to which said cause is returnable, or in a criminal case by the State or defendant at the time the case is called and both parties have announced ready. The clerk of said court shall keep blank forms of demand for trial by a jury, and when a jury of twelve is not especially demanded, the party making the demand shall be entitled to a trial by a jury of six. A mere demand for a trial by a jury shall be a waiver of a trial by a jury of twelve, and the party or parties must proceed to a trial with a jury of six. Demand for jury.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all judgments obtained in said court shall be a lien on all property of the defendant or defendants throughout the State in the same manner as judgments in the superior courts are; all executions issuing from said city court shall be attested in the name of the judge, signed by the clerk, and directed to the sheriff or his deputies of the City Court of Fairburn, and to all and singular the sheriffs and their deputies of the State of Georgia. And processes of all kinds issued from said court shall be directed in the same manner as executions. Judgments, executions, process.

Sec. 17. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that said city court shall have jurisdiction of all claims where personal property is levied upon under execution or other process from said court. Such claims shall be tried in the same manner as claims are tried in the superior court. Claim cases.

Sec. 18. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid that claims to real property levied upon under execution or other process from said city court shall be returned to the superior court of the county where said real property is situated, and shall there proceed as other claims in the superior courts.

Sec. 19. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws upon the subject of attachments and garnishments as to any matters whatever in the superior
courts of this State shall apply to said city court as if named with the superior court, so far as the nature of the city court will permit. All attachments in said city court returnable to said court shall be directed to the sheriff or his deputies of the City Court of Fairburn, and to all and singular the sheriffs and constables of said State, and the judge of said city court may, or any justice of the peace or notary public ex-officio justice of the peace may, issue attachments returnable to the superior court. Attachments, garnishments.

Sec. 20. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the garnishment and attachment proceedings and proceedings on distress warrants in said city court shall be conformable to the laws of the State on the subject in the superior courts. Same. Distress warrants.

Sec. 21. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that scire facias to make parties in any cause in said court shall be had as in the superior courts, but scire facias shall run throughout the State and may be served by any sheriff or his deputies thereof. Scire facias.

Sec. 22. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the general laws of the State with regard to the commencement of suits in the superior court, defenses, set-offs, affidavits of illegality, arbitration, examination of parties to suits or witnesses by interrogatories, or under subpoenas, witnesses and their attendance, or other matters of judicial nature within the jurisdiction of the said city court, shall be applicable to said city court. Other laws applicable.

Sec. 23. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the judge of said city court shall have power to cause testimony to be taken and used de bene esse, and for the purpose of perpetuating testimony within his jurisdiction in all cases according to the laws of the State; and the judge and all other officers of said court shall have the power respectively to administer all oaths pertaining to their office as the judge and other officers of the superior court may in like cases do; and said judge shall have the
power to attest deeds and other papers and administer affidavits in the State in which, by existing laws, deeds and papers may be attested and affidavits may be administered by the justice of the peace of the State; and the judge of said city court shall have all power and authority throughout his jurisdiction as the judge of the superior court, and all laws relating to the government of judges of the superior courts shall apply to the judge of said city court in so far as the same may be applicable, except as herein provided. Testimony de bene esse. Judge's power to take affidavits, etc.

Sec. 24. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the City Court of Fairburn shall be a court of record and shall have a seal and such records and files as are required by law to be kept for the superior courts, shall be kept in and for said city court in the same manner and all laws applicable to the duties of the clerk and sheriff of the superior court shall apply to them in said city court, except where they conflict with the provisions of this Act. Records.

Sec. 25. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the judge of said city court shall have the power to enforce the orders, to preserve order, to punish for contempt, and to enforce all of his judgments, as is vested by law in the judges of the superior courts of this State. Contempt.

Sec. 26. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the clerk of said city court shall prepare and keep on file in his office a complete list of all persons within the territorial jurisdiction of said city court who are liable and competent to serve as petit jurors in the superior court of Campbell County, and it shall be the duty of said clerk to make out tickets of equal number to the number of names in said list. He shall write upon each ticket the name of one of the said persons and deposit the same in a box to be provided and numbered one (1) until there shall be a ticket bearing the name of each person on said list. Said jury-box or list of names in said jury-box shall be revised by the clerk every time the jury-list of the county is revised by the jury commissioners of Campbell County.
Said box shall be known as the city-court jury-box and shall be so constructed that it shall have two compartments and kept under one lock and key, and shall not be opened by any one except the judge of said city court or some judge acting in his stead for the purpose of drawing juries, or for revising as herein provided for. The compartments of said jury-box shall be numbered one and two, and when compartment number one is exhausted by the drawing of juries the tickets and names in number two shall be placed back in number one, and the same process shall be gone over again and again as box number one shall be exhausted. The clerk shall keep a jury-box and the sheriff shall keep the key to the same. At each October and April term of said city court the presiding judge shall in open court draw from jury-box eighteen (18) names of persons to serve as jurors at the next term of said court, and shall cause the clerk of said court to record the names of the jurors so drawn.
