It shall be the right and privilege of the defendant to demand a trial by jury, by request made
orally or in writing by himself or herself or counsel, and such case shall stand for trial at the next following jury term. Trial without jury.Demand for jury.

Sec. 37. Be it further enacted, that defendants in criminal cases in said city court shall be tried on a written accusation plainly setting forth the offense charged, founded upon affidavit of the prosecutor and signed by the solicitor of said court. In all criminal cases within the jurisdiction of said city court, the defendant shall have or not have the right to demand an indictment by the grand jury of Wilkes County as shall be determined by an election to be ordered by the proper authority of Wilkes County, and held at the same time as the primary for county officers of said county is held in 1930, and the managers of said primary shall keep a separate box for the voters in said special election, and shall count said vote, and make their returns to the ordinary of said county, who shall canvass and consolidate said vote and declare the result. If at said election the majority of the vote cast shall be for not allowing to defendants charged with misdemeanors in the City Court of Washington the right to demand indictments by the grand jury of said county, then they shall not have the right to demand indictment. If the majority of the vote at said special election is in favor of allowing such defendants the right to demand indictment by the grand jury of said county, then such demands shall be allowed. At such election, the proper authority of the county ordering such election shall furnish for the voters voting therein two forms of ballot, reading, For allowing defendants in misdemeanors the right to demand indictment, and For not allowing defendants in misdemeanors the right to demand indictment. In all proceedings after accusation, the rules governing like cases in the superior courts of this State shall apply except where inconsistent with this Act, except there shall be no jury trial unless demanded by the accused as herein provided. In all accusations the offense charged shall be set forth with the same particularity both as to form and substance, as is now or may hereafter be requisite by the rules and laws of criminal pleadings to be observed upon trials
in criminal cases in the superior courts of this State. If before trial, or after hearing evidence, the judge of the city court shall determine that the offense with which the accused is charged is a felony, he shall immediately suspend trial and commit or bail over the defendant to the superior court as in cases of preliminary examinations. Accusation.Election as to right to demand indictment.Ballot.

Sec. 38. Be it further enacted, that the judge of the Superior Court of Wilkes County shall, at the close of each session thereof, transmit to said City Court of Washington for trial all presentments and bills of indictment found by the grand jury for offenses within the jurisdiction of said city court, which are then pending and undisposed of. The order so transmitting such cases shall be entered on the minutes of both courts. All bonds returnable to the Superior Court of Wilkes County shall follow the cases so transmitted to the City Court of Washington, and defendants in such cases shall be bound to appear in said city court at its first monthly sitting after such cases are transmitted. Transfer of cases from superior court.

Sec. 39. Be it further enacted, that in misdemeanor cases transferred from the Superior Court of Wilkes County to the City Court of Washington, the cost of the solicitor-general of the circuit shall be five dollars, to be collected and paid as other costs in said city court. Costs of solicitor-general in transferred cases.

Sec. 40. Be it further enacted, that fines and forfeitures imposed and collected by said court shall by the clerk of said city court be paid into the county treasury of Wilkes County, and shall constitute the insolvent fund of said court, which said insolvent fund shall be paid pro rate on warrant or order of the judge of said city court to the solicitor, sheriff, clerk of said court, and magistrate in cases founded on warrants issued by them and disposed of in said city court, upon their respective insolvent bills approved by the judge of said court. So much of said fund as originates from cases transferred from the superior court to said city court shall in like manner be prorated between the officers of said city court above mentioned, and the solicitor-general,
clerk, and sheriff of the superior court, and magistrates who may be entitled to costs in such transferred cases, on their insolvent bills approved by the judge of said city court. The treasurer of Wilkes County shall keep said insolvent fund separate from all other funds in his hands. Beginning with the first day of December, 1912, there shall be an annual accounting between the clerk of said city court and the treasurer of Wilkes County as to said insolvent fund; and if there is left in the county treasury any part of said fund after the payment of the approved insolvent bills hereinbefore provided for, it shall be covered into the general fund of said County ofWilkes by order of the judge of said city court drawn on said insolvent fund in favor of the treasurer of Wilkes County, and such fund so covered into the general fund of said county shall be applied first to the payment of the expenses of said City Court of Washington, before any part thereof shall be used for any other purpose; the solicitor of said city court shall from time to time and from year to year keep up his insolvent cost bills and have the same approved as the other officers do, so as to have the same participate in the division of such insolvent fund for the benefit of said County of Wilkes after the payment of one thousand dollars herein provided for his compensation as such solicitor. Disposition of fund from fines and forfeitures.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, that for the term beginning September 1st, 1905, and ending December 1st, 1907, the judge and solicitor of said city court shall be appointed by the Governor of this State under the same rules as now govern the appointment of such officers. All vacancies occurring in either office before December 1st, 1907, shall be filled in like manner. The officials thus appointed shall hold till December 1st, 1907, or until their successors, to be elected as provided for in sections 2 and 11 of this Act, are elected and qualified. Election of judge and solicitors.
Sec. 42. Be it further enacted, that this Act does not go into effect till September 1st, 1905.
Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby abolished.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend An Act to establish the City Court of Waycross in and for the County of Ware, to define its jurisdiction and powers, and for other purposes, so that from and after the passage of this Act, and until otherwise provided, the salary of the judge of said court shall be three thousand dollars per annum, approved August 7th, 1923, by striking therefrom the words three thousand words three thousand dollars wherever the same occurs therein, and inserting in lieu thereof the words thirty-six hundred dollars, so that the salary of said judge shall hereafter be fixed at said sum of thirty-six hundred dollars per annum.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that the above-recited Act be and the same is hereby amended by striking therefrom the words three thousand dollars wherever the same occurs therein, and inserting in lieu thereof the words thirty-six hundred dollars, so that the salary of the judge of said City Court of Waycross shall hereafter be fixed at the sum of thirty-six hundred dollars per annum. Judge's salary, $3,600
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved August 3rd, 1923, amending the Act establishing the City Court of Waycross in and for the County of Ware, defining its jurisdiction and powers, and for other purposes, so that from and after the passage of this Act, and until otherwise provided, the salary of the solicitor of said court shall be twenty-seven hundred dollars per annum.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act, the Act approved August 3, 1923, on pages 197 and 198 of the Acts of the Georgia Legislature of 1923, be and the same is hereby amended as hereinafter provided.

Sec. 2. The second section of said Act is hereby amended so as to make the salary of the solicitor of said City Court of Waycross the sum of twenty-seven hundred dollars per annum, instead of twenty-two hundred and fifty dollars per annum as therein provided; so that when amended said section shall read as follows: Solicitor's salary, $2,750.

Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the passage of this Act, and until otherwise provided, the salary of the solicitor of the City Court of Waycross shall be twenty-seven hundred dollars per annum, which shall be paid monthly out of the treasury and out of the general county funds.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: WRIGHTSVILLE CITY COURT; TERMS; SPECIAL SESSIONS; STENOGRAPHER.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act establishing the City Court of Wrightsville, approved August 19th, 1912, to provide for the judge to adjourn the quarterly terms of said court, to provide for the judge to hold special sessions of same, to provide an official reporter for said court and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act the following words of the second paragraph of section 19 of said Act shall be stricken, The judge shall have power to hold said court in session from day to day, for a period not longer than one week from the beginning of each term; provided that, and inserting in lieu thereof the following words: The judge shall have power to adjourn the regular quarterly terms of said court in the same manner and under the same rules and laws provided for the holding of adjourned terms of the superior courts of this State. The judge shall have power to hold special sessions of said court in the same manner and under the same rules and laws provided for the holding of special sessions of the superior courts of this State; so that when section 19 of said Act shall have been amended, the whole of said section 19 of said Act shall read as follows: Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the regular terms of the said city court of Wrightsville shall be held quarterly and monthly; monthly for the trial of criminal jail cases, and criminal cases in which the defendant waives trial by a jury in writing, and quarterly for the trial of both civil and criminal business. The quarterly terms of said court shall be on the second Mondays in February, May, August, and November of each year; and the monthly terms shall be held on the second Monday in each month of the year
except the months herein designated for the quarterly term. Terms of court; adjournment of term: special sessions.

The judge shall have power to adjourn the regular quarterly terms of said court in the same manner and under the same rules and laws provided for the holding of adjourned terms of the superior courts of this State. The judge shall have power to hold special session of said court in the same manner and under the same rules and laws provided for the holding of special sessions of the superior courts of this State. Said court shall stand open from day to day for the trial of all cases where a trial by jury is waived in writing by the defendant or his attorney.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act, there shall be a stenographer of the City Court of Wrightsville, appointed by the judge thereof, and all civil cases in said court may be reported at the request of the plaintiff or defendant, or in the discretion of the judge, and the fees for reporting such case shall be the same as allowed for similar service in the superior court. In criminal cases he shall be paid on the basis of ($10.00) ten dollars per diem for services rendered in such misdemeanor cases as are directed by the judge of said city court to be reported, such compensation to be paid by the county authorities on order of the judge of said court, the transcript of such evidence to be furnished without cost, when deemed necessary by the judge of said court. Stenographer; per diem, etc.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved July 29, 1915, entitled An Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the County of Appling State of Georgia, prescribe their powers and duties, to fix their compensation, and for other purposes, and the Acts amendatory thereof, by amending said original Act and the amendatory Act approved August 6, 1924, by changing and increasing the salary of said commissioners and providing for the employment of any member thereof as road superintendent, and striking from said Act as amended the provision limiting the rate of tax levy; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it and it is hereby enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that section VI (6) of the Act approved August 29, 1915, be and the same is hereby stricken from said Act, and the following section be and the same is hereby inserted in lieu thereof so that said section shall read when amended as follows: Section VI. The regular meetings of the board of commissioners shall be at the court-house, once a month, on the first Tuesday in every month, and special meetings may be had from time to time, as necessity may require at such times as may be fixed by the chairman of said board of commissioners, of which due notice shall be given each commissioner at least three days before the time for such meeting. Each of said commissioners shall be paid the sum of nine dollars per day for attendance upon said regular meetings and five dollars per day for attendance upon special meetings and for services rendered in behalf of said county outside of and other than attendance upon said meetings, but no commissioner shall be paid for more than fifteen days in any one calendar year for attendance upon special meetings of said board and service rendered to said county other than attending meetings of said board; provided that any member of said
board may be employed by said board as superintendent of roads of said county at a salary to be fixed by said board not in excess of one hundred twenty-five dollars and such salary so fixed by said board shall be full compensation for such member so employed and he shall not receive the perdiem compensation as above specified for payment of members of said board during such employment, and provided further that in the event that any member of said board is employed as such superintendent that during such employment the chairman of said board shall not receive a salary as is provided for in section 14B of said original Act as amended by Act approved August 6, 1924, for any amount in excess of the sum of sixty dollars per month for his entire services as chairman. Meetings and pay of commissioners.Road superintendent, commissioner may be appointed as.Salary.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that section 14H of said Act as amended by Act approved August 6, 1924, in section II of said amendatory Act which limits the rate of tax levy, be and the same is hereby stricken from said Act. Tax rate.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of same, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to repeal an Act entitled An Act to create a commissioner of roads and revenues for Atkinson County, Georgia; to provide for his election and fix his term of office; to fix his compensation and to provide his expense account, and to fix his bond, and to prescribe his powers and duties; to provide for a clerk for said commissioner
and to fix his duties, and his bond, and his compensation; to provide for recall of the commissioner; to prevent the commissioner or clerk from speculating or purchasing in county warrants; to prevent the commissioner from making purchases for the county from any business concern in which he or his clerk is interested; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act that the Act above entitled, creating the commissioner of roads and revenues for the County of Atkinson in the aforesaid State, and approved August 23rd, 1927, and found in the Acts of the Legislature, 1927, pages 477 and 487, inclusive, be and the same is hereby repealed. Repeal of Act creating office.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act entitled An Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the County of Atkinson; to provide for the appointment and election of members thereof; to provide for appointment of a clerk; to define their duties and powers, and prescribe their qualifications, approved August 23rd, 1927, and to provide when this Act shall go into effect; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that on and after the first Monday in August, 1929, an Act entitled An Act to create a board of
commissioners of roads and revenues for the County of Atkinson; to provide for the appointment and election of members thereof; to provide for appointment of a clerk; to define their duties and powers, and prescribe their qualifications, and for other purposes, approved August 23rd, 1927, be and the same is hereby repealed. Provided, however, that this Act shall not go into effect until the first Monday in August, 1929. Repeal of Act creating board of commissioners.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the County of Atkinson; to provide for the appointment and election of members thereof; to provide for appointment of a clerk; to define their duties and powers, and prescribe their qualifications; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the County of Atkinson, consisting of one commissioner for each road district of said county and one commissioner from the county at large, making a total of five commissioners, is hereby created. Said commissioners shall be qualified voters of said county, and shall be elected by the qualified voters of the entire county, but one of said commissioners shall be a resident of and be elected or selected from each of said road districts; each road district being thus represented on said board by a resident, respectively, and one commissioner
shall be elected from the county at large and can reside in either of said four road districts. Board of commissioners created.Qualifications.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that for the purpose of this Act, said County of Atkinson shall be divided, and is hereby divided, into four road districts, to be constituted as follows: Road District Number One shall comprise and constitute 1026 Militia District, or Willachoochee District; Road District Number Two shall comprise and constitute 1353 Militia District, or Axson District. District Number Three shall comprise and constitute a part of the 1130 Militia District, and shall be known as the Pearson District, and is hereby described and bounded as follows: Commencing at the northeast corner of said 1130 Militia District and running west along district line to the northeast corner of lot of Land No. 109 in the 6th Land District, and taking the eastern boundary of said lot of land as a line, running thence south through the entire district to the southeast corner of lot of land No. 212 in the 7th Land District, and thence running the said district line east to the southeast corner of said 1130 Militia District, and thence running north along said district line to the point of beginning. Road District Number Four shall comprise and constitute the remainder of the 1130 Militia District, and shall be known as the Kirkland Road District, and more fully described and bounded as follows: Commencing at the northwest corner of said Pearson Road District and running west to the Willachoochee District, thence running south along the eastern boundary of the Willachoochee District to the southeast corner of the said Willachoochee District, and thence east to the southwest corner of the Pearson Road District, and thence north to the point of beginning. Road districts.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the following named persons are hereby appointed, constituted, and made commissioners of roads and revenues of said County of Atkinson under this Act, to wit: Geo. F. McCranie, Sr., for District No. 1, or the Willacoochee
Road District; Chas. E. Griffis for District No. 2, or the Axson Road District; B. S. Malone for District No. 3, or the Pearson Road District; Hiram Mancel, Jr., for District No. 4, or the Kirkland Road District; J. W. Davis for the county at large; that the terms of office of the above-named commissioners of roads and revenues shall begin on the first Monday in August, 1929, and shall continue until the first day of January, 1933, or until their successors are elected and qualified. Commissioners named.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that B. S. Malone is hereby appointed, constituted, and made chairman of the commissioners of roads and revenues of said county, and he shall hold the chairmanship of said commissioners of roads and revenues until the first day of January, 1933, or until his successor is elected and qualified, and shall have and exercise all authorities and powers conferred by this Act upon the chairman of said board of commissioners. Chairman named.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that at the general election to be held in the year of 1932 said board of commissioners of roads and revenues shall be elected for a term of four years, whose term of office shall begin on the first day of January, 1933, and who shall serve for a term of four years or until their successors are elected and qualified. Elections and terms of commissioners.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that should a vacancy occur in the board of commissioners of roads and revenues by death or otherwise, the chairman or acting chairman of said board shall notify the ordinary of said county of such vacancy in writing, and said ordinary is hereby authorized and empowered to call an election to fill the vacancy in the same manner as is provided for elections to fill vacancies in other county offices. The ordinary shall report such elections to the Governor, who shall issue a commission to the successful candidate for the unexpired term. Vacancies.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the board of commissioners of roads and revenues as herein provided shall be commissioned by the Governor for the term of office for which they are elected or appointed, and before entering upon the discharge of their duties they shall subscribe to the oath before the ordinary of said county required by law for the other county officers, and shall give good and solvent surety bond, to be approved by the ordinary of said county, in the sum of two thousand ($2,000.00) dollars each and payable to the ordinary of said county, for the faithful performance of any and all duties of said office. Said bond when approved by the ordinary shall be by him recorded in the record of official bonds kept by him in his office. Commissions from Governor; bond.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the chairman of the commissioners of roads and revenues, as provided for in this Act, shall preside at all meetings, sign the minutes of all proceedings, sign his name as chairman to all orders, warrants, summons, subpoenas, or other processes issued by said board, or by authority of said board. Duties of chairman.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the board of commissioners of roads and revenues shall at their first meeting in August, 1929, elect one of their body as vice-chairman, who shall, in the absence of the chairman, preside over the meeting of said board and discharge all of the other duties required of the chairman; provided, however, that the said vice-chairman shall have no authority to countersign vouchers, or make any contracts binding on the county, which are by the provision of this Act required by said chairman. Vice-chairman.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said board of commissioners at their first meeting shall elect a clerk at such pay as the board may allow, not to exceed three hundred ($300.00) dollars per year. Said clerk shall give a good and solvent bond in the sum of two thousand ($2,000.00) dollars, payable to the ordinary of
Atkinson County, and to be approved by the ordinary of said county. Said bond shall be conditioned for the faithful performance of all duties of said clerk to the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of the said County of Atkinson. Said board of commissioners shall have power to remove said clerk at their pleasure by a majority vote of said board. It shall be the duty of said clerk to attend all meetings of the board of commissioners of roads and revenues, and keep a full record of all its proceedings, and to keep on file and preserve all papers relating to its business, to keep in a special book a statement of all taxes levied, and for what purposes, minutely specified and designed; also an inventory of all county property, including all road machinery, like stock, chain-gang outfit, and road-working tools; to keep in his record, separate from other financial affairs of the county, an accurate and itemized account of all expenditures of said commissioners. He shall also keep a separate book, in which shall be kept an account of the commutation tax collected by the commissioners of said county. He shall also keep an itemized statement of all accounts paid by the board of commissioners and shall show what fund is liable for the payment of said account. He shall also keep a book to be known as his Record of County Vouchers, in which shall be kept a complete record of warrants or vouchers drawn upon the funds of said county, which record shall show by proper entry the fund from which same is payable, the person to whom payable, the date of record, and the amount of such voucher or warrant. It shall be his duty to sign all vouchers and warrants as clerk, but he shall in no instance issue any warrant or voucher until same shall have been countersigned by the chairman of the board of commissioners of roads and revenues. All records provided for in this section shall be kept in the commissioner's office of said county. The clerk of the Superior Court of Atkinson County or any qualified voter of said county over twenty-five (25) years of age, who is of good moral character, may be selected by said board of commissioners of roads and revenues to
act as clerk for said board of commissioners of Atkinson County, or they may select one of their number other than chairman or vice-chairman to act as clerk. Clerk; salary, bond, duties; removable at pleasure; qualifications.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said board of commissioners of roads and revenues shall hold their first meeting on the first Monday in August, 1929, and shall hold a regular court for the transaction of business pertaining to county matters on the first Monday of each month of the year thereafter. They shall hold their meetings in the offices set apart for the use of said board of commissioners of roads and revenues at the court-house. Said commissioners may hold special sessions at any time that the business of the county shall demand. Meetings.

A majority of the board of commissioners of roads and revenues shall constitute a quorum, and it shall require a majority of said commissioners to pass any order or to transact business. The chairman, or vice-chairman in the absence of the chairman, shall at any meeting of the commissioners of roads and revenues be authorized to administer oaths, and said board may hear testimony as to matters of which said board has jurisdiction, and when sitting as a court shall have power to punish for contempt, under the same rules and regulations as are provided by law for other courts. Quorum.Powers of board.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said commission shall have exclusive jurisdiction and control over the following matters, to wit: In controlling and directing all property of said county as they may deem expedient according to law; in levying taxes according to law; in establishing or abolishing bridges and roads according to law; in establishing or abolishing or changing election precincts or militia districts; in supervising the tax-collector's and tax-receiver's books; in allowing insolvent list of said county; in settling claims and accounts of officers having the care and management and disbursement of funds belonging to or appropriated for the use and benefit of said county, and bring them to settlement
; in providing for the paupers of the county, and for the promotion of health as granted by law and not inconsistent with law; in examining the tax digest of said county for the correction of errors; in regulating and fixing license fees as may be provided by law; in establishing and maintaining a county chain-gang; in working said gang on public roads of said county as provided by law; in electing or appointing all minor officers and employees of said county whose election is not otherwise provided by law, such as superintendent or warden, guards of convicts on chain-gang, janitor of court-house or jail, and superintendent of the county farm; in making such rules and regulations as they may deem best for the interest of the county, governing all minor officers and employees appointed by them, and fixing reasonable compensation for them as said board of commissioners may deem best for the interest of the county, and providing for the collection of the commutation road-tax, fixing the amount to be paid in number of days' work on the roads of said county in lieu thereof, according to law; in trying all road defaulters in accordance with law, and generally to have and exercise all powers heretofore vested in the ordinary of said county when sitting for county purposes, and to exercise all such other powers as are granted by alw or as may be indispensable to their jurisdiction over county matters or county finances. Jurisdiction of board.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that each of said commissioners except the chairman of said board shall receive for his services the sum of three ($3.00) dollars per day for each day of actual service rendered by him, not to exceed fifty (50) days in any calendar year; that the chairman of said board shall give and devote as much of his time and attention to the duties of said office as in the judgment of the majority of the board the duties of said office may require, for which services he shall receive five ($5.00) per day; providing, however, that the chairman shall not receive pay for more than 100 days in one calendar year. Pay of commissioners.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the board of commissioners of roads and revenues shall prepare and submit to the grand jury, at each spring term of the superior court of said county, a full and complete statement of the finances of the county, which statement shall be sworn to and subscribed by the chairman of said board. Said statement and report to the grand jury shall show an account of all receipts and disbursements, the source from whence received, and the purpose for which expended; said statement shall also show the number of persons who have paid the commutation tax, and the amount thereof, and the number of persons subject to road duty who have neither worked their time on the public road nor paid the commutation tax. Said board of commissioners of roads and revenues shall publish in some newspaper having a general circulation in said county the statement so prepared and submitted to the grand jury. Said board of commissioners of roads and revenues shall also publish in the official organ of said county a monthly itemized statement of all receipts and expenditures of said commission. Annual report of commissioners.Monthly financial statement.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the chairman of the board of commissioners shall be the purchasing agent for said county for all things needed by the different departments of said county, and especially for all supplies for convicts, and feed for mules and horses owned by said county, and for all machinery used for said county, and, in fact, everything purchased by said county. And said chairman of board of commissioners of roads and revenues shall secure, as far as possible, competitive bids for such supplies; and this shall apply to all supplies for county officers. Purchases for county.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted, that if any part of this Act is held to be unconstitutional and invalid, then that fact shall not affect the remaining portions of this Act which are not of themselves unconstitutional and invalid. Invalidity of part of Act. not invalidate remainder.

Sec. 17. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the board of commissioners of roads and revenues
shall employ a capable and competent auditor for the purpose of thoroughly auditing the books of the said county commissioners' office, covering all receipts and disbursements of said commissioners' office during the past six years, or for a longer period if they deem it necessary. Provided, however, that they shall have no authority to employ any auditor who has audited the books and records of said commissioners in the past. Auditor.

Sec. 18. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said board of commissioners of roads and revenues shall have the authority to employ a capable attorney to represent them and the county in all litigation pertaining to county affairs, if from said audit of the county records it is discovered any amounts are due said county it shall be the duty of the said county commissioners to institute legal proceedings immediately to recover said amount. Attorney for commissioners
Sec. 19. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to abolish the office of tax-receiver and tax-collector of Atkinson County, Georgia; to create the office of county tax-commissioner of Atkinson County, Georgia; to fix the term and compensation of said officer; to provide that the laws of force as to tax-receivers and tax-collectors, when the provisions of this Act become effective, shall be of full force and effect as to the county commissioner so far as the same are applicable; to provide that all taxes due at the time the provisions of this Act become effective and all tax fi. fas. theretofore issued shall have full force and effect and be collectible as
issued; to provide that all fees and comissions and other compensation that would be paid to or collected by the tax-receiver and tax-collector were it not for the provisions of this Act shall be collected by the county tax-commissioner herein provided for, and paid into the treasury of Atkinson County, Georgia; to provide for the election of said county tax-commissioner, and the method of filling vacancies; to provide for giving bond; to provide for putting into effect the constitution of this State as contained in article eleven (11) section three (3), paragraph one (1); and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the offices of tax-receiver and tax-collector of Atkinson County, Georgia, are hereby abolished, and the duties of the two offices aforesaid are hereby consolidated into one office. Offices of tax-receiver and tax-collector abolished.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the office of county tax-commissioner of Atkinson County, Georgia, is hereby created in lieu of said abolished office, and the rights, duties and liabilities of the said office of county tax-commissioner of Atkinson County, shall be the same as the rights, duties, and liabilities of the tax-receiver and tax-collector of said county, so far as same are applicable. Office of tax-commissioner created; duties.
Sec. 3. This Act shall not take effect until January 1st, 1933, at the expiration of the term of office of the present tax-collector of Atkinson County, Georgia. Act effective Jan. 1, 1933.

Sec. 4. There shall be held at the general election for county officers in the year 1932 an election for tax-commissioner of Atkinson County, Georgia, who shall be elected at the same time and in the same manner as other county officers of Atkinson County, and whose term of office shall begin on January 1st, 1933, and be for the term of four years thereafter, or until his successor is elected and qualified. The duties of said tax-commissioner shall be as herein provided. Election and term.
Sec. 5. Said tax-commissioner shall be commissioned and qualified as the clerks of the superior courts are. Commission.
Sec. 6. If a vacancy for any cause occurs in said office of tax-commissioner, it shall be filled in the following manner: Vacancies.

item.p: (a) If said vacancy occurs within six months of the expiration of the existing term, the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Atkinson County, Georgia, shall appoint some qualified person to discharge the duties of said consolidated office for the remainder of said term, and the person so appointed shall be commissioned and qualified as clerks of the superior court, and shall receive the pro rata part of the compensation accruing to said office for the time so appointed.

(b) If said vacancy occurs more than six months prior to the expiration of the existing term, the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Atkinson County shall appoint some qualified person to discharge the duties of said consolidated office until a tax-commissioner is elected, and it shall be the duty of the ordinary of Atkinson County to call a special election for the election of a tax-commissioner to serve the remainder of said term, which election shall be ordered not sooner than twenty (20) days and not later than forty (40) days after said vacancy occurs; and the ordinary shall give notice, of the date of said election by publication thereof in a public gazette published in Atkinson County, and before the court-house door of said county at least ten (10) days before said election. The person elected on said day shall perform the duties of said consolidated office for the expired term of his predecessors. The return of said election shall be made to the Governor, who shall commission the person so elected. The person so temporarily appointed and the person so elected shall each receive his pro rata part of the compensation accruing to said office for the time he serves. Election to fill vacancy.

law.p:
Sec. 7. Should any two or more candidates at an election to fill said vacancy, or any regular election, have the
highest and an equal number of votes, said ordinary shall call and advertise another election within twenty days, in the manner above provided, and so do until a choice is made.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all taxes that are due and payable at the time the provisions of this Act become effective, and all tax fi. fas. theretofore issued by the tax-collector of Atkinson County, Georgia, shall have full force and effect, and be collectible as issued. Taxes collectible by commissioner.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all fees, commission, and all other compensation allowed to the tax-receiver and tax-collector of Atkinson County, Georgia, at the time this Act becomes effective, or that might be legally be allowed to such officers there-afterward were it not for the provisions of this Act, shall be collected by said county tax-commissioner and paid into the treasury of Atkinson County, Georgia. Compensation.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the compensation of the county tax-commissioner of Atkinson County, Georgia, shall be a sum equal to fifty (50) per cent. of the fees, commission, and all other compensation accruing to the tax-receiver and tax-collector of Atkinson County, Georgia, at the time this Act becomes effective, or that might legally be allowed to such officers thereafterward were it not for the provisions of this Act; and same shall be paid proportionately, monthly, as near as the same can be estimated, until the same is changed by law. Same.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that before entering upon the duties of his office the said county tax-commissioner shall take the oath now prescribed by law for the tax-collector, and shall give bond in double the amount of money reasonable estimated to pass through his hands annually, which bond shall be signed as surety by a bonding company legally authorized to do business in the State of Georgia, and the fee or cost
for the suretyship on said bond shall be paid out of the funds of Atkinson County, Georgia, as part of the expense of county government. Oath and bond.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that if for any reason any portion of this Act shall be held by the court of last resort of this State to be unconstitutional, the whole of this Act shall not thereby become void, but only so much of the same as may be held to be unconstitutional; the purpose of this Act being to put into effect the constitution of this State, as is contained in article eleven (11), section three (3), paragraph one (1). Invalidity of part of Act, not invalidate remainder.
Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act, be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to abolish the offices of tax-receiver and tax-collector of Bartow County, Georgia; to create the office of county tax-commissioner of Bartow County, Georgia; to fix the term of office and compensation of said officers to provide that the laws of force as to tax-receiver and tax-collector when the provisions of this Act become effective shall be of full force and effect as to the county tax-commissioner so far as the same are applicable; to provide that all taxes due at the time the provisions of this Act become effective and all tax fi. fas. theretofore issued shall have full force and effect and be collectible as issued; to provide that all fees and commissions and other compensations that would have been paid to or collected by the tax-receiver and tax-collector, were it not for the provisions of this Act, shall be collected by the county tax-commissioner herein provided for, and
paid into the treasury of Bartow County, Georgia; to provide for necessary assistants for said county taxcommissioner and their salaries, and for necessary expenses of said office; to provide for the election of said county tax-commissioner, the method of filling vacancies; to provide for giving bond; to provide for putting into effect the constitution of this State as contained in article eleven (11), section three (3), paragraph one (1), and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the offices of tax-receiver and tax-collector of Bartow County, Georgia, are hereby abolished, and the duties of the two officers aforesaid are hereby consolidated into one office. Offices abolished.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the office of county tax-commissioner of Bartow County, Georgia, is hereby created in lieu of said abolished offices, and the rights, duties, and liabilities of the said office of county tax-commissioner of Bartow County, Georgia, shall be the same as the rights, duties, and liabilities of the tax-receiver and tax-collector of said county, so far as the same are applicable. Office of tax-commissioner created: duties.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all taxes that are due and payable at the time the provisions of this Act become effective, and all tax fi. fas. therefore issued by the tax-collector of Bartow County, Georgia, shall have full force and effect, and be collectible as issued. Taxes collectible by commissioner.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all fees, commissions, and other compensation allowed to the tax-receiver and tax-collector of Bartow County, Georgia, at the time this Act becomes effective, or that might legally be allowed to such officers thereafterward, were it not for the provisions of this Act, shall be collected by said county tax-commissioner and paid into the treasury of Bartow County, Georgia. Compensation.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that at least ninety (90) days before the first day of January (beginning with January, 1933) the commissioner of roads and revenues of Bartow County, Georgia, shall fix the salary of the county tax-commissioner, which salary shall be sufficient to enable the said county tax-commissioner to employ and pay out of the salary so awarded the said county tax-commissioner for such needed deputy assistance as he may need in transacting and performing the duties of the office, and it is hereby expressly provided that the commissioner of roads and revenues of Bartow County, Georgia, shall fix for the succeeding term the salary of the said county tax-commissioner at an amount which shall include the expense of employment by the county tax-commissioner of deputies and assistants, subject to the provisions of this Act hereinafter contained; provided, however, that it shall be within the power and authority of said county tax-commissioner, after the beginning of his term of office, to designate and name the person or persons who shall be such assistants, and to remove them at the will and pleasure of such county tax-commissioner. Said salary shall be fixed for each term at the time aforesaid, and shall not be changed during said term. Salary.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that before the action of the commissioner of roads and revenues of Bartow County, Georgia, in fixing the salary of the county tax-commissioner shall become effective, the same shall be submitted to the grand jury then sitting, or, in the event no grand jury is in session at the time of said fixing of salary, the next grand jury convening thereafter. It shall be the duty of the said commissioner of roads and revenues to submit to the said grand jury a report stating the amount at which he has fixed the salary of the county tax-commissioner, which shall include a statement of what amount of expense for deputy hire he had considered in reaching his conclusion as to salary. The first order of business of the grand jury to which this
Act applies, after the submission of such report, shall be the consideration of such report. The grand jury shall have the power to disapprove the report by a vote of twelve of the members thereof, but unless the grand jury so disapproves the said report, the salary shall remain as fixed by the said commissioner of roads and revenues of Bartow County, Georgia. In the event that the grand jury fails to act upon the said report within ten days after the submission thereof, then said salary shall remain as fixed by the commissioner of roads and revenues. In the event the grand jury disapproves of the amount of salary so fixed and reported by the commissioner of roads and revenues, then the foreman of said grand jury shall appoint a committee from said grand jury, consisting of four members, which committee shall meet in joint conference with the commissioner of roads and revenues of Bartow County, Georgia, for the purpose of harmonizing their contentions and determining upon an amount to be fixed as salary for the county tax-commissioner, and the salary so approved by a majority of said joint conference committee shall be final. Same.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that after said salary is so fixed and determined as provided in section five (5) and six (6) hereof, it shall be proper for the custodian of the county funds, on or before the 15th day of each month, to pay the monthly portion of such salary to said county tax-commissioner. Same.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that before entering upon the duties of his office the said county tax-commissioner shall take the oath now prescribed by law for the tax-collector and tax-receiver, and shall give bond in double the amount of money reasonably estimated to pass through his hands annually, which bond shall be signed by a bonding company legally authorized to do business in the State of Georgia. Oath and bond.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the first election of county tax-commissioner
of Bartow County shall be held at the same time and under the same laws as other county officers are elected at the general election for county officers in the year 1932, and quadrenially thereafter, and that the person so elected shall enter upon the duties of office hereby created on January 1, 1933, and shall serve for a term of four years. If a vacany shall occur, then the office shall be filled in the same manner as vacancies are filled in other county offices. Election and term of offices.Election and term of office.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the commissioner of roads and revenues of Bartow County, Georgia, shall levy and collect a tax to pay the salary of said county tax-commissioner and for office supplies, and that the said commissioner of roads and revenues shall pay out of the general funds of the county the premium on any bond or bonds required of said county tax-commissioner of and for said county. Tax to pay salary, etc.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that if for any reason any portion of this Act shall be held by the court of last resort of this State to be unconsitutional, the whole of this Act shall not thereby become void, but only so much of the same as may be so held to be unconstitutional; the purpose of this Act being to put into effect the constitution of this State as is contained in article eleven (11), section 3, paragraph 1. Invalidity of part of Act not invalidate remainder.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that before this Act shall go into effect the same shall be ratified at an election to be called by the ordinary of Bartow County, Georgia, to be held on the same day in 1930 that the democratic primary is held for the nomination of Governor of the State of Georgia, and all qualified voters of Bartow County, Georgia, shall be eligible to participate in said election so called and held. If this Act is ratified by a majority of those voting at said election the provisions of this Act consolidating the two offices shall go into effect on January 1, 1933. The ballot to be furnished the voters in this election shall have printed thereon, For
abolishing offices of tax-receiver and tax-collector and creating of office of county tax-commissioner, and Against abolishing offices of tax-receiver and tax-collector and creation of office of county tax-commisisoner. Said election shall be held under the law, rules, and regulations now governing speical elections. Provisions therefor shall be under the direction of the ordinary of Bartow County, Georgia, and the result of said election shall be declared by said ordinary. All expenses of said election shall be borne by County of Bartow. Referendum.
Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to establish, a county board of commissioners for the County of Bibb, to define their duties, and for other purposes therein named, which said amendatory Act was approved December 23, 1896, said amendment hereby sought being a change of compensation of said county board of commissioners for said county.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act the first section of the above-recited amendatory act approved December 23, 1896, be amended by striking out from said section, wherever the same appears, the words three hundred ($300), and inserting in lieu thereof the following words, viz: six hundred ($600), so that said section as amended shall read as follows: That it shall require three of said commissioners to constitute a quorum
for the transaction of business, and three must concur to pass any order or decree. Each of said commissioners shall be entitled to a salary at the rate of six hundred ($600) dollars per annum for their services as county commissioners during their continuance in office, to be paid out of the treasury of said county upon warrant drawn by said board, or a majority thereof. Increase of salary.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to abolish the office of county treasurer of Brantley County, Georgia, and providing the manner of appointment of some bank or banks, or person to whom said county funds shall be turned over, and prescribing the duties of such bank or banks, or person, in receiving and disbursing the county funds and fixing compensation, if any; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that on and after the first day of January, 1933, the office of county treasurer of Brantley County, be and the same is hereby abolished. Office of treasurer abolished.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of said county shall disignate some legally chartered bank, located in the State of Georgia as conveniently as possible, as depository, to become effective on the first day of January, 1933, and when possible make contract with said bank for the payment of interest on monthly balances or deposits, and in no event shall said board be authorized
to pay said depository for service in handling county funds a sum exceeding one hundred and fifty dollars per annum. Bank to be depository, beginning Jan. 1, 1933.Compensation.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all officers having charge of the funds of said county shall deposit the same in such duly designated depository by direction of said board. Deposit of funds.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the words county funds as used in this Act shall include all funds raised by taxation or otherwise, all road-tax of all kinds, all monies coming into the county funds from all sources whatsoever to be used for roads or county purposes, and all special taxes levied for special purposes, all appropriations either State or Federal, for road building pruposes, and any and all funds generally known as county funds. Definition of county funds.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said board of commissioners of roads and revenues shall require a bond in some surety company doing business in the State of Georgia in an amount not less than $20,000.00 from said depository, payable to said county authorities, to be recorded as other county bonds by the ordinary, conditioned to faithfully account for all funds turned over to it by said county authorities. Bond.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that no warrants drawn on such county depository shall be honored or paid by it except as such as are now authorized to be paid by the treasurer of said County of Brantley. Payment of warrants.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that such depository shall report to the county authorities having charge of the finances of said county as often as once every month, or oftener if required by said authorities, showing the amount of funds on hand, and return all warrants; but this section shall not be construed to prohibit such bank from rendering to said authorities their usual and customary statements; and such depository
shall be required to keep such books and records as may be directed by said county authorities. Accounts and reports.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said county authorities shall be authorized to change said depository when in their judgment it is necessary or expedient, but so long as any bank remains such depository the tax-collector of said county and all officers or persons collecting money due to said county shall turn the same over to the said depository; that all officers or other persons making deposits in said depository shall take receipts for such deposits in duplicate, keeping one and delivering the other to said county authorities. Change of depository.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said depository and disbursing agent as provided for in this Act shall be liable both civilly and criminally, just as county treasurers are liable for any nonfeasance or malfeasance of duty, and that said authorities shall have the right to proceed against said depository or the securities on its bond, as said treasures may now be proceeded against in the case of nonfeasance or malfeasance in the conduct of the affairs of his office. Malfeasance or nonfeasance.
Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authroity aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal section 11, page 508, of the Acts 1927, relating to the duties of the county commissioners of Bryan County, to require all persons of said county subject to road duty to either work the roads or pay the commutation tax; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the same, that from and after the passage of this Act that section 11, page 508, of the Acts 1927 be and the same are hereby repealed and not enforceable by the county commissioners of said county; said section relating to the duties of the county commissioners of Bryan County to require all persons of said county subject to road duty to either work the roads or pay the commutation tax. Repeal of Sec. 11 of Act of 1927 as to road duty, etc.
Sec. 2. That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Burke County, Georgia, to define the duties of said commissioners, and for other purposes, approved August 31st, 1911, as amended by an Act approved August 16th, 1912, so as to change the method of electing said commissioners and provide that they shall hereafter be selected by the grand jury of said county instead of by election of the qualified voters of said county as now provided by law; to provide for the posting of the collections and expenditures of revenues once a month; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act section one of the Acts of 1911, Georgia Laws 1911, pages 390 to 398, inclusive, which provides for the election of a board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Burke County, Georgia, be stricken and the following section be substituted
therefor: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act there shall be created and established a board of commissioners of roads and revenues of the County of Burke in the State of Georgia, consisting of five persons, who shall be selected by the grand jury of Burke County, Georgia, as follows: That at the fall term, in the year 1932, of the grand jury of Burke County, Georgia, the said grand jury shall select five persons to compose the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Burke County, Georgia, which said five persons shall be not less than twenty-eight years of age and shall have been resident freeholders in said county for three years or more, and eligible for election as a member of the General Assembly of Georgia. The said five persons so selected shall assume the duties of office on the first day of January, 1933. The said grand jury, in the year 1932, shall designate two of the men so selected to hold office as such commissioners for a period of two years, and also designate three of said persons so selected to hold office for a period of four years. Provided further that at intervals of two years, each grand jury serving at the fall term of the Superior Court of Burke County, Georgia, shall select two or three persons (as the case may demand) with the above qualifications to serve as commissioners of roads and revenues of Burke County, Georgia, the terms of which shall be for four years each. Election of commissioners by grand jury.Qualifications, terms.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that section twelve of the Acts 1911, Georgia Laws 1911, page 395, be amended by adding at the end thereof the following: It shall be the duty of the commissioners of roads and revenues of Burke County, Georgia, to post on a bulletin board before the court-house door of the County of Burke each month the names of the payees and the amounts of each bill paid and also a statement of all revenues collected and sources from which such revenues were collected, so that when so amended said section twelve shall read as follows: Section 12. Be it further enacted, that said board of commissioners
shall keep in view the proper, just, and legal management of all of the affairs of the county entrusted to them by law, and shall not approve or pay any account, claim, insolvent cost, or other cost of any kind, or any other demand against said county, unless the same is directed and authorized by law. It shall be the duty of the commissioners of roads and revenues of Burke County, Georgia, to post on a bulletin board before the court-house door of the County of Burke each month the names of the payees and the amounts of each bill paid, and also a statement of all revenues collected and sources from which such revenues were collected. Monthly financial bulletins.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act, be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: CALHOUN COUNTY SITE REMOVED TO MORGAN.
law.fulltitle: An Act to remove the county site of Calhoun County from Arlington to Morgan in said county; to declare Morgan the county site of said county; and for other purposes.
law.p: Whereas, an election has been duly and legally held in Calhoun County for the removal of the county site of said county, and at said election, by a majority or more than two thirds of the qualified voters in said county voting at said election, it was voted that the county site should be moved from Arlington to Morgan in said county;

Whereas, the Secretary of State has duly certified the results thereof, pursuant to law, showing that there were 1533 votes polled in said election, and that 1033 of said votes were for removal to Morgan, 496 was against removal, and 4 was for removal to Edison; that two thirds of 1533
is 1022; said election therefore resulting in favor of removal of said county site from Arlington to Morgan;
Be it therefore enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same:

item.p: (1) That the county site of Calhoun County be and the same is hereby removed and changed from Arlington to Morgan in said county. Removal of county site from Arlington.
(2) That from and after the passing of this Act the City of Morgan in Calhoun County be and the same is hereby declared to be the county site of Calhoun County.
(3) That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: CAMPBELL AND FULTON COUNTIES; MERGER, REFERENDUM.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to merge Campbell County with Fulton County; to provide that all property belonging to Campbell County shall become the property of Fulton County; that all indebtedness of Campbell County shall become the valid obligations of Fulton County; that the county officers and county boards of Campbell County be abolished; that all local laws in reference to county government, including the Act of 1874 and the Act of 1923, be repealed; that certain officers and boards of Campbell County shall be officers and boards of Fulton County, and that new commissions be issued to same; to transfer all pending suits, both civil and criminal, to the courts of Fulton County, confer jurisdiction to determine the same; to provide for the enforcement of judgments, executions, orders, and decrees of the courts of Campbell County;
to transfer matters pending before Board of County Commissioners and County Board of Education to similar bodies in Fulton County, with authority of such bodies to determine the same; to make the valid contracts of Campbell County the valid contracts of Fulton County; to provide for the collection of taxes due Campbell County; to abolish Fairburn as county seat and to transfer all records to Fulton County and to provide for the payment of expenses incident thereto; to provide when this Act shall become effective; to provide for its ratification or rejection; to provide for the calling of an election to ratify or reject same; to provide for the filing and determination of contest; to provide that the Secretary of State shall determine when said Act has been ratified, and that upon the certificate of the Secretary of State the Governor shall issue his proclamation declaring the same ratified; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that the County of Campbell be and the same is hereby merged with and made a part of the County of Fulton in said State. Merger of Campbell into Fulton County.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all property, both real and personal, and of what ever kind or nature, wherever located or situated, belonging to Campbell County shall be and become the property of Fulton County, Georgia. Property of Campbell County to be property of Fulton.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all valid bonded indebtedness of the County of Campbell is hereby made the valid binding obligation of the County of Fulton, said State. Bonded indebtedness.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all valid floating indebtedness of whatever kind or nature of Campbell County is hereby made the valid obligations of Fulton County, said State. Floating indebtedness.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the following offices of Campbell County be and
the same are hereby abolished: representative, ordinary, judge city court of Fairburn; solicitor city court of Fairburn; clerk superior court; clerk city court of Fairburn; sheriff city court of Fairburn; tax-collector, tax-receiver, coroner, county depository; board of commissioners of roads and revenue; county board of education; county superintendent of schools; county attendance officers; county attorney; county physician; clerk county commissioners; county warden; deputy warden; county police; board of tax equalizers; board of jury commissioners; board of registrars. Offices abolished.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the Act creating the board of county commissioners of Campbell County, found on page 335 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1874, and all Acts amendatory thereto, be and the same are hereby repealed. Act of 1874 and amendments repealed.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the Act approved July 28, 1923, creating city court of Fairburn and all Acts amendatory thereto and the same is hereby repealed. City Court of Fairburn, abolished.
Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all local laws in force touching county government of Campbell County be and the same are hereby repealed. Other acts repealed.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all boards of trustees of local school districts in Campbell County shall hold their same office for the remainder of the term for which they were elected in Fulton County, as if no merger had taken place, and the county superintendent of schools of Fulton County is hereby directed to issue new commissions to the members of such boards, commissioning them for the remainder of their term as officers of Fulton County. School trustees.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all justices of the peace and notaries public who are ex-officio justice of peace of Campbell County shall retain their offices and become such officers of Fulton
County, and the Governor shall recommission such officers as officers of Fulton County for the balance of the term to which they were elected or appointed. Justices of the peace, etc.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all regularly commissioned constables of Campbell County shall be constables of their respective district in Fulton County for the remainder of the term for which they were elected or appointed, and the ordinary of Fulton County is hereby directed to issue new commissions to such officers as officers of Fulton County. Constables.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all suits at law or in equity, and all indictments, criminal cases, and other matters pending in the superior court of the County of Campbell, be and they are hereby transferred and made pending in the superior court of Fulton County. Said matters shall have exactly the same status in the superior court of Fulton County as they had in the superior court of Campbell County, and said superior court of Fulton County is hereby given jurisdiction to try and determine all of said matters. Pending business of courts of Campbell County.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all civil cases pending in the city court of Fairburn be and they are hereby transferred and made pending in the city court of Atlanta. Said cases shall have exactly the same status in the city court of Atlanta as they had in the city court of Fairburn, and said city court of Atlanta is hereby given jurisdiction to try and determine all of said cases. Same.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all accusations and criminal cases pending in the city court of Fairburn be and they are hereby transferred and made pending in the criminal court of Atlanta. Said cases shall have exactly the same status in the criminal court of Atlanta as they had in the city court of Fairburn, and said criminal court of Atlanta is hereby given jurisdiction to try and determine all of said cases. Same.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all matters pending in or over which the court of ordinary of Campbell County has jurisdiction are hereby transferred to the court of ordinary of Fulton County, and said court is hereby given jurisdiction to try and determine the same. Same.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all judgments, executions, orders, and decrees of the several courts of Campbell County shall have the same force and effect as if this Act had never been passed, and the corresponding courts and officers of Fulton County are hereby granted authority to enforce the same. Judgments, executions.

Sec. 17. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all matters pending before the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Campbell County are hereby transferred to the commissioners of Fulton County, and said board of commissioners of Fulton County is hereby given authority and jurisdiction to determine said matters. Matters pending before board of commissioners.

Sec. 18. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all matters pending before the county board of education of Campbell County are hereby transferred to the county board of education of Fulton County, and said county board of education of Fulton County is hereby given authority and jurisdiction to determine said matters. Matters pending before board of education.
Sec. 19. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all valid contracts of the County of Campbell are hereby made valid contracts of the County of Fulton. Contracts.

Sec. 20. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all uncollected tax belonging to the County of Campbell is hereby made the property of the County of Fulton, and said County of Fulton is hereby given authority to enforce said taxes in as full and ample a manner as the same could be enforced by Campbell County. Uncollected taxes.

Sec. 21. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that nothing in this Act shall be construed as changing
the county seat of the County of Fulton, and Fairburn shall no longer be a county seat. County seat.

Sec. 22. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all county records, including court records, land records, personal property records, etc., shall be by the present custodians of same delivered to the corresponding officers of Fulton County, provided however that the expense of transfer shall be borne by Fulton County. Transfer of records, etc.

Sec. 23. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that this Act shall become effective on the first day of January, 1932, after its ratification by the qualified electors of Campbell County and Fulton County as hereinafter provided; provided, however, that in no event shall the same become effective prior to January 1, 1932. Act to be effective Jan. 1, 1932, if ratified.

Sec. 24. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that upon the petition of ten per centum of the registered qualified voters of Campbell County, or upon the recommendation of two successive grand juries of Campbell County, the ordinary of Campbell County shall call an election, which shall be held in not less than 20 and no longer than 60 days from the date of such call, for the purpose of submitting to the qualified electors of Campbell County the question of whether or not this Act shall be ratified. At said election those favoring the ratification of this Act shall have written or printed on their ballot, For merger with Fulton, and those opposed to the ratification of this Act shall have written or printed on their ballot, Against merger with Fulton County. Election in Campbell County as to ratification of Act.Form of ballot.

Sec. 25. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that in the event two thirds of the registered qualified voters of Campbell County voting in said election shall favor the merger, this Act shall be declared ratified by the people of Campbell County.

Sec. 26. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the managers of said election shall meet at the court-house at Fairburn at 12:00 o'clock noon on the
next day after said election and consolidate the same and make their return to the Secretary of State, who shall determine the result of said election.

Sec. 27. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that in the event this Act is ratified by the voters of Campbell County, such fact shall be by the Secretary of State certified to the ordinary of Fulton County, Georgia, who shall call an election on or before September 1st, 1931, to be held in Fulton County, for the purpose of submitting to the qualified voters of said county the question of whether or not this Act shall be ratified. At said election those favoring the ratification of this Act shall have written or printed on their ballot, For Campbell County Merger, and those opposed to the ratification of this Act shall have written or printed on their ballot, Against Campbell County Merger. Election in Fulton County.Form of ballot.

Sec. 28. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that in the event a majority of the registered qualified voters of Fulton County voting in said election shall favor the merger, this Act shall become effective as hereinbefore provided.

Sec. 29. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the managers of said election shall meet at the court-house in Atlanta at 12:00 o'clock noon on the next day after said election and consolidate the same and make their return to the Secretary of State, who shall determine the result of said election. Consolidation of votes.

Sec. 30.
