That, in accordance with and by authority of an amendment to the constitution of the State of Georgia, approved August 18, 1924, and ratified at the general election in 1924, the offices and duties of the tax-receiver and the tax-collector of Heard County, Georgia, shall, on and after the first day of January, 1933, be and remain consolidated, and the official performing the duties of said two officers shall be known and designated as Heard County tax-commissioner. Consolidation of offices.
Sec. 2. That said tax-commissioner shall hold office for a term of four years, the first term beginning January 1, 1933, and ending December 31, 1936. Term of office.

Sec. 3. Said tax-commissioner shall be elected at the general election held in the State of Georgia in the year 1933, and at the general election each four years thereafter, in the same manner, time and place as clerks of the superior court are elected. Election.
Sec. 4. Said tax-commissioner shall be commissioned and qualified as the tax-receivers and tax-collectors are. Commission.
Sec. 5. If a vacancy, for any cause, occurs in said office of tax-commissioner it shall be filled in the following manner: Vacancy in office.

item.p: (a) If said vacancy occurs within six months of the expiration of the existing term, the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Heard County, Georgia, shall appoint some qualified person to discharge the duties of said consolidated office for the remainder of the term, and the person so appointed shall be commissioned and qualified as tax-receiver and tax-collector, and shall receive the pro rata part of the compensation accruing to said office of the time so appointed.

(b) If said vacancy occurs more than six months prior to the expiration of the existing term the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Heard County shall appoint some qualified person to discharge the duties of said consolidated office until a tax-commissioner is elected, and it shall be the duty of the ordinary of Heard County to call a special election for the election of a tax-commissioner to serve the remainder of said term, which election shall be ordered not sooner than twenty (20) days and not later than forty (40) days after said vacancy occurs, and the ordinary shall give notice of the date of said election by publication thereof in a public gazette published in Heard County and before the court-house door of said county at least ten (10) days before said election. The person elected on said day shall perform the duties of said consolidated office for the unexpired term of his predecessor. The return of said election shall be made to the Governor, who shall commission the person so elected. The person so temporarily appointed and the person so elected shall each receive his pro rata part of the compensation accuring to said office of the time he serves.

law.p: Sec. 6. Should any two or more candidates at an election to fill said vacancy, or at any regular election, have the highest and an equal number of votes, said ordinary shall call and advertise another election within twenty days, in the manner above provided, and so do until a choice is made. Second election.

Sec. 7. Said tax-commissioner, whether elected or appointed, before entering on the duties of his office, besides the oath required of all civil officers, shall take and subscribe the following oath: I swear that I will truly and faithfully perform the duties of county tax-commissioner of Heard County, Georgia, that is to say, all duties heretofore required and prescribed for tax-receiver and tax-collector, and such other duties as might be required by law; that I will not receive any return but on oath or affirmation; that I will search out and make a true return of all defaulters, polls, professions, and all taxable property not returned; that I will account for and pay over all taxes collected by me, as required by law; and will, to the best of my ability, carry out all requirements made upon me by law; so help me God. Oath.
And said tax-commissioner shall also, at the same time, give bonds and security as follows:

item.p: (a) Bond and security, payable to his Excellency, the Governor and his successors in office, in the sum equal to one half of the State tax estimated to be due from Heard County for the year for which officer is required to give bond, to be filled up by the comptroller-general before being sent out to the county from the Executive Office, and to be conditioned as bonds of tax-collectors for State taxes are now conditioned. Bond.

(b) Bond and security, payable to the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Heard County, Georgia, conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties as such tax-commissioner, in a sum to be fixed by said board of commissioners, which said bond must be filed with and approved by said board of commissioners, and recorded on the records of said board.

law.p:
The security on both of said bonds shall be reliable bonding company. If said tax-commissioner, whether elected or appointed, shall fail or neglect to give and file said bonds, as above required, within ten (10) days from the time beginning the discharge of the duties of his office,
said board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Heard County shall declare a vacancy in said office, which vacancy shall be filled in the manner above provided. That the premiums on the bond herein required shall be paid out of and from the funds of Heard County, Georgia, by the Treasurer of said county.

Sec. 8. Said tax-commissioner, whether elected or appointed, shall perform each, every and all of the duties now required by law of both the tax-receiver and tax-collector of Heard County, Georgia, and in the manner prescribed by law, shall be subject to all the pains and penalties, and have all the powers, rights, and privileges of said two offices and officers, except compensation. Duties.

Sec. 9. The commissions now fixed and allowed by law to the tax-receiver and tax-collector of Heard County, Georgia, for the return and collection of county and school taxes, shall, on and after January 1, 1933, be abolished and no longer charged or allowed. Commissions abolished.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the compensation of said commissioner shall be one thousand eight hundred dollars and no cents ($1800.00) per annum, to be paid at the rate of one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) per month at the end of each calendar month; however, the grand juries which may see fit to so do can in their wisdom diminish said one thousand and eight hundred dollars ($1800.00) as salary of said commissioner as low as one thousand two hundred dollars ($1200.00) per annum, or as high as two thousand dollars ($2000.00) per annum, provided two successive grand juries may concur in said decrease or increase of said commissioner's salary; otherwise it shall remain as provided for in this Act, viz: one thousand eight hundred dollars ($1800.00) per annum; and said tax-commissioner, out of said salary, is to pay whatever clerical help that may be necessary for him to perform the duties of this office. Said salary to be paid by the commissioners of roads and revenues from the funds in the county treasury, raised by taxation, as provided in section 11 of this Act. Salary.

Sec. 11. The board of commissioners of Heard County are hereby authorized and empowered, for and in behalf of Heard County, to levy and collect a tax on all taxable property in Heard County, Georgia, sufficient to pay said salary of said tax-commissioner. Tax to pay salary.
Sec. 12. Said tax-commissioner shall have an office in the court-house, which said office shall be kept opened at all times except Sundays and legal holidays. Keeping office open.

Sec. 13. That all fees, commissions, percentages, and allowances now paid by the State of Georgia to the tax-receiver and tax-collector for receiving and collecting the State taxes shall be by said commissioner collected and paid over to the treasurer of Heard County or to the bank the board of commissioners of Heard County shall designate as a depository for county funds; also all fees and costs now allowed by law to the tax-collector for issuing fi. fas. against delinquent taxpayers shall be by said tax-commissioner collected and paid over to the treasurer of Heard County or the bank designated as a depository for county funds. Fees to be turned over to treasurer.
Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved August 18, 1925, entitled An Act to abolish the offices of tax-receiver and tax-collector of Henry County, Georgia, to create the office of county tax-commissioner of Henry County, Georgia, to fix the term and compensation of said officer, to provide for giving bond, etc., and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same that from and after the passage of this Act that Section 5 of an Act approved August 18, 1925, entitled An Act to abolish the offices of tax-receiver and tax-collector of Henry County, Georgia, to create the office of county tax-commissioner of Henry County, Georgia, to fix the term and compensation of said office, to provide for giving bond, etc., and for other purposes, be and the same is hereby repealed.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of same, that a new Section shall be added to said Act to be known as Section 5, which shall read as follows:

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the compensation of the county tax-commissioner of Henry County, Georgia, shall be $2400.00 per annum, payable monthly in the sum of $200.00 per month, and payable at the end of each month. Salary $2,400.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that Section 6 of said Act be and the same is amended by striking therefrom the words The fee or cost for the suretyship on said bond shall be paid by the tax-commissioner of Henry County, Georgia, and inserting in lieu thereof the words the fee or costs for the suretyship on said bond shall be paid by Henry County, Georgia, out of the funds in the treasury of said county, so that said section when amended shall read as follows: Cost of suretyship.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that before entering upon the duties of his office the said county tax-commissioner shall take the oath now prescribed by law for the tax-collector and shall give bond in double the amount of money reasonably estimated to pass through his hands annually, which bond shall be signed as surety by a bonding company legally authorized to do business in
the State of Georgia, and the fee or cost for suretyship on said bond shall be paid by Henry County, Georgia, out of the funds in the treasury of said county.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of law in conflict with this Act be, and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: To be entitled an Act to amend an Act creating an advisory board for the County of Lamar, approved August 6, 1927, by fixing the salary of the ordinary of Lamar County as chairman of said advisory board at seventy-five ($75.00) dollars per month; defining his duties and the duties of other members of said board, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of same, that Section 8 of an Act creating an advisory board of the County of Lamar, approved August 6, 1927, be and the same is hereby stricken, and the following section is inserted in lieu thereof, and which said Section 8, from and after the approval of this Act, shall read as follows:

Section 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the ordinary, as chairman of said board, shall receive a salary of seventy-five ($75.00) dollars per month for his services or duties as chairman of said advisory board of roads and revenues, to be paid monthly out of the proper fund. The compensation herein provided shall be in lieu of any further compensation to the said ordinary for his services as such chairman, and shall be in lieu of all clerk hire and office rent, both of which the said ordinary, as chairman of said advisory board, is to furnish at his own expense. Said advisory board shall each receive the sum
of two hundred ($200.00) dollars per annum, to be paid monthly out of the county funds. Salary of ordinary, as chairman of advisory board.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the words compensation for such clerk shall not exceed one hundred and fifty ($150.00) dollars per annum to be paid monthly out of the proper fund of Lamar County, appearing in Section 7 of said Act approved August 6,1927, be and the same are hereby stricken, and the following words are inserted in lieu thereof: The compensation for such clerk shall not exceed one hundred and fifty ($150.00) dollars per annum, to be paid monthly by the ordinary as chairman of said board from his own funds and at his own expense. Said section, after being so amended, shall read as follows:

Section 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said ordinary and advisory board shall have power to select a clerk for said board if in their judgment they need it; either one of advisors of the ordinary can act as clerk. The compensation for such clerk shall not exceed one hundred and fifty ($150.00) dollars per annum, to be paid monthly by the ordinary as chairman of said board from his own funds and at his own expense. It shall be the duty of the clerk of said board to keep a book of inventory of all county property, including road machinery, live stock, machinery, road-work tools, and every other kind and class. Said board may discharge said clerk at any time and elect a successor. Pay of clerk.

Sec. 3. If any section or part of any section of this Act shall be held invalid, such invalidity shall not be construed to affect the validity of any other portion of this Act. Invalidity of part of Act not invalidate other part.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for Lamar County, Georgia, to provide for the election of same, to define their powers and duties; to provide for the fixing of their compensation; to repeal an Act approved August 6, 1927, known as an Act creating an advisory board for the County of Lamar, and to provide for a referendum, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of same, that on and after the passage of this Act Lamar County shall have three commissioners of roads and revenues, comprising one chairman and two commissioners. Commissioners.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that this Act shall not become effective until January 1, 1931, and not until after a majority of the voters of Lamar County approve same at an election to be held as hereinafter provided for. Referendum.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, that a certain Act approved August 6, 1927, and known as an Act creating an advisory board for Lamar County, is hereby repelaed, subject to the ratification of this Act by a majority of qualified voters of Lamar County at an election to be held as hereinafter set forth. Repeal of Act creating advisory board.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the Lamar County board of commissioners hereby created shall consist of three residents who are citizens and qualified voters of said county, and who shall be elected by the qualified voters of the entire county as hereinafter provided. One of said commissioners shall be a resident of that part of Lamar County known as the Red Bone and Johnsonville Districts; one of the said commissioners shall be a resident of that part of Lamar County known as the Chapel and Milner Districts, and the other commissioner
shall be a resident of that part of Lamar County known as Barnesville and Piedmont District. Residence of commissioners.

Sec. 5. The members of the present board known as advisory board shall remain in office and perform their duties until the new board of commissioners hereby created shall be elected and qualified, when their functions are to cease. In the event that the election herein provided for should not be held, or the election should not be called in compliance with this Act, then in that event the judge of the superior court of the Flint Circuit shall appoint three commissioners to serve under the provisions of this Act. Advisory board continues until when.

Sec. 6. All elections for members of Lamar County board of commissioners under this Act shall be held at the same time and place and, under the same rules and regulations as primary and general elections, are held for members of the General Assembly of Georgia. First election hereunder shall be in 1930, at the time and place of the electin for the members of the General Assembly of Georgia. The said Lamar board of commissioners so elected shall enter upon the discharge of their duties on January 1, 1931. Election of commissioners.

Sec. 7. The first board of commissioners to be elected, or appointed, as the case may be, under this Act shall serve for the following terms of office, or until their successors are elected and qualified, to-wit: The term of one commissioner shall be until January 1, 1933, and the term of the other two commissioners shall be until January 1, 1935, said three commissioners shall determine among themselves by lot who shall serve the short term and who shall serve the long term. The term of office of said commissioners after the first board of commissioners shall be for four years. Thereafter one commissioner shall be elected at the next general election, and then two commissioners shall be elected at the next general election following. Terms of commissioners.

Sec. 8. The members of said board of county commissioners, before entering upon their duties, shall take an oath before the ordinary or the clerk of the superior court, to faithfully and honestly discharge all the duties of the
office of county commissioners, according to the laws and the constitution of the State of Georgia, which oath shall be subscribed by them and recorded upon the minutes of said board. Oath.

Sec. 9. Any vacancy in the office of commissioner shall be filled by the remaining commissioners for and during the unexpired term for which the vacancy was occasioned. In case the remaining commissioner cannot agree, the judge of the superior courts of said Flint Circuit shall appoint. Vacancy.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said board of county commissioners shall hold a regular meeting on the first Monday in every month at the court-house in said county, but they may hold special meetings at any time and place in said county that their duties may require. At the first meeting of the board one of the members shall be elected chairman, whose duties shall be to preside at all meetings and who shall retain that position during his term of office. At all meetings two members shall constitute a quorum to transact business and the concurrence of any two members of said board shall be necessary to decide all questions. It shall be the duty of the sheriff, when required, to attend the meetings of said board, for which service he shall be allowed three dollars per day. Meetings.

Sec. 11. The said county commissioners shall be paid out of the county treasury as follows: Each of the commissioners other than the chairman shall receive the sum of seven dollars per day while in the actual discharge of their duties, but such compensation shall not in any year equal more than two hundred and fifty dollars. Per diem of commissioners.

Sec. 12. The salary of the chairman of the board shall be not less than two hundred and fifty dollars and not more than seven hundred and fifty dollars, to be assessed and determined by the grand jury of the superior court of Lamar County at the last term of court in each year, and such salary so fixed and determined shall apply throughout the
ensuing year. Such salary shall be paid monthly out of the proper funds of Lamar County. Salary of chairman.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, that the said board shall have the power to select a clerk for the said board if in their judgment they need one. The compensation for such clerk shall be fixed by the board, but shall in no event be more than one hundred and fifty dollars per annum. The amount so fixed shall be paid monthly out of the proper funds of Lamar County. Said board may discharge such clerk at any time and elect a successor. Any member, including the chairman of said board, may act as clerk of the board, but in such event such member shall not receive any compensation for his services as clerk. Clerk, pay of.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said board of county commissioners shall, in their discretion, employ a superintendent of roads and bridges, who shall be selected on account of his efficiency and knowledge and skill in practical road and bridge building. He shall have charge of the laying out, building, repairing, improving, and maintaining of the public roads and bridges of the county, under the orders of the board of county commissioners. He shall receive such salary as may be fixed by said board, and his term of office shall be such as may be fixed by said board, with authority reserved to said board to discharge him at any time and employ a successor. Superintendent of roads etc.; duties, pay.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said board of county commissioners of roads and revenues shall have, and they are hereby vested with exclusive jurisdiction over the following matters: In directing and controlling and caring for all county property; in levying taxes according to law; in establishing, abolishing, altering public roads, private ways, bridges, and ferries according to law; in establishing, abolishing and changing election precincts and milita districts; in supervising the tax-collector's and tax-receiver's books and allowing the insolvent list for said county, according to law; in settling all claims against the county, examining and auditing all
claims or accounts of officers having the care, management, keeping, collecting, or disbursement or money belonging to the county, or purposed to be used by its use and benefit and bringing them to settlement, and this may be done by the commissioners, their clerk, or their designated auditor, and they may require from such officers such reports as may be necessary to keep said board of county commissioners fully informed at all times of the financial condition of the county; in making such rules, regulations, and provisions for the support of the poor of the county; in preserving and promoting the public health of the county, with authority to quarantine against contagious diseases and epidemics, as provided by law; in regulating peddling, and fixing license fees according to law; in the levying and collecting of the road taxes and in trying all road defaulters, according to law; and generally to have and exercise all the powers which are by the constitution and laws of Georgia vested in ordinaries when sitting for county purposes, and to exercise such other powers as are granted by law or as may be indispensable to their jurisdiction over county matters or county finances, including all powers not inconsistent with this Act, which have been heretofore exercised by the advisory board of roads and revenues of Lamar County under the Act approved August 6, 1927, and under all Acts amendatory thereof; in selecting and appointing all subsidiary officers and employees of the county, whose election or appointment is not otherwise provided for by law, such as superintendent and guards of convicts, county physician, health officer, tax-assessors, janitor of the courthouse, and other employees or officials as may be required or authorized by law. Said board shall have entire management and control of the convicts of said county sentenced to work upon the roads or public works of said county, and all convicts of the State assigned to work in said county by the proper authorities of the State, and shall so employ them according to law, and under such plans of working, building, repairing, and maintaining the public roads, bridges, and public works of said county, as now provided
by law, or may be hereafter adopted or enforced by law in said county. Jurisdiction of Board.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said board of county commissioners may receive contributions for the building or improvement of the public roads and bridges of the county from persons who own property along the same or from any other persons, or from the State Government or the United States Government, and such contributions received shall be used for the improvement of the roads and bridges designated by the contributor. Contributions for building roads, etc.

Sec. 17. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that it shall be unlawful for said commissioners to employ any person related within the second degree, either by blood or marriage, to any member of the said board, or contract with such person or persons for any equipment materials, or supplies to be used upon the public roads, bridges, or other public works of said county. If any commissioner knowingly or wilfully violates any provision of this section, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be punished as for a misdemeanor, as provided by the Penal Code of Georgia, and shall also forfeit his office or be discharged from employment. Unlawful employment of kin, etc., a misdemeanor; penalty.

Sec. 18. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said board may employ a competent attorney to act as attorney for said county, and shall pay for such legal services such compensation as said board, in its discretion, may deem reasonable. Attorney for county.

Sec. 19. Be it further enacted, that all supplies, equipment, and materials used by the county amounting to two hundred dollars or over shall be purchased only after notice and competitive bids received by said commissioners; the board to award same to the best and most successful bidder. The said board reserving the right of rejecting any and all bids. Whenever said commissioners deem it advisable or necessary, in their discretion, that any perishable property belonging to the county be sold, they shall sell same, after
due advertisement in the official gazette of the county, at public outcry to the highest bidder for cash before the court-house door. Purchases and sales by commissioners.

Sec. 20. Be it further enacted, that said board is required under this Act to publish monthly in the official gazette of said county a synopsis of itemized expenditures of the county, approved by said board during the preceding month, showing the amount paid out, to whom paid, and the general character of the expenditure, and the sources of same, in order that the general public may be fully informed at all times of the receipts and disbursements of the county and its financial condition. Monthly financial statement.

Sec. 21. Be it further enacted, that said board of county commissioners shall have the power to supply by appointment all vacancies in county offices, and in ordering elections to fill the same in the same manner as said powers are now given to the ordinaries of the counties. Vacancies in offices.

Sec. 22. Be it further enacted, that said board of county commissioners shall have the right to summons witnesses and to punish any and every person for contempt as the judges of the superior courts of this State now have. Contempt.

Sec. 23. Be it further enacted, that if any section of this Act shall be held invalid, such invalidity shall not be construed to affect the validity of any other portion of this Act. Invalidity of part of Act not invalidate whole.

Sec. 24. Be it further enacted, that this Act shall not become effective until approved at an election to be held in said County of Lamar as follows: The ordinary of said county is hereby required to call an election by the qualified voters of said county not earlier than sixty days, nor later than ninety days, to be held in the usual manner of holding special elections in this State in which the qualified voters in said county shall vote on the question of this Act becoming effective. Those voting for the Act to become effective shall have printed or written on their ballots the words, For New Commissioners' Bill, those voting to the contrary shall have written or printed on their ballots the
words, Against New Commissioners' Bill. The ordinary shall give notice of said election by publication in the official organ of the county of the three insertions preceding said election. The return of said election shall be consolidated as in cases of elections for members of the General Assembly, except that the returns shall be to the ordinary of said county, who shall canvass said returns and declare the results. If the majority of those voting in said election shall vote, For New Commissioners Bill, this Act shall become effective, and ordinary shall so declare. If a majority votes to the contrary, the Act shall not become effective, and the ordinary shall so declare. Referendum.
Sec. 25. All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues, and public buildings, and public property, and finances for the County of Lee; to provide that said board shall consist of three members to be elected by the grand jury of said county; to prescribe their terms of office, to prescribe their duties, rights, and powers, to fix their compensation, and for other purposes, approved August 6, 1921, and as amended in Acts of the General Assembly of Georgia of 1922, approved August 16, 1922; so as to provide that said board shall consist of five members, to be elected by the people of the county; to prescribe the districts of the members of said board; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same that an Act of the General Assembly
of the State of Georgia, approved August 6, 1921, creating a board of commissioners of roads and revenues, and public buildings, and public property, and finances for the County of Lee, and for other purposes, pages 517, 518, 519, 520 and 521 of the Acts of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia of 1921, and as amended by an Act approved August 16, 1922, pages 404, 405, 406 and 407 of the Acts of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia of 1922, be and the same is hereby amended by the repeal of section 1 of said Act as amended by the General Assembly of Georgia in 1922, and the insertion, in lieu and instead thereof, another section, to be known as section 1, and which shall read as follows: That at the general election in 1930 for the election of members of the General Assembly and officers of the State there shall be elected, by the voters of Lee County qualified to vote in said election, five (5) commissioners of roads and revenues for said county, for a term of two years, beginning their terms of office January 1st, 1931, following their election. That each one of the five militia districts in Lee County is hereby created a road district of Lee County, also, as follows: The 915th Militia District shall be known as the 1st Road District; the 938th Militia District shall be known as the 2d Road District; the 975th Militia District shall be known as the 3d Road District; and the 976th Militia District shall be known as the 4th Road District; and the 1238th Militia District shall be known as the 5th Road District, and one commissioner shall be elected by the voters of the entire county from each one of the said road districts, and that not more than one commissioner shall serve from the same road district at any one time; that the successors to the five commissioners to be elected in 1930 shall be elected in the same manner for terms of two years; provided that nothing in this Act shall affect in any way the terms of office of any commissioner of said county now or heretofore in office, that the ballot to be used in the general election in Lee County in 1930 shall have a blank line thereon, preceded by the words: For Chairman County Commissioners, and the voters voting may write on their
ballot the name of the candidate for county commissioner in said election whom they desire to be chairman of said board of roads and revenues; and the candidate for county commissioner who is elected commissioner in said election and who also receives the largest number of votes for chairman in said election shall be chairman of the board of roads and revenues herein provided. That said chairman shall devote as much time and attention to said office as is required to diligently perform the same, and shall have and maintain an office in the court-house in the City of Leesburg; he shall act as the agent of said board of roads and revenues, and as purchasing agent of said board of roads and revenues, and shall receive and be paid a salary of six hundred ($600.00) dollars per year; provided that said chairman shall at all times be under the jurisdiction of, and amenable to, the said board of roads and revenues. That the other four members of said board of roads and revenues shall each be paid a salary of sixty dollars per annum; and a clerk shall be elected by said board who shall be paid at the rate of three hundred dollars per year as his salary. That said board of commissioners shall make all purchases for the county by fair and reasonable competitive bids, so far as may be possible and for the best interest of the county, and shall not make purchases from members of the board nor their families, except when necessary; and a full and completely detailed statement of all of the expenditures of the county and all of the acts and doings of the said board of commissioners shall be published in the newspaper of the county which is its official organ, at least once every three months. Number of commissioners, 5; election terms, districts.Chairman's duties and salary.Salaries of commissioners and clerk.
Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act for the protection of fur-bearing animals in Lee County, Georgia; to make it unlawful to capture, kill, or destroy any of said fur-bearing animals by means of traps, for a duration of three years from the date of the passage of this Act; to provide penalties for violating this Act; to repeal all laws in conflict with this Act; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that it shall be unlawful for any person or persons to take, capture, kill, or destroy by means of traps, deadfalls, or other similar devices, or to set or use any traps, deadfalls, or other similar devices for the purpose of capturing, taking, killing, or destroying any of the said fur-bearing animals in Lee County, Georgia, for a duration of three years from the date of the passage of this Act by the General Assembly of Georgia. Unlawful trapping.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that the following shall be deemed fur-bearing animals: mink, otter, beaver, bear, wild cat, musk rat, skunk, racoon, opossum, and fox. Fur-bearing animals designated.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, that any person or persons who shall violate this Act shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and he shall be fined not less than $25.00 and costs of court, and not more than $200.00 and all costs of court, or sentenced to work on the chain-gang in said county for not less than thirty days or more than ninety days, or by imprisonment in the common jails of said county for not less than thirty days or not more than ninety days, either or all of said punishments in the discretion of the court. Punishment.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and they are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to make it unlawful for any live-stock dealer to buy, sell, transport, or otherwise deal in live-stock in Liberty County, Georgia, until and unless said live-stock dealer shall have previously thereto registered as a live-stock dealer as hereinafter in this Act provided, and until and unless said live-stock dealer shall have previously thereto paid the license-tax hereinafter in this Act prescribed.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act it shall be unlawful for any live-stock dealer to buy, sell, transport, or otherwise deal in live-stock in Liberty County, Georgia, until and unless said live-stock dealer shall have previously thereto registered as a live-stock dealer as hereinafter in this Act provided, and until and unless said live-stock dealer shall have previously thereto paid the license tax hereinafter in this Act prescribed. Registration as live-stock dealer.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that a live-stock dealer as contemplated by this Act shall be held and construed to mean any person, firm, or corporation who shall, either by himself, or itself, or themselves, as the case may be, or acting through an agent, buy, trade for, transport, or otherwise handle or deal in live-stock, including cattle, hogs, goats, and sheep, whether the same be in live state, carcasses, or in butchered state for the purpose of resale, regardless of the place of said resale shall be made, or contemplated. This term live-stock dealer shall also be held to include any butcher selling at wholesale or retail live-stock in butchered state, either at an established or permanent place of business, or peddling the same. Live-stock dealer defined.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that before any live-stock dealer shall do business or
offer to do business in said County of Liberty, as set forth in this Act, he, they, or it shall first register as a live-stock dealer with the clerk of the board of commissioners or board of commissioners of roads and revenues of said county. And said live-stock dealer is hereby required (and it shall be unlawful to fail or refuse to do so) to furnish to said clerk the names and addresses of any and all agents authorized to act for such dealer in said county. It shall be unlawful for any dealer to do business or offer to do business in said county before such registration as hereinbefore and hereinafter set out. Further provided, that any person who shall do business or offer to do business as a live-stock dealer in said county shall be deemed and held to be a live-stock dealer under the terms of this Act, unless such person shall have been registered as herein provided as an agent for some named live-stock dealer. Unless so registered as such agent, such person shall be subjected to the same penalties as provided herein for live-stock dealers in said county. Agents.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by authority of the same, that in addition to the registration provided for in section three hereof, said live-stock dealer, before doing business or offering to do business as a live-stock dealer as contemplated by this Act, in said County of Liberty, he, they, or it, as the case may be, shall pay to the said clerk aforesaid the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) as a license-tax to do business in said county as such live-stock dealer. This license-tax to apply to each dealer as aforesaid. Upon such registration and payment of such tax aforesaid, the said clerk aforesaid shall issue to such dealer a license to do business in said county for the term of twelve months. It being intended that payment of such tax shall authorize said dealer to do business in said county for the space and term of twelve months from such registration and payment; provided that at the end of said twelve-months period said license, and the right to conduct business thereunder, shall be null and void, and the licensee thereunder shall occupy the same status as if no such license had been
issued. Provided further that said license shall not be transferrable. License-tax.License not transferable.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted b the authority aforesaid, that the said clerk aforesaid shall keep in his office a registration book for live-stock dealers to register themselves and their agents in, and also keep on hand blank licenses to issue upon such registration and payment of the tax aforesaid. Registration book, licenses.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that it shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to do business, or offer to do business in said county as a live-stock dealer before payment of the license-tax prescribed in section four of this Act. Any original owner of live-stock may butcher his own stock and sell same to be resold as fresh meats at some fixed place of business within said county, and such person shall not be construed as being a dealer, and is exempted from provisions applying to dealers in this Act. Exemption of owner butchering or selling.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the funds derived from the sale and issuances of said licenses as aforesaid to live-stock dealers in said county shall be placed in a separate fund by the county commissioners or board of roads and revenues, or by whatever name the governing authorities of said county are known, and said funds shall be used in the enforcement of this Act, to be paid from such funds only upon order of said county governing authorities based upon approved bills. Provided, however, that if at the end of any year there remains a balance of said special fund, said county authorities shall have the right if they deem proper to transfer said balance so remaining to the common-school funds of said county. Funds from licenses, use of.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the term agent as referred to in this Act shall include any truck-driver, stock-driver, or any person, either and all, acting in any manner or capacity whatsoever
in connection with the operation of the business of a live-stock dealer as defined in this Act. Meaning of agent.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that any person, firm, or corporation butchering live-stock in said County of Liberty shall be, and they are, hereby required to exhibit to a register, in the militia district of said county where said animal is butchered, the hide of each cow, bull, steer, and calf so butchered, with the ears thereon and in undisfigured state. And each person, firm, or corporation butchering hogs in said county shall exhibit the head of the animal so butchered to such registrar, said exhibit to include the whole head with the ears in undisfigured state. And each person, firm, or corporation butchering a sheep in said county shall likewise exhibit to such register the whole head of the animal so butchered, with the ears thereon in undisfigured state and each person, firm, or corporation butchering a goat in said county shall exhibit to such registrar the whole head of such animal with the ears thereon in undisfigured state. It is hereby required that each and every live-stock dealer as defined in this Act, be and are hereby required to register with officer appointed to keep such record the mark, brand, and sex of each and every cow, hog, sheep, and goat shipped or moved from said county. Provided, however, that butchers who have fixed and permanent places of business for the sale of butchered meats shall have the privilege of exhibiting said hides or heads, as the case may be, to a registrar of the militia district of the county in which said places of business are located; this proviso to apply only to such permanent or fixed places of business located in said county. And it shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation so butchering said animals, or any of them, to fail or refuse to exhibit said hides and heads, as the case may be, to the registrar as aforesaid within twenty-four hours after the butchering of any of the said animals aforesaid. Exhibition of head, etc., of butchered animal; and registration.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by authority of the said General Assembly of Georgia, that the judge of the superior court of the Atlantic judicial circuit of Georgia shall appoint
and maintain in office at least one registrar for each militia district of said County of Liberty, whose duty it shall be to register the earmarks, flesh-marks, color, sex, size, and approximate age of the animal killed, as appears from the hides and heads, as the case may be, so exhibited to said registrar. The person, firm, or corporation exhibiting and having registered any such hides and heads, as the case may be, as provided in section nine hereof, shall be required to pay to said registrar the following fees for registering the same, to wit: For cow, bull, steer, yearling and calf hides the sum of twenty-five cents each such hide; for each hog head, sheep head and goat head the sum of fifteen cents. Provided, however, the said superior-court judge shall have the authority to appoint more than one registrar in any or all of the militia districts of said county. Said registrars shall be appointed for a term of two years each and until their successors are appointed and qualified. Said registrars may be removed by said judge with or without cause at any time, and their successors appointed. It shall be unlawful for any registrar to fail or refuse to register any hide or head, as the case may be, exhibited as provided therein. Each of said registrars shall keep a permanent record of all such hides and heads so registered, which record shall at all times be open to public inspection by any citizen of Georgia applying for such privilege, and it shall be unlawful for any registrar to fail or refuse to keep such record, and to fail or refuse to exhibit the same to any citizen of Georgia applying for the privilege of such inspection. And it shall be the duty of said superior-court judge to file with the clerk of the superior court of said county a list of the registrars appointed by him from time to time, which lists shall be kept on file in said clerk's office open to public inspection. Registrars; appointment, terms, fees, duties.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by authority of the same, the said General Assembly of Georgia, that it shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to drive, haul with trucks, wagons, or carts, or otherwise transport live-stock, either dead or living, or move the same, in,
through, or across said County of Liberty between sunset and sunrise, which period is hereby declared to be nighttime as contemplated by this Act. Nighttime moving of live-stock unlawful.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the provisions of this Act with reference to registration of hides and heads and the payment of fees therefor shall not apply to the owners of such animals so butchered if the meats from such animals so butchered be not offered for sale, or sold; otherwise said provisions shall apply to said owners of such animals. Act not applicable where meat is not sold or offered for sale.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that any person, firm, or corporation violating any of the provisions of section one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven, and twelve of this Act shall, upon conviction or plea of guilt, be punished for a misdemeanor as set forth in section 1065 of the Penal Code of Georgia. In the event any person, firm, or corporation is found guilty of violating more than one provision of this Act, the presiding judge shall have the authority to impose sentence and punishment for each violation, which said punishments may run concurrently, or consecutively, in the discretion of said judge. Punishment.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the aforesaid authority, that in the event any portion or provision of this Act shall be held to be unconstitutional for any reason, or upon any ground, that the remainder of this Act not affected by such ruling or judgment, shall be and remain of full force and effect. Invalidity of part of Act not invalidate remainder.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that any and all laws or parts of laws now of force in this State operative in said County of Liberty in conflict with any of the provisions of this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to establish a board of commissioners of roads and revenues of the Counties of Habersham and Lowndes, to define their duties and for other purposes, approved December 11, 1871, and found in the Acts of 1871 and 1872, page 227, as amended by the Act amendatory thereof, approved August 20, 1872, and found in the Act of 1872, page 425, so far as said Act relates to Lowndes County by providing that the commissioners of roads and revenues of said Lowndes County shall meet twice each month, on Wednesday after the first Monday, and on Wednesday after the third Monday, and called meetings as often as is necessary; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that an Act approved August 20, 1872, No. 301O. No. 55, on parts of pages 424 and 425, Georgia Laws 1872, be and the same is hereby amended in so far as the same relates to Lowndes County, Georgia, by striking therefrom all of the words embraced between the figure 2 of section 1, on page 425, and the figure 3 of said section on said page, and inserting in lieu thereof the words: The commissioners of roads and revenues for Lowndes County shall meet twice each month, to wit, on Wednesday after the first Monday, and on Wednesday after the third Monday in each month. They may adjourn from time to time, hold such special terms, and have such call meetings as in their discretion may be necessary for the transaction of the business of said county, and have authority to fix the time and place of holding all of such meetings, so that said section 1, of said Act, when amended, shall read as follows: Section 1. The General Assembly of the State of Georgia do enact, that the above-recited Act be amended by adding thereto the following provisions: 1. The members of the board shall be commissioned by
the Governor. 2. The commissioners of roads and revenues for Lowndes County shall meet twice each month, to wit, on Wednesday after the first Monday, and on Wednesday after the third Monday in each month. They may adjourn from time to time, hold such special terms, and have such call meetings, as in their discretion may be necessary for the transaction of the business of said county, and have authority to fix the time and place of holding all of such meetings. 3. They shall have exclusive authority to grant licenses for the several purposes recited in section 564, and to exercise the powers required of the Inferior Court by section 1601 of the Revised Code. 4. The board may, in their discretion, issue an order, and post the same at the court-house, and at other public places, in their discretion, as soon as practicable after the passage of this Act, requiring holders, resident within the county, of claims of every character against the county, including jury certificates, to present the same to the board on or before its second regular term next after the date of said notice, for registration. After the notice given as above, every claim not so presented, shall be held fraudulent on its face, and shall be enforced against the county only after a favorable verdict in an issue on mandamus. Time of meeting of commissioners.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the above Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act approved August 11th, 1925, published in Georgia Laws 1925, pages 702 to 705 inclusive, by amending the later paragraph of section four (4) of said Act by adding thereto the words, the premium on said bond to be paid by the county treasurer upon
order of the county commissioners; thereby making said paragraph of said section to read as follows: Said tax-commissioner shall give bond and security in the sum and manner now provided by law for tax-collector; the surety on said bond to be a reliable bonding company; which said bond shall be filed and approved before said tax-commissioner enters upon the discharge of his duties. The premium on said bond to be paid by the county treasurer upon order of the county commissioners.

An Act to require in the County of McIntosh inoculation with serum for prevention of rabies each dog in said county, and to require the registration of each dog in said county and the payment of a registration fee; to require the sheriffs of said county to keep a registration book for the registration of dogs and fix his compensation; to require owners to provide collars for each dog registered; to provide for the disposition of any dog killing or injuring any live stock; to fix penalty for keeping a sheep-killing dog; to provide a penalty for the violation of this Act; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act each dog in McIntosh County shall be inoculated with serum for the prevention of rabies, and each dog in said county shall be taken by the owner to the county physician or some other reputable physician to be inoculated, and shall pay the cost of the inoculation, and said physician shall furnish such owner with a proper certificate showing that said dog has been inoculated. Inoculation required, owner to pay cost; certificate.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the owner of each dog in said county shall register said dog with the sheriff of the county in which he resides and pay to said sheriff a registration fee of $2.00 per year for each dog registered by him, and shall also provide for each dog registered a collar with a number plate. Registration with sheriff; fee, collar.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the sheriff of said county shall be the registrar for dogs and shall keep a book for the registration of each dog in his county, giving name of owner, color, and sex of dog, number on plate on the collar, and any other data necessary to identify such dog. Registration book; entries.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that any and all dogs in said county that have not been inoculated within 60 days after the passage of this Act, as required by this Act, and any dog not registered within said time as required by this Act, and any dog found killing or injuring any live stock, shall be destroyed by the sheriff of the county or his lawful deputy. When dogs are to be destroyed.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that any person owning or keeping any sheep-killing dog, after 10 days' notice has been given him with proof of the viciousness in that respect of such dog, the owner or keeper thereof shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as prescribed in section 1065 of the Penal Code, and shall also be liable in damages to the owner of the sheep or other live stock killed or injured. Penalty.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted that this Act shall not become law until having first been ratified by a majority of those voting at the next general election to be held in and for McIntosh County. At said election a special ballot shall be prepared in such manner as to permit those voting to correctly express their wishes either for or against this Act. Referendum.
Sec. 7. Be it further enacted that all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act requiring live-stock dealers in McIntosh County, Georgia, to register and pay a dealer's license-tax; defining the term live-stock dealer; prescribing an officer with whom said live-stock dealers shall register; providing for disposition of funds arising from license-taxes; defining the term agent as used in said Act; requiring exhibition and registration of the hide of each cow, bull, steer, yearling, and calf butchered in said county; requiring the exhibition and registration of the head of each hog, goat, and sheep butchered in said county; providing for appointment of registrars in said county and prescribing their compensation and duties; prohibiting transportation of live-stock in, through, or across said county in the night time; providing a penalty for violation of any provision of said act; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act it shall be unlawful for any live-stock dealer to buy, sell, transport, or otherwise deal in live-stock in McIntosh County, Georgia, until and unless said live-stock dealer shall have previously thereto registered as a live-stock dealer as hereinafter in this Act provided, and until and unless said live-stock dealer shall have previously thereto paid the license-tax hereinafter in this Act prescribed. Registration as live-stock dealer.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that a live-stock dealer as contemplated by this Act
shall be held and construed to mean any person, firm, or corporation who shall, either by himself, or itself, or themselves, as the case may be, or acting through an agent, buy, trade for, transport, or otherwise handle or deal in live-stock, including cattle, hogs, goats, and sheep, whether the same be in live state, carcasses, or in butchered state, for the purpose of resale, regardless of the place said resale shall be made or contemplated. This term live-stock dealer shall also be held to include any butcher selling at wholesale or retail live-stock in butchered state, either at an established or permanent place of business, or peddling the same. Live-stock dealer defined.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that before a live-stock dealer shall do business or offer to do business in said County of McIntosh, as set forth in this Act, he, they, or it shall first register as a live-stock dealer with the clerk of the board of commissioners, or board of commissioners of roads and revenues, of said county. And said live-stock dealer is hereby required (and it shall be unlawful to fail or refuse to do so) to furnish to said clerk the names and addresses of any and all agents authorized to act for such dealer in said county. It shall be unlawful for any dealer to do business, or offer to do business, in said county before such registration as hereinbefore and hereinafter set out. Further provided, that any person who shall do business, or offer to do business as a live-stock dealer in said county shall be deemed and held to be a live-stock dealer under the terms of this Act, unless such person shall have been registered as herein provided as an agent for some named live-stock dealer. Unless so registered as such agent, such person shall be subjected to the same penalties as provided herein for live-stock dealers in said county. Agents.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by authority of the same, that in addition to the registration provided for in section three hereof, said live-stock dealer, before doing business or offering to do business as a live-stock dealer as contemplated by this Act, in said County of McIntosh, he, they, or it, as the case may be, shall pay to the said clerk
aforesaid the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) as a license-tax to do business in said county as such live-stock dealer. This license-tax to apply to each dealer as aforesaid. Upon such registration and payment of such tax aforesaid, the said clerk aforesaid shall issue to such dealer a license to do business in said county for the term of twelve months, it being intended that payment of such tax shall authorize said dealer to do business in said county for the space and term of twelve months from such registration and payment. Provided, that at the end of said twelve months period said license, and the right to conduct business thereunder, shall be null and void, and the licensee thereunder shall occupy the same status as if no such license had been issued. Provided further that said license shall not be transferable. License-tax.License not transferable.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said clerk aforesaid shall keep in his office a registration book for live-stock dealers to register themselves and their agents in, and shall also keep on hand blank licenses to issue upon such registration and payment of the tax aforesaid. Registration book, licenses.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that it shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to do business, or offer to do business, in said county as a live-stock dealer before payment of the license-tax prescribed in section four of this Act. Payment of tax required before doing business.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the funds derived from the sale and issuances of said licenses as aforesaid to live-stock dealers in said county shall be placed in a separate fund by the county commissioners, or board of roads and revenues, or by whatever name the governing authorities of said county are known, and said funds shall be used in the enforcement of this Act to be paid from such funds only upon order of said county governing authorities based upon approved bills. Provided, however, that if at the end of any year there remains a balance in said special fund, said county authorities shall have the right, if they deem proper, to transfer
said balance so remaining to the common-school funds of said county. Funds from use of licenses

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the term agent as referred to in this Act shall include any truck-driver, stock-driver, or any person, either and all, acting in any manner or capacity whatsoever in connection with the operation of the business of a live-stock dealer as defined in this Act. Meaning of agent.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that any person, firm, or corporation butchering live-stock in said County of McIntosh shall be and they are hereby required to exhibit to a registrar, in the militia district of said county where said animals is butchered, the hide of each cow, bull, steer, and calf so butchered, with the ears thereon and in undisfigured state. And each person, firm, or corporation butchering a hog in said county shall exhibit the head of the animal so butchered to such registrar, said exhibit to include the whole head, with the ears in undisfigured state. And each person, firm, or corporation butchering a sheep in said county shall likewise exhibit to such registrar the whole head of the animal so butchered, with the ears thereon in undisfigured state. And each person, firm, or corporation butchering a goat in said county shall exhibit to such registrar the whole head of such animal, with the ears thereon in undisfigured state. Provided, however, that butchers who have fixed and permanent places of business for the sale of butchered meats shall have the privilege of exhibiting said hides, or heads, as the case may be, to a registrar of the militia district of the county in which said places of business are located. This proviso to apply only to such permanent or fixed places of business located in said county. And it shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation so butchering said animals, or any of them, to fail or refuse to exhibit said hides and heads, as the case may be, to the registrar as aforesaid within twenty-four hours after the butchering of any of said animals aforesaid. It shall be unlawful for any person,
firm, or corporation to have or transfer in any manner any of the animals named in this Act from a point in said county to another point, either within or without said county, unless and until such person, firm, or corporation shall register the marks, brands, sex, and number of animals so transported with one of the registrars appointed under the authority of this Act, whether such animals are transported alive or not; and the registrar shall receive the same compensation and in the same manner as when said animals are butchered. Exhibition of head, etc., of butchered animal; and registration.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by authority of the said General Assembly of Georgia, that the judge of the superior courts of the Atlantic Judicial Circuit of Georgia shall appoint and maintain in office at least one registrar for each militia district of said County of McIntosh, whose duty it shall be to register the earmarks, fleshmarks, color, sex, size and approximate age of the animal killed, as appears from the hides and heads, as the case may be, so exhibited to said registrar. The person, firm, or corporation exhibiting and having registered any such hides and heads, as the case may be, as provided in section nine hereof shall be required to pay to said registrar the following fees for registering the same, to wit: For cow, bull, steer, yearling, and calf hides the sum of twenty-five cents each such hide; for each hog head, sheep head and goat head the sum of fifteen cents. Provided, however, the said superior-court judge shall have the authority to appoint more than one registrar in any or all of the militia districts of said county. Said registrars shall be appointed for a term of two years each and until their successors are appointed and qualified. Said registrars may be removed by said judge, with or without cause, at any time, and their successors appointed. It shall be unlawful for any registrar to fail or refuse to register any hide or head, as the case may be, exhibited as provided herein. Each of said registrars shall keep a permanent record of all of such hides and heads so registered, which record shall at all times be open to public inspection by any citizen of Georgia applying for such privilege, and
it shall be unlawful for any registrar to fail or refuse to keep such record, and to fail or refuse to exhibit the same to any citizen of Georgia applying for the privilege of such inspection. And it shall be the duty of said superior-court judge to file with the clerk of the superior court of said county a list of the registrars appointed by him from time to time, which lists shall be kept on file in said clerk's office, open to public inspection. Registrars; appointment terms, fees, duties.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by authority of the same, the said General Assembly of Georgia, that it shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to drive, haul with trucks, wagons, or carts, or otherwise transport livestock, either dead or living, or move the same in, through, or across said County of McIntosh between sunset and sunrise, which period is hereby declared to be nighttime as contemplated by this Act. Nighttime moving of live-stock unlawful.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the provisions of this Act with reference to registration of hides and heads and the payment of fees therefor shall not apply to the owners if such animals so butchered be not offered for sale, or sold; otherwise said provisions shall apply to said owners of such animals. Act not applicable when meat is not sold.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that any person, firm, or corporation violating any of the provisions of sections one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven, and twelve of this Act shall upon conviction or plea of guilt be punished for a misdemeanor, as set forth in section 1065 of the Penal Code of Georgia. In the event any person, firm, or corporation is found guilty of violating more than one provision of this Act, the presiding judge shall have the authority to impose sentence and punishment for each violation, which said punishments may run concurrently or consecutively, in the discretion of said judge. Punishment.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the aforesaid authority, that in the event any portion or provision of this Act shall be held to be unconstitutional for any reason or
upon any ground, that the remainder of this Act not affected by such ruling or judgement shall be and remain of full force and effect. Invalidity of part of Act not invalidate remainder.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that any and all laws or parts of laws now of force in this State, operative in said County of McIntosh, in conflict with any of the provisions of this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues in the County of Miller, and for other purposes, approved August 22, 1905, by striking from section 10 thereof the word Tuesday and inserting in lieu thereof the word Wednesday, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that section 10 of the Act of the General Assembly entitled An Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues in the County of Miller, and for other purposes, approved August 22, 1905, be and the same is hereby amended by striking from section 10 thereof the word Tuesday and inserting in lieu thereof the word Wednesday, so that said section as amended will read as follows:

blockquote.p:
Sec. 10. Be it further enacted that said commissioners shall hold their meetings upon the first Wednesday in each month and shall keep a record of all their proceedings in a well-bound book to be purchased by them for that purpose, and shall be paid for by the county treasurer on their order, which record shall be submitted by them to the grand
jury of the superior court at each term of said superior court. Said commissioners may hold special sessions in addition to their regular monthly meetings whenever the interests of the county demand it. Times of board meetings.

law.p: Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the Act approved August 22, 1905, and found in the Georgia Laws for that year, pages 569-72 inclusive, which Act was entitled An Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the County of Miller, and for other purposes, so as to provide for the election of the county commissioners in each militia district in said County of Miller, and for other puposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act that the aforesaid Act approved August 22, 1905, creating the board of commissioners of roads and revenues in and for the County of Miller be and the same are hereby amended by adding another section to said Act, to be known as section 2(b) and to read thus: That at the next regular election after the passage of this Act that each of the militia districts in said county shall elect members of the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Miller County by the qualified voters of each militia district, and the person or persons so elected shall hold their offices as now prescribed by law until their successors are elected and qualified. Election in each district.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: MILLER COUNTY COMMISSIONERS; REFERENDUM AS TO REPEAL OF ACT.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal An Act to amend an Act approved August 22, 1905, and entitled an Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues in the County of Miller and for other purposes, and an Act amendatory thereof, approved August 7, 1912, so as to provide for the election of members of said board, and to fix the pay thereof, and to provide for the election of the clerk of said board and to fix the salary of same; and for other purposes, approved July 20, 1927; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of same, that the foregoing entitled Act approved July 20, 1927, embraced in the Georgia Laws for the year 1927, pages 630-32 inclusive, be and the same is hereby repealed. Repeal of Act of 1927.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted, that it shall be the duty of the ordinary of Miller County, Georgia, immediately upon the passage of this Act, to call an election at all the voting precincts in said county and submit to the qualified voters of the said County of Miller the question as to whether or not the Act approved July 20th, 1927, and embodied in the Georgia Laws for that year, pages 630 to 632, inclusive,
shall be repealed, and it shall further be the duty of the ordinary of said County of Miller to appoint the election managers and the clerks to hold the election herein provided for, and the ordinary of Miller County shall have tickets printed for said election and furnish them to the managers, and those who want the Act of 1927 which was approved July 20th, 1927, and found in the Georgia Laws of that year, pages 630 to 632, inclusive, repealed shall have printed on their ballots the words For repeal of Act of 1927, and the following words shall be printed under those words, namely: That means that you will not have to pay the $50.00 to the ordinary. And there shall be printed on the ballots the following words, Provided if you desire to pay the $50 a month to the ordinary, to wit: Against repeal of Act of 1927, and there shall be printed on this ballot just under those words the following: That means that you are to continue to pay the $50.00 a month to the ordinary. And be it further provided that the managers of said election which are appointed by the ordinary shall make their returns to the ordinary on the following day after the election, and it shall be the duty of the ordinary to declare the result of said election, and in his declaration of the result give the number of votes for the repeal of the Act of 1927, and the number of votes that were against the repeal of Act of 1927. And if there were more votes cast for the Act for 1927 to be repealed than there were for it not to be repealed, then it stands repealed. And provided further that in case the ordinary does not call and have held the election herein provided for prior to the 15th of September, 1929, then and in that event the Act of 1927 referred to in House Bill No. 243, and approved July 20th, (See Georgia Laws of that year, pages 630 to 632, inclusive), stands repealed. Provided further that the provisions of this Act shall in no event go into effect until January 1st, 1930, regardless of how the election comes out. Referendum.

law.fulltitle: An Act to create the County of Monroe, State of Georgia, as a whole and independent school or tax district, authorizing the levy of a tax of not more than $3.00 per thousand, in addition to the constitutional provisions of $5.00 per thousand on all property of said county, including the levy of said property as assessed by the tax equalizers of said county and the comptroller-general of this State, the tax to be levied on recommendation of the board of education of said county with and by the unanimous consent and approval of the county commissioners of roads and revenues of said county for educational purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the County of Monroe, State of Georgia, is hereby created an independent school or tax district, and as such is authorized to levy a tax of not more than $3.00 per thousand in addition to the constitutional provisions of $5.00 per thousand, on all property of said county, including the levy of said property as assessed by the tax equalizers of said county and the comptroller-general of this State, the tax to be levied on recommendation of the board of education of said county with and by the unanimous consent and approval of the county commissioners of roads and revenues of said county, for educational purposes. Tax rate.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that all Acts or parts of Acts in conflict herewith be and they are hereby repealed.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that this Act shall take effect from date of its approval by the Governor.

law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act approved August 12, 1921, and as amended August 6th, 1924, creating a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the County of Murray, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that an Act approved August 12th, 1921, creating a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the County of Murray, and the amendment thereto, approved August 6th, 1924, be and the same is hereby repealed. Repeal of Act creating board.

law.fulltitle: An Act to create the office of commissioner of roads and revenues for the County of Murray, to consist of one man; to provide for his appointment and election; to prescribe his term of office; to fix his salary, provide that he shall give bond; define his powers and duties, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that there is hereby created the office of commissioner of roads and revenues, for the County of Murray, to consist of one member, said first commissioner to be J. W. Harris, who shall hold office until the first day of January, 1933, and until his successor is elected and qualified.
