At the February term, 1933, of Murray superior court a comisioner shall be elected by a two-thirds vote of the grand jury, and in like manner a commissioner shall be elected each two years thereafter, for a term of two years. His
term of office to begin immediately thereafter, upon his qualifying and making bond, as hereinafter required by this Act. The election of such commissioner shall be certified by the clerk of the superior court of Murray County to the Governor, who shall issue a commission to such commissioner. Should a vacancy occur in the office of commissioner by death, resignation or otherwise, the ordinary of Murray County shall appoint a successor to such commissioner, who shall possess the qualifications hereinafter required of the commissioner; who shall hold office until the following February term of Murray superior court, at which time a successor shall be elected to serve out the unexpired term. Office created.Election, term, bond.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the commissioner shall have full power and authority over county matters, such as were formerly exercised by the inferior courts of this State, and shall include: Commissioner's powers and duties.
1. He shall levy all taxes for whatever purpose in said county.
2. He shall have exclusive jurisdiction in directing and controlling the property of the county.
3. He shall have exclusive jurisdiction in establishing and changing election precincts and militia districts.
4. He shall have exclusive jurisdiction in establishing, altering or abolishing all roads, bridges and ferries in said county, as provided by law.
5. He shall fix the commutation tax to be paid in lieu of road work in said county, as provided by the road laws now in effect, and shall have authority to try all road defaulters.

6. He shall make rules and regulations for the care and support of the poor of the county, for county police, for the promotion of health and quarantine, as granted by law or not inconsistent therewith.
7. He shall have exclusive and full authority in examining, settling, and allowing all claims against the county.

8. He shall pay out the funds of the county, upon proper vouchers drawn against the proper funds of the county, derived from taxes levied and any other source, and for the purposes levied and no other.
9. He shall have authority to employ a competent attorney, as county attorney, and provide for his compensation.
10. He shall have authority and may establish, equip and maintain a chain-gang in said county.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the commissioner shall select some solvent bank in said county, as depository of county funds, which said depository so selected shall receive all funds of the county, and disburse the same only on vouchers signed by the commissioner; except it may pay jury script and court bailiff's hire, issued by the clerk of the superior court of said county, and orders drawn by the judge of the superior court. Such depository so selected shall keep a record of all funds of the county and make report thereof once a month to the commissioner, free of charge to the county.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the commissioner shall appoint a competent clerk, who shall hold office during the pleasure of the commissioner; who shall be able to and shall keep all the necessary records of the commissioner. Said clerk shall receive such salary as may be fixed by the commissioner, but not to exceed fifty ($50.00) dollars per month, to be paid monthly from funds of the county. Clerk, pay of.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the books and records of the commissioner shall be so kept that the financial condition of the county may be ascertained at any time and a balance shall be brought forward monthly; which condition of the affairs of the county
shall be laid before the grand jury at each regular term of Murray superior court. Records, how kept.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the commissioner shall have the books of all officers of the county audited once in each year, between the first day of January and the meeting of the grand jury at the February term of Murray superior court; the audit to be made by a competent accountant of Georgia, and who shall be paid not exceeding ten dollars per day, and no audit to exceed the amount of two hundred dollars. Auditing, pay for.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that, to be eligible to hold the office of commissioner under this Act, he shall be not less than thirty years of age, and must have been a bona fide resident of the county for two years or more, must be a freeholder and of good moral character, and shall be experienced in matters of finance. He shall not hold any other office during his term of such commissioner, nor engage in any business that will interfere with his duties; and should it for any reason become necessary for him at any time, to have leave from his office and duties, he shall appoint a competent man, possessing the qualifications herein named, who shall act in his stead and shall be paid out of the salary of the commissioner, the commissioner to be held responsible for his acts. Qualifications of commissioner.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the commissioner shall not buy, contract for, or otherwise obligate the county for the expenditure of any sum for any purpose, whereby a debt or obligation is created against the county in excess of the sum of ten thousand dollars, in any one year in excess of the revenue levied for any purpose during that year. Limit of expenditures.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the commissioner shall keep an office at the courthouse, and shall meet on the first Monday in each month for transacting the general county business, and he shall meet on such other days during the month as he may fix. He shall give his entire time to the duties of his office,
and shall be paid out of county funds the sum of eighteen hundred ($1800.00) dollars per year, to be paid monthly. And the commissioner shall, before entering upon the discharge of his duties, take and subscribe to an oath before the ordinary of the county, for the faithful discharge of his duties as required herein, and shall enter into a bond in the sum of twenty-five thousand dollars, with some surety company doing business in Georgia; the premium to be paid out of county funds. Said bond shall be payable to the ordinary and his successors in office for the use of Murray County, conditioned for the faithful discharge of the duties of such commissioner and the faithful accounting for all property and funds coming into his hands by virtue of his office. Meetings.Salary of commissioner.Bond.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that this Act shall become effective immediately upon its passage and approval, and shall supersede all other laws in reference to the control of county matters in the County of Murray, and should any part thereof be declared unconstitutional, it shall not affect the remainder of this Act. Invalidity of part of Act not invalidate other part.
Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to create a board of county commissioners of roads and revenues of the County of Oconee; to provide for the members thereof, for their removal from office; to provide for their compensation, and for other purposes, approved August 18, 1917, as amended by Act approved August 19, 1919.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that section 2 of an Act entitled an Act to amend an Act to create a board of county commissioners of roads and revenues of the County of Oconee be amended by striking from said section line five of same, the words and figures one thousand five hundred ($1,500.00), and by adding to said section the following words and figures: two thousand ($2,000.00). Increase of salary.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the County of Peach; to provide for the election of the members of said board; to provide for the compensation of the members of said board; to define the powers and duties of said board; to provide for a clerk of said board; to provide for the compensation of said clerk of the board; to define the duties of said clerk; to provide for the election by said board of an attorney for said board, and his compensation; to provide for the filling of vacancies of said board; to provide for the term of office of the members of said board; to provide for the election by the board of a superintendent of roads and bridges, who shall be in sole charge of the building, construction, and repair of the roads and bridges of Peach County, subject to the direction and control of the board as represented by its orders issued at regular or call meetings of such board; to provide for the compensation of such superintendent, and to prescribe his duties, if elected
or employed; to provide for the abolishing and consolidating of any office or offices where such abolition or consolidation is within the discretion of the county authorities to do so under the law; to prescribe the jurisdiction of said board; to provide the method of election of the members of the board; to prescribe a date when the provisions of this bill shall become effective; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the County of Peach, in said State, is hereby created to consist of five (5) members, who shall be freeholders, qualified voters of said county, and a resident of said county for a period of two (2) years or more. Board created.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the purpose of this Act the said County of Peach shall be divided into five (5) road districts, to be constituted as follows, to wit: Road District No. 1, No. 2, No. 3, No. 4, No. 5. Road districts.
Road District No. 1 to embrace the 1813th G. M. District, composed of the City of Fort Valley and vicinity.
Road District No. 2 to embrace the 1814th G. M. District, composed of the Town of Powersville and vicinity.
Road District No. 3 to embrace the 1815th G. M. District, composed of Myrtle and vicinity.
Road District No. 4 to embrace the 1816th G. M. District, composed of Claude and vicinity.

Road District No. 5 to embrace the 1817th G. M. District, composed of the Town of Byron and vicinity. And each of the five (5) road districts shall be entitled to one (1) commissioner residing in the jurisdiction of the district, as its representative on said board of commissioners of roads and revenues.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that on or before the ninth (9th) day of October, 1929, the ordinary shall call and order a special election for the purpose of deciding the question whether or not the said County of Peach shall have a board of commissioners as aforesaid in this Act, said election to be held in the manner that elections for county officers are now held, at which election the qualified voters of Peach County shall vote on the question of whether or not the provisions of this Act shall become operative and effective on January 1st, 1930, at which election ballots shall be used having on such ballots these words, For commissioners, and Against commissioners, also it shall be provided that the same ballots shall have printed thereon the name or names of a candidate or candidates from each district, provided said candidate or candidates qualify according to the laws governing elections of this the State of Georgia. Referendum.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said commissioners shall be elected by the qualified voters of the entire county, but one (1) of the said commissioners shall be a resident of and be elected from each road district being thus represented on the board by a resident respectively. The resident of a road district receiving the highest number of votes cast in the entire county shall be declared elected to represent his district, provided a majority of the voters vote For commissioners, and then if a majority of votes cast at said special election, the returns of which shall be consolidated at noon on the day after such election in the office of the ordinary of Peach County, Georgia, and the results of such election then and there declared by said ordinary shall be For commissioners, then in that event the ordinary shall declare that the provisions of this Act shall become operative and effective as aforesaid in this Act on January 1st, 1930. If on the other hand the results of said election by which the majority of the voters of the county vote Against commissioners, then in this event the ordinary shall declare that the provisions of this Act shall be void and of no effect. Election of commissioners.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that at any time the commissioners shall create a new militia district they shall have authority, by a majority vote of their board, to attach said new militia district to any one of the five (5) districts. New militia district.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the members of the board of commissioners shall be exempt from all jury duties during their term of office. Commissioners exempt from jury duty.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said commissioners elected on or before the ninth (9th) day of October, 1929, shall go into office on the first (1st) day of January, 1930, and shall serve for a term of three (3) years, and their successors shall be elected regularly in the November (general) election for terms of four (4) years each, and that all commissioners thus elected shall serve until their successors are elected and qualified. Terms of office.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the present ordinary who is county manager also of roads and revenues of Peach County, Georgia, elected under an Act of 1924, is hereby required to turn over all books, papers, and other documents pertaining to the said office of county manager for Peach County, Georgia, immediately upon the election and qualification of the commissioners of roads and revenues of Peach County, Georgia. Transfer of records.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that should a vacancy from death, resignation, removal from county or otherwise occur on said board of commissioners, the same shall be filled by appointment by the senior judge (if there be more than one judge in this circuit) of the superior court of Peach County, until the first day of January after the general election held next after the expiration of thirty (30) days from the time such vacancy occurs, at which election a successor for the unexpired term shall be elected. The qualification of such appointee by said senior judge (provided there be two or more judges in this circuit) shall be the same as those of his predecessors as to residence and otherwise. Vacancies.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that each commissioner, before entering upon his duties, shall give bonds in the sum of two thousand ($2,000.00) dollars each, to be signed by a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Georgia, payable to the ordinary of Peach County, Georgia, and his successors in office, and shall take and subscribe to an oath before a judge of the superior court of said county to well and faithfully perform his duties as such commissioner under this Act, and the said bonds shall be filed with the ordinary and recorded upon his minutes, and the fee for suretyship on said bonds, as well as the bond of the clerk hereinafter referred to, shall be paid out of the general funds of Peach County as other expenses of county government are paid. Said bond shall be for the faithful performance of the duties of the office, and may be sued on by the ordinary on his own motion or by direction of the grand jury, and any commissioner and his sureties shall be liable for any breach thereof by way of malfeasance in office or for any neglect of duty. Bond of commissioner.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said commissioners shall hold at least one (1) session on the first Tuesday in each month at the county site in the county court-house, in the office of the ordinary (who is also clerk of the board) or where the clerk of said commissioners shall keep a regular office. At and on the first Tuesday, January, 1930, or as soon thereafter as practical, the board of commissioners shall organize by electing one of the members as a chairman, one as a vice-chairman, the said chairman shall preside during the entire time of said board, and nothing herein shall prevent the re-election of any chairman or vice-chairman at the expiration of his or their term, provided he or they be re-elected to the membership of the board. The vice-chairman, shall, in the absence or disqualification of the chairman or during the vacancy in the office of chairman, perform and discharge all the duties of chairman; and in the event of a vacancy in the office of chairman or vice-chairman, the same shall
be filled by the board at its regular meeting. The chairman shall be the chief executive of the board. He shall see that all orders, resolutions, and rules of said board are faithfully filled and impartially executed and enforced, and that all officers, employees, and agents of said board faithfully discharge the duties required of them. He shall have the general supervision of the affairs of the county, acting under orders of the board, and shall have the power to convene the board in extra session upon his own motion or upon the written request of the other members of the board, and shall do so whenever the other four members make such request. Organization of board.Chairman's duties and powers.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the salaries to be received by the commissioners shall be five ($5.00) dollars per day, but no commissioner shall receive pay for more than fifty (50) days in any one (1) year, and his pay shall be for actual services rendered. At the regular meetings each commissioner shall furnish the clerk a statement of his services for the previous month, and upon approval of the board he shall be paid therefor from the county treasury in the same manner as other expenses of the county are paid. Per diem of commissioners.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that under the provisions of this Act the ordinary shall be clerk of the board of commissioners, and his salary shall be fixed by the commissioners but shall not exceed the sum of two hundred ($200.00) dollars per month, nor shall it be less than the sum of one hundred ($100.00) dollars per month; and before entering upon his duties as such clerk, shall give bond, same to be approved by the members of the board, payable to the clerk of superior court or the commissioners of roads and revenues of Peach County, Georgia, or his or their successors in office, in the sum of five thousand ($5,000.00) dollars, conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties as such clerk and to account for any and all funds, property, or effects which may come into his hands as such clerk, which bond shall be filed with the clerk of superior court of said county and
recorded on his minutes, and may be sued on in like manner as the bonds of said commissioners, and the fee for suretyship on said bond shall be paid out of the general funds of Peach County as other expenses of county government are paid (see section 9 of this Act). The board of commissioners shall cause the clerk to keep proper and accurate books of minutes, wherein shall appear all acts, orders, and proceedings of the board, and shall also cause him to keep full and accurate books of accounts, wherein shall appear in detail all orders, warrants, and other proceedings drawn by the board of commissioners on the county treasury or depository, for what purpose and on what fund; and all other orders and warrants shall be drawn as to specify the purpose and on what fund drawn. Said books and records shall be so kept as to show at all times the financial conditions of the county, and shall be open to inspection by any tax-payer or citizen of the county or any other person interested in the same. The clerk shall also keep a book of inventory of all the county property, including road machinery, live-stock, chain-gang outfits (in case the county authorities organizes a chain-gang), road-working tools, and every other kind and class of property belonging to the said County of Peach, together with a fair valuation of the same, where located, in whose custody, and in what condition, which inventory shall be carefully revised each year; and the clerk shall keep such other books and records as may be necessary, or as the board may order, and shall perform generally all and singular the acts and duties necessary to be performed by him as such clerk, and such other duties as said board of commissioners may require. Said clerk's oath shall be for the faithful performance of his duties under this Act, and shall be administered to him by the board. Clerk; salary, bond, duties.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the clerk of the board of commissioners shall be purchasing agent of the board, and shall, upon orders of the board, purchase all equipment, material, and supplies of said county, of such kind and quality and in such quantities
as he may be directed by said board of commissioners; and, whenever practical, purchases of all equipment, material, and supplies shall be by competitive bids, which bids shall be kept on file in the office of the commissioners (which is the ordinary's office also), and subject to inspection by the grand jury, or other interested taxpayers or citizens. Said clerk and chain-gang warden or the county superintendent, if one be had, shall together, on or before the 25th day of each month, prepare and file with said board a requisition for all supplies, material, equipment, etc., as near as the same can be ascertained, which will be required for the succeeding month; and, after said requisition is filed with the board, the clerk of said board shall call upon those having said material for sale to make bids, or to submit bids, for the sale of such material or such portions thereof as such person or firm might sell. All purchases made by the clerk shall be upon, written orders, and duplicate copies of said orders shall be kept on file in the office of the board of commissioners and subject to inspection of the grand jury and other interested parties. Nothing herein shall prevent the purchases being made by the board of commissioners, or by committee of said board appointed for such purposes, but written orders therefor shall be given by the clerk. All purchases shall be charged to Peach County; and before bills therefor are submitted to the board for approval, they shall be audited and payment therefor recommended by the clerk, if purchases by him, and if approved by the board of commissioners at a regular meeting thereof, said approval shall be endorsed upon said bills by the chairman and a list thereof entered upon the minutes of the board, and when this is done warrants therefor shall be regularly drawn, which warrants shall be signed by the clerk and chairman as all other warrants drawn on the treasury of the county shall be signed before payment thereof is made, except that in the absence of the chairman and while the vice-chairman is acting as chairman, said vice-chairman shall be authorized to sign warrants on the county treasury or depository. Clerk to be purchasing agent.Purchases.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said board of commissioners may at their discretion and when they deem necessary elect a superintendent of roads and bridges, to be selected on account of his skill and knowledge and efficiency in practical road-building. The superintendent may also be convict warden (in the event the board creates a chain-gang or one is created before this Act is passed), but aside from his duties as warden, if elected to that position, he shall not engage in any other business, trade, or calling during his term of service. This officer shall have charge of laying out, building, repairing, improving, and maintaining the public roads and bridges of the county under orders of the board of commissioners. He shall receive such salary as may be fixed by the board of commissioners, and his term of office shall be such as may be fixed by the board, with authority vested in the board to discharge at any time and elect or employ a successor. The superintendent or warden shall give his receipt in writing to the clerk of the board for all supplies and materials furnished to him by the board, which receipt shall be filed in the office of the board of commissioners. Superintendent of roads, etc.Not to engage in other business.Salary.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said board of commissioners shall have the power and authority to abolish and consolidate any office or offices that the General Assembly has made or shall make discretionary with the county authorities to abolish and consolidate, or if this authority vests in the grand jury, the board may recommend same to said grand jury, provided such is done for the best interest of the county and done according to law; or said board of commissioners may petition the ordinary to call a special election, so that the people may vote upon said abolition or consolidation of such office or offices, provided same is done according to law. Power to abolish or consolidate offices.

Sec. 17. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the board of commissioners shall have the books and accounts of the clerk of superior court, ordinary, tax-collector, tax-receiver, treasurer, sheriff, superintendent
of schools, and commissioners of roads and revenues audited by a certified public accountant of this State, immediately after they take charge of the affairs of the county, to cover such period as they may think advisable, and each year thereafter they must have the books and acccounts of said officers examined for the year previous. Full reports of such audits, including statements of assets and liabilities, of revenues and expenses, as such schedules may be necessary for a clear understanding of the affairs of the county, as of January 1st each year, shall be made and such audits shall be completed and furnished to the next succeeding term of the grand jury of the county. And an intelligent statement of each, showing the financial condition of the county, its receipts and disbursements, shall be published by the commissioners in the official organ of the county, if satisfactory prices therefor can be made for such publication; if not, then in some newspaper having a general circulation in the county, that the citizens and taxpayers may fully understand the financial condition of the county. Said board shall publish each month in such newspaper an itemized statement of receipts and disbursements. Auditing.Financial statements.

Sec. 18. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said board of commissioners of roads and revenues shall have, and they are hereby vested with, exclusive jurisdiction and control over the following matters, to wit: in directing, controlling, and caring for all the property of the county, according to law; in levying taxes according to law; in regulating peddling license according to law; in establishing, altering, or abolishing public roads, private ways, bridges and ferries according to law; in establishing, abolishing, or changing election precincts and militia districts according to law; in supervising the county tax-collector's or tax-commissioner's and tax-receiver's books, and in allowing the insolvent list for said county according to law; in settling all claims against the county according to law; examining and auditing all claims and accounts of officers having the care, management, keeping, collecting, or disbursement of money belonging to the county,
or appropriated for its use or benefit, and bringing them to settlement; and especially are they charged with frequently examining and auditing and checking the books of the clerk of superior court, ordinary, county treasury or depository, the tax-collector, tax-receiver, the sheriff, the superintendent of public schools, or other officers of said county through whose hands county funds may pass; and this may be done by the commissioners themselves, or through their clerk or auditor, and they may require from all such officers, subject to examination, such reports as may be necessary to keep such board of commissioners fully informed at all times of the financial condition of the county; in controlling, caring for, and managing the convicts of the county or of the disposal of said convicts to other counties according to law; in making rules, regulations, and provisions for the support of the poor of the county, according to law; in promoting and preserving the public health of the county, with authority to quarantine against contagious diseases and epidemic, according to law; in regulating and fixing licenses fees as may be provided by law; in providing for the levying and collecting of the commutation road-tax, fixing the amount to be paid in money or the number of days work to be performed in lieu thereof; in trying all road defaulters, in accordance with the law, and generally to have and exercise all powers theretofore vested in the ordinary of said county when sitting for county purposes; and to exercise such other powers as are granted by law, or as may be indispensable to the jurisdiction over county matters or county finances, in selecting and appointing all minor officials of the county, whose election or appointment is not otherwise provided for by law, such as warden, superintendent, and guards of convicts and chain-gang (should one be established), farm demonstrator, janitor of the court-house, superintendent of pauper farms, (should one be established), county physician and health officer (if necessity warrants same), tax-assessors, county policemen (discretionary) and other officers and guards as needed and authorized by law; and such board shall have authority to employ a competent attorney at law as
county attorney to advise the board and represent the county in such matters as the board of commissioners may direct, who shall be paid such salary as the board of commissioners may fix, provided such salary does not exceed the sum of twenty-five ($25.00) dollars per month, said salary to be paid out of the regular county funds of the county, with the authority of said board of commissioners to fix his term of office or to discharge him at any time; said board at any time, when in their opinion the interest of the county shall demand it, shall have the right to employ additional counsel at a price that may seem fair and reasonable. Said board shall have entire control and management of convicts of said county (in case a chain-gang be established, or other disposition of said convicts) sentenced to work upon the roads or works of said county, and all convicts of this State assigned to this county by the proper authorities of the State, and shall employ them according to law, and under such plans of working, building, repairing, and maintaining the public roads, bridges, and works of said county as may now or hereafter be adopted by law in said county. Jurisdiction and powers of commissioners.

Sec. 19. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said board of commissioners may receive contributions for the improvements of the public roads of the county from persons who own property along the same, or from any other persons, or from the State government or the United States government, who may be interested in the improvement of the roads, and such contributions when received shall be used for the improvement of the road designated by the contributor or donor, and it shall be the duty of the clerk to receive such contributions and to disburse the same as directed by the commissioners; and he shall keep a book of accounts which shall correctly show all such contributions, from whom received, and a correct disbursement of the same, to whom paid, and shall take and file receipts for all such disbursements; and for any misappropriation of any such funds he and his sureties on his bond shall be liable therefor. Contributions for improvements.

Sec. 20. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that it shall be unlawful for any member of said board or their clerk to have any financial interest in the sale or purchase of any articles to or from the county, or to receive any rebate, expense account, transportation, or other valuable consideration in connection with or through the purchase of any equipment or supplies for the county or awarding of any contract for said county, and if any commissioner or the clerk shall knowingly and wilfully violate any provision of this section, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be punished as prescribed in section 1065 of the Penal Code of Georgia, 1910, and shall forfeit his office or be discharged from employment. Unlawful interest in purchases or contracts.Penalty.

Sec. 21. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the chairman and two (2) other members of said board, or, in the absence of the chairman, the vice-chairman and two other members of the board of commissioners, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business of the board; and all votes of the board making appropriations, authorizing the expenditure of county funds, or fixing the salaries of officers, agents, or employees, shall be ayes and nays duly recorded on the minutes, and on any question or matter before the board any member may demand an eye and nay vote, and on such demand the vote shall be taken and recorded on the minutes. Quorum of board.

Sec. 22. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the clerk of the superior court shall on the first (1st) Tuesday in each month report in writing to the county commissioners a true statement of all money that has been spent by the judge or judges of the superior or inferior courts, or by the clerk of the superior court, in paying jurors or witnesses summoned or otherwise, and same shall be published accordingly as specified under section 17 of this Act. Monthly reports.

Sec. 23. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the Act approved July 18, 1924, creating the office
of county manager for the County of Peach, be and the same is hereby repealed, and that on and after January 1st, 1930, Peach County shall have a board of commissioners as prescribed in this the aforesaid Act, provided the qualified voters of said Peach County ratify this Act in a special election to be called on October 9, 1929. Repeal of Act of 1924.Election as to ratification.

Sec. 24. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the ordinary shall be clerk of the board of commissioners, but in case the present ordinary (who is also county manager) refuses or declines to act as clerk to the board, then in this event the board of commissioners shall have the power and authority to elect a clerk, and his duties shall be the same as prescribed in section 13 of this Act. The compensation of the clerk shall be the same as prescribed in section 13 of this Act. Said commissioners may discharge said clerk at any time they see fit and elect a successor, but hereafter the successor of the present ordinary shall be clerk of the board whether appointed or elected, whatever the case may be. Clerk of board.
Sec. 25. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal section one of an Act approved August 15th, 1922, to be found in Georgia Laws of 1922, page 414, said section one providing for the recall of the commissioner of roads and revenues of Pulaski County; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that section one of an Act approved August 15th, 1922, to
be found in Georgia Laws 1922, page 414, providing for the recall of the commissioner of roads and revenues of Pulaski County, be and the same is hereby repealed. Repeal of Act as to recall of commissioners.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act of the General Assembly approved August 19th, 1919, as shown by Georgia Laws of 1919, at pages 736 to 741, so as to increase the number of county commissioners of Quitman County, Georgia, from three to four, to provide that there shall be one commissioner from each of the militia districts of said county, that said commissioners shall not meet more than twice in one month, that their compensation shall not be more than three dollars per day, that the bond of said commissioners shall be fixed at five hundred dollars each, and that the premiums on said bond are to be paid from the county funds and that the present board of county commissioners of said county shall hold office until the first day of January, 1931, and their successors to be elected at the general election to be held in November, 1930, and be installed into office on the first day of January, 1931, and to provide for a successor in case of a vacancy.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that an Act entitled An Act to amend an Act to create a board of county commissioners of roads and revenues for the County of Quitman and Acts amendatory thereof, said Act approved February 22, 1873, to provide
for compensation, term of office, and election of said commissioners by the qualified voters of the county, to provide a clerk for said board, his compensation and duties, and for other purposes and the Acts amendatory thereof, be and the same are hereby amended as follows:

Sec. 2. That section two of said Act be stricken and the following section, to be known as section two, be enacted in lieu thereof: There shall be elected by the qualified voters of said County of Quitman at the general election to be held in and for said county on Tuesday after the first Monday in November, 1930, four county commissioners of roads and revenues, and each militia district of said county shall have representation on said board, there being four militia districts, and all of said militia districts shall each have a member of said board, and the said commissioners' term of office shall be for two years, and they shall take the oath of office before the ordinary of said county and be installed into office on the first day of January, 1931. Election of commissioners, term of office, oath.

Sec. 3. Section five of said Act is stricken and another section, numbered five, shall be inserted, as follows: Said commissioners shall not meet more than twice in any one month, and their compensation shall be not more than three dollars per day. Meetings, per diem.

Sec. 4. Section nine of said Act is hereby re-enacted and there is added to said section nine the following: In the event of the death, resignation, or any vacancy on said board, then and in that event the remaining members of said board are hereby empowered to select a member to fill said vacancy, provided that said member so selected shall reside in the same militia district as the member who has resigned, died, or whose place on said board is being filled. Vacancies.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: RABUN COUNTY DISTRICTS EXEMPT FROM FENCE LAW.
law.fulltitle: An Act to exempt the 587th and 556th militia districts of Rabun County, Georgia, from the operation of the provisions of section 2037, volume 1 of the Code of Georgia, in so far as relates to district line fences and gates across public roads; to authorize the impounding of trespassing stock in said districts, and their sale; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act the provisions of section 2037, volume 1 of the Code of Georgia, relating to elections in militia districts, shall not apply to either the 587th or the 556th militia districts of Rabun County, Georgia, in so far as same relates to the erection and maintenance of district line fences, and gates across public roads. C. C. 2037 not to apply to 587th or 556th militia district of Rabun County.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the passage of this Act it shall be unlawful for any stock to run at large, or trespass on any property lying, situated, and being in either of the two militia districts aforesaid; and it shall be lawful to impound, advertise, and sell any trespassing stock in said districts as now provided by law. Unlawful for stock to be at large in districts named.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: To be entitled an Act providing for the hunting and killing of cat squirrels in Rabun County, Georgia, from September 15th to January 1st.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act it shall be lawful for any person to hunt and kill cat squirrels in Rabun County, Georgia, from September 15th to January 1st, and any person who shall hunt or kill cat squirrels in said county after the 1st of January to September 15th shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as now prescribed by law. Season for squirrel hunting.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: RICHMOND BOARD OF EDUCATION; BOND ISSUE.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to authorize the county board of education of Richmond County to issue and sell one million dollars of coupon bonds, with provision for registration and reconversion into coupon bonds, the proceeds to be used in purchasing land, erecting, equipping, remodeling, and repairing buildings for public school purposes in the City of Augusta and the rural districts of Richmond County; also to levy and collect taxes for the payment of the principal and interest of said bonds and to pay and retire said bonds; also to determine the amount of such bonds to be issued and sold, the dates of issuance and of maturities
thereof, and other details; all after said proposed issue has been approved at an election to be held as provided by law, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, that the county board of education of Richmond County, the same being one of the county authorities of said county, be and it is hereby authorized to issue and sell one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) of coupon bonds, with the funds realized therefrom to be used in purchasing land, erecting, equipping, remodeling, and repairing buildings for school purposes in the City of Augusta and in the militia districts of the County of Richmond, after the said proposed issue of bonds has been approved at an election to be held as provided by law. Bond issue for schools.

Sec. 2 Be it likewise enacted, that said issue of bonds shall consist of one thousand (1,000) separate bonds of a par value of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) each, bearing interest at a rate not exceeding five per cent. (5) per annum, payable semi-annually, for which interest coupons shall be attached. Said bonds shall be divided into annual maturities in such manner as shall be provided by the county board of education of Richmond County, so that a portion of the principal amount of said bonds shall fall due each year during the life of said issue of bonds, with the least instalment of said bonds to become due and payable not more than thirty (30) years after the date of issue. The principal and interest of said bonds shall be payable in gold coin of the United States of the present standard of weight and fineness at any bank or banks in the United States designated by said board of education. Bonds described.
Sec. 3. Be it likewise enacted that before said bonds shall be issued two conditions precedent shall be complied with, to-wit:

item.p:
(1) The proposed issue of bonds must be assented to by two thirds of the qualified voters of said county voting at an election to be called for that purpose, and conducted by the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Richmond
County on the first Wednesday of November, 1929; provided said two thirds so voting shall be a majority of the registered voters and said election shall be conducted in the manner prescribed in sections 440, 441, and 442 of the Code of Georgia of 1910, as modified by any amendment thereof. Conditions precedent to issuance.Election.

(2) Provisions must be made by the county board of education of Richmond County for the assessment and collection of an annual tax sufficient to pay the principal and interest falling due each year on bonds then uttered and outstanding, in the same general manner that said board of education assesses and collects its revenues for annual tax, may be made by action of said board of education at any regular or called meeting subsequent to the date of the election at which the issuance of the bonds has been legally assented to. Tax to pay bonds and interest.

law.p: Sec. 4. Be it likewise enacted that said board of education of Richmond County shall have full power to determine all matters of detail concerning the issuing and selling of said bonds not specifically prescribed by this Act or other existing law, including the determination of what amount of said bonds shall become due each year during the life of said issue, and further including the right of said board to provide for the registration of any of said bonds after the same have been issued, and for the discharge from registration of bonds so registered, so as to reconvert the same into coupon bonds, provided that all of said bonds shall be issued and sold within a period not exceeding five years after the date of said election. Authority of board of education.
Sec. 5. Be it likewise enacted that said bonds shall be validated as provided in sections 445, 446, 447, 448, 449, 450, and 451 of the Code of Georgia of 1910. Validation of bonds.
Sec. 6. Be it likewise enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: RICHMOND BOARD OF EDUCATION; QUALIFICATIONS, TERMS, ELECTIONS, POWERS, ETC.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to regulate the public instruction in the County of Richmond, approved August 23, 1872, so as to reduce the number of members of the county board of education so that it will consist of two representatives from each ward in the City of Augusta and one representative from each militia district located wholly or in part without the limits of the City of Augusta; to prescribe the qualifications and terms of office of the members of said board of education, and the time and manner of their election; to put the control of the expenditures of all funds of the said board into the board as a whole; to provide for the method of determining the length of school terms in rural schools; to terminate the tenure of office of certain of the present members of the board of education on the second Saturday of January, 1930; to prescribe the powers and duties of said board, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it resolved by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same that the Act entitled An Act to regulate public instruction in the County of Richmond, approved August 23, 1872, be amended by striking section 1 of said Act and inserting in lieu thereof the following section, to wit:

Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, that from and after the second Saturday in January, 1930, the general interest in education in the County of Richmond shall be confided to the control and management of a board of education consisting of one legal voter, freeholder in said county of Richmond, from each militia district in the said county, as they now exist or may hereafter be created, located wholly or in part without the limits of the City of Augusta, and two legal voters, freeholders in the said county, from each ward in the City of
Augusta, as they now exist or may hereafter be created; that the terms of office of those members of the present board of education elected from the militia districts to serve until the second Saturday of January, 1931, shall expire on the second Saturday of January, 1930. There shall be no election held in November, 1929, but the office of those members whose terms expire on the second Saturday of January, 1930, will not be filled, but shall terminate with expiration of the terms of offices of those now filling them. On the first Saturday of each November immediately preceding the January in which the terms of offices of the members of the board of education as constituted by this Act shall expire, there shall be held an election to elect the successors of those whose terms thus expire, in which election the legal voters in each militia district or ward as the case may be shall elect one freeholder from their number as a member of the board of education to serve for a period of three years beginning on the second Saturday of January next succeeding the date of the said election; provided, however, that the members of the board of education elected from the wards in the City of Augusta on the first Saturday of November, 1928, shall remain in office until the second Saturday in January, 1933, but thereafter their terms of office shall be three years only, as in the case of the other districts. The purpose of this provision being such that each year the term of office of approximately one-third of the members of the board of education will expire. All members shall be eligible for reelection. Board of education; membership, terms of office.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said Act be further amended by striking out section 3 and all amendments thereof, and inserting in lieu thereof the following section, to wit:

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, that the members of the board of education shall meet on the second Saturday in January, 1930, and shall continue its organization by retaining in office the president elected for three years on the second Saturday of January, 1928, and by electing as secretary any citizen having experience and skill in the business
of education; which latter office, by virtue of such election, shall become the county school commissioner. The president and secretary shall each hold office for the space of three years from and after the day of their installation. Ten members of the board shall constitute a quorum. The board of education shall have authority to fix the number and occasion of its meetings, provided, that all meetings shall be held in the City of Augusta; and provided further, that no meeting shall be legal unless after due publication in the city papers, or after special notice from the secretary to each and every member at least three days in advance of the meeting. By a three-fourths vote the board of education shall have authority to remove any officer of the board before the expiration of his term of office, and to elect a new officer in his stead, provided that said board shall state their reasons for such dismissal to said officer, if desired by him. Should any vacancy occur on said board, by death, resignation, or otherwise, before the regular expiration of the term, the said board of education (if no election has been called within thirty days from the beginning of such vacancy by the qualified voters of such ward or district as herein provided), shall have the authority to fill such vacancy for the remainder of said term; provided, however, that if ten per cent. of the qualified voters of the ward or district in which such vacancy exists shall petition said board of education in writing to call an election to fill such vacancy on said board of education, such board of education shall order an election to fill said vacancy. Said election to fill such vacancy shall be held after thirty days' notice has been published in the official organ of Richmond County. Meetings.Quorum.Vacancies.

The board of education shall have the authority to employ and dismiss teachers or to prescribe the way in which it shall be done; to fix and regulate the salary of teachers, and the conditions of their employment, to prescribe the text-books to be used in all grades of the public schools of the county, and to make such rules, regulations, and bylaws as they deem expedient for their own government. Powers.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that section 5 of the said Act be amended by striking the third provision of said section, which reads as follows: to wit: And provided further that the expenditures by the board of the county school fund, after paying all expenses of the board at large, the remainder shall be apportioned to the several districts upon the basis of the aggregate number of youths in such districts between the ages of six and eighteen years. The quota apportioned for each school district shall be used for such purposes as may be prescribed by the local trustees for such school districts, as hereinafter provided. And insert in lieu thereof the following, to wit: And provided further that the expenditures by the board of the county school fund, that fund to be expended for education by the said board, from whatsoever sources the said fund may be derived, shall be expended under directions of the said board acting as a whole. Expenditures.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said Act be further amended by striking out section 6, and inserting in lieu thereof the following section: Section 6. There shall be no discrimination between length of the school term or compensation of teachers of the schools located without the City of Augusta and in the militia districts of the county and those located in the City of Augusta, but it is hereby provided that the schools without the limits of the City of Augusta shall have the same length of school term as the schools in the City of Augusta; provided, however, that the trustee from a militia district may in his discretion request of the county board of education that any school within his district shall have a school term shorter than that provided above, giving good and sufficient reasons therefor. Discrimination between city schools and others prohibited.Proviso as to school terms.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said Act shall be further amended by striking out section 19, and inserting therefor the following section: Section 19. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that admission to all schools of the county,
including high schools, shall be free to children, actual residents of Richmond County, but the board shall charge such sums for tuition and incidental expenses in junior college as the board from time to time shall prescribe. Tuition.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said Act shall be further amended by striking out sections 4 and 8, and that the said sections be and are hereby repealed, and also that the said Act shall be further amended by striking out the following words from section 7 of said Act, to wit: In all matters mentioned in section 8 the trustees shall be free and independent of the county board, but

blockquote.p: It shall be the duty of said trustees to manage and control the other local interests of their respective school districts, subject to the rules and regulations prescribed by the county board at large. The trustees shall not have authority to levy any tax for local expenses, but shall certify and forward all bills, claims, or accounts, pertaining to their school districts to the county commissioners for the approval of the county board. Should the local trustees in any school district fail to discharge their duties in regard to the school within their jurisdiction, it shall be the duty of the board at large to perform such duties and secure such schools the same privileges enjoyed by other schools in the county. Failure of local trustees to discharge duties.

law.p: Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said Act be further amended by omitting section 11 and inserting the following section in lieu thereof; Section 11. Be it further enacted that each member of the board shall be paid the sum of three dollars for each meeting of the board that he attends, provided that no member shall be paid more than $36.00 in any one year. The president of the board shall be paid $300.00 a year in lieu of the per diem allowed each member. Per diem of members of board. Pay of president.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the said board of education as herein constituted, and the individual members thereof in acting as trustees for their respective school districts
as provided for in said Act of 1872, entitled An Act to regulate public instruction in the County of Richmond, shall be endowed with all powers, duties, obligations, privileges, and limitations conferred upon the board of education by the said Act of 1872, and any and all Acts amendatory thereto, except as by this Act ratified. Powers of board.

This Act shall not take effect until the second Saturday of January, 1930; provided, however, that there shall be no election held in November, 1929, to elect members of the board of education as provided for under the said Act of Act of 1872. The board of education provided for in this Act shall be a continuation of the board of education of Richmond County in existence at the time of the passage of this Act, and there shall not be any termination of the corporate existence of the present board by reason of the reduction made in its membership by virtue of the provisions of this Act, and the members of the board of education holding offices at the time of the passage of this Act shall continue to hold office as members of the new board of education created by this Act until the expiration of the term of office for which they were elected except as to members whose offices are declared to be terminated in the first section of this Act. Act effective when.
Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of law in conflict herewith be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: RICHMOND BOARD OF EDUCATION; SCHOOL BOOKS.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to repeal the Act amending an Act entitled An Act to regulate public instruction in the County of Richmond, approved August 23, 1872, by adding directly at the conclusion of Section 3 thereof a proviso, and prescribing
that the county board of education shall use and adopt the same books for use in its schools as are adopted and used by the board of education of the State of Georgia, which was approved August 6, 1924, so that upon the repeal of said amending Act, the original Act of August 23, 1872, will be unaffected by the provisions of said amendatory Act of August 6, 1924, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that the Act entitled An Act to amend an Act entitled, An Act to regulate public instruction in the County of Richmond, approved August 23, 1872', by adding directly at the conclusion of Section 3 thereof a proviso, and prescribing that the county board of education shall use and adopt the same books for use in its schools as are adopted and used by the board of education of the State of Georgia, which was approved August 6, 1924, be and the same is hereby repealed, so that said original Act of August 23, 1872, shall be unaffected by said amendatory Act approved August 6, 1924. Repeal of provision as to school books.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that this Act shall become effective immediately upon its adoption and approval.Act effective immediately.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to amend an Act approved March 2, 1874, and entitled, `An Act to alter and amend Section 3 and Section 5 of an Act approved
August 23, 1872, to regulate public instruction in the County of Richmond,' by providing that the term of office of the secretary of the county board of education shall be two years beginning with the second Saturday in January, 1928, and extending to the second Saturday in January, 1930, and thereafter the term of office of the secretary of said board shall be two years, by providing that the term of office of the secretary of the county board of education shall be three years, beginning with the second Saturday in January, 1930, and thereafter the term of office of the secretary of said board shall be three years; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that Section 1 of an Act approved August 23, 1927, and entitled An Act to amend an Act approved March 2, 1874, entitled `An Act to alter and amend Section 3 and Section 5 of an Act approved August 23, 1872, to regulate public instruction in the County of Richmond', by providing that the terms of office of the secretary of the county board of education shall be two years, beginning with the second Saturday in January, 1928, and extending to the second Saturday in January, 1930, and thereafter the term of office of the secretary of said board shall be two years, be and the same is hereby amended by striking from said section the clause, And thereafter the term of said office shall be two years, where the same appears immediately after the words, January, 1930, in the thirteenth and fourteenth lines of the published Act, and inserting in lieu thereof the words, but thereafter the term of said office shall be three years, so that said section when so amended shall read as follows: Term of office of secretary of board.

Section 1. Be it enacted, etc., that from and after the passage of this Act the following words, to wit: `The president and county school commissioners shall each hold their offices for the space of three years from and after the day of their installation', in the third section of an Act entitled `An Act to regulate public instruction in the County of
Richmond', be and the same are hereby striken from said section, and the following be inserted in lieu thereof: `The president shall hold his office for the space of three years from and after the day of his installation; the county school commissioner shall hold his office for the term of one year from and after the day of his election; provided that at any time within thirty days after the approval of this Act an election shall be held for a secretary, who shall hold his office until the second Saturday in January, 1875, and until his successor is elected and qualified; and provided further, that all future elections for secretary shall be held on the second Saturday in January of each year until the second Saturday in January, 1928. From and after the second Saturday in January, 1928, the term of office of said secretary shall be for a period of two years and extending to the second Saturday in January, 1930, but thereafter the term of office shall be three years.' And an election shall be held by the board of education of said county on the second Saturday in January, 1928, for the office of such secretary, who shall hold office from the second Saturday in January, 1928, until the second Saturday in January, 1930, and until his successor is elected and qualified.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the County of Richmond, to define their powers and duties, and for other purposes, approved August 19, 1907, (Acts 1907, page 324), as amended by the Act, approved August 16,
1920, (Acts 1920, page 606), and also as amended by an Act, approved August 15, 1927 (Acts 1927, page 649), by striking from line nine of Section 1, on page 651 of Acts 1927, the word two, and inserting in lieu thereof the word twelve, and by inserting after the word annum in the same line the following words: Beginning on the first day of the month after the approval of this Act, and by striking from line thirteen of the Act approved August 15, 1927 (Acts 1927, page 652), the word fifteen and inserting in lieu thereof the words twenty-five, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act the Act of 1907 entitled An Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the County of Richmond; to define their powers and duties, and for other purposes, approved August 19, 1907 (Acts 1907, page 324), as amended by the Act, approved August 16, 1920 (Acts 1920, page 606), and also as amended by the Act, approved August 15, 1927, (Acts 1927, page 649), be amended by striking from line nine of Section 1, on page 651 of the Acts of 1927, the word two and inserting in lieu thereof the word twelve, and by inserting, after the word annum in the same line, the following words: Beginning on the first day of the month after the approval of this Act,' and by striking from line thirteen of Section 6 of the Act approved August 15, 1927 (Acts 1927, page 652), the word fifteen and inserting in lieu thereof the words twenty-five, so that said Act when amended shall read as follows:

Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that a board of commissioners of roads and revenues, to consist of five citizens, for the County of Richmond, is hereby created. The first commissioners to be chosen under this Act shall be elected at the general election to be held on the first Wednesday in October, 1908, by the
voters of Richmond County qualified to vote for county officers. The terms of the members of said board elected on the first Wednesday in October, 1908, shall commence on the twenty-fourth day of September, 1909. Three of the commissioners, one from the county and two from the county shall hold office until January 1, 1911, or until their successors are elected and qualified. Twoone from the country and one from the countyshall hold office until January 1, 1913, or until their successors are elected and qualified. The successors to three whose term will expire January 1, 1911, shall be elected on the first Wednesday in October, 1912, and at the general election every four years thereafter, and the term shall be for four years commencing January 1, 1911. The successors of the twoone from the country and one from the countywhose terms expire January 1, 1913, shall be elected on the first Wednesday in October, 1912, and be for the term of four years, commencing January 1, 1913. Of the five members of said board, two must be non-residents of the City of Augusta, and shall be voted for under the designation: For commissioners from the country. Of those thus voted for, the two receiving the largest vote, irrespective of the votes cast for the commissioners, shall be elected and shall hold office as hereinbefore provided. The other commissioners to be elected on the first Wednesday in October, 1908, shall be voted for under the designation of county commissioners. The commissioners elected shall, before entering upon the discharge of their offices, elect a chairman from among their number, to serve as such until his term as commissioner expires, and upon such an expiration his successors, from time to time, as chairman, shall be in like manner, and for a like term chosen, take an oath before the judge of the superior court to faithfully discharge their duties, and shall receive, as compensation for their services as such commissioners, the sum of twelve hundred dollars each per annum, beginning on the first day of the month after the approval of this Act. At the first meeting of the commissioners, and as soon as they have elected a chairman and taken the oath of office, they shall determine by lot
the three commissioners whose term shall expire January 1, 1911, and the two commissioners whose terms shall expire January 1, 1913. Election and terms of commissioners.Chairman.Salaries of commissioners.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that all commissioners elected for said county shall hold their offices until their successors are elected and qualified; and should a vacancy occur by death, resignation, or otherwise, the remaining commissioners shall fill such vacancy, and the person chosen to fill the same shall do so until the next succeeding biennial general election, when a successor to such commissioner shall be elected by the voters in such election, for the balance of the unexpired term. Vacancy.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, that the said board of commissioners shall exercise all the powers relative to county matters that were vested in the judge of the city court as ex-officio commissioner of roads and revenues under and by virtue of an Act to constitute the judge of the city court in the County of Richmond ex-officio commissioner of roads and revenues for Richmond County; to define his powers and duties, and for other purposes, approved September 17, 1883. Powers.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, that said commissioners shall hold one session for county purposes at the court-house on the first Tuesday in every month, and at other times as often as in their judgment the powers and duties herein conferred may require. Sessions.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, that they shall cause to be kept a book of minutes containing their acts and doings as commissioners, a complete record of the affairs of the county. Said minutes, records, and vouchers for all funds of the county disbursed shall be kept in the commissioners' office in the court-house, and subject to the inspection and examination of the grand juries at each and every term of the superior court; and they shall at the spring term of the superior court make to the grand jury thereof a full and explicit report of the condition of the affairs of the county for the year preceding, and accompany said report with a
statement of the receipts and disbursements for the year, and to furnish any information to the grand jury that they may desire concerning county matters.Records.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, that said board of commissioners shall have power and authority to elect a clerk, who shall have an office at the court-house and observe from 9:00 a. m. to 2:00 p. m., and from 3:30 to 5:00 p. m. as his office hours. Said clerk shall keep minutes of the proceedings of said board, and perform such other clerical work as the board may require. He shall have authority to administer oaths. Said clerk shall be elected for the term of two years, subject to removal at the pleasure of the board. He shall give bond in the sum of two thousand dollars, payable to said board and its successors in office, for the faithful performance of his duties as clerk. Said clerk shall receive as compensation the sum of twenty-five hundred dollars per annum, payable monthly. And shall receive no further compensation for any other services rendered the county. Clerk; duties, bond. salary.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act, and especially section 41 of An Act to establish a city court in the County of Richmond; to provide for the appointment of the judge and solicitor thereof, and to define their powers and duties, approved September 22, 1881; and An Act to constitute the judge of the city court in the County of Richmond ex-officio commissioner of roads and revenues for Richmond County; to define his powers and duties; and for other purposes, approved September 17, 1883, be and the same is hereby repealed. Laws repealed.
Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this amendment be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to amend an Act entitled `an Act to create the office of County Commissioner of Screven County,' and for other purposes, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of same, that an Act entitled An Act to amend an Act entitled `an Act to create the office of Courty Commissioner of Screven County,' and for other purposes, approved August 16, 1915, and found in Georgia Laws for 1915, commencing at page 345 and ending at page 354, be amended by striking from Section 9, commencing at line 14 of said section, with the words Be it further enacted, the entire remainder of said section and inserting in lieu thereof the following: Be it further enacted, that it shall be the duty of the commissioners to provide, keep and maintain one or more repair gangs, composed of such numbers as said commissioners deem necessary, and to employ one or more overseers, as may be necessary, at a salary to be agreed upon between the commissioners and such overseers, whose duty it shall be to look after the maintenance and repair work on all public roads, bridges, and causeways in the county. The commissioners shall provide for sufficient repair gangs, under this section, to keep said roads, bridges and causeways in reasonably good condition. Repair gangs.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that Section 6 of said Act approved August 16, 1915, be amended by striking from said section, commencing at line 4 of said section, the words that the chain-gang used in, the entire remainder of said section, and inserting in lieu thereof the following: The commissioners shall be authorized to contract with the State Highway Department of Georgia, for the construction of roads, bridges, and causeways, and may employ the chain-gang or other labor for the purpose of such construction. While not so employed,
the chain-gang shall be used in constructing, maintaining and repairing other public roads, and it is the intention of this Act that said chain-gang shall work, as nearly as practical, an equal length of time in each commissioner's district of said county, when not employed in construction of roads, bridges, and causeways, under contract with said State Highway Department. The manner, place, and time where said chain-gang shall work, shall be determined by the commissioners in their discretion. Chain-gang.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that Section 11 of said Act approved August 16, 1915, be amended by striking from said section, commencing at line 4 of said section, with the words Be it enacted by the, the entire remainder of said section and inserting in lieu thereof: Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said board of commissioners shall be the purchasing agent of said county, and it shall be unlawful for them to purchase any article, goods, wares, merchandise, or supplies, which amount in bulk to more than five hundred ($500.00) dollars, without having first advertised in the official organ of said county, for two weeks, for bids from parties desiring to furnish said supplies, merchandise, articles, goods, or wares, and the parties desiring to furnish said county shall submit their bids in writing to the commissioners of said county, which shall be directed to the clerk of said board, and shall be kept by the clerk of said board in said commissioners' office until their next regular monthly meeting, when same shall be opened in open court, and the contract for supplies, wares, merchandise, or other articles shall be let to the lowest bidder; provided that the commissioners, in their discretion, may reject all of said bids. The bids so submitted shall be filed, and kept on file and preserved as a part of the record of said commissioner's office. Provided further that no purchase shall be made for more than one hundred ($100.00) dollars and up to five hundred ($500.00) dollars, without first obtaining two or more competitive quotations, and said purchase shall be made at the lowest quotation, but said commissioners
shall have a right, in their discretion, to reject any of said offers. Such quotations as shall have been submitted shall be kept on file and preserved as a part of the records of said commissioners' office. Purchases.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to fix the compensation of the commissioners of roads and revenues of Spalding County, so as to fix the compensation of the chairman of said board not to exceed nine hundred dollars ($900.00) per annum, and the compensation of the other two commissioners not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) each. Amending Acts of General Assembly approved July 26, 1920.
law.p:
Section 1.
