Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the terms of the officers of said board shall be fixed at one year, and at their last regular meeting at the close of each year they shall elect officers for the ensuing year, and no officer shall have any compensation except such as may be fixed by the mayor and council of the City of Alma, and not to exceed the sum of twenty-five dollars per annum; provided, however, that said board shall fix the compensation of the secretary and treasurer, and the same shall be fixed prior to his election by said board, not to exceed one hundred fifty dollars per annum. Said board shall be authorized, if the necessity arises, to employ and pay any attorney a reasonable fee for services performed for said board. Terms of officers.Compensation.Attorney for board.
Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, that the schools herein established shall operate for a period of not more than ten scholastic months and not less than five, in each year. School term.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, that all school children between the ages of six and eighteen years, who are bonafide residents of said city with their parents or guardians, shall be entitled to the benefit of said schools, and no such child or children shall be required to pay tuition for such course of study as may be prescribed by the board of education. Free tuition.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the board of education of Bacon County, or such
body, as may have charge of the public schools of said county, shall not establish or open any school or schools within the corporate limits of said City of Alma, or have any authority or voice in the management of the schools herein referred to in said City of Alma, nor have any control of any school property in said City of Alma. County board not to establish school in city.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the State school superintendent of Georgia is hereby required to pay over to the board of education of the City of Alma the pro rata share of the State and county school fund to which said city is entitled, according to the number of children of school age residing within the corporate limits of the City of Alma, as shown by the last school census. The amount thus to be paid shall be paid at such time as the teachers of the county schools of Bacon are paid, and when paid shall be expended by said board for the support and maintenance of said public schools of the City of Alma. It shall be the duty of the board of education of the City of Alma to have prepared and furnish to the State school superintendent immediately, and at such times thereafter as the school census for the county or city may be taken, a list or census of all school children of school age residing within the corporate limits of said City of Alma. The board of education for the City of Alma shall have authority to admit the children of nonresidents upon such terms as to it may seem reasonable and just, also to admit the children of public-school age who reside in Bacon County but without the corporate limits of the City of Alma, upon the payment of a tuition in the sum of the estimated cost of the teaching of a child in said school for one term. Share of State and county school fund.Children of nonresidents, tuition charged for.
Sec. 16. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws, parts of laws, rules, regulations, and resolutions in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act establishing a new charter for the mayor and council of the City of Athens, approved August 24, 1872, and the several acts amendatory thereof, and for other purposes:
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the mayor and council of the City of Athens is hereby authorized and empowered to establish and change the trade of any public streets in the corporate limits of the mayor and council of the City of Athens, and to improve the same by paving with material to be determined by it, together with curbing therefor, whenever in its judgment the public convenience and welfare may require such improvements, subject only to the limitations prescribed in this Act. Paving and curbing.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that any street-railroad now having or which may hereafter have tracks running through the streets of said city shall be required by the mayor and council to pave within the limits of said tracts and for one foot on each side thereof in the same manner that the rest of the street shall be ordered paved. If said mayor and council determine to pave any street in said city where such railroad shall have tracks, said railroad after thirty days' notice from the mayor and council of the City of Athens shall pave for the space designated in the same manner as said mayor and council shall determine to pave said street. If such railroad shall refuse at such time, such work may be done by the mayor and council of the City of Athens at the cost and expense of such railroad company, and such costs and expenses shall be a lien against all of the property against said railroad company which may be enforced against said property as hereinafter provided for the enforcement of other liens for paving, with the right in said street railroad company to file illegality to the propriety or enforcement of such lien. Paving railroad tracks.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted that wherever the said mayor and council of the City of Athens shall by resolution declare that the paving and curbing of any street or parts of streets in the limits of said city necessary to the public convenience and welfare, such resolution shall be published in six consecutive issues of the legal gazette of Clark County, Georgia; and if a majority of the owners of the land liable to assessment to pay for such improvement of any such highway shall not within fifteen (15) days after the last publication file with the clerk of said city their protest in writing against such improvement, then said mayor and council shall have power to cause said improvement to be made and to contract therefor and to levy assessments or liens provided for and to proceed further as hereinafter set out. Any number of streets or parts of streets may be included in said resolution, but any protest shall be made as to each street separately. If a majority of the owners of the land liable to assessment for any such improvement petition said mayor and council therefor, describing therein the character of the paving and curbing desired, the width thereof and the material thereof preferred by the petitioners it shall be the duty of said mayor and council to do such paving and curbing within a reasonable time, and in such event the resolution aforesaid of said mayor and council shall not be required. Resolution by Mayor and council, as to paving and curbing.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted that the lots, pieces of parcels of land fronting and abutting upon both sides of said paving shall be charged with three eighths of the entire cost of said paving, and the remaining one fourth of said cost shall be paid by the mayor and council, on the basis of lineal foot frontage; provided that the frontage of intersecting public streets shall be assessed as real estate abutting upon said public street and said mayor and council shall be liable for and compelled to pay for all of the paving within the intersection of said public streets and shall pay from the city treasury the just pro rata of the entire cost of said work or improvement for said frontage. Apportionment of cost, assessment.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted that whenever such paving and curbing shall have been determined in the manner aforesaid, said mayor and council shall have the power to establish all such rules and regulations by ordinance as may be necessary to require the owners of all property subject to assessment to pay the cost of such paving and curbing as hereinbefore set forth. Power to adopt ordinances.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted that if such paving and curbing shall be determined upon either of the two methods above set out the mayor and council shall adopt a resolution reciting that no sufficient protest has been filed to its determination to pave and curb, or that the majority of the property owners have requested paving and curbing, and further reciting that said mayor and council shall proceed with said paving and curbing, with the statement of the material to be used, the manner of construction, the extent, character, and width of such paving and other such matters as may be necessary to instruct the city engineer to prepare necessary plans, plots, profiles, specifications and estimates. Said resolution shall also set out the terms and conditions which said mayor and council shall impose with reference to the letting of the contract and the provisions thereof, and said mayor and council therein shall provide that the contractor shall execute to it a good and sufficient bond in an amount to be stated, conditioned upon the full and faithful performance of the contract and for the protection of the city and all property owners against any loss or damages by reason of the negligence or improper execution of the work, and may require a bond conditioned upon the maintenance in good condition of such paving and curbing by said contractor for a period of time to be determined by said mayor and council. Said resolution shall also direct the city engineer to advertise for sealed proposals for the furnishing of materials for said paving and curbing, and for the work necessary for such paving and curbing. Said notice shall state the street, part of street, or streets to be paved and curbed, the manner of such paving and curbing, the bonds to be required, and the time
and place where such sealed proposals shall be filed, and when and where the same will be considered by the mayor and council. The said notice shall be published in ten consecutive issues of the legal gazette of Clark County. A deposit of not less than 10% of any bid to be received shall accompany all such bids, and such deposits shall be returned to all the unsuccessful bidders, and the deposit of the successful bidder shall be retained by said mayor and council until said successful bidder shall be actually proceeding with the work contracted for, and in the event that said successful bidder shall not proceed with the work contracted for, said deposit shall be retained as liquidated damages. At the time and place specified in such notice the mayor and council shall examine all bids received, and shall without unnecessary delay award the contract to the lowest and best bidder. No bid shall be received which shall exceed the original estimate of the cost of said project as estimated by the city engineer in the manner hereinbefore required. Contents of resolution of council as to paving.Advertisement.Bids by contractors.Deposit by bidder.

Sec. 7. The acceptance of said bid shall not be binding upon said city until the mayor and council shall have appointed a board of appraisers consisting of the city engineer of said city, clerk of said city, and the chairman of the board of tax-assessors, to appraise and apportion the costs and expenses of the same to the several tracts of lands abutting on said paving as hereinbefore provided. Within ten days after the appointment of said board, said board shall file with the said mayor and council a written report of its assessment and its apportionment of the costs of said paving and curbing to the several abutting owners. When said report is received said mayor and council shall appoint a time for the holding of a meeting by it for the hearing of any complaints or objections that may be made concerning said appraisement and apportionments as to any of said abutting lot owners, and notice of such meeting for the purpose stated shall be published by the clerk of said mayor and council in at least five consecutive issues of the legal gazette aforesaid. The report of said board shall be filed in the
clerk's office of said city and shall be open to the inspection of any person affected. At said meeting the mayor and council shall have power to review and correct said appraisements and apportionments upon objections to the same. Assessments in conformity to said appraisements and apportionments as confirmed by council shall be payable in ten equal installments and shall bear interest at the rate not exceeding 7% per annum until paid, payable in each year as shall be determined then and there by said mayor and council. The said mayor and council shall by ordinance levy assessments in accordance with said appraisement and apportionments as so confirmed against the several tracts of land liable therefor. Any property owner desiring to do so may within thirty days after said assessment pay the amount assessed against him to said city and relieve themselves of all liability for said paving. Appraisement and apportionment.Hearing of objections.Assessments.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted that said assessment shall be a lien against all of said abutting lots from the date of the ordinance levying the same, which lien shall be coequal with the lien of other taxes and prior to and superior to all other liens against such abutting lots, which liens shall continue until the full payment of such assessments. Lien of assessment.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted that said mayor and council, after the expiration of thirty-one days from the passage of said ordinance confirming and levying said assessment, shall by resolution provide for the issuance of bonds in the aggregate amount of such assessments remaining unpaid, bearing date fifteen days after the passage of the ordinance levying the said assessments, and of such denominations as the said mayor and council shall determine, which bond or bonds shall in no event become a liability of the mayor and council of the City of Athens, issuing the same. One tenth in amount of any such series of bonds, with the interest upon the whole series to date, shall be due and payable fifteen days after the date fixed by said mayor and council for the payment of the assessments against said abutting property owners, and one tenth thereof with the yearly interest of the whole remaining unpaid shall be payable
on the same day in each succeeding year until all shall be paid. Such bonds shall bear interest at a rate not exceeding 7% per annum from their date until maturity, payable annually, and shall be designated as street-improvement bonds, and shall on the face thereof recite the street or streets or parts thereof for the improvement of which they have been issued, and that they are payable solely from assessments which have been levied upon the lots and tracts of land of the abutting property owners benefited by said paving and curbing. Said bonds shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the clerk of council, and shall have the impression of the corporate sea of said city thereon, and shall have interest coupons attached, and all bonds issued by the authority of this Act shall be payable at such place either within or without the State of Georgia as shall be designated by the said mayor and council. Said bonds shall be sold at not less than par and the proceeds thereof applied to the payment of the contract price for said paving and curbing by the said mayor and council, or such bonds in the amount that shall be necessary for that purpose may be turned over and delivered to the contractor at par value in payment of the amount due him on his contract. Said bonds shall be registered by the clerk of council in a book to be provided for that purpose, and certificates of registration by said clerk of council shall be entered upon each of said bonds. Bond issue.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the assessments provided for and levied under the provisions of this Act shall be payable by the person owning the said lots or tracts of land as the several installments become due, together with the interest thereon, to the treasurer of the City of Athens, who shall give proper receipts for such payments. It shall be the collections by him made, and such collections shall be kept in a special fund to be used and applied for the payment of such bonds and the interest thereon, and for no other purpose. It shall be the duty of said treasurer or clerk of council, not
less than thirty days and not more than forty days before the maturity of any installment of such assessments, to publish in two successive issues of said legal gazette a notice advising the owner of the property affected by such assessment of the date when such installment and interest will be due, and designating the street or streets, or other public places for the improvement of which such assessments have been levied, and that unless the same shall be promptly paid, proceedings will be taken to collect said installment and interest. And it shall be the duty of said treasurer promptly after the date of the maturity of any such installment or assessment and interest in case of a default of payment of such installment or assessment with interest, to issue an execution against the lot or tract of land assessed for such improvement, or against the party or person owning the same for the amount of such assessment with interest, and shall turn over the same to the marshal or chief of police of the City of Athens, who shall levy the same upon the real estate liable for such assessment and previously assessed for such improvement, and, after advertisement and other proceedings as in case of sales for city taxes, the same shall be sold at public outcry to the highest bidder; and such sales shall vest an absolute title in the purchaser, subject to the lien of the remaining unpaid installments with interest, and also subject to the right of redemption as provided in sections 880, 1169, 1170, 1171, 1172, of the Code of Georgia of 1910, provided that the defendant shall have the right to file an affidavit denying that the whole or any part of the amount for which said execution is due, and stating what amount he admits to be due, which amount so admitted to be due shall be paid or collected before the affidavit is received, and the affidavit received for the balance. All affidavits (and the foregoing and following provisions shall apply to the street-railroads against whom execution shall be issued for the cost and expense of paving) shall set out in detail the reasons why the affidavit claims the amount is not due, and when received by the city marshal or chief of police, shall be returned to the City Court of Athens,
and there be tried and the issue determined as in cases of illegality, subject to all the pains and penalties provided for in cases of illegality for delay under the Code of Georgia. The failure of the said treasurer or clerk to publish said notice of maturity of any installment of said assessment and interest shall in no wise affect the validity of the assessment and interest and the execution issued therefor. Payment of assessment; installments.Execution.Sale under execution.Affidavit of illegality.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that no suit shall be sustained to set aside any such assessment or to enjoin the said mayor and council from making any such assessment or levying or collecting any such assessments, or issuing such bonds or providing for their payment as herein authorized, or contesting the validity thereof on any ground or for any reason other than for the failure of the mayor and council to adopt and publish the preliminary resolution provided for in section three of this Act in cases requiring such resolution and its publication, and to give the notice of the hearing of the return of the appraisers as herein provided for, unless such suit shall be commenced within sixty (60) days after the passage of the ordinance making such final assessment, provided that in the event any special assessment shall be found to be invalid or insufficient in whole or in part for any reason whatsoever, the said mayor and council may at any time in the manner provided for the levying an original assessment proceed to cause a new assessment to be made and levied which shall have like force and effect as an original assessment. Grounds for enjoinin or setting aside assessments.New assessment.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that in all cases where said mayor and council shall deem it necessary to repave, redrain, remacadamize or otherwise improve any street, alley, avenue, lane, or other public place, which has been paved or improved prior ot the passage of this law, or which shall have been heretofore paved, macadamized, or drained under the provisions of this Act, such pavement or improvement is hereby authorized to be done under and in pursuance of the provisions of this Act, and in such cases all provisions of this
Act providing for making such improvements and levying assessments therefor and the issuance of bonds shall apply; provided that in the judgment of said mayor and council of said city the pavement is worn out nd no longer serviceable. Repaving.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the publication of all notices in a daily newspaper called for in this Act shall be for the number of days therein specified, exclusive of Sunday and legal holidays. Time for publication.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that whenever the abutting land owners of any street, alley, avenue or land of said city petition the said mayor and council as herein set out, or said mayor and council shall pass the resolution provided for in section three of this Act, for the pavement of any such street, avenue, alley or land, or other public place, where the State or any of the political subdivisions is the owner of the property on said street, the frontage so owned is to be counted as if owned by an individual, and shall be likewise treated for the purposes of assessment; and where the State is the owner of the property the Governor is authorized to sign any petition provided for in this Act for and in behalf of the State, and where the county is the owner the chairman of the board of county commissioners of Clarke County is authorized to sign in behalf of the county; and where the City of Athens is the owner the mayor of Athens is authorized to sign in behalf of the city. Petition for paving.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted that the provisions of this amending Act shall not affect the right of the mayor and council of the City of Athens in any event whatsoever to itself to do all of the paving and curbing herein contemplated at its own cost and expense. In the event that the mayor and council of the City of Athens shall elect to so pave and curb any of the streets of said city the cost thereof shall be prorated against the property owners as provided in this Act, that is by assessing each abutting lot owner three eighths of the actual cost of said paving and curbing in
proportion to the lineal foot frontage of each abutting property owner on each side of said street, the said mayor and council being bound to pay for the one-fourth remaining cost of said paving and curbing, and being bound to pay all of said paving cost where said street is intersected by other streets for the full space of said intersection. In the event that said mayor and council shall so elect to pave at its own cost and expense, all of the provisions of the present laws and charter of the mayor and council of the City of Athens shall apply to the assessment, collection of assessment, and all other details incident to the assessment of such paving and curbing cost and to the collection of the same whether by fi. fa. or otherwise. Authority of mayor and council to pave and curb at expense of city and apportion cost.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted that where the paving on any part or portions of a street within the limits of such existing paving shall not have been paved, whether occupied by a street-railroad or otherwise, the provisions of the present law in reference to paving within the mayor and council of the City of Athens shall not be annulled and voided by this Act, but this Act shall be in addition to that portion of the old Act herein saved and kept in full force and effect. Provisions cumulative of old Act.
Sec. 17. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act establishing a new charter for the City of Atlanta, approved February 28th, 1874, and the several Acts amendatory thereof; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of
same that an Act establishing a new charter for the City of Atlanta, approved February 28, 1874, and the several Acts amendatory thereof be and the same are hereby amended as follows:
Section 1. The sections of the city charter codified in sections 1322, 1323 and 1324 of the City Code of 1924, which read as follows:

Sec. 1322. MovingTransfer Companies and Draymen to make ReportsCards forMarshal. It shall be unlawful for any storage or transfer company, licensed dray, moving-van, or similar moving companies, to move persons from one locality to another within the city limites without daily reporting said removals to the city marshal. It shall be the duty, to carry out this ordinance, of the city marshal to supply said storage and transfer companies, moving-vans, licensed drays, etc., with a properly indexed card giving the date of the removal, the name of parties removing, the street and house number from which moved, and the street and house number into which said persons are moved; and, if moved out of the city, note that fact on the card; also the name of the company or drayman making the transfer. These blanks must be properly filled in and mailed or sent to the city marshal within twenty-four hours after the removal. Sections amended.
Sec. 1323. Marshal Keep Loose-Leaf Book of TransfersDaily ReportsOpen to Public. The city marshal is hereby directed to have prepared a suitable loose-leaf book, so that said removal can be listed alphabetically in said ledger, and notices of removal sent to him daily shall be properly recorded therein, and said ledger shall be kept open for inspection by the general public.
Sec. 1324. Penalty. For any violation of the above ordinance the offender shall be fined an amount not exceeding $25.00, or sentenced to work on the streets and public places for not more than thirty days, one or both sentences to be inflicted in the discretion of the recorder, be and the same is hereby amended by striking said sections
in their entirety, and inserting in lieu thereof new sections, which shall read as follows:

Sec. 1322. MovingTransfer Companies and Draymen to Make ReportsCards for Clerk. Permits for Moving. It shall be unlawful for any storage or transfer company, licensed dray, moving-van, or similar moving companies to move persons from one locality to another within the city limits without first obtaining a permit from the city clerk. To carry out this ordinance it shall be the duty of the city clerk to keep a supply of said application blanks, and all storage and transfer companies, moving-vans, licensed dray, and like persons shall file an application giving the date of the proposed removal, the name of parties removing, the street and house number from which moved and the street and house number into which said persons, are moving, or if moving out of the city, and shall note the fact on the card; also the name of the company or drayman making the transfer. These applications must be properly filled in and filed with the city clerk not less than three days prior to making such transfer and application made for a permit for such removal. A fee of twenty-five cents therefor must be paid, which permit shall be issued instanter by the city clerk granting a permit to make such removal at the end of three days. In case of fire or from other cause any building shall become uninhabitable, upon approval of the chief of the fire department or the building inspector a permit for removal from such building shall issue granting leave to make such removal instanter. Provisions for the expense and pay of an employee at a salary of not less than $150.00 per month for this purpose in the office of the city clerk shall be made by the city. Sections as amended.Moving, permit for.Fee for permit.Pay of clerk.

Sec. 1323. Clerk Keeps Loose-Leaf Book of TransfersDaily ReportsOpen to Public. The city clerk is hereby directed to have prepared a suitable loose-leaf book, so that said permits can be listed alphabetically in said ledger, and shall be properly indexed and recorded therein, and said ledger shall be kept open for inspection by the general public. Book of permits.

Sec. 1324. Penalty. For any violation of the above ordinance, the offender shall be fined an amount not exceeding $50.00, or sentenced to work on the streets and public places for not more than thirty days, one or both sentences to be inflicted in the discretion of the recorder. Penalty.

Sec. 2. That the terms of aldermen are hereby increased from three to four years, and the terms of councilmen are hereby increased from two to three years. This increase to take effect upon the terms of aldermen and councilmen elected to succeed the aldermen and councilmen now in office. Terms of aldermen and councilmen increased.

Sec. 3. That the term of the mayor of the City of Atlanta is hereby increased from two years to four years, with the right on the part of the mayor to succeed himself for one term only in direct succession. Term of mayor increased.
Sec. 4. That the provisions of the pension laws of the City of Atlanta, as found in sections 460 to 466, inclusive, City Code of 1924, be amended by adding thereto the following provisions:

The pensions hereinbefore provided for are hereby increased so that the following pensioners, to wit, W. N. Seridan, J. W. Norman, W. M. Cason, G. C. Garner, J. J. Greene, D. F. Cook, A. C. Kerlin, J. M. Glower, W. R. Jones, and Geo. H. Phillips, who have heretofore been retired, shall be paid from the treasury of the City of Atlanta monthly, as a pension, to each one of them a sum equal to the money or pensions now paid to the members of the Police Department of the City of Atlanta under a general law approved August 18th, 1925; that is, one half of the salary each one of said pensioners was receiving at the time of his retirement. This amendment is proposed because under the general law policemen who are now retired secure a much larger sum as a pension than those who were heretofore retired under the old law. Provided this Act shall not change or affect the said general police pension Act of 1925. Pensions of named persons increased.

Sec. 5. That section 10 of an Act approved August 23rd, 1927, amending the charter of the City of Atlanta, be itself amended by striking the words two-thirds in the second sentence of the first paragraph of said section and substitute in lieu thereof the words three-fourths, so that the mayor's disapproval of the budget of the board of education cannot be passed over his veto except by three-fourths vote of the board of education. Furthermore, adding at the end of said paragraph, following the word advisable, the following: The budget so adopted shall set apart sufficient funds to pay for the entire calendar year all salaries of teachers, instructors, and other officials, and the funds so set apart shall not be diverted or used for other purposes during such year. Three-fourths vote necessary to overcome Mayor's veto of budget of board of education.Funds not to be diverted.

Sec. 6. That under the charter amendment approved August 10th, 1919, there is provided a system of paving streets of the City of Atlanta from the issue of bond money, etc., and it is provided under the last paragraph of subdivision G that a fund of ten per cent. shall be set aside for the upkeep of streets at the end of the five-year guarantee period, and it develops that all of this fund is not required to make said repairs, and the accumulations should be made available for street or bridge purposes; and accordingly there shall be added to said paragraph the following: The mayor and general council may use such amount as may be necessary, or all of said fund, for the purpose of rebuilding or constructing the Mitchell Street Viaduct. Unexpended fund for upkeep of streets, to be used for Mitchell Street viaduct.

Sec. 7. That the City of Atlanta may enter into an agreement for the pavement of streets that form a part of the boundary of said city, under which agreement the city will pay one half of the cost of paving such streets or portions of such streets; and it is hereby authorized to assess the property abutting thereon and lying within the limits of the City of Atlanta for the total cost of the pavement so laid; provided, however, the owners of such property may pay said assessments either in cash or one fourth in cash and the balance in one, two, or three years, represented
by notes bearing interest at the rate of seven per cent. per annum. This work shall be done on petition of the owners of a majority of the frontage on the street desired to be paved; provided further, under this amendment, unless the owners of the property on the other side of the street lying without the limits of the City of Atlanta or the municipality in which the property is located shall themselves agree to pay the other one-half of the cost of the pavement of such streets or portions of streets, for which one-half the City of Atlanta shall not in any way become liable or make contracts for same, but the contractor shall look only to the City of Atlanta for its one-half and to parties living without the City of Atlanta for the remaining portion. All the charter provisions with reference to paving streets on petition are hereby made applicable to paving under this charter amendment, and such provisions shall be followed as to advertisements and to forms of assessment and to contracts for pavement, assessment thereon, and the collection of same whether with or without fi. fa. Paving of streets forming part of boundary of city.

Sec. 8. That the present limits of the City of Atlanta be amended by striking therefrom the land covered by the following description, to wit: Beginning at a point on the easterly right of way of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company in land lot 190 of the 17th District of Fulton County, at an intersection with a line between the D. Greenfield heirs and lots 25, 24, 23, 22, 21, and 13 of the subdivision of property as recorded, produced easterly to intersect said right of way; thence in a westerly direction along the above-described line to a point directly south of the rear of lots on the east side of Loraine Street (Holly Street) produced southerly; thence in a northerly direction to the northerly side of Rockdale Street produced westerly; thence in an easterly direction along the northerly line of Rockdale Street produced westerly 175 feet to a point; thence north 175 feet to a point; thence east 100 feet, more or less, to a point directly south of the line between lots 7 and 8; thence north in a line produced south between lots 7 and 8 and along in the line between lots 7 and 8 and
continuing north to an intersection with the existing limits the south line of right of way of the Southern Railway Company; thence westerly and northwesterly along said right of way of the Southern Railway to a point 200 feet north of Southern Street; thence in a westerly direction, 200 feet north of and parallel with Southern Street, to the west line of land lot 224 of said district; thence in a southerly direction along the west line of land lots 224 and 225 of said district to the southwest corner of said land lot 225; thence in an easterly direction along the south line of land lots 225 and 190 to an intersection with the easterly right of way of said Louisville and Nashville Railroad; thence in a northwesterly direction along said Louisville and Nashville Railroad right of way to the point of beginning. The foregoing land is to be cut out of the present city limits, and the lines of the city is amended by taking out said described strip and running around same as shown by following the lines around this property left after taking said property from the present limits. Corparate limits changed by stiking out certain territory

Sec. 9. There shall be created, as a part of the government of the City of Atlanta, a commission to be known as the City Planning Commission, which commission shall consist of six citizens to be appointed by the mayor, with the mayor as an ex-officio member thereof. City Planning Commission created.

Sec. 10. Said commission shall have all the power hereinafter set forth, and, in addition thereto, such powers as may be proper and consistent with the organization and operation of said commission as may be established by ordinance passed by the mayor and general council; and an office shall be provided for said commission at the city hall, if possible, at which to hold its meetings, transact its business, and keep its records. Said commission shall have power and authority to employ consulting advice on municipal problems and such other help as may be necessary, and to pay for the services thereof, including disbursements incurred by its members in the performance of their duties under the direction of such commission, from such
funds as may be pledged at the disposal of said commission by authority of the mayor and general council. Powers of commission.Disbursements.

Sec. 11. It shall be the duty of said commission and they shall have power to recommend or make suggestions to the general council and to all other authorities concerning the laying out, widening, extending, and parking and location of streets, sidewalks, and boulevards; the relief of traffic conditions, congestion, and development of housing and sanitary conditions, and the establishment of zones or districts; suggestions concerning the use, height, area, and build of buildings or structures; to recommend to the general council and all other public authorities plans for the future growth, development, and improvement of the municipality, and especially with regard to its public and private buildings, and works, streets, parks, grounds, and vacant lots, and plans consistent with the future growth and development of the city, looking towards the proper sanitation and especially service by public utilities; and generally to do and perform any and all other acts and things necessary or proper to carry out the provisions of this Act; to study and propose such measures as may be advisable for the promotion of public interests, health, morals, safety, comfort, convenience, and welfare of said city. In this connection said commission shall have authority to make similar suggestions to the general council, the commissioners of roads and revenues of Fulton County, and the General Assembly of Georgia, with reference to an area covering six miles adjacent to the present limits of the City of Atlanta. Duties and powers as to streets, zones, buildings, municipal improvements, etc.Territory outside city.

Sec. 12. Said commission shall have authority to investigate and make recommendations concerning all plans for sewers, both sanitary and storm-water, where placed in any property or subdivision or lots which are intended to be sold. Whenever said city undertakes the erection of a public building aside from school buildings, the buildings here referred to constitute buildings to be owned and controlled by the City of Atlanta, the plans and locations thereof must first be submitted to the commission and
receive its approval before the erection of such building is begun. Said commission shall have authority to make recommendations to all parties, corporations, or public authorities with reference to the erection of buildings, structures, or work to be erected or remodeled, and such persons or authorities shall have authority to call upon the commission for a report as to the construction, placing, or designing of buildings or other structures and improvements or objects of art. Plans to be submitted to commission.
Sec. 13. All officials of said city shall at all times render assistance to said commission when it calls upon them for such service. Assistance from city officials.

Sec. 14. The mayor and general council shall make such appropriation for carrying on the work of said commission in like manner and form as appropriations are made to other departments of the city. Said commission shall have authority to receive gifts, bequests, and devises of property, and to carry out the general purposes of same; and when such gifts, bequests, or devises are made to said commission it shall have full, complete, and final control and disposition over same, and same shall not pass into the city treasury or otherwise be counted as a part of the revenue of the city. Appropriations for work of commission.

Sec. 15. Said commission shall prepare and submit to the general council a comprehensive plan for zoning the city, for the purpose of suggesting the proper location of streets, apartment-houses, dwellings, and other uses of property, the height of buildings, the area of the lot, the provision of yard space and the fixing of building lines. It is not intended by this provision to vest in said commission or the general council authority to finally control the location and operation thereof, but only to make suggestions which shall be given publicity, and to give the owners or builders the benefit of the suggestions, all looking towards the final betterment and improvement of the city. Zoning plans.

Sec. 16. No ordinance or resolution authorizing any buildings, works, or improvements, where same is done by authority of the city or for the benefit of the city, shall be passed by the general council unless same shall have first been submitted to the commission for its consideration and had report thereon. Afterwards the general council may accept or reject the report; but it is the purpose of this provision to provide for a recommendation, either favorable or unfavorable, by the commission thereon, to wit, public buildings, as above stated, where undertaken by or on behalf of the City of Atlanta, except school buildings, viaducts, bridges, street fixtures, and other street structures and appurtenances; opening, widening, vacation or extension of any street. Ordinances to be submitted to commission before adoption.

Sec. 17. Where any ordinance or resolution relating to the matters just named are introduced in the general council, the city clerk shall, upon its introduction, refer such ordinance or resolution to the commission, and the general council shall not act thereon until report shall be made by the commissioners, as above stated; except where such report is delayed beyond a period of thirty days, the general council may take it up and pass same without such report. Same.

Sec. 18. Zoning, Regulation. The mayor and general council may, in the interest of the public health, safety, order, convenience, comfort, prosperity, or general welfare, adopt by ordinance a plan or plans for the districting or zoning of the city for the purpose of regulating the location of trades, industries, apartment-houses, dwellings, or other uses of property, or for the purpose of regulating the height of the buildings or other structures, or for the area or dimensions of the lots or of the yards used in connection with buildings or other structures, or for the purpose of regulating the alignment of buildings or other structures near street frontages. The zoning regulations may be based upon any one or more of the purposes above described. The city may be divided into such number of zones or districts, and such districts may be of such shape
and area as the mayor and general council shall deem best suited to accomplish the purposes of the zoning regulations. In the determination and establishment of districts and regulations, classifications may be based on the nature or character of the trade, industry, profession or other activity conducted or to be conducted upon the premises, the number of persons, families or other group units to reside in or use buildings, the public, quasi-public, or private nature of the use of premises, or upon any other basis or bases relevant to the promotion or the public health, safety, order, morals, conveniences, prosperity, or welfare. Zoning.

Residence Sections. For the reasons above stated, said mayor and general council shall have the further right and power, in any districts proposed to be set aside primarily for residence purposes, to further classify the use thereof and to provide therein the class or classes of residents to be housed therein and to provide therein such other and similar regulations and restrictions as shall secure the peace and good order of the city and the residents thereof. No such ordinance or amendment thereto authorized by either of the above sections shall be adopted except by three fourths vote of the general council. Classification of use of property in residence sections.

Preparation of Plan; Notice and Hearings; Ordinance. No ordinance adopting zoning regulations as above authorized shall be passed by the mayor and general council until after a comprehensive plan for the zoning of the city has been prepared and submitted to the mayor and general council by the City Planning Commission. Whenever the City Planning Commission shall certify to the mayor and general council a plan for the zoning of the city, the mayor and general council shall hold a public hearing thereon, and shall give notice of the time and place thereof in a newspaper in general circulation in the city; and during said time a copy of such plan and proposed ordinance shall be on file for public examination in the office of the City Planning Commission or any such other office as may be designated by the mayor and general council. No ordinance, measure, or regulation which violates, differs, or
departs from the plan or report submitted by the City Planning Commission shall take effect unless passed by a three-fourths vote of the mayor and general council. Comprehensive plan for zoning city to be first adopted and filed for public examination.

Amendment of Zone Plan. The mayor and general council may from time to time amend or change the regulations or districts established by the zoning ordinance, but no such amendment or change shall become effective unless the ordinance proposing such amendment or change shall be first submitted to the City Planning Commission for approval or disapproval, and the City Planning Commission shall have been allowed a reasonable time, not less than thirty days, for consideration and report. Whenever the owners of 50 per cent. of the land in any area shall present a petition, duly signed and acknowledged, to the mayor and general council, requesting an amendment of the regulation prescribed for such area, it shall be the duty of the mayor and general council to vote upon such amendment within 90 days of the filing of same by the petitioners with the city clerk. Amendment of regulations.

Board of Zoning Appeals. The zoning regulations shall be enforced and administered by the inspector of buildings under rules and regulations of the Board of Zoning Appeals. The mayor and general council shall create a Board of Zoning Appeals, which board shall hear and decide appeals from, and review any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by, the inspector of buildings in the enforcement of the zoning regulations. The mayor and general council may authorize the Board of Zoning Appeals to administer the details of the application of any zoning regulations, and may delegate to such board, in accordance with general rules set forth in the zoning ordinance, power to permit exceptions to and variations from the zoning regulations, and to administer the zoning regulations as specified therein; or such administrative powers and functions may be delegated by the mayor and general council, either in whole or in part, to the City Planning Commission, and the City Planning Commission when acting in
accordance with such delegations shall be the Board of Zoning Appeals. Board of Zoning Appeals.

Certiorari to Review Decision of Board of Zoning Appeals. Every decision of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall be subject to writ of certiorari issued from the superior court upon the same terms as such writs are issued in any case. Certiorari to review decisions of board.
Sec. 19. That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this law be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: ATLANTA; EXCHANGE OF LAND FOR PARK; CHANGES IN CORPORATE LIMITS; CITY CLERK TO BE CLERK OF ATLANTA.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act establishing a new charter for the City of Atlanta, approved February 28th, 1874, and the several acts amendatory thereof; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, as follows:

Section 1. That an Act establishing a new charter for the City of Atlanta, approved February 28th, 1874, and the several acts amendatory thereof be amended by granting permission to the Mayor and General Council of the City of Atlanta to exchange that portion of Maddox Park lying south of North Avenue, east of the A. B. C. railroad right of way and north of Simpson Street, for an equal number of acres lying on Marietta Street, Niles Avenue and the right of way of the A. B. C. Railroad, provided that the land obtained in this exchange shall itself be used for and maintained as a public park. This amendment is made because the present charter of said city prohibits the sale or exchange of any of the park properties. Exchange of part of Maddox Park for other land.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the following territory shall be and is hereby annexed to the City of Atlanta and shall hereafter form a part of the limits of Atlanta, to wit: Beginning on the present city limits at a point two (200) hudred feet from the center of Stokes Avenue, where the present city limits make a corner, and running thence west and parallel with Stokes Avenue eighteen hundred and eleven (1811) feet, more or less, to the east line of land lot 172, of the 14th district of originally Henry, now Fulton County, Georgia; thence north along said land-lot line ten hundred and fortynine (1049) feet, more or less, to the property of the West View Cemetery Association; thence eastwardly along the south line of said West View Cemetery Association property eighteen hundred and fifty-five (1855) feet, more or less, to the present city limits; thence south along the present city limits one thousand (1000) feet, more or less, to the point of beginning. Said property being part of wha t is known as Westmeath Park, located in land lot 149 of the 14th district of Fulton County Annexed territory from Westmeath Park.

Be it further enacted, that the following described property be removed from the corporate limits of the City of Atlanta: Beginning at the southeast corner of land lot 225 of the 17th district of Fulton County; thence west along the southern boundary of land lot 225, of said district, to the southwest corner of said land lot 225; thence north along the west line of land lots 225 and 224, of said distrcit, to a point 200 feet north of the center of Southern Street; thence east parallel with Southern Street, to an intersection with the right of way of the Southern Railway thence southeasterly and easterly along said right of way to the west line of land lot 189 of said district; thence north along the west line of land lot 189, to the south line of the right of way of the Western and Atlantic Railway; thence southeasterly along said south line of right of way to a point in land lot 112, opposite the dividing line between property of the Exposition Cotton Mills and the O. A. Smith property, said dividing line being the rear of lots facing on Alamo
Street; thence in a westerly direction along said dividing line and along the rear of said lots, to the northeasterly side of Marietta Street; thence northwesterly and westerly along the north side of Marietta Street to an intersection with the north line of land lot 190 of said district; thence west along said north line of land lot 190 to the northwest thereof; thence south along the west line of said land lot 190 to the point of beginning, excepting, however, from the above description, property situated on the north side of Marietta Street known as No. 1153 and No. 1163 according to the present house numbering of the City of Atlanta. Annexed territory.

Sec. 3. Said property is hereby annexed to the limits of the City of Atlanta and shall be included therein, and all the property and persons therein shall hereafter be subject to all laws governing municipalities and especially to the charter and ordinances of the City of Atlanta. The City of Atlanta extends its protection over said property and citizens, and likewise the property and citizens therein are subject to same as any other property or citizens of the City of Atlanta.

Provided, that the clerk of the City of Atlanta shall be clerk of Atlanta under the bill approved by the Governor on the..... day of August, 1929; the said clerk, however, to receive no compensation for his services from Atlanta as provided in said bill until after December 31, 1930. Clerk of City of Atlanta to be clerk of Atlanta, without pay until 1931. See Act No. 261, Sections 5, 6, p. 839 post.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: ATLANTA; AUTHORITY TO SELL CERTAIN LAND.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act establishing a new charter for the City of Atlanta, approved February 28, 1874, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that an Act establishing a new charter for the City of Atlanta, approved February 28, 1874, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, be and the sam are hereby amended as follows:

Section 1. That the present provisions of the charter whereby the Mayor and General Council have no authority to sell property or other assets belonging to its system of waterworks, as set out in section 229 of the City Code of 1924, be amended by adding to said section the following: The Mayor and General Council are authorized to sell and convey to the B. F. Goodrich Company, or the Southern Goodrich Rubber Company, the following parcel or tract of land now forming a part of the new waterworks system: All that tract or parcel of land lying and being in land lots one hundred forty-eight (148) and one hundred forty-nine (149) of the seventeenth (17th) district of Fulton County, Georgia, and more particularly described as follows: Beginning at the northeast corner of Fourteenth Street and Hemphill Avenue and running thence north twenty-seven (27) degrees and thirteen (13) minutes west, and along the east boundary of said Hemphill Avenue a distance of four hundred ninety-five (495) feet to a point; thence north fifty-three (53) degrees and thirty-seven (37) minutes east a distance of four hundred twenty (420) feet to a point; thence north thirty-three (33) degrees and forty-three (43) minutes west a distance of fifty (50) feet to a point; thence north fifty-six (56) degrees and seventeen (17) minutes east a distance of two hundred thirty-seven and seventy-five one-hundredths (283.75) feet to an intersection with a curve to the left and of a radius of two hundred eighty and nine-tenths (280.9) feet; thence in a general north-westerly and westerly direction along said curve a distance of one hundred thirty-four and seventy-eight one-hundredths (134.78) feet to the point of compound with a curve and of a radius of four hundred fifty-five and nine-tenths (455.9) feet; thence along said curve a distance of one hundred
seventy-nine and eleven one-hundredths (179.11) feet to an intersection with a curve to the right and of a radius of six thousand eitht hundred twenty-five and six tenths (6825.6) feet (this curve being the right of way line of the Southern Railway Company); thence in a general northeasterly direction and along said right of way curve a distance of forty (40) feet to a point; thence north eighty-nine (89) degrees and thirty-five (35) minutes east a distance of five and eighty-five one-hundredths (5.85) feet to an intersection with a curve to the right and of a radius of four hundred sixty-nine and nine-tenths (469.9) feet; thence along said curve a distance of one hundred forty-one and twenty-five one-hundredths (141.25) feet to the point of compound with a curve of a radius of two hundred ninety-four and nine-tenths (294.9) feet; thence along said curve a distance of thirty-one and three-tenths (31.3) feet to a point; thence north eighty-nine (89) degrees and thirty-five (35) minutes east a distance of three hundred thirty and eighteen one-hundredths (330.18) feet to a point; thence south two (2) degrees and twenty-four (24) minutes east a distance of four hundred and six-tenths (400.6) feet to a point on the original north boundary of land lot one hundred forty-nine (149); thence north eighty-nine (89) degrees and nineteen (19) minutes east along said original north boundary of said land lot one hundred forty-nine (149) a distance of one hundred fifty-five (155) feet to a point; thence south no (0) degrees and thirty-three (33) minutes west a distance of five hundred twenty-eight and ninety-six one-hundredths (528.96) feet to a point on the north line of Fourteenth Street; thence south eighty-nine (89) degrees and twenty (20) minutes west, and along said north line of said Fourteenth Street a distance of six hundred sixty-six and eighty-five one-hundredths (666.85) feet to the point of beginning. Authority to sell certain land of new waterworks system to B.F. Goodrich Co.

Under this amendment the Mayor and General Council are authorized to sell said described parcel of land and the mayor sign deed conveying same to the B. F. Goodrich Company for the sum of twenty-five thousand ($25,000.00)
dollars, this being the consideration already agreed upon; it appearing that the particular land above described is not now needed nor will it be needed in the future for the waterworks system. Consideration $25,000.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: ATLANTA; INCORPORATION OF MUNICIPALITY SO DESIGNATED; CITIES INCLUDED, TO BE KNOWN AS BOROUGHS; UNINCORPORATED COMMUNITIES INCLUDED, ETC.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to incorporate the municipality of Atlanta, which shall be known as Atlanta, in which name said municipality may sue and be sued, and perform all of its functions; the limits thereof to consist of the territorial limits included in the Cities of Atlanta, in Fulton and DeKalb Counties, Georgia, East Point and Hapeville in Fulton County, Georgia, and College Park in Fulton and Clayton Counties, Georgia, and the Cities of Decatur and Avondale Estates, DeKalb County, Georgia, and all the unincorporated communities within the territorial limits of the County of Fulton described as follows: The whole of Peachtree Militia District No. 1362 G. M., not now in the City of Atlanta, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 1; the whole of Buckhead Militia District No. 722 G. M., not now in the City of Atlanta, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 2; the whole of Collins Militia District No. 1328 G. M., not now in the City of Atlanta, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 3; the whole of Cook's Militia District
No. 469 G. M., not now in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 4; the whole of Center Hill Militia District No. 1511 G. M., not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 5; the whole of Adamsville Militia District No. 1289 G. M., not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 6; the whole of East Point Militia District No. 1332 G. M., not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 7; the whole of the Hapeville Militia District No. 1589 G. M., not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 8; the whole of the College Park Militia District No. 1615 G. M., not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 9; the whole of the Black Hall Militia District No. 530 G. M., not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 10; the whole of the South Bend Militia District No. 1348, not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 11; the whole of the Edgewood Militia District No. 1422 G. M., not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 12; the whole of Bryants Militia District No. 479 G. M., which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 13; the whole of Poole's Militia District No. 1762 G. M., which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 14; and all the following land lots in the Fifteenth District of DeKalb County, Georgia, not now in the city limits of Atlanta or Decatur Georgia, to wit: land lots 178, 179, 180, 181, 182, 238, 237, 244 and 243, 247 and 248, and all of the following land lots in the Eighteenty District of DeKalb of County, Georgia, not in the city limits of Atlanta, or in the city limits of Decatur, to wit: land lots 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 51, 52, 53, 54, 55, 57, 58, 59, and 60, not now in any incorporated town, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 15; to provide for a mayor and council and other officers of said municipality and prescribe all
of their duties and authority; to provide a government for said municipality, and to specify the manner in which it shall exercise its powers, and to provide that for the purpose of this Act only the Cities of Atlanta, Decatur, Avondale Estates, Hapeville, College Park, and East Point shall be known as boroughs; and for other purposes: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, as follows:
law.p: Section 1. A municipality to be known as Atlanta be and the same is hereby incorporated as a municipal corporation, to include the territory hereinafter designated, and said municipality shall be known as Atlanta, and in the name of Atlanta it may sue and be sued, and make such contracts and perform such functions as may be authorized by this Act. Incorporation of municipality of Atlanta.

Sec. 2. The corporate limits of Atlanta shall embrace the territory now included, and which may hereafter be included, in the Cities of Atlanta, in Fulton and DeKalb Counties, Georgia, East Point and Hapeville, in Fulton County, Georgia, and College Park in Fulton and Clayton Counties, Georgia, and the Cities of Decatur and Avondale Estates, in DeKalb County, Georgia, and the Unincorporated Communities within the territorial limits of Fulton County, Georgia, described as follows: The whole of Peachtree Militia District No. 1362 G. M., not now in the City of Atlanta, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 1. The whole of Buckhead Militia District No. 722 G. M., not now in the City of Atlanta, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 2. The whole of Collins Militia District No. 1328 G. M., not now in the City of Atlanta, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 3. The whole of Cook's Militia District No. 469 G. M., not now in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 4. The whole of Center Hill Militia District No. 1511 G. M., not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 5. The whole of Adamsville Militia District No. 1289 G. M., not in any incorporated
city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 6. The whole of East Point Militia District No. 1332 G. M., not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 7. The whole of the Hapeville Militia District No. 1589 G. M., not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 8. The whole of the College Park Militia District No. 1615 G. M., not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 9. The whole of the Black Hall Militia District No. 530 G. M., not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 10. The whole of the South Bend Militia District No. 1348 G. M., not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 11. The whole of the Edgewood Militia District No. 1422 G. M., not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 12. The whole of Bryant Militia District No. 479 G. M., not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 13. The whole of Poole's Militia District No. 1762 G. M., not in any incorporated city, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 14. And all of the following land lots in the Fifteenth District of DeKalb County, Georgia, not now in the city limits of Atlanta or Decatur, Georgia, to wit: land lots 178, 179, 180, 181, 182, 238, 237, 244 and 243, 247 and 248. (a) All of the following land lots in the Eighteenth District of DeKalb County, Georgia, not now in the city limits of Atlanta, or in the city limits of Decatur, to wit: land lots, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 51, 52, 53, 54, 55, 57, 58, 59, and 60, not now in the corporate limits of Atlanta or Decatur, which shall be known as Unincorporated Community No. 15. Inclusion of cities of Atlanta, East Point, Hapeville, College Park, Decatur, Avondale Estates, as boroughs, and unincorporated communities designated by numbers 1 to 15 inclusive.

Sec. 3. That from and after the passage and approval of this Act the charters of the Cities of Atlanta, Decatur, Avondale Estates, Hapeville, East Point and College Park, and all amendments thereto, for the purposes of this act only are respectively amended so that wherever the titles of corporate names of said cities appear the word
City shall be stricken and the word Borough inserted in lieu thereof. But it shall not be unlawful to refer to a borough as a city, and when the word city is used either in official documents or in contracts or private writings, such irregularity shall not vitiate, but the reference shall be understood to be to the borough, unless it is plainly intended otherwise. The word Borough substituted for City in the charters of the cities included.

Sec. 4. The municipal officers of Atlanta shall be a mayor, twenty (20) councilmen, and a city clerk; the mayor [Illegible Text] the acting mayor of the Borough of Atlanta to be ex-officio the mayor of Atlanta, and the mayors or acting mayors of the Borough of Decatur, Avondale Estates, Hapeville, East Point, and College Park, respectively, and a resident freeholder of each of said Unincorporated Communities, to constitute the council of Atlanta, and the resident freeholders for the unincorporated Communities in Fulton County shall be chosen by the board of county commissioners of Fulton County, and the resident freeholders for the unincorporated communities of DeKalb County shall be chosen by the board of county commissioners of DeKalb County. Mayor of Borough of Atlanta to be ex-officio Mayor of Atlanta.Council to include mayors of boroughs, etc.

The councilmen from all of said Unincorporated Communities shall hold office for one year from January 1st, 1930, and all councilmen from the Unincorporated Communities shall cease to be such whenever they cease to be freeholders and/or residents of the Unincorporated Communities for which they were elected. Terms of councilmen.
In the meetings of the council the mayor shall preside, but shall not vote except in elections of city clerk and when there is a tie vote of council. Vote of Mayor.

Sec. 5. The mayor and councilmen of Atlanta shall serve without compensation. The city clerk shall receive a salary to be fixed by the council, not to exceed $1,200.00 per annum, payable in twelve (12) monthly installments, the money for which shall be appropriated and paid by the proper governing authorities of the Boroughs of Atlanta, Decatur, Avondale Estates, Hapeville, East Point
and College Park, and the Counties of Fulton and DeKalb, in proportion to the population of each of said boroughs and the parts of said counties not included in any of said boroughs, said proportions to be fixed from time to time by the mayor and council of Atlanta. Clerk, salary.See Act No. 413, p. 832, ante.

The mayor and council of Atlanta shall meet in the city hall of the Borough of Atlanta once a month on the second (2d) Monday in each month at three o'clock (3:00) p. m., but the mayor shall have power to call special meetings on not less than one day's notice in writing. A majority of said council shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business.

Sec. 6. The city clerk shall be elected by the council at its first meeting in January of 1930 for a term of one year and until his successor is elected and qualified, and thereafter the council shall at its regular meeting in December of each year elect the city clerk for the following year. Clerk's election and term of office.See p. 832, ante.
Sec. 7. The mayor and council of Atlanta shall have the following powers, duties and obligations: Duties and powers of mayor and council.

item.p: (a) To study and inquire into all governmental, sanitary, water, and police conditions which may be deemed by them important to the City of Atlanta and its inhabitants or any of the constitutent parts thereof, and by resolution to recommend to the various governing bodies of the boroughs and the counties affected such legislation or other action as may be deemed beneficial.

(b) To exercise in said Unincorporated Communities in the Counties of Fulton and DeKalb the power and authority of zoning real property and regulating building in the manner and to the extent exercised by the Borough of Atlanta under its charter. Zonong.

(c) To draft for submission to the General Assembly of Georgia, not earlier than its 1939 session, a new charter for the city of Atlanta, providing for a consolidation of the governments of its constituent boroughs and said Unincorporated Communities; but no such charter or law shall
have any force or effect in any of said boroughs or in any of said Unincorporated Communities within the territorial limits of the Counties of Fulton and DeKalb respectively, until the same shall have been ratifid by a vote of the majority of the qualified voters voting at a special election to be held in each of said boroughs and in each of said Unincorporated Communities not earlier than sixty (60) days after the final passage and approval of any such new charter for Atlanta; provided, however, that the people within the corporate limits of each of said boroughs and the limits of each of said Unincorporated Communities shall vote separately; and, before the said new charter shall go into effect in respect to any one of said boroughs or in respect to any one of said Unincorporated Communities, a majority of those voting in such borough or in such Unincorporated Community shall vote in favor of said new charter. To draft new charter.Election to ratify new charter.

(d) To make recommendations to said boroughs and said counties of all steps that may be deemed necessary to protect said boroughs and said Unincorporated Communities against the results of unsanitary conditions; and in the event of emergencies to call upon said borough to send a police force to any point in Atlanta for the purpose of quelling extraordinary disturbances, and/or unusual breaches of the peace. Recommendations as to sanitary matters.Emergencies calling for police force.

law.p:
Sec. 8. In the exercise of the powers expressly granted herein the mayor and council of Atlanta shall have the power to expend, under such rules and regulations as may be adopted by them, any and all sums of money which may be contributed from private sources or may be appropriated and paid by the Boroughs of Atlanta, Decatur, Avondale Estates, Hapeville, East Point and College Park, and the Counties of Fulton and DeKalb. Said boroughs and counties are hereby given power and authority to appropriate and pay to Atlanta such reasonable amounts as may seem fit to them in furtherance of the objects of this Act, but said Atlanta shall have no right to exercise any taxing power, nor to issue bonds nor assess any property.
Nor shall said Atlanta have the right to license, or to grant any license or franchise, nor shall it have the right to appropriate money or incur any expense, except such as shall be satisfied and paid out of the income it is herein expressly authorized to receive. Expenditures.No power to tax, assess property, issue bonds, grant licenses, franchises, etc.

Sec. 9. The Boroughs of Atlanta; Decatur, Avondale Estates, Hapeville, East Point and College Park, and the Counties of Fulton and DeKalb, shall respectively remain unaltered and unaffected by this Act, with all of the governmental and other powers, rights, properties, duties, jurisdiction and authority now had or hereafter by law vested in said cities and counties, except as herein otherwise expressly provided. Rights and powers of boroughs and counties not affected by this Act.

All existing legal contracts now of force and to which any of said cities are parties shall remain of force, equally binding on and in favor of said cities as boroughs. All such contracts are hereby authorized, ratified, and confirmed, and the faith of the State is hereby pledged that the same shall not be abrogated nor their obligation impaired except by the full and free consent of all parties thereto. Existing contracts of cities to remain binding.

Sec. 10. All the inhabitants residing in said Boroughs of Atlanta, Decatur, Avondale Estates, East Point, Hapeville, and College Park, and in said Unincorporated Communities shall be deemed to the residents of Atlanta, except that the specific and occupation taxes and license taxes, payable by persons doing business in any of said boroughs shall not be determined by the population of the municipality hereby created, but shall be determined by the population of the borough in which the business is located. Who deemed residents of Atlanta.

Sec. 11. The operation of the public schools in said boroughs and in said Unincorporated Communities shall not be changed by this Act, and the title to school buildings, grounds, and other school property in said boroughs and in said Unincorporated Communities, and the title to all other public property therein, shall not be changed or affected hereby, and this Act shall in no way deprive said
boroughs and said counties of the police powers they now have in any of said territory, or may hereafter have or acquire. Said Unincorporated Communities being now attached to and constituting parts of the rural school systems of the counties in which they respectively lie, nothing in this act contained shall be held, taken or construed to affect said connection or separate them from said rural systems, but they shall each and all continue to retain their status as parts of said rural systems as though this Act had not been passed. Schools.
Sec. 12. The municipality hereby created shall have no power, right, or authority except such as is herein expressly granted. Rights limited to those expressly granted.

Sec. 13. No material amendment except such as may pertain to sewerage or foul water shall be passed to this Act unless it shall contain provisions to the effect that before it shall become binding on any of said boroughs or Unincorporated Communities, it shall first be approved by a majority vote of the qualified voters in a separate election in each such borough or Unincorporated Community, but this shall not interfere with a repeal of this Act at any time. Power and mode of amendment of this Act.
Sec. 14. All laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: ATLANTA; PENSIONS FOR CERTAIN RETIRED FIREMEN.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act establishing a new charter for the City of Atlanta, approved February 28th, 1874, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is enacted by the authority of same, that an Act establishing a new charter for the City of Atlanta, approved February 28th, 1874, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, be and same are hereby amended as follows:

Section 1. That the charter of the City of Atlanta as set out in section 466 of the City Code of 1924, containing the following language: No payment of pension shall exceed the sum of $50.00 per month, be amended so that the following members of the Fire Department, to wit: W. L. Bural, retired lieutenant; G. B. Hudson, retired driver; W. H. Cook, R. E. Little, W. P. Evans, M. J. Smith, W. M. Watkins and J. C. Martin, retired horsemen, who have heretofore been retired under the provisions of the section of the charter just quoted, shall hereafter receive an amount of money corresponding to that paid other firemen on retirement, and it is accordingly enacted that the firemen above mentioned be hereafter paid that sum per month which they would have received had they been retired under the present provisions of the general law providing for pensions to firemen in cities the size of Atlanta. However, the City of Atlanta shall itself provide a fund for the payment of the pension of the retired firemen above enumerated from the general funds received from taxation or otherwise. Amount of pension of named firemen.
Sec. 2. That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act establishing a new charter for the City of Atlanta, approved February 28th, 1874, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, by extending the limits of said city so as to include and embrace within same the
following territory, to wit; and for other purposes.
