Be it further enacted that the City of Austell is authorized and empowered to purchase, own, operate, and maintain a system of water supply in said City of Austell, and the mayor and council of said City of Austell shall have the right and power to regulate the sale and use of such water supply to the inhabitants of said city or other persons or corporations within or without said city, and said City of Austell shall have the right to issue bonds for the construction, maintenance, repair, and extension of such water system in said city or for said city. The mayor and council of said City of Austell are authorized to create a water committee, which water committee shall, for and in the name of the mayor and council of the City of Austell, take and hold the lands and real estate, rights, franchises, and property of every kind purchased by the City of Austell for the construction of any water system, acqueduct, reservoir, or waterworks for conveying or containing water, or for the erection of any building or machinery, for the laying of any pipes or conduits for conveying the water into or through the said City of Austell or other places, and in general to do any other act necessary or convenient for accomplishing the purposes contemplated by this Act. Said water committee shall have the power to make and create rates, schedules of rates, etc., and to collect, by themselves or other persons, all monies which they may charge for the use of or for water, which monies collected shall be kept in a separate account from all monies derived from other sources, and said water committee shall set aside from such funds or monies a reserve for replacements, betterments, etc., and also a sinking fund for the payment of the interest and of the bonds. Water system, bond issue for.

Sec. 47. Be it further enacted, that the City of Austell is authorized and empowered to purchase, own, operate, and maintain a system of fire department for said City of Austell, and said City of Austell is authorized to issue bonds to purchase any property, real or personal, for this purpose.
Said City of Austell is authorized and empowered to create a fire committee, which fire committee shall have the right and power to take and hold all property, both real and personal, purchased by the City of ustell for said fire department, and said City of Austell is authorized to issue bonds for the purchase of needed property for said fire department. Fire department, bond issue for.

Sec. 48. Be it further enacted, that the said City of Austell shall have the right to issue bonds for any public purpose as is prescribed by the general laws of the State of Georgia, and the mayor and council of said city shall have the right to call elections and fix the date of the same; that the elections held under this section and the issuance of bonds and their validation shall be in strict conformity with articles 1, 2 and 3 of chapter 3 of the 6th title of the Code of Georgia, and said mayor and council are hereby vested with all the authority vested in municipal corporations under said law. Bond issues.
Sec. 49. Be it further enacted, that the mayor and council shall have the right and power to call any special election for referendum or other purposes in the City of Austell. Special elections.

Sec. 50. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the mayor and council shall have the right and power by ordinance to maintain a chain-gang in said city for the purpose of working such persons as have been placed in said chain-gang by the recorder's court of said city, and said mayor and council shall have the right to prescribe the rules and regulations governing said chain-gang. Chain-gang.

Sec. 51. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the mayor of the said City of Austell shall have the right to pardon or parole any offender against the ordinances of said city. Pardon or parole.

Sec. 52. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all ordinances, rules, and regulations now in force in the Town of Austell shall remain in force and effect in the City of Austell created by this charter, until the same have been repealed by ordinances or otherwise. Ordinances continued of force.

Sec. 53. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the City of Austell created by this charter be invested with all the rights, powers, and authority that is granted and given to municipalities by the general law of the State of Georgia or that hereafter may be given to the municipalities by the laws of this State. General powers.
Sec. 54. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: BARNESVILLE POLICE AUTHORITY EXTENDED TO WATERWORKS, ETC.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved December 11, 1871, which was an Act to confer additional powers upon the corporate authorities of the Town of Barnesville, now the City of Barnesville, then in Pike County, now Lamar County, so as to provide for the extension of the police authority of said city over property acquired in 1928 for waterworks purposes; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that after the passage of this Act the Act approved December 11, 1871, which was an Act to confer additional power upon the corporate authorities of the Town of Barnesville, now the City of Barnesville, then in Pike County, now in Lamar County, and to define its incorporate limits, is hereby amended so that the police power of said City of Barnesville shall extend in a northern direction along the paved National Highway one quarter of a mile north of the tract of land purchased of Miss Rochelle Woodall on July 30, 1928, and recorded in Deed Book 5, page 529, in the office of the clerk of the superior court of Lamar County,
Georgia, and shall extend west of said tract of land one quarter of a mile and east of said tract of land one quarter of a mile; and said city shall have police power over the strip of land over which the City of Barnesville has an easement as described in a deed from James Worthy to the City of Barnesville and recorded in Deed Book 5, page 583-4, in the office of the clerk of the superior court of Lamar County, Georgia. The mayor and council of the said City of Barnesville shall have authority over the territory herein described, to preserve the peace and maintain order therein the same as if it was in the corporate limits, and to prohibit, by penal ordinance, any person from trespassing upon or damaging the city's water works located on said described property, from polluting the water or in any manner interfering with the transmission of the water or electricity. Police authority, extension of.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act approved December 11, 1871, which was an Act to confer additional powers upon the corporate authorities of the Town of Barnesville, now City of Barnesville, then in Pike County, now Lamar County, and the various Acts amendatory thereof; to enlarge by providing additional powers and authority therein, so as to provide for a method, time, and place for registration of voters for all elections held in said city; to prescribe rules and regulations in regard to registration, and define the authority of the mayor and aldermen of said city in regard to such registration, and the revision and purging of registration lists; to
prescribe the manner of selection of registrars and define their duties and authority and fix their compensation; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that in all elections held in the City of Barnesville, whether primary elections, special or general elections, the voters, in addition to the qualifications already prescribed, shall be registered as herein provided for. It shall be the duty of the clerk of the City of Barnesville to open at his office in said city, within thirty days from the date of approval of this Act, a book for the registration of voters for said City of Barnesville, and keep the same open at his office at all times when his office is open for the payment of taxes or transaction of city business, except as hereinafter provided. There shall be kept in said book a separate list of white and colored voters, and each person entitled to vote in said city shall subscribe in said book, which shall be arranged in alphabetical order, his or her name, age, place of residence, and occupation. Said clerk must not permit any one to register who is not entitled to do so, and if he knowingly permits this to be done, he shall be discharged from office or otherwise punished as the mayor and aldermen may decide. Such registration shall be permanent, and all names registered as herein prescribed shall remain upon said list and be qualified to vote in any election so long as said voter shall not become disqualified or his or her name be stricken from the registration list as hereinafter provided. Registration.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that said registration book shall be closed ten (10) days immediately preceding each election held in said city, whether the same be a primary election, special, or general election, after which time no one shall be allowed or permitted to register for such election, and not until after such election, when said book shall be reopened for the registration of voters. At all other times said book shall be kept open as herein provided. No person shall be allowed to
vote at any election held in said city unless he or she has registered prior to the closing of said books and his or her name appears upon the registration list. Time of registration.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that it shall be the duty of the clerk of said city clerk to check the registration lists from time to time as may be required by the mayor and aldermen of said City of Barnesville, and upon finding the name of any voter who has become disqualified by failure to pay taxes, removal from the city, or other legal cause, he shall furnish the mayor and aldermen of said city with a list of such names with the reasons for their disqualifications, and it shall be the duty of the said mayor and aldermen to revise said registration lists and determine whether the name of such voter should be stricken from the list, after the clerk has given five days' written notice to said voter of the time and place when said matter will be acted upon by said mayor and aldermen, said notice to be served either personally by any officer of said city authorized to serve city processes, or by mailing same to the last known address of the voter. At the time fixed in the notice the voter shall have the right to be heard by the said mayor and aldermen before any final action is taken, if he or she so desires. Checking and revising registration list.Notice and hearing to voter.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the mayor and aldermen of the City of Barnesville may prescribe such further rules and regulations with reference to registering, or the revision of the registration lists, as they may see fit and proper, and may create a board of registrars if deemed best, and may fix their duties and determine their compensation, and may delegate to and place upon said board of registrars any or all of the duties herein imposed upon the clerk or the mayor and aldermen, and they may place any or all of said duties upon any official or officials of said city they may designate, and provide additional compensation to be paid therefor if they see fit. Board of registrars.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: BARNESVILLE TAX LIMIT INCREASED; TAXES TO BUILD GRAMMAR SCHOOL; REFERENDUM.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to amend the Act entitled `An Act to confer additional powers upon the corporate authorities of the Town of Barnesville, in the County of Pike,' approved December 11, 1871; to increase the maximum tax levy of the City of Barnesville from one percentum to twelve and one half mills; to increase the maximum tax levy of the City of Barnesville from twelve and one half mills to seventeen and one half mills; to provide for the setting aside of three and one half mills each year for five years with which to build a grammar school for the City of Barnesville; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that the Act entitled An Act to confer additional powers upon the corporate authorities of the Town of Barnesville in the County of Pike, approved December 11, 1871, and as amended by the Act approved August 1, 1923, be and the same is amended as follows, to wit:

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that the following words contained in section 2 of the Act approved August 1, 1923, be stricken, to wit; That said mayor and council shall have power to levy such tax as in their judgment shall be necessary upon all property, both real and personal, within the limits of said town, provided, such tax shall not exceed twelve and one-half mills, and the following words substituted
therefor, to wit: That said mayor and council shall have power to levy such tax as in their judgment shall be necessary upon all property, both real and personal, within the limits of said town, provided, such tax shall not exceed seventeen and one half mills, and when so amended section 2 of the Act approved August 1, 1923, shall read as follows, to wit: Be it further enacted, that the words, provided such tax shall not exceed one per centum be and the same are hereby stricken from section 10 of said Act and the following words are hereby substituted for them, to wit: provided such tax shall not exceed twelve and one-half mills, so that said section when so amended shall read as follows: That said mayor and council shall have power to levy such tax as in their judgment shall be necessary upon all property, both real and personal, within the limits of said town, provided, such tax shall not exceed seventeen and one-half mills. Tax limit.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council for the period of five years beginning with the year 1930 shall set aside out of the money raised by taxation in the City of Barnesville three and one-half mills thereof which shall be held by the mayor and council of said city with which to build a grammar school for said city, and shall not be used for any other purpose other than for the building and equipping a grammar school. Fund for building Grammar School. See Sec. 6. post.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the passage of this Act the said authorities of the City of Barnesville shall have the power and authority to levy and collect taxes to the maximum amount provided in this Act. Authority to tax.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted that the provisions of this Act shall become effective immediately upon the passage thereof, subject to the referendum herein provided. Act effective when.

Sec. 6. However, be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that in event of the City of Barnesville selling and disposing of its electrical and power-distribution system or any part of same to any person, firm, or corporation,
then in such event the tax rate in the City of Barnesville shall not exceed sixteen mills upon property, both real and personal, within the city limits of Barnesville, and in such event three and one-half mills of the said sixteen mills for a period of five years beginning with the year 1930 shall be held by the mayor and council of said City of Barnesville with which to build a grammar school for said city and shall not be used for any purpose other than for the building and equipping a grammar school. Tax rate in case of sale of electrical and power system.Grammar School.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that before this Act shall become effective the same shall be submitted to the qualified voters of the City of Barnesville at an election to be called by the mayor and council of said city, to be held not more than fifty (50) days from the passage of this Act. Said election shall be as the elections for mayor and aldermen of said city, and the same rules and regulations shall apply. Those voters desiring to vote in favor of this Act shall have written or printed upon their ballots the words, For maximum tax rate of seventeen and one half mills, and those desiring to vote against this bill shall have written or printed on their ballots Against maximum tax rate of seventeen and one half mills. If a majority of those voting in said election shall vote in favor of this bill, the provisions of this bill shall become effective immediately, and the mayor and council are directed immediately to put in operation the provisions thereof. If a majority of those voting vote against this bill the same shall be void and of no effect. Referendum.
Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: BLUE RIDGE; SCHOOL FUND FROM SALE OF LIGHT AND WATERWORKS SYSTEM.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize, empower, and direct the board of school commissioners for the City of Blue Ridge to deliver and pay over to the board of trustees of any public-school district which may be created as provided by the Act of the General Assembly of this State approved August 19, 1919, and known as the Code of School Laws of this State, and all laws amendatory thereof, in which said public-school district the territory embraced within the corporate limits of the said City of Blue Ridge may be consolidated with any other school districts or parts of school districts, adjacent to said City of Blue Ridge, the sum of twenty-one thousand ($21,000.00) dollars realized from the sale of electric-light and waterworks systems of said City of Blue Ridge, and to provide how said fund shall be used and expended by said board of trustees, and for what purposes; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that the board of school commissioners for the City of Blue Ridge, a municipal corporation of Fannin County, Georgia, is hereby authorized, empowered, and directed to deliver and pay over to the board of trustees of any public-school district which may be created as provided by an Act of the General Assembly of this State, approved August 19, 1919, and known as the Code of School Laws of this State, and all Acts amendatory thereof, which includes the territory embraced within the corporate limits of the City of Blue Ridge, and which may be consolidated with any other school districts or parts of school districts, adjacent to said City of Blue Ridge, the sum of twenty-one thousand ($21,000.00) dollars, now on deposit with the Fannin County Bank, of Blue Ridge, Georgia, said county, which was realized from the sale of the electric-light and waterworks systems of the said City of Blue Ridge, to the
Toccoa Electric Power Company, a corporation of said county, and to be used and expended by said board of trustees of said public-school district, if and when the same is created, for the purpose of constructing, equipping, and maintaining public-school buildings, and acquiring and maintaining grounds upon which the same are located, and said public-school buildings, when so constructed and equipped, to be used for the operation and maintenance of public schools and a public-school system for said public-school district, and for other purposes. Fund on deposit, $21,000, to be used for schools.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the City of Brunswick and the County of Glynn, either jointly or severally, to establish, own, operate, or lease an airport in Glynn County, and to build, equip, and maintain the same out of any funds available and not otherwise appropriated; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act the City of Brunswick and the County of Glynn, either jointly or severally shall be authorized to establish, own, operate or lease an airport in Glynn County, and to build, equip, and maintain the same out of any funds available and not otherwise appropriated. Authority to establish airport.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: BRUNSWICK; PENSIONS FOR POLICEMEN AND FIREMEN.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the City of Brunswick; to authorize the payment of pensions to policemen and firemen; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the City of Brunswick is hereby authorized to grant and pay such members of the police department and fire department, who have served continuously for not less than twenty years in either of said respective departments, a pension payable monthly, in a sum of fifty per cent. of the average salary of such member of said department for the last three years of such service. Authority to grant pensions.
Sec. 2. All laws and parts thereof in conflict herewith are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: BRUNSWICK; POWERS AS TO STREETS, PARKS, ETC.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the City of Brunswick, Georgia; to confer certain additional powers therein named with respect to alleys and certain streets upon its city commission; to preserve and protect the parks and squares of said city; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia as follows, to wit:

Section 1. That at any time after the passage of this Act the City of Brunswick, a municipal corporation, acting under authority of its city commission, shall have the right and power to execute and deliver to Hercules Power
Company, a corporation of Wilmington, Delaware, a quitclaim deed conveying all of said city's right, title, and interest in and to certain areas in the northeastern portion of said city, shown upon the map of said city made in the year 1912 by J. Low Zachry, city engineer of said city, as streets and alleys, as follows, to wit: Authority to execute quitclaim deed to rights in named streets, and alleys.

item.p: (a) Couper Street from M Street on the south to N Street on the north.
(b) The two alleys in the blocks lying on each side of Couper Street between M Street on the south and N Street on the north.
(c) du Bignon Street commencing at a point 90 feet north of the northern line of L Street on the south to the southern line of N street on the north.
(d) N street from the eastern line of du Bignon Street on the west to the northern line of Town Commons on the east.
(e) O Street from the eastern line of du Bignon Street on the west to the northern line of Town Commons on the east.
(f) Colson, Harvey, Cook, Putnam, Stacy, and Cleveland Streets from the northern line of N Street on the south to the northern line of Town Commons on the north.

law.p: Sec. 2. That the city commission of said municipality is hereby empowered to authorize the conveyance to said Hercules Power Company of all or any portion of the streets and alleys described in the preceding section upon such terms and with such reservations or restrictions, and with or without consideration as said commission, in its absolute discretion, may deem to be wise and to the best interest of said city. Same.

Sec. 3. That with reference to any and all alleys shown upon the aforesaid Zachry map of said city, and of all of the subdivisions within the corporate limits of said city laid out subsequent to the date of said map, as well as of any
subdivisions that hereafter may be laid out, the city commissioner of said city is hereby authorized and empowered, in its absolute discretion, to convey by quitclaim to the owner or owners of property abutting on such alleys all right, title, and interest of said city in and to the same or any part thereof, where such alleys are not in actual use as alleys; and where any alley may be in actual use as an alley, and the owners of all property abutting the same on each side thereof shall agree that the same be closed, then the city commission of said city is authorized and empowered to order the same closed as an alley, and to convey all right, title, and interest of said city therein and thereto to the owners of the abutting property. Where the authority in this section conferred may be exercised by said city commission, one half of the alley or part thereof affected shall be conveyed to the owner or owners of the abutting property on one side thereof, and the other half to the owner or owners of the abutting property on the other side. Same.Closing alleys.

Sec. 4. That the said City of Brunswick shall not have the power or authority to convey, lease, sell, use, or alienate any of the parks or squares of said city, either now existing or hereinafter acquired, for any use, public or private, or for its own municipal use; and that said parks and squares of said city shall forever exist and be used for the benefit of the people for parks purposes, and for no other purpose; that no structure or building now erected on that portion of Queens Square south of Mansfield and east of Newcastle Streets shall be rebuilt thereon; that no street shall traverse or be extended, or pass through, or exist in, on, or through the following parks in said city, to wit: Queens, Hanover, Kings, Hillsboro, Wright, and Halifax Squares, and Magnolia, Orange, and Palmetto Parks, as named upon the maps of said city, save and except Newcastle and Mansfield Streets as now traversing Queens Square; and Mansfield, George, and Prince Streets as now traversing Hillsboro, Wright, and Halifax Squares, respectively, shall not come within the provisions of this Act; that the present status and existance of Prince and Newcastle Streets
through said Kings Square is left undetermined by this Act; but said city is hereby prohibited from the extension or construction of any street-paving through said Kings Square on either of said streets, save that said city shall not be prohibited from the temporary repair, from time to time, of any roadways now traversing said square. Parks and squares not to be alienated.

Sec. 5. That the following words: If as many as twenty-five per cent. of the persons who were qualified voters in the last city election shall present a written petition to the secretary of the commission, naming the commissioner or commissioners whose recall is desired, and specifying in such petition the reasons why they think such commissioner or commissioners should be recalled, then the secretary shall at once publish a notice in the official newspaper, stating that such a petition has been filed with him, and that a book for the registration of voters who may desire to vote in the election will be opened on a named day, which day shall be twelve days after the first publication of the notice. Such notice shall be published daily for ten days, excluding Sundays; appearing in section twelve of that certain Act entitled An Act to amend the charter of the City of Brunswick, to change the corporate name of said city, to abolish offices of mayor and alderman and certain offices of said city created by legislative enactment, to provide for a commission manager form of government for said city, and for other purposes, approved August 11, 1920, be and the same are hereby stricken; and there shall be and are hereby inserted in lieu thereof the following words, to wit: If as many as twenty-five per cent. of the persons who were qualified voters in the last city election shall present a written petition to the secretary of the commission, naming the commissioner or commissioners whose recall is desired, then the secretary shall immediately file the same; and said secretary shall twelve days thereafter open the registration book of said city for said recall election, unless the said twelfth day shall fall on Sunday, in which event he shall open the same on the following day. It shall be the duty
of the secretary, upon the filing of said petition, to at once publish a notice in the official newspaper, stating that such petition has been filed with him, and the date of the opening of said registration book, and said notice shall be published for at least five daily issues in said newspaper prior to the opening of said registration; but the failure of the secretary to publish said notice, or the publication thereof, as herein required, shall not invalidate said recall election. That said recall petition shall specify the reason or reasons why petitioners think such commissioner or commissioners should be recalled, but the reasons assigned therein shall not invalidate said recall petition. Recall of commissioner.
Sec. 6. That all laws in conflict herewith are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to repeal all laws and amendments to laws heretofore passed incorporating the Town of Buford, in the County of Gwinnett, and to establish a new charter for the same, approved December 23, 1896, and as amended by an Act approved August 8, 1903, and as amended by an Act approved August 11, 1913, and as amended by an Act approved August 7, 1920, by amending section 18 of said Act and amendments thereto, so as to authorize the mayor and council of the City of Buford to pave, macadamize, or otherwise improve the streets, parks, and sidewalks of said city or any part thereof, and to assess adjoining property on each side to pay one third each for the cost of macadamizing or improving any of the streets or parks of said city, the city to pay the remaining one third thereof, and to assess the adjoining property to pay the total cost of paving, macadamizing, curbing,
or improving any of the sidewalks of said city or any part thereof; and to provide for the levy and collection of assessments against adjoining property for such improvements to streets, parks, or sidewalks; and for other purposes:
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act section 18 of said original act as amended by the Act approved August 7th, 1920 (Georgia Laws 1920, page 806-814), inclusive, be amended by striking the words two thirds of the in the 49th and 50th lines of said section, after the word assess and before the word costs (Acts 1920, page 810), and by striking the words the city to pay the remaining one third of the cost thereof, in the 52nd and 53rd lines of said section, after the word sidewalks and before the word and, so that said section when amended shall read as follows: Sec. 18. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council of said city shall have full power and authority to lay off, vacate, open, alter, cut, pave, and keep in good repair roads, alleys, streets, sidewalks, cross-walks, squares, drains, and gutters for the use of the public or any of the citizens thereof; and to improve and light the same; regulate the width of sidewalks or the streets, and to order the sidewalks, crossings, footings, drains, and gutters to be curbed and paved and kept in good order and repair, firm and clean, by the owner or occupants of the real property adjacent thereto; to prevent injury or annoyance to the public or individuals from anything dangerous, offensive, unwholesome; to prevent hogs, cattle, horses, sheep and other animals and fowls of all kinds from running at large in said city; to protect places of divine worship wherever held in said city, to abate or cause to be abated anything which in the opinion of the whole council, shall be a nuisance; to regulate the keeping of gunpowder and other combustibles; to provide in or near the city places for the burial of the dead and to regulate interments therein; to provide for the regular building of houses or other structures;
to provide regulations guarding against danger or damage by fire, and to equip a fire department; to protect the person and property of the citizens of said city, and for this purpose to appoint a police force to assist the marshal in the discharge of his duties; to prescribe the powers and define the duties of the officers appointed by them; to fix their term of service and compensation where not provided for in this Act; to adopt rules and regulations and government of its own body, not in conflict with the laws of this State; to provide a revenue for said city and for the annual assessment of taxable property therein and the mode and manner of valuing such property for taxation; provided, however, that no tax-assessor shall be apointed who is not a freeholder and who is not an elector under this Act. The mayor and council of said city shall have full power and authority, in their discretion, to grade, pave, macadamize and otherwise improve the travel or drainage of the sidewalks, streets, alleys, and public parks of said city; and, to carry into effect the authority herein granted, the mayor and council shall have full power and authority to assess two thirds of the cost of paving, macadamizing, or otherwise improving the streets of said city against the real estate abutting on said streets, that is one third on each side, the city to pay the remaining one third of the cost thereof, and to assess the total cost of paving macadamizing or otherwise improving the sidewalks of said city against the real estate abutting on such sidewalks; and any street-railroad company or other railroad company having tracks running through or across the streets of said city shall be required to pave, macadamize, or otherwise improve such street in such proportion as the mayor and council shall provide by ordinance. Said mayor and council shall have full power and authority to adopt by ordinance such a system of equalizing assessments on real estate for the purposes above stated as may be just and proper, estimating the total cost of each improvement made, and prorating the cost thereof on real estate according to the frontage on the streets or portion of streets so improved, or according to the area of value of said estate, either or all as may be determined
by ordinance. The amount of each assessment on each piece of real estate shall be a lien on such real estate from the date of the passage of the ordinances providing for the work and making the assessment. Said mayor and council shall have full power and authority to enforce the collection of any assessment so made for work either upon the streets or sidewalks, by execution issued by the city clerk against the real estate so assessed against the owner at the date of the passage of the ordinance making such assessment, which execution may be levied by the marshal of said city on such real estate, and, after advertising and other proceedings as in case of other sales, the same shall be sold at public outcry to the highest bidder. Said sale shall vest absolute title in the purchaser. The marshal shall execute a deed to the purchaser and shall have authority to eject the occupants and put the purchaser in possession; provided the owner of said real estate shall have the right to file his affidavit, denying the whole or any part of the amount he admits is due, which amount admitted to be due, with all cost, shall be paid before the affidavit is received, and the affidavit shall be returned to the superior court of Gwinnett County and there tried and the issue determined as in case of illegality, subject to the penalty provided for illegality filed for the purpose of delay. The mayor and council shall have authority to pave and contract to pave the whole surface of the streets or sidewalks without giving any railroad company or other property owner or occupant of the street the option of paving such streets or sidewalks themselves. The lien of the assessment on abutting property and on street railroads or other railroad company for street or sidewalk paving, curbing, macadamizing, grading, or draining shall have rank and priority of payment next in point of dignity to liens for taxes, such liens to date from the passage of the ordinance authorizing the execution of the work in each case. Said mayor and council shall have power and authority to prescribe by ordinance such rules as they in their discretion think necessary to grade, pave, drain, or macadamize or curb the streets, sidewalks, and alleys of said city, to enforce
by execution the cost thereof against adjacent property owner and railroad company, and to provide how the agent or owners thereof shall be served with notice by personal service or publication. Assessments for paving, etc.Lien of assessment.Collection of assessment.Affidavit of illegality.Rank of lien.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act, be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: CAIRO; POWER TO DISPOSE OF PUBLIC UTILITIES LIMITED; ELECTION.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act creating the charter of the City of Cairo, approved August 6, 1906, providing for the limitation of the power and authority of the mayor and council of the City of Cairo to sell, lease, or otherwise dispose of any public utilities owned by the City of Cairo; to provide for an election to pass upon the selling, leasing, or other disposition of the same; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the mayor and council of the City of Cairo shall not have authority to sell, lease, or otherwise dispose of any of the public utilities owned by the City of Cairo, including the light plant, water plant, or franchise for the operation, distribution, or sale of electricity or water, until such proposed sale, lease, or disposition of the same has been favorably voted upon by two thirds of those voting in a special election to pass upon the same; which election shall be called by the mayor and council not less than thirty days nor more than sixty days after the mayor and council shall have approved a proposed sale, lease, or other disposition of the said properties or any of them; and the registration books shall be open from the day of the calling of such
election until five days prior thereto, and all citizens qualified to vote under existing laws at the time of such election who have registered for said special election shall be entitled to vote therein. Said election shall be conducted and the result declared in the same manner as election for mayor and council. Sale of public utilities not authorized without election and two-thirds vote.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws or parts of laws in conflict herewith be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the City of Calhoun, in the County of Gordon, State of Georgia, approved August 18, 1919, to define and establish the territorial limits of said City of Calhoun, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that an Act entitled An Act to amend the charter of the City of Calhoun, County of Gordon, State of Georgia, to define the territorial limits of said City of Calhoun, approved August 18, 1919, be and the same is hereby amended by extending said territorial limits of said City of Calhoun as follows: Beginning at a point marked by an iron pipe in the south side of the Rome and Calhoun highway and running north 59 minutes along McConnell Street for a distance of 2035.4 feet to an iron pipe in the east side of McConnell Street, thence north 68 degrees 30 minutes west to an iron pipe a distance of 299 feet, thence north 1 degree 30 minutes west to an iron bar a distance of 435 feet, thence 86 degrees 40 minutes east to an iron pipe in the south side of the Calhoun and Oostanaula Road, a distance of 301 feet, thence north 59 minutes west along
the extension of McConnell Street to the corner of the present territorial limits of the said City of Calhoun. New territory.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: CALHOUN; SALE OR LEASE OF WATERWORKS AND LIGHTING SYSTEM; FRANCHISES FOR USE OF STREETS, ETC.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the City of Calhoun, in Gordon County, Georgia, approved August 20, 1918, to provide for the manner of sale or lease of the system of waterworks and lighting system owned by the City of Calhoun; to provide for the granting of franchises to the use of any street or streets or any other passageway, for railroad, telegraph, telephone, gas, water, and electric-light purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same as follows:

Section 1. That section 63 of the Act creating a new charter for the City of Calhoun, in Gordon County, Georgia, approved August 20, 1918, be amended by striking said entire section, and inserting in lieu thereof the following: Sec. 63. That no contract for the sale or lease of the system of waterworks or lighting system owned by the City of Calhoun, nor shall any franchise for the use of any street or other passageways or easements for railroad, telegraph, telephone, gas, water, or electric-light purposes, be entered into, granted, renewed, or extended between the City of Calhoun and any person, firm, or corporation, except by ordinance which must be authorized and approved by a
majority of the registered voters voting thereon at a general or special municipal election, at which the question to be submitted to the voters shall be printed in appropriate form on such ballot, and the said general and special municipal election shall never be held in connection with, or upon the same day, with any State, county, or congressional election or primary. Provided that if an election is held under this section concerning a franchise, the expenses thereof shall be paid by the person, firm, or corporation seeking such franchise, and the payment of said expense must be secured to the satisfaction of the mayor and aldermen of said city before such election is held. Substitute for Sec. 63 of charter.Election to authorize sale or lease of public utilities, or franchise for use of streets, etc.Expenses of election for franchise.

blockquote.p: Sec. 63(a). Nothing in this Act shall be held to invalidate any ordinance or contract heretofore passed and entered into between the City of Calhoun and any person, firm, or corporation now existing, but all ordinances, resolutions, agreements and contracts heretofore passed, agreed to, or entered into by said city are hereby declared to be valid. Existing ordinances and contracts [Illegible Text] valid.

law.p: Sec. 2. That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: CANTON; FRANCHISES IN STREETS, ETC., TIME LIMIT REPEALED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the Town of Canton in Cherokee County, as granted by Act of the General Assembly, approved August 1st, 1922, and contained in Georgia Laws 1922, pages 604 to 627, by striking from section 32 thereof, relating to the granting of franchises, the following proviso, to wit: Provided, however, that the same shall not be granted for a longer term than twenty (20) years; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the charter of the Town of Canton, in Cherokee County, as granted by Act of the General Assembly approved August 1st, 1922, and contained in Georgia Laws 1922, pages 604 to 627, be and is hereby amended by striking from section 32 thereof, relating to the granting of franchises, the following proviso, to wit: Provided, however, that the same shall not be granted for a longer term than twenty (20) years, so that said section as amended shall read as follows: Sec. 32. Be it further enacted that said mayor and council shall have the power and authority to grant franchises, permits, easements and rights of way in or under and over the streets, alleys, lanes, sidewalks, parks and other property of the town, upon such terms, reservations, and conditions as the said mayor and council may fix. Franchises heretofore granted by the mayor and council of the Town of Canton are continued of force for and against the Town of Canton created by this Act. Repeal of time limit of franchises.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: CARROLLTON; CONTRACTS, PURCHASES, PAYMENTS; CLERK'S DUTIES; RECORDER; TAX COLLECTION; SCHOOL TAXES.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act to establish a charter for the City of Carrollton, Georgia, approved September 9, 1891, and all Acts amendatory thereto; to prescribe the duties of the mayor of the City of Carrollton, the clerk; to provide for a recorder of the City of Carrollton and to define his duties; to prescribe the time of closing the tax-books of said City of Carrollton, Georgia, that all taxes due City of Carrollton, Georgia, unpaid on December
20th of each year, must bear interest at the rate of seven per centum per annum, and to prescribe the manner and time of enforcing the collection of said taxes in said city; to amend an Act of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia approved August 7, 1912, amending the Act of November 26, 1886, establishing a system of public schools of the City of Carrollton, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, so as to provide for the rate of taxation for school purposes of said city not to exceed sixty-five one-hundredths of one per cent. per annum.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority aforesaid, that immediately from and after the passage of this Act the charter of the City of Carrollton is hereby amended as follows:

item.p: (1) The Mayor. Be it enacted that the mayor of the City of Carrollton must approve all contracts and purchases to be made for and on behalf of the City of Carrollton, when and after same is authorized by the mayor and city council in a meeting assembled; and the distribution of any and all funds must be by voucher, countersigned by the mayor of the City of Carrollton, or in his absence, or his disqualification for any cause, by the mayor pro tem. Mayor's approval required for contracts and purchases.Vouchers.

(2) There shall be a clerk of the mayor and city council of Carrollton, who must be elected annually by the mayor and city council of Carrollton at the first meeting night after the general election held in October each year. The clerk shall have attained the age of twenty-one years before he shall be qualified to act as clerk, and to take and subscribe to an oath, and shall give a bond in some surety company licensed to do business in the State of Georgia, in the sum of fifteen thousand ($15,000.00) dollars, payable to the mayor and city council, conditioned to faithfully, fairly, and fully discharge all duties as clerk, and to account for all funds coming into his hands as clerk. Clerk; election, Oath, bond.

(2a) The further additional duties of the clerk shall be as follows: to keep a complete, itemized, and accurate statement of all funds received, and disbursed; to keep a complete itemized, daily cash-book, showing the receipts, the source thereof, and daily disbursements, together with each daily balance, and he must deposit all funds belonging to the City of Carrollton daily in such bank, or banks as may be designated by the mayor and city council of Carrollton; and he is hereby authorized to issue executions for the nonpayment of taxes or license that may be due the City of Carrollton. The clerk must keep a permanent record of all taxes, or special license paid into the City of Carrollton, and must collect all taxes and license at the time so fixed by law, or as soon thereafter as possible. He shall keep his office open from eight o'clock a. m. until five o'clock p. m., and any and all records of the City of Carrollton shall be open for inspection to any resident or taxpayer in said City of Carrollton during said hours; and it shall be the duty of the clerk to furnish any information to any taxpayer of the City of Carrollton that he may desire relative to the affairs of said City of Carrollton during office hours. The clerk must make up and submit to the mayor and city council of Carrollton at its first meeting in each month a complete, itemized, detailed statement of the income and disbursements of the City of Carrollton, and when approved must be spread upon the minutes of the City of Carrollton. A summary of the financial condition of the City of Carrollton must be published quarterly, and more often if ordered by the mayor and city council of Carrollton. The clerk must devote his entire time to the affairs of the City of Carrollton, and shall be paid such salary as may be fixed by the mayor and city council of Carrollton; however, in no event, shall same exceed two hundred fifty dollars per month. Duties.Salary limit.

(3) That the tax-books of the City of Carrollton must be closed annually on December 20th of each year, at 6:00 o'clock p. m., and all taxes or license due the said City of Carrollton after that date shall bear interest at the rate
of seven per cent. from said date, and the clerk must, immediately after said date, issue executions against all persons, firms, or corporations for any and all taxes or license due said City of Carrollton. Said executions shall bear interest at the rate of seven per cent. per annum from December 20th each year until paid. That on or by January 1st each year thereafter the clerk shall have any and all executions so issued that are unpaid recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of Carroll County, Georgia, on the general execution docket of said county, and, after being recorded, deliver immediately all of said executions so issued to the chief of police or marshal of said City of Carrollton, for collection, taking his receipt therefor. The sum of $1.00 cost shal be added for issuing said execution, which sum, when collected, shall go into the general funds of the City of Carrollton. Tax executions.

(4) In addition to the duties of the chief of police, or marshal, already prescribed, it shall be his further duty, immediately upon receipt of any and all executions for taxes, or license, to immediately proceed to collect same, by levy, and sale after advertisement, or otherwise. Each day he shall make a written report of any and all collections of executions so issued and placed in his hands to the city clerk; and within sixty days from January 1st of each year he shall make a full, final, and complete written report to the mayor and city council of Carrollton, through the clerk of said mayor and city council of said city, of all tax fi. fas. or license fi. fas. delivered to him by the clerk, and in case of levy of any execution the sum of $3.00 shall be added as cost, in addition to all cost of collection, to be paid by the defendant as now provided by law which said cost shall be paid into the general funds of the City of Carrollton. Collection of tax executions.

(5) There is hereby established the office of city recorder for the City of Carrollton, who shall be an attorney at law having not less than one year actual experience as an attorney at law, who may also be the city attorney, who shall be elected by the mayor and city council in a meeting duly assembled; and when so elected and qualified he must
preside over the trial of all cases in the police court, under the restrictions, regulations, and power so imposed upon the mayor, or a member of the city council in like capacity. He shall be the presiding officer in said court, except when disqualified or when absent, when the mayor may preside or designate one of the city council of Carrollton to preside over said court, with full powers as the city recorder. The mayor and city council shall fix the salary of the said city recorder, and shall have the power to define his duties under ordinance not in conflict with this Act. His term of office, when elected, shall be for two years. Said city recorder, when elected and qualified, shall have all the powers and authority conferred upon him, as city recorder, as now exercised by the mayor, or mayor and city council of Carrollton under and by virtue of said charter of the City of Carrollton and the several amendments thereto. Before entering upon the discharge of his duties as city recorder the person elected and appointed shall take and subscribe the following oath: I do solemnly swear that I will administer justice without respect to persons, and do equal right to the rich and poor, and that I will faithfully and impartially perform and discharge all duties which may be required of me as city recorder of the City of Carrollton, according to the best of my knowledge and ability and understanding, agreeably to the laws and constitution of the State of Georgia and of the United States. So help me God. Recorder.Oath of recorder.

law.p:
Sec. 2. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the last sentence in section two of the Act of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, approved August 7, 1912 (amending the Act of November 26, 1886, establishing a system of public schools for Carrollton, Georgia), which amendatory act is headed Carrollton, City of, Public School system amended, being No. 398 of the printed acts of 1912, pages 712 and 713, beginning with the word provided and ending with the words legal claims, be and the same is hereby repealed, and
that the following words are hereby enacted and inserted in lieu thereof: Provided that the rate of taxation under this Act shall not exceed sixty-five (65) one hundredths of one percentum per annum; and that when collected the collecting officer of said mayor and city council shall pay same over to the treasurer of the board of education of Carrollton, Georgia, which shall then constitute a fund to be expended by said board in the payment of all legitimate expenses in running said schools and other legal claims. School tax.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted that all parts of the charter of the City of Carrollton at variance or in conflict with this amendment are repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to amend, consolidate, and supersede the several Acts incorporating the City of Cartersville, in Bartow County, State of Georgia; to create a new charter and municipal government for said corporation; to declare the rights and powers of the same, and for other purposes, approved August 1, 1906, by striking from section 58 of said Act, pertaining to the granting of franchises, easements, and rights of way over, in, under, and on the public streets, lanes, alleys, sidewalks, parks, and other property of said city, all that portion thereof beginning with and following the word Provided, in the sixth line, and which reads as follows: Provided that no such franchise shall be granted for a term of more than twenty years, nor without compensation to said city, to be provided for in said franchise ordinance, which compensation shall not be less than the following per cent. annually, received from or on account of said franchise or its use, to wit: For the first five years, one per cent. per annum;
for the second five years, two and one half per cent. per annum; for the next ten years, five per cent. per annum. This compensation shall be paid annually and a failure to thus pay the same shall work a forfeiture of said franchise; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that an Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to amend, consolidate, and supersede the several Acts incorporating the City of Cartersville, in Bartow County, State of Georgia; to create a new charter and municipal government for said corporation; to declare the rights and powers of the same, and for other purposes, approved August 1, 1906, be and the same is hereby amended by striking from section 58 of said Act, pertaining to the granting of franchises, easements, and rights of way over, under, and on the public streets, lanes, alleys, sidewalks, parks, and other property of said city, all that portion thereof beginning with and following the word Provided, in the sixth line, and which reads as follows: Provided that no such franchise shall be granted for a term of more than twenty years, nor without compensation to said city, to be provided for in said franchise ordinance, which compensation shall not be less than the following per cent. annually, received from or on account of said franchise or its use, to wit: For the first five years, one per cent. per annum; for the second five years, two and one half per cent. per annum; for the next ten years, five per cent. per annum. This compensation shall be paid annually, and a failure to thus pay the same shall work a forfeiture of said franchise; so that when amended said section 58 will read as follows to wit: Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the mayor and alderman of said city shall have power to grant franchises, easements, and rights of way over, in, under, and on the public streets, lanes, alleys, sidewalks, parks, and other property of said city, on such terms and conditions as they may fix. Repeal of provisions as to term of franchises. and as to compensation.

Be it further enacted that all ordinances or resolutions providing for the granting of such franchises as contemplated in said section 58 shall be passed and become effective only when passed in the manner provided in the city charter for the passage of such ordinances or resolutions, and subject to the provisions for referendum contained in section 35 of the charter of 1917 of said city as amended, if amended by the General Assembly at this present session. Referendum.
Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act, are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to amend, consolidate, and supersede the several acts incorporating the City of Cartersville, in the County of Bartow, State of Georgia; to create a new charter and municipal government for said corporation, to declare the rights and powers of the same; to provide for the creation of a board of mayor and aldermen for the administration of the affairs of said city; to provide means by which legislation can be initiated and franchises granted, to fix salaries of officers and employees, to provide means of electing a school board, and for other purposes, approved August 20, 1917, and the Acts amendatory thereof, so as to provide: For the division of the City of Cartersville, Georgia, into four wards, as follows: First Ward that section of Cartersville, Georgia, east of main-line track of the N. C. St. L. Railroad (W. A. Railroad) and north of East Market Street; Second Ward, that section of Cartersville, Georgia, east of main-line track of N. C. St. L. Railroad (W. A. Railroad) and south of East Market Street; Third Ward, that section of Cartersville,
Georgia, west of main-line track of N. C. St. L. Railroad (W. A. Railroad) and south of West Market Street; and Fourth Ward, that section of Cartersville, Georgia, west of main-line track of N. C. St. L. Railroad (W. A. Railroad) and north of West Market street; and to provide for the election of a mayor and four aldermen, and requiring statements of candidacies to specify the position sought by each candidate, that is whether for mayor or for alderman from one of abovespecified wards, so that the mayor shall be elected from the city at large, and so that the mayor shall be elected from each of aforesaid wards, and providing that the mayor and aldermen so elected must receive a majority vote of all the qualified voters participating and voting in any general election in the City of Cartersville, Georgia; and to provide that the mayor and aldermen thus elected shall at their first meeting, or as soon as possible thereafter, elect from said four aldermen, two members of the school board of Cartersville, Georgia, for the ensuing two years, only one of whom shall reside west of the N. C. St. L. Railroad (W. A. Railroad) main-line track, and only one of whom shall reside east of said track; and to provide for submitting this amendment to a vote of the duly qualified and registered voters of the City of Cartersville, Georgia, prior to November 1st, 1929; and that if the same is approved and adopted by a favorable majority vote of those voters casting their ballots in such election, then the same shall go into effect for the election in December, 1929, of mayor and aldermen of the City of Cartersville, Georgia, and shall govern all such subsequent elections; and for the purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the Act, approved August 20, 1917, entitled An Act to amend, consolidate, and supersede the several Acts incorporating the City of Cartersville, in the County of Bartow, State of Georgia; to create a new charter and municipal government for said corporation; to declare the rights
and powers of the same; to provide for the creation of a board of mayor and aldermen for the administration of the affairs of said city; to provide means by which legislation can be initiated and franchises granted; to fix the salaries of officers and employees, to provide means of electing a school board, and for other purposes, be and the same is hereby amended as follows: Act of 1917 (Ga. L. 1917, p. 555) amended.

Sec. 2. That aforesaid Act, approved August 20, 1917, and all Acts amendatory thereof, and all previous Acts and amendments creating charters and governments for said city, not heretofore repealed and superseded, are hereby repealed and superseded, in so far as the provisions of any of said Acts conflict with this Act. Repeal of conflicting provisions.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, that the City of Cartersville, Georgia, be and the same is hereby divided into four wards as follows: First Ward, that section of Cartersville, Georgia, east of main-line track of the N. C. St. L. Railroad (W. A. Railroad) and north of East Market Street; Second Ward, that section of Cartersville, Georgia, east of main-line truck of N. C. St. L. Railroad (W. A. Railroad) and south of East Market Street; Third Ward, that section of Cartersville, Georgia, west of main-line track of N. C. St. L. Railroad (W. A. Railroad) and south of West Market Street; and Fourth Ward, that section of Cartersville, Georgia, west of main-line track of N. C. St. L. Railroad (W. A. Railroad) and north of West Market Street. Wards.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, that the municipal government of said City of Cartersville shall consist of and be vested in a mayor and four aldermen; that the present mayor and the two aldermen of said city who were elected in December, 1927, shall continue in the offices to which they were elected until the first Wednesday in January, 1930, or until their successors are elected and qualified, and said mayor and said aldermen shall exercise all the powers and authority conferred upon the board of aldermen of the City of Cartersville, created by charter, and on the third Wednesday
in December, 1929, there shall be elected one mayor from the city at large, and there shall be elected one alderman from each of the aforesaid wards, in said city, who shall continue in office until the first Wednesday in January, 1932, or until their successors are elected and qualified, as herein provided and as is provided by the former charters of said city. Mayor and four aldermen; election.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, that aforesaid Act approved August 20, 1917, and section 3 of the same, is hereby amended so as to add to said section the following words, to wit: Except as hereinafter provided for in the selection of the two aldermen who shall be ex-officio members of the board of education, so that said section as amended shall read as follows, to wit: Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, that the system of public schools as now established and existing in said city is preserved, together with all provisions for the financing of the same, and the method of paying and transmitting the school funds raised by the State and apportioned to the city shall remain unchanged by this Act, except as hereinafter provided for the selection of the two aldermen who shall be ex-officio members of the board of education. Sec. 3 of Act of 1917 amended.Two aldermen ex-officio members of board of education.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, that section 4 of aforesaid Act is hereby amended so as to strike from the fifth and sixth lines of said section the following words, to wit: The two members of the board of aldermen, other than the mayor, and insert therein in lieu thereof the following words, to wit: The board of aldermen of the City of Cartersville, consisting of the mayor and four aldermen, shall at their first meeting, or as soon as possible thereafter, elect from said four aldermen, other than the mayor, two members of the school board of Cartersville, Georgia, for the ensuing two years, only one of whom shall reside west of the N. C. St. L. Railroad (W. A. Railroad) main-line track, and only one of whom shall reside east of said track, and said two members; so that said section as amended shall read as follows, to wit: Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, that beginning with the election and qualification of the
first board of aldermen provided for in this Act, and thereafter, the board of education shall consist of five members chosen and selected in the following manner, to wit: The board of aldermen of the City of Cartersville, consisting of the mayor and four aldermen, shall at their first meeting, or as soon as possible thereafter, elect from said four aldermen, other than the mayor, two members of the school board of Cartersville, Georgia, for the ensuing two years, only one of whom shall reside west of the N. C. St. L. Railroad (W. A. Railroad) main-line track, and only one of whom shall reside east of said track, and said two members shall be ex-officio members of the board of education and shall be qualified to act and enter upon their duties as members of the board of education immediately after taking the oath and qualifying as aldermen, and without additional oath or ceremony, and shall not be subject to removal except by recall as hereinafter provided. The other three members of the board of education shall be elected by the board of aldermen as they are now elected by the board of commissioners, and at the time or times as now provided, and their terms of office shall remain as now, and they shall not be subject to removal except by the unanimous vote of the board of aldermen. Provided, that it is not the intention of this Act and it shall not be so construed as to terminate or alter the terms of the several members of the board of education as it is now constituted. The board shall select its own president or chairman from among the three members appointed by the board of aldermen. Sec. 4 amended.Election of of members of board of education.Chairman of board.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, that section 9 of said Act is hereby amended so as to strike the word two in the fourth line of said section, between the word and and the word aldermen, and by striking out the word hereinafter in the fifth line of said section, between the word as and the word provided, and inserting in lieu thereof the words therein and herein, so that said section as amended shall read as follows, to wit: Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, that a governing board, to be known as The Board of Aldermen of the City of Cartersville, is hereby
created, and shall consist of a mayor and four aldermen, who shall be elected by the qualified voters of said city at large as therein and herein provided. They shall have, besides the powers herein conferred, all powers of government and other powers now conferred upon the board of commissioners, except as otherwise provided in this Act. They shall serve without compensation. Sec. 9 amended.Aldermen, number of, changed.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, that section 15 of said Act is amended so as to insert after the words required bond, in the seventeenth line of said section, the following words, to wit: and that he is offering for election as mayor from the city at large, or as alderman from one of the wards of said city, as the case may be, and in the event he is offering for such alderman he shall specify the ward in which he maintains his residence, so that said Act as amended shall read as follows, to wit: Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, that on the second Wednesday in December, 1917, and on the second Wednesday in December every second year thereafter, a primary election shall be held by the election managers at the court-house in said city (or such other convenient and central place as the board of aldermen may provide by ordinance for holding elections if the court-house should become unavailable for the purpose), under the regulations as hereinafter provided, for the nomination of candidates for membership of the board of aldermen, to be voted for at the regular election. Every person desiring to become a candidate shall file or cause to be filed with the election managers, not later than ten nor earlier than twenty days before the primary election, a statement of his candidacy and a certificate sworn to by him that he is qualified to fill the office to which he seeks election, and that he can make the required bond, and that he is offering for election as mayor from the city at large, or as alderman from one of the wards of said city, as the case may be, and in the event he is offering for such alderman he shall specify the ward in which he maintains his residence. He or some other person qualified to vote in the city shall file a certificate of no less than ten persons
qualified to vote and who are property taxpayers in the city, that his candidacy is desired by them and that to the best of their knowledge he is qualified to fill the office to which he seeks election. Sec. 15 amended.Primary election, to nominate mayor and aldermen.Statement of candidacy.See Sec. 10. post.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, that said Act is amended so as to strike from the third, fourth and fifth lines of section 16 of said Act the following words, to wit: more than six qualified persons comply with the requirements of section 15, and insert in lieu thereof the following words, to wit: more than two qualified persons comply with the requirements of section 15 as candidates for mayor, or more than two qualified persons comply with the requirements of section 15 as candidates for aldermen from any one or more of the four wards established in said city, so that said section as amended will read as follows, to wit: Sec. 16. Be it further enacted, that if, during the time allowed in section 15 for the filing of statements and certificates by those desiring to become candidates, more than two qualified persons comply with the requirements of section 15 as candidates for mayor, or more than two qualified persons comply with the requirements of section 15 as candidates for aldermen from any one or more of the four wards established in said city, the election managers shall hold a primary election as provided in said section, and shall cause the names of all such persons to be printed as candidates upon the ticket to be used in the primary election, and shall cause to be published at least once in a newspaper published in the city the name of candidates who will appear on the ticket at the primary election, or post written notice thereof at some conspicuous place at the city-hall and two or more other conspicuous places within the city at least five days before the day of the election. No person's name who has not complied with section 15 of this Act shall be placed upon the ticket. The election managers shall not permit the tickets prepared for any election to be distributed before the day of the election. Sec. 16 amended.Tickets, requirements as to.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, that said Act is hereby amended so as to strike from the first and second lines of
section 19 the following words, to wit: only six, or less than six, persons comply with section 15, and insert in lieu thereof the following words, to wit: only one or two persons comply with section 15 in offering themselves as candidates for mayor or candidates for aldermen from each separate ward of said city, as herein established, and comply with said section 15; so that said section as amended shall read as follows, to wit: Sec. 19. Be it further enacted, that in the event only one or two persons comply with section 15 in offering themselves as candidates for mayor or candidates for aldermen from each separate ward of said city, as herein established, and comply with said section 15 as to filing statements and certificates, no primary election shall be held, but the names of all such persons shall be placed on the ballots as candidates for the board of aldermen in the general election, and shall be voted for as such, unless any one or more should expressly withdraw before the election. Sec. 19 amended.When no primary election.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, that said Act is amended so as to strike from the first line of section 20 of said Act the following words, to wit: six persons and inserting in lieu thereof the following words, to wit: two persons offering for mayor from the city at large and two persons from each ward in said City of Cartersville offering for aldermen from each of said established wards, and by striking from the fifth line of said section 20 the word six between the word the and the word shall, and inserting in lieu thereof the following words, to wit: ten, or less than ten, in the event that not more than one person shall offer for the office of mayor or the office of one or more of the offices of alderman from any specified ward; and by inserting in the thirteenth line of said section, between the word votes and the word shall, the following words, to wit: for mayor or having the same number of votes for alderman from any aforesaid specified ward, and by striking from the sixteenth line of said section, after the word then and the word six, and inserting in lieu thereof the following words, to wit: ten, or more than two for
mayor, or two from each separate ward, so that said section as amended shall read as follows, to wit: Sec. 20. Be it further enacted, that the two persons offering for mayor from the city at large and two person from each ward in said City of Cartersville offering for aldermen from each of said established wards, receiving the highest number of votes at the primary election held under the provisions of section 16, shall be declared the nominees to be voted for at the general election, and the names of the ten, or less than ten, in the event that not more than one person shall offer for the office of mayor, or the office of one or more of the offices of alderman from any specified ward, shall be placed on the ballots as candidates for the board of aldermen at the general election, unless any one or more shall expressly withdraw before the election. Provided that in case of a tie, in order to obtain the necessary number of candidates for the general election, it becomes necessary to take one or two or more persons having the same number of votes, then the names of all the aforesaid persons having the same number of votes for mayor, or having the same number of votes for alderman from any aforesaid specified ward, shall be printed on the official ballot as candidates for the general election, together with the names of all persons receiving a higher number of votes, even though it makes the number of candidates more than ten, or more than two for mayor, or two from each separate ward. Sec. 20 amended.Who declared nominees.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, that said Act is amended so as to strike from the first and second lines of section 22 of said Act the words three candidates, and insert in lieu thereof the words one candidate for mayor from said city at large and one candidate for alderman from each of aforesaid wards, and by inserting in said section and in the fifth line thereof, between the word votes and the word shall, the following words, to wit: for mayor, and by inserting after the word candidates, in the seventh line of said section, and before the word receive, in the eighth line of said section, the following words, to wit: for mayor or for alderman from any ward specified in
this Act; and by striking from the seventeenth and the remaining lines of said section the following words, to wit: provided further that in the event less than three persons qualify under the provisions of this Act as candidates for the board of aldermen at the general election, then any qualified person may become a candidate; provided further that in case the three candidates receiving the highest number of votes at the general election should all receive the same number of votes, an election shall be held on the following Wednesday as provided in this section to elect a mayor at which all three of those elected as members of the board of aldermen at the general election shall be placed on the ballot and the one receiving the highest number of votes shall be declared mayor; provided further that where there are only three candidates for the board of aldermen in the general election, one of the three shall be designated as `mayor' by the voters by writing the word `mayor' under his name on the ticket, and the one thus designated by the highest number of votes shall be mayor, and so that said section as amended shall read as follows, to wit: Sec. 22.
