For the violation of the laws and ordinances of said city the mayor may impose such fines or punishment as in his discretion he may think best, provided no fine shall exceed the sum of a hundred dollars, or the punishment inflicted shall not exceed imprisonment in the guard-house or county jail for a space of time to exceed ninety days, at labor on the streets of said city. Said mayor may impose any one or all above fines or punishments. Said mayor shall have the same power as other judges of this State to punish for contempt officer and others by a fine
not to exceed fifty dollars and imprisonment in the city guardhouse not exceeding ten days, nor either or both in his discretion; he shall to all intents and purposes be a justice of peace so far as to enable him to issue warrants for offenses committed within the corporate limits of said city, which warrants may be executed by any member of the police force of the city, and to commit the offenders to the county jail of Calhoun County, or to admit them to bail in bailable cases, for their appearance at the next term of the court of competent jurisdiction to be held in and for said county. Fines and punishments.Bail.

Sec. 57. Be it further enacted that in criminal cases the defendant shall have the right to appeal to the general council from the decision or judgment of the mayor, and the right of certiorari shall exist in all criminal cases from the judgment of the mayor. Said certiorari shall be obtained in the same manner and under the same conditions as a writ of certiorari is obtained from the judgment of a justice of the peace, provided that any person convicted in said court, or his attorney, shall give written notice that he intends to apply for a writ of certiorari to the superior court of said county, when it shall be the duty of the mayor or other presiding officer to suspend said sentence until said certiorari shall have been heard and finally determined by the superior court, which ever the case may be, but no person shall be released from custody until he shall have paid the costs and given a good and sufficient bond and security, to be fixed and approved by the presiding officer of said court, for his appearance to carry and perform said sentence in the event the said certiorari is affirmed, said bond to be in form and operate as other supersedeas bonds in criminal cases; the mayor being required to certify and send up to the superior court a complete and accurate history of the case as his answer to the petition for certiorari, and the defendant having the right to traverse said answer as provided by law, the mayor and council shall be authorized to pass ordinance regulating the costs for appeals and certioraries; also for the forfeiture of all bonds. Certiorari.

Sec. 58. The city clerk of Edison shall be ex-officio clerk and treasurer of the mayor's court, and shall by himself or deputy attend all sessions of said court, and do and perform all other duties required of him in connection with said court by the mayor and council. Ex-officio clerk of mayor's court.

Sec. 59. The ministerial officers of the mayor's court shall be the marshal and policemen of the City of Edison, to whom all mesne and final processes shall be directed. All of said officers or a sufficient number shall attend the sessions of the court for the purpose of executing the orders of said court, and shall do and perform such and other duties connected with said court as may be required of them by the mayor. Officers of mayor's court.

Sec. 60. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council of Edison shall have full power and authority to pass all laws and ordinances, rules and regulations necessary and proper to secure the efficient and successful administration of the business of this court, also all other ordinances that they may deem necessary to preserve order, suppress crime and immorality, or to prevent idleness, vagrancy, or loitering in said city, not in conflict with the constitution of the laws of the State of Georgia. General powers of mayor and council.

Sec. 61. Be it further enacted that there may be a city chain-gang for said City of Edison, which is hereby created and established, and shall be put in operation whenever deemed necessary by the mayor and council as hereinafter provided. The said chain-gang shall be used for working the streets of the City of Edison, and for doing and performing other work in and for said city, or for its benefit, and shall be made up of convicts convicted in the mayor's court of Edison, and by employing from the proper authority persons convicted as misdemeanor in other courts of the State. Said chain-gang shall be governed by the same rules and regulations as govern other municipal and county chain-gangs in this State, unless otherwise provided herein. Chain-gang.

Sec. 62. The mayor and council of Edison shall have the power to select a competent warden for said chain-gang, or they may select the chief of police, who shall receive no extra compensation, and who shall be empowered to contract with the County of Calhoun or any other person or corporate body for sleeping quarters and board for said convicts. Warden for chain-gang.

Sec. 63. Be it further enacted that the authorities in charge of the chain-gang shall have prepared and have published full and complete reasonable and humane rules and regulations for the government of the convicts under their control, which rules may be amended as the occasion may require, but shall specifically prescribe powers and duties in all respects, of the superintendent, commissioner, and boss, or other person connected with the management of the convicts, as to care, keeping, control, work, and discipline of convicts. Rules for government of chain-gang.

Sec. 64. Be it further enacted that the superintendent, commissioner, guard, boss, or other person or employer of convicts shall be personally responsible or liable for any injury or damage to any convict resulting from the employment, care, control, keeping, work, and discipline of convicts, who are under the direction of said governing authorities respectively, in accordance with reasonable and humane rules and regulations adopted as aforesaid. Liability for injury to convict.

Sec. 65. Be it further enacted that white and colored convicts shall not be confined together at any time or place, nor shall female convicts be confined in the same compartment with male convicts, and should be worked separately as far as practicable. Separation of races and sexes.

Sec. 66. Be it further enacted that the boss, superintendent, or other person having the convicts in charge shall keep a book in which he shall record the names of all persons placed in his charge, giving their age, sex, color, time received, time worked, behavior while confined, offense with which they are charged, a record of number of times a convict was whipped, and the number of licks given,
time of discharge, and such other information as may be required of him by the city authorities. Record of convicts, whippings, etc.

Sec. 67. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council shall have power, in their discretion, to hire out and dispose of the convicts convicted in the mayor's court of said city, in the same manner and under the same rules and regulations as the convicts who are convicted in the State court in said county, for which length of time they may see proper to do so, if in their discretion it would be better for the city's interest than to maintain a chain-gang in said city. Hire of convicts.

Sec. 68. Be it further enacted that the rules of practice in the mayor's court, so far as practicable, shall be the same as the rules of practice in the superior courts of this State, including the rules of evidence. All officers shall be legal witnesses on trial. Rules of practice in mayor's court.
Sec. 69. Be it further enacted that all persons put on trial in the mayor's court shall have opportunity to employ counsel if they so desire. Opportunity to employ counsel.

Sec. 70. Be it further enacted that persons who have worked one or more days in the chain-gang, and, becoming able to pay the fine imposed, shall have the fine reduced according to the number of days worked, and shall be released upon the written authority of the mayor, based on the information of the clerk and treasurer of said city that such fines have been paid. Payment of fine after serving part of sentence.

Sec. 71. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council of the City of Edison shall have the power and authority to open, lay out, widen, straighten, or otherwise change the streets, avenues, alleys, sidewalks, crossings, or other passageways of said city, and shall have the power to vacate, close up, open, after, grade and fill, curb, pave, drain and repair the same. They shall have power and authority to prescribe such rules and regulations for laying out, constructing, and maintaining the same, and shall also have the power of curbing and paving the whole of any street,
avenue, alley, sidewalk, crossing, or other passageways of the city. They shall also have power to prescribe by ordinance for the curbing, paving of all squares, triangles and intersections of said city, as they may deem necessary from time to time; they shall prescribe the kind of material to be used in such construction, and shall fix the time when notice shall be given and when the work shall be completed, to supervise the construction of the same, and have power to reject any work not performed in compliance with such prescribed regulations. They shall have full and complete power and authority to require any street, avenue, alley, sidewalk, street-crossing and railroad-crossing, or other passageways, to be paved in such manner, with such material as they may determine by resolution or ordinance. One third of the expense of paving streets shall be borne by the city and the other two thirds by the abutting property owners in just proportion to the foot frontage of their property thereon. Whenever the mayor and board of councilmen shall determine to pave any street, alley, avenue, sidewalk, street-crossing and railroad-crossings, or other passageways in said town, they shall require the city clerk to notify in writing all persons owning property abutting or fronting thereon of such intention, together with a statement of the amount assessed against said property therefor; and the said city shall at once proceed to do said paving or cause it to be done, and when the same is completed it shall be the duty of the said property owner to pay into the treasury of the city, within 20 days after said work is completed, the amount so assessed against their property, and in case any property owner shall fail or refuse to do so, the city clerk is authorized and empowered to issue instanter an execution against said owner and against said property, which shall be a lien on said property superior to all other liens, except liens for taxes, and said execution shall be levied on said property by the marshal or chief of police, and the same advertised and sold at public auction in conformity to the laws of this State governing the sales of property under judgment and execution by sheriffs. Said marshal or chief of police shall make to the
purchaser a good and valid deed thereto, conveying titles as fully as the sheriffs of this State are authorized to do at public sales under judgment and execution. The City of Edison shall have full right to bid on and purchase said property at said sale, if it choose to offer the highest bidder therefor, wherefore said deed shall be made to said city, said marshal or said chief of police being duly authorized and empowered to proceed at once to dispossess said owner, and put the purchaser at said sale in possession. Whenever two thirds of the property owners on any street, square, avenue or block shall petition the mayor and council to pave, curb, or otherwise improve the street, square, avenue or block on which they own real property, it shall, immediately on filing such petition with the city clerk, become the duty of the mayor and council to do such improving under the terms of this section; and said city shall have the right of condemnation of private property for the use of the city and the public schools of the city under the methods as are now prescribed by the laws of the State. Powers as to streets, sidewalks, etc.Apportionment of expense of paving.Notice to property owners.Lien of assessment.Sale under execution.Petition for improvement.

Sec. 72. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council of the city have full power and authority to levy and collect an ad valorem tax, or special street tax, upon all property, real or personal, within the city limits of said city, for the purpose of paying the city's one third of the paving expenses referred to in section 71 of this Act immediately preceding, which said tax shall be collected in the same manner as is provided elsewhere in this charter for the enforcement and collection of taxes. Condemnation of property.Taxation to pay city's third of paving expenses.

Sec. 73. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council of said city are given the power and authority to pass all ordinances and necessary legislation for the successful and efficient carrying out of the purposes and intent of the above and foregoing sections relating to paving, as to them may be deemed to the best interest of and which shall not be in conflict with the constitution and laws of Georgia. Paving ordinances, power as to.

Sec. 74. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council shall have the power and authority, at any time that
they may deem necessary, to appoint a park commission, and shall, by proper ordinances, prescribe the manner of election, term of office, duty and salary of the same. Park commission.

Sec. 75. Be it further enacted that all male residents of said city between the ages of 21 and 50 who have resided in said city for thirty days before the first day of June each year shall be subject to work the streets of said city, not to exceed ten days in each year, or pay a commutation tax in lieu thereof, not to exceed ten dollars, as the mayor and council may determine. Should any person liable to work the streets under this section fail or refuse to do so, or to pay the street tax assessed in lieu thereof after having received the notice from the marshal or other public officer so to do, such person may be sentenced by the mayor to work upon the streets of said city for and during the term of not exceeding fifteen days under the direction and control of the marshal, or to be fined, or placed in the guardhouse, in the discretion of the mayor. Street work; commutation tax.

Sec. 76. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council of said city shall have full power and authority to levy and collect an ad valorem tax, not to exceed one and one half per cent., all property, real and personal, within the corporate limits of the city, which is taxable under the laws of this State, and to provide the manner in which the same shall be collected. Ad valorem tax, limit 1 per cent.

Sec. 77. Be it further enacted that should any person fail to refuse to pay the tax or license imposed by the city authorities according to this charter, within the time allowed or prescribed by the ordinance of said city, the clerk shall issue an execution against such delinquent taxpayer for the amout due by him to the city, which shall be signed by the city clerk in his official capacity and bear in the name of the mayor and the city council of Edison. Execution for tax or license.

Sec. 78. Be it further enacted that said execution shall bind all the property of that said defaulting taxpayer owned in said town on the first day of January in the year
for which such taxes are due. Said executions shall be directed to and enforced by the marshal or chief of police of said city, who, after levying the same upon the property of such defaulting taxpayers, shall, if the property be personal property, advertise the sale by posting notices in three of the most public places of said city, ten days before the date of sale, and if the property be real estate, he shall advertise the same once a week for four weeks in the official organ of said city before selling the same. All sales under such executions shall be made by the city marshal or chief of police before the door of the council chamber, or at such places as may be prescribed by ordinance, notice of which place and time of sale shall be contained in the advertisement. The property levied upon shall be sold by the marshal or chief of police at public outcry to the highest and best bidder. Where the sale is of personal property, the marshal or chief of police shall deliver possession thereof to the purchaser. When real estate is sold, the marshal or chief of police shall make to the purchaser a deed against whom the execution is issued, and it shall be the duty of such marshal or chief of police, upon application of the purchaser or his agent, to put said purchaser or agent in possession of the real estate sold; provided the said marshal or chief of police shall not be authorized to turn out any other person than such delinquent taxpayer, his heirs, tenants, or assigns, since the lien of the city taxes attached. Same.Sale under execution.

Sec. 79. The city clerk shall be entitled to fifty cents for each fi. fa. issued, and the marshal or chief of police to the same fees for levies as are hereby allowed the bailiffs in this State, and the same fees for selling as are required by sheriffs for selling property in this State; provided the mayor and council may by ordinance provide for all such costs to go into the city treasury and pay the city clerk and marshal, or chief of police a regular salary for their whole duty to the city. Fees for exectuion, levy, sale.

Sec. 80. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council of said city shall have power and authority to prescribe by ordinance the time and manner in which all persons
shall return for taxes all property of every kind and nature and also prescribe when all businesses and occupation tax and license shall be paid to the city. Tax returns.

Sec. 81. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council shall have power and authority each year, if in their discretion they see proper, to appoint three tax-assessors, whose duty it shall be to value the real estate in said city whose duty it shall be to value the real estate in said city for taxation and to scrutinize carefully each return of property, real and personal, by any taxpayer of the city, and in their judgment they shall find the property embraced in their return, or any portion of it, returned below its proper value, they shall assess the value thereof, or they think may act as such tax-assessors. Tax-assessors.

Sec. 82. Be it further enacted that whenever the assessors shall raise the valuation at which the taxpayer has returned his property, they shall give him written notice of their assessment, and it shall be the taxpayer's privilege, if dissatisfied with the assessment, within ten days after notice, to have the matter left to three disinterested freeholders, residents of the city, one of whom shall be elected by him, one by the assessors, and the third by those two selected, and the majority of these arbitrators shall fix the assessment, which shall be final and conclusive. The mayor and council are also given authority to fix the compensation of the said tax-assessor and also pass such ordinance bearing on the question as they may deem proper. Notice of increase of assessment.Arbitration as to value.Pay to tax-assessor.

Sec. 83. Be it further enacted that the provisions of this charter may be pleaded, and shall be a defense to any action brought against the mayor and city council of Edison, or either of them in accordance with the provisions and ordinances passed in pursuance thereof. Charter as defense to action against mayor and council.

Sec. 84. Said mayor and council shall have authority to establish a guardhouse and provide regulations for the same, in which to confine for punishment, when necessary, persons sentenced by the mayor for violating any of the city laws ordinances, or any penal sections of this charter,
and for the safe detention of all disorderly persons committing or attempting to commit crimes, and the marshal or any policeman of the city, shall have the right to take up all disorderly person or persons and confine them in the guardhouse to await their trial. Guardhouse; confinement of disorderly persons.

Sec. 85. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council of said city shall have the right to establish and maintain a city stockade for the confinement of all the convicts of the city, and to prescribe suitable rules and regulations for the same whenever they deem the same necessary. City stockade.

Sec. 86. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council shall have power, whenever they deem it necessary and to the best interest of the city, to establish a bureau for the commercial and business interest of the city, to be known as the Edison Chamber of Commerce, and the said mayor and council may prescribe scope for its work, the duties devolving upon its membership, its officers and appropriate such sums for its maintenance, and operation as they deem proper. Chamber of Commerce.

Sec. 87. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council of said city, or the water and light commission, whenever such may be created, shall have the right to make contracts with persons, firms, or corporations residing beyond the limits, to furnish them with light and water, or water, or lights, whenever the same can be done without interfering with the efficient service of the city light and water plant to the inhabitants of the city. Water and lights.

Sec. 88. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council may have the right to employ a competent accountant to examine the books of the officers of the city, relative to the affairs of the city, as often as said mayor and council shall consider necessary. Accountant.

Sec. 89. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council shall have full power and authority to regulate the running of all railroad-trains and bus lines within the city limits, and to prescribe the manner in which same may be run and the rate of speed of the same. Regulation of running of trains and bus lines.

Sec. 90. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council of said city shall have power and authority to order elections at various times to determine the issue of bonds, and to issue bonds in accordance herewith, for all public improvements as they may deem necessary; that they may bond for the purpose of enlarging the waterworks and sewer system of the city, to establish a light plant, to erect a city-hall where the public business of the city shall be transacted, to curb and pave the streets, and for such other public improvements as they may deem proper, and shall provide how the public debt of the city shall be paid, and may constitute such sinking fund for that purpose, if they may deem necessary. Bond issues, elections as to.

Sec. 91. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council of said city are hereby authorized and empowered to levy, assess and collect annually a sufficient tax upon and from the taxable property in said city, real and personal, to pay the principal and interest on such bonds as they shall become due. This tax shall be separately assessed, levied, and collected for the specific purpose herein designated, and shall not be used or applied to any other purpose whatever. Said mayor and council are hereby authorized and empowered to issue interest coupons, payable annuaaly, for the interest on said bonds. Any money remaining in hand received and collected under this act, after the payment of maturing interest coupons and bonds each year, shall be held by the mayor and council as a sinking fund for the payment of the bonds and interest maturing the next year. Tax to pay bonds.Sinking fund

Sec. 92. Be it further enacted that said bonds shall be signed by the mayor and clerk of said city and registered and sold in such manner and in such sums and at such times as the mayor and board of councilmen may determine for the best interest of said city and the speedy execution of the objects of this Act. Sale of bonds.

Sec. 93. Be it further enacted that every ordinance and resolution passed by the board of councilmen may be
subject to the veto by the mayor in the following manner: The mayor shall within three days write out his objections to such ordinance or resolution, and the board of councilmen, at the next regular meeting at which a quorum shall be present, order said objections entered on the minutes and take a vote on the question as to whether said ordinance, resolution, or other action shall become adopted over said veto. Should as many as three councilmen vote in the affirmative, said resolution and ordinance shall stand affirmed and become effective without the approval of the mayor, otherwise not. The ayes and nays shall in all cases be entered on the minutes. Veto of mayor.

Sec. 94. Be it further enacted that this Act shall not abolish any of the ordinances now of force in said city, except where they come in conflict with this charter, but shall preserve and continue the same. Ordinances and laws not in conflict herewith not abolished.

Sec. 95. Be it further enacted that all other Acts heretofore approved by the General Assembly relating to the City of Edison, except such part or parts thereof as may be in conflict with this Act, be and they are hereby continued in operation, confirmed, and consolidated with and made a part of this Act.

Sec. 96. Be it further enacted that whenever any real estate is sold for taxes the owner thereof shall have the privilege of redeeming it within one year by paying the purchaser the amount paid therefor, with ten per cent. premium thereon, and interest on said principal amount at the rate of seven per cent. per annum. When at any such sale for taxes due no person present shall bid for the property put up for sale as much as the amount of such execution and all costs, after such property shall have been carried a reasonable time, then any fully authorized or appointed agent of the city may bid off such property for the city, and the police officer or such other officer making the sale shall make the City of Edison deed to the property so sold, and deliver the same, and the title thus acquired by the city shall be perfect and valid, after the period
for the redemption by the owner shall have expired, and the policemen, or other officer making the sale shall put said city in possession, and the mayor and council shall have no right or authority to divert or alienate the title to any property so purchased except by public sale to the highest bidder in the manner to be prescribed by ordinance of said city. Redemption of property sold for taxes.

Sec. 97. The City of Edison shall have the power and authority to condemn land and property for any public use to wit: for streets, alleys, sidewalks, ditches, drainage, schools, school grounds, public playgrounds, court-house, parks, public libraries, waterwork, light plants, cemeteries, jails and for any and all public uses, when needed, under the rules and methods and regulations as are now provided by law. Condemnation of property.
Sec. 98. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: ELBERTON; DEBTS AND SALES REQUIRING APPROVAL BY POPULAR VOTE.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act providing a charter for the City of Elberton, approved December 19, 1896, by adding to section thereof the following: Provided no debt for an amount exceeding $10,000.00 shall be contracted, nor sale of any property, right, or franchise where the amount involved exceeds $10,000.00 shall be made, until such proposed debt or sale shall be approved by a majority vote of the qualified voters of said City of Elberton at an election held for that purpose; to repeal conflicting laws; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia that an Act of 1896 providing a charter for the
City of Elberton, approved December 19, 1896 (Acts of 1896, page 148-156), be and the same is hereby amended by adding at the end of section 16 thereof (page 153 of said Acts of 1896) the following: Provided no debt for an amount exceeding $10,000.00 shall be created, nor sale of any property, right, or franchise where the amount involved exceeds $10,000.00 shall be made, until such proposed debt or sale is approved by a majority vote of the qualified voters of said City of Elberton at an election held for that purpose. Debt of sale for more than $10,000 must be approved by popular vote.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be, and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act of the legislature of Georgia approved November 22, 1900, providing a system of public schools for the City of Elberton, as amended by an Act approved August 4, 1917, by striking from line six of section 10 of said Act as so amended the words: one half of one per centum, and inserting in lieu thereof the words: eight mills, provided, should the city council find such rate insufficient for school needs for any one year, it may by resolution at any meeting increase said rate as may be necessary, but not exceeding two addittional mill; to repeal conflicting laws; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, that section 10 of the Act approved November 22d, 1900, providing a system of public schools for the City of Elberton, as amended by the Act of 1917 approved August 4, 1917, pages 670 and 671, be and the same is hereby amended by striking from line six of said
section 10 the words: one half of one per centum, and inserting in lieu thereof the words: eight mills, provided should the city council find such rate insufficient for school needs for any one year, it may by resolution at any meeting increase said rate as may be necessary, but not exceeding two additional mill; so that when so amended said section shall read as follows: Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the city council of the City of Elberton be and the same is hereby authorized and empowered to levy and collect as other taxes are levied and collected a special tax upon the taxable property of said city of not exceeding eight mills, provided, should the city council find such rate insufficient for school needs for any one year, it may by resolution at any meeting increase said rate as may be necessary, but not exceeding two additional mills, in addition to all other taxes now authorized, to be known as the school tax, which shall be covered into the city treasury of said city and appropriated by the city council for school purposes only, as the need of the public schools may require. School tax.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved August 3, 1925, incorporating the City of Fairburn by amending section seven (7) of said act so as to provide a two (2) year term for the mayor and council of said city; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this act the act
of the legislature of Georgia approved August 3, 1925, incorporating the City of Fairburn, be and the same is hereby amended by striking the words one (1) year in the first line of section seven (7) of said act and inserting in lieu thereof the words two (2) years, so that said section when so amended shall read as follows: Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that there shall be elected at the next annual election and annually thereafter a mayor, who shall hold his office for two (2) years. Mayor's term two years.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby amended.

law.shorttitle: FAIRBURN; PART OF SMITH STREET CLOSED FOR SCHOOL GROUND.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the mayor and council of the City of Fairburn to close Smith Street in said City of Fairburn, between Green Street and Malone Street, and to authorize the use of said street for public-school ground purposes and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that the City of Fairburn be and it is hereby authorized to close Smith Street in said city, between Green Street and Malone Street, provided said city shall dedicate such closed portion of said street to the board of trustees of the Fairburn School District, for use as public-school grounds, and provided further that the right to open and use said street shall revert to the City of Fairburn when its use as a public-school ground by said Fairburn School district is discontinued. Authority to close part of Smith Street.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: FOREST PARK; TIME OF ELECTIONS; TERM OF MAYOR, ETC.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend An Act to incorporate the Town of Forest Park, in the County of Clayton; to prescribe its limits; to provide for a mayor and council of said town and prescribe their duties and powers and the manner of their election; to provide for the government of said town, and for other purposes; approved August 14, 1908, so as to change the time of holding elections for mayor and aldermen and to fix the terms of office of mayor and aldermen; to fix the time for holding elections for such officers; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this act that an Act to incorporate the Town of Forest Park, in the County of Clayton; to prescribe its limits; to provide for a mayor and council of said town and prescribe their duties and powers and the manner of their election; to provide for the government of said town, and for other purposes, approved August 14, 1908, be and the same is hereby amended by striking from section 5 of said Act the following: that on the second Wednesday in January, 1909, and on the same day in each year thereafter, an election shall be held in the council chamber of said town for a mayor and aldermen thereof, who shall hold their offices for one year from said date and until their successors are elected and qualified, and by adding and inserting in lieu thereof the following: that on the second Wednesday of December,
1929, an election shall be held in the council chamber of said town for a mayor and two aldermen thereof, who shall hold their offices for two years from the second Tuesday in January, 1930, or until their successors are elected and qualified, and also three aldermen thereof, who shall hold their offices for one year from second Tuesday in January, 1930, or until their successors are elected and qualified, and that on the second Wednesday in December of each succeeding year there shall be held in said council chamber an election for the offices of such mayor and aldermen whose terms of office shall expire on the second Wednesday of the following January, who shall hold their offices for two years, so that three aldermen shall be elected one year for a term of two years, and the following year a mayor and two aldermen for a term of two years, and alternately each year thereafter, so that said section when amended shall read as follows: Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, that on the second Wednesday of December, 1929, an election shall be held in the council chamber of said town for a mayor and two aldermen thereof, who shall hold their offices for two years from the second Tuesday in January, 1930, or until their successors are elected and qualified, and also three aldermen thereof, who shall hold their offices for one year from the second Tuesday in January, 1930, or until their successors are elected and qualified, and that on the second Wednesday in December of each succeeding year there shall be held in said council chamber an election for the offices of such mayor and aldermen whose terms of office shall expire on the second Tuesday of the following January, who shall hold their offices for two years or until their successors are elected and qualified, so that three aldermen shall be elected one year for a term of two years, and the following year a mayor and two aldermen for a term of two years, and alternately each year thereafter, all persons being eligible to hold said office who are qualified at the time to vote for members of the General Assembly of this State and have resided in said town three months immediately preceding said election. All persons shall be qualified to vote for said offices
who are qualified as above to hold the same. Such elections shall be held and conducted as are those for county officers, and the certificate of the managers shall authorize the persons so elected to enter upon the discharge of the duties of said offices, the returns of said election being made to the mayor and aldermen of said town. In the event of a vacancy occurring in any of said offices, the same shall be filled as to the mayor by the board of aldermen selecting one of their number to fill the unexpired term; and as to an alderman by the selection of some fit and proper person of the town by the mayor and remaining aldermen. Term of two years for mayor and aldermen; elections.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: GAINESVILLE; AUTHORITY TO SELL LIGHTING EQUIPMENT; REFERENDUM.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend sections one and two of the Act of the General Assembly of Georgia approved December 12th, 1892 (Georgia Laws, 1892, page 168), amending the charter of the City of Gainesville, said sections constituting parts of the existing charter of said city, by striking therefrom the words light plant wherever they occur in relation to sale of the same or parts thereof, and to confer power and authority on the city commission of said city to sell and dispose of the entire streetlighting system now owned by the city, in accordance with the provisions and requirements of the Act of the General Assembly approved August 25th, 1925 (Georgia Laws 1925, page 177), prescribing the method of sale of municipally owned public utility properties, and to provide method of ratification.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly, and it is hereby enacted by the same, that sections One and Two of the Act of the General Assembly approved December 12th, 1892 (Georgia Laws 1892, page 168), amending the charter of the City of Gainesville, which said sections constitute parts of the existing charter of said city, be and are hereby amended by striking therefrom wherever they occur the words light plant, relating to sale of the same or parts thereof, so that said sections as amended shall no longer apply to the sale of the electric-light properties owned by the city, but shall apply only ot the water-works and appurtenances owned by the city. Referendum as to authority to sell light plant.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that power and authority is hereby conferred on the city commission to sell, lease, or otherwise dispose of the street-lighting system and all parts and appurtenances thereof owned by the city, but not including any building or real estate used in connection therewith. Provided that no sale, lease, or disposition of said municipally owned electric utility properties shall be made except in accordance with the requirements and provisions of the Act of the General Assembly, approved August 25, 1925, providing for the sale, lease, or other disposition of municipally owned public utility properties. Sale of electric utility properties.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted that this Act shall not become effective until ratified by a vote of the people of Gainesville. This may be called by the city commission, by publishing a notice to that effect in each of the two newspapers now published in said city, for a period of four weeks next preceding the date fixed for said election, and which election shall be held in accordance with law now provided for other elections in said city as to qualification of voters and determining the result thereof. Ballots shall be prepared with the words written or printed thereon: For authority to sell city's electrical lighting equipment, and Against authority to sell city's electrical lighting equipment. If a majority of the votes cast at said election shall vote for authority to sell the city's electrical
lighting equipment, then and thereupon this Act shall become effective and binding on all parties; if a majority shall vote against said authority, then this Act to be void. Election.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted that ll laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be and are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: GRIFFIN CORPORATE LIMITS EXTENDED; FIRE-DEPARTMENT SALARIES.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved July 21st, 1921, entitled An Act to revise and consolidate the several acts of the General Assembly of Georgia, granting and amending the charter of the City of Griffin in Spalding County, Georgia; to amend the charter of said city; to declare the rights and powers of said municipality, and for other purposes, as amended by an Act of the General Assembly approved August 11th, 1924 (Acts 1924, page 591), by extending the corporate limits of the City of Griffin so as to include therein a tract of land on West Poplar and 15th Street; to amend section 51 of said charter, fixing the salaries of engineers and members of the fire department; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same as follows: That section 2 of an Act approved July 21st, 1921, entitled An Act to revise and consolidate the several acts of the General Assembly of Georgia, granting and amending the charter of said city; to declare the rights and powers of said municipality, and for other purposes, be and the same is hereby amended by extending the corporate limits of the City of Griffin so as to include therein a tract of land on West Poplar and 15th Street
more particularly described as follows: Beginning at the southwest corner of West Poplar and 15th Street and running thence west along the south side of West Poplar Street one hundred sixty-four feet (164 ft.) thence south two hundred eighty-five (285 ft.) feet thence east one hundred sixty-three feet (163 ft.) to 15th Street and thence north two hundred eighty-five feet (285 ft.) to the beginning point, being the property commonly known as the property of H. H. Jones Jr., Mrs. Mollie Crane and A. Kirkland, together with all lands lying and being between said described property and the present corporate limits of the City of Griffin. A plat of said property is recorded in the clerk's office of Spalding County Superior Court in Plat Book 2, page 129. New territory.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that section 51 of said Act approved July 21st, 1921, be and the same is hereby amended so that said section 51 shall hereafter read as follows: Engineers of Fire Department. The city manager shall employ engineers and members of the fire department, who shall receive for their services a salary, not exceeding $1500.00 per annum each, payable monthly, except the chief, who shall be paid a salary not exceeding $2000.00 per annum, payable monthly. Fire department salaries.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: GRIFFIN; CORPORATE LIMITS; SALARIES OF POLICEMEN.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved July 21, 1921, entitled An Act to revise and consolidate the several acts of the General Assembly of Georgia, granting and amending the charter of the
City of Griffin, in Spalding County, Georgia; to amend the charter of said city; to declare the rights and power of said municipality, and for other purposes, as amended by an Act of the General Assembly approved August 11, 1924 (Acts 1924, page 591), by extending the corporate limits of the City of Griffin so as to include therein all of lot No. 174, and certain designated portions of lots Nos. 173, 147, and 148 all in the second district of original Monroe, now Spalding County, Georgia; to amend section 46 of said charter fixing the salary of regular policemen; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the corporate limits of the City of Griffin, as defined in an Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved July 21, 1921, and amended by an Act approved August 11, 1924, be and the same are hereby extended so as to add thereto and include therein all of the following territory and tract of land, to wit: All of lot No. 174 in the second district of original Monroe, now Spalding County, Georgia, and the following described portion of lots Nos. 173, 147, and 148, also in the second district of original Monroe, now Spalding County, Georgia, to wit: Beginning at an iron stake on the south line of said lot No. 174, which point is 1,415 feet east of the southwest corner of lot 174, and running thence south 43 minutes east 675 feet, thence north 75 degrees and 19 minutes west 743 feet to a public road known as the Sixth Street Extension; thence west 1,640 feet to the property of J. H. Walker, thence north 23 minutes, west 455 feet to an iron stake; thence north 16 degrees and thirty-seven minutes east 228 feet; thence north one degree and two minutes west 1,152 feet; thence north 46 degrees and 29 minutes west 292 feet; thence north one degree and 37 minutes east to the present city limits. The portion of lots 147, 148, and 173 is shown by reference to a plat dated May 12, 1925, made by N. S. Westbrook, civil engineer, and recorded in the clerk's office of Spalding County, Georgia, in Plat Book No. 2, page.....New territory.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the territory above described and the people now or hereafter residing or being therein, and the property now or hereafter located thereon, shall be subject to all the laws relating to and ordinances of the City of Griffin. Laws extended to new territory.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that section 45 of the said Act approved July 21, 1921, be and the same is hereby amended by striking from the seventh line of said section the figures $1,500.00, and substituting in lieu thereof $2,400.00, so that said section when amended shall read as follows: The city manager shall appoint a chief of police who shall be ex-officio marshal of said city, and who shall have all authority and power of a marshal. Said chief of police shall be required to give oath as prescribed by ordinance, and shall receive such salary, payable in equal monthly installments, not exceeding the sum of $2,400.00 per year. The balance of said section to remain as now is. Salary of chief of police.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that section 46 of the said Act approved July 21, 1921, be and the same is hereby amended by striking from the last line of said section the figures $1,200.00, and substituting in lieu thereof $1,800.00, so that said section when amended shall read as follows: The city manager shall employ a sufficient force of regular policemen to enforce the ordinances of said city. The salary of each policeman of said city shall be such an amount payable in monthly installments not exceeding the sum of $1,800.00 per year. Salaries of policemen.
Sec. 5. That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act, approved August 19th, 1912, incorporating the Town of Hahira, in Lowndes County, Georgia, known as No. 623, pages 951 to 930, inclusive, of 1912 Georgia Laws, as amended by an Act approved August 10th, 1920, known as Act No. 590, pages 1000 to 1001, inclusive, of 1920 Georgia Laws, by striking from the seventh line of section 23 of said Act as amended as aforesaid the words one hundred cents, and inserting in lieu thereof the words two hundred cents; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that an Act incorporating the Town of Hahira, known as Act No. 623, pages 951 to 980, inclusive, of 1912 Georgia Laws, approved August 19th, 1913, as amended by an Act approved August 10th, 1920, known as Act No. 590, pages 1000 to 1001, inclusive, of 1912 Georgia Laws, be and the same is hereby amended by striking out the words one hundred cents, in the seventh line of section 23 of said Act, and substituting therefor the words two hundred cents, so that when said section is amended it shall read as follows: Sec. 23. For the purpose of raising revenue for the support and maintenance of said government, the mayor and council shall have the full power and authority, and they shall provide by ordinance, for the assessment, levy, and collection of an ad valorem tax on all real estate and personal property within the corporate limits of said town, not exceeding two hundred cents on the hundred dollars, exclusive of taxation for public schools. Ad valorem tax rate; limit $2 on $200, exclusive of school tax.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid that all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: HAPEVILLE CORPORATE LIMITS REDUCED; RECORDER; STREET-TAX ON WOMEN.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to incorporate the City of Hapeville, Georgia, and for other purposes, approved September 16, 1891, and several acts amendatory thereof; to repeal section six of an Act of the General Assembly of 1927 (Acts 1927, page 1199), which said section of said act extended the corporate limits of said City of Hapeville, Georgia; to amend section five of the Acts of General Assembly of 1927 (Acts 1927, page 1198), so as to require female citizens, who desire to register and vote in city elections, to pay a street-tax of $1.00 per annum instead of the same amount as is required of male citizens; to so amend the charter of said City of Hapeville as to give the mayor and council the right, in their discretion, to elect a recorder for said City of Hapeville, prescribe his duties, and fix his salary; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that section 6 of an Act to amend the charter of the City of Hapeville, Georgia, passed by the General Assembly and approved on August 15, 1927 (Acts 1927, page 1199), be and the same is hereby repealed, and the corporate limits of said City of Hapeville, Georgia, are hereby restored and declared to exist just as they were prior to the passage of said section 6 of said Act.
offenders against the laws or ordinances of said city, in that particular said recorder shall have the same power and authority as is now vested in the mayor. Repeal of Sec. 6 of Act of 1927, as to corporate limits.Recorder; salary, duties.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, that section 5 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1927 (Acts 1927, page 1198) be and the same is hereby amended by striking the words, The same street tax as required of male citizens of said city, and inserting in lieu thereof $1.00 per annum street-tax, so that said section when amended shall read as follows: Be it further enacted, that all female citizens, who desire to register and vote in any city election, shall be required to pay $1.00 per annum street-tax, but said street-tax shall not be required of nor collected from any female citizen unless she desires to register and vote in some city election. Street-tax on women.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: HAWKINSVILLE; NEW FORM OF GOVERNMENT, REFERENDUM AS TO.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to provide for the City of Hawkinsville a new form of government, to be composed of a mayor and six aldermen; to declare the rights and powers of said government; to amend or repeal such sections of the charter of said City of Hawkinsville as may be necessary to carry into effect said new form of government to be composed of a mayor and six aldermen; to create the office of recorder, and a recorder's court, and to provide for the compensation, power, and term of office of said recorder, and the jurisdiction and powers of said recorder's court; to provide that this Act shall go into effect on January 1st, 1930, in the event the electors
of said City of Hawkinsville have approved an Act repealing an Act to be found in Georgia Laws for 1923, page 671; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that the government of the City of Hawkinsville shall be vested in a city council, to be composed of a mayor and six aldermen. City council; membership.

Sec. 2. The said mayor and said six aldermen of said City of Hawkinsville shall be elected at a special election to be held for that purpose, under the same rules and regulations as to the registration and qualification of voters, and other conditions and requirements of city elections, on the second Wednesday in December, 1929, between 7:00 a. m. and 6:00 p. m. The said election shall be called by the commissioners of said City of Hawkinsville then in office, who shall consolidate the returns of said election and declare who shall be elected in said special election. Election of mayor and aldermen.
Sec. 3. The person who shall be elected mayor in said special election shall hold office until the first day of January, 1931. Mayor's term.

Sec. 4. The six persons who shall receive the highest number of votes for aldermen shall be declared elected as such, and their terms of office shall be determined as follows: The clerk of the City of Hawkinsville shall by lot determine that three of said six persons elected as aldermen shall hold office until the first day of January, 1931, and that the other three said persons elected as aldermen shall hold office until the first day of January, 1932. Terms of aldermen.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that on the second Wednesday in December, 1930, and regularly every two years thereafter, there shall be elected a mayor, who shall serve for two years, and until his successor is elected and qualified. Election of mayor.

Sec. 6. Beginning on the second Wednesday in December, 1930, and annually thereafter, there shall be an
election held in said city for three aldermen, each to serve for two years and until their successors are elected and qualified. Election of aldermen.

Sec. 7. At the first meeting of said mayor and aldermen after their election and qualification, which said first regular meeting of said mayor and aldermen shall be held on the first day of January of each year, unless that day shall fall on Sunday; and then on the Monday immediately following they shall elect from said aldermen a mayor pro tem., whose term of office shall be for one year. First meeting of mayor and aldermen.Mayor pro tem.

Sec. 8. In the event a vacancy occurs in the office of mayor or aldermen by reason of resignation, removal from the city, death or any other cause, the said city clerk shall order an election to fill said vacancy, which election shall be held not less than ten days and not more than thirty days from the date of said vacancy. Notice of this election shall be published one time in one or more newspapers in said city, and by posting a written notice thereof for ten days at two or more of the most public places in said city and at the city hall of said city. Said election shall be held and managed, returns made, and results declared in the same manner as regular elections, as provided in the laws governing elections in said City of Hawkinsville. Vacancies.

Sec. 9. Provided, however, that if any vacancy occurs in the office of mayor, or any aldermen, within less than four months from the date of the next regular election, the city council shall themselves select some fit and proper person for said vacancy, and by resolution declare him chosen to fill the vacancy. If the office of mayor pro tem. shall from any cause become vacant, the city council shall elect one of the remaining aldermen as mayor pro tem. for the unexpired term. Same.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that no person shall be elected to the office of mayor or aldermen unless he shall have resided in said city for one year immediately preceding his election, and unless
he shall be a qualified voter in elections in said city for officers of said city, and unless he shall be entitled to register under the registration laws of force in said city. Eligibility.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the mayor of said city shall be its chief executive officer. He shall see that all laws, ordinances, resolutions, and rules of said city are faithfully and fully executed; and that all the officers of said city faithfully execute the duties required of them. He shall have general supervision of the affairs of said city, and shall preside at all meetings of the city council, except as herein otherwise provided. Mayor's duties.

Sec. 12. The mayor, and mayor pro tem. while acting as mayor, shall not have the right to vote upon any question before the council except in case of a tie; but said mayor, or mayor pro tem. while acting as mayor, shall have the right to veto any resolution or ordinance adopted or enacted by the council, which veto must be filed with the clerk in writing, together with his reasons therefor, within four days after their action on said measure and be entered of record on the minutes of council; and said measure shall not be effectual unless passed over said veto by a vote of two thirds of a council at the first or second regular meeting of council after said veto, and not thereafter. Provided, however, that within two days after said veto power is exercised, the mayor, or mayor pro tem. as the case might be, shall call a special meeting of council, and if all the aldermen, or all save one of the aldermen, be present, they may in their discretion then and there act on said measure so vetoed. Mayor votes only in case of tie.Veto.

Sec. 13. During the absence, sickness, or disqualification of the mayor, the mayor pro tem. shall act as mayor; and in the sickness, disqualification, or absence of the mayor pro tem. any one of the aldermen chosen by the city council shall be clothed with the rights and privileges of the mayor, and shall perform the mayor's duties for the time being. Mayor pro tem.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the mayor and four aldermen shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business before the city council, and the majority of the votes cast shall determine all questions and elections before the council. On all questions before the city council the mayor, or mayor pro tem. if he be presiding, shall be entitled to vote only in case of a tie. Said city council shall have regular meetings at stated times at the council chamber in said city, and shall hold such meetings as may be ordered by the mayor for special purposes or when requested by a majority of the aldermen. All meetings by the council shall be public, and the public shall be allowed at all times to witness their deliberations, except when the city council resolves itself into executive session, when the public shall be excluded. Meetings of council; quorum.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid: There is hereby created a recorder's court, to be presided over by a recorder, who shall be chosen by a majority of said aldermen, who shall fix his salary, and whose term of office shall be two years. Said recorder's court shall be open at all times for the transaction of such business as may come before it, and shall have jurisdiction to try and to punish all persons, firms, or corporations charged with a violation of the ordinances of said city. Said recorder's court shall have power to enforce its judgment by the infliction of such penalties as are now, or hereafter may be, provided by law and the ordinances of said city, and shall have power to punish witnesses for failure to attend upon said court, and to punish for contempt of said court by fine not to exceed $10.00, or by imprisonment in the city jail not to exceed ten days. In the absence, disability, or disqualification of said recorder, said court shall be presided over by the mayor of said city; or in the absence, disability, or disqualification of said mayor, by the mayor pro tem. of said city; or in the absence, disability, or disqualification of said mayor pro tem., by some one of the aldermen of said city, designated for that purpose by the clerk of the said city. Recorder's court; powers.

Sec. 16. No appeal shall lie from decisions of the presiding officer of said recorder's court, but the right of certiorari as is set forth in section 19 of the Act approved December 18th, 1902, is hereby preserved. Certiorari.

Sec. 17. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the same person shall not be qualified to hold the office of recorder of said city and of city attorney of said city at the same time. Same person not to be recorder and city attorney.

Sec. 18. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that this Act shall become effective if and when an Act providing for the repeal of an Act to be found in Georgia Laws of 1923, page 671, etc., is ratified at an election to be held for said purpose, which said election is now provided for by law. Referendum as to this Act.
Sec. 19. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: HAWKINSVILLE; PUBLICATION OF MINUTES, FINANCIAL STATEMENTS, ORDINANCES; CODIFICATION; SEWERAGE, DRAINAGE; NUISANCES; PAY OF OFFICERS; RECORDER, CITY ATTORNEY.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend the charter of the City of Hawkinsville, to provide that it shall be the duty of the city clerk of said city to publish, as is required in this Act, the minutes of all meetings of the mayor and council or the commissioners of said city, as the case may be; to provide that the city clerk of said city shall publish, as is provided in this Act, financial statements of the City of Hawkinsville, of its light and water plant and of its public-school system; to provide for the payment of
the expense of the publication of said minutes and said financial statements; to provide the duties of the governing body of said City of Hawkinsville in reference to sewerage and drainage systems in said city; to provide for the codification of the ordinances of said city; to provide for the publication of the ordinances of said city relating to franchise and license taxes of said city; to authorize the mayor and council or commissioners, or the governing body of said city, to provide ordinances declaring what are nuisances; and for other purposes. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same:
law.p: Section 1. That from and after the passage of this Act it shall be the duty of the city clerk of said City of Hawkinsville to publish in the official organ of Pulaski County, Georgia, published next after any meeting of the mayor and council, or commissioners, a true copy of the minutes of any and all meetings of the said mayor and council, or commissioners, as the case may be, of said City of Hawkinsville; the cost of which publication shall be paid out of the general fund of the said City of Hawkinsville. Publication of minutes.

It shall also be the duty of said city clerk, to post on a bulletin board, to be located in some public place in the building used as an office by said city clerk, a true copy of the minutes of all meetings of the mayor and council, or commissioners, as the case may be, of said City of Hawkinsville, within forty-eight hours after the adjournment of such meetings.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all minutes of all meetings of said mayor and council, or commissioners, as the case may be, of said City of Hawkinsville, shall be reduced to writing and approved by the mayor, mayor pro tem., or chairman of the board of commissioners, as the case may be, of said City of Hawkinsville, before the adjournment of such meetings, and not later than forty-eight hours after the adjournment of such meetings the said minutes shall be recorded on the minute
book of said City of Hawkinsville by said city clerk, which said minute book shall be permanently bound. Time of writing, approving and recording minutes.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that it shall be the duty of said city clerk to publish quarterly, in some newspaper published in said city, beginning January 1st of each year, a statement showing the true financial condition of said City of Hawkinsville, of the water and light plant of said City of Hawkinsville, and of the public school system of said City of Hawkinsville; the expense of which said publication shall be paid out of the general fund of said city. Publication of financial statements quarterly.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that it shall be the duty of the governing body of said City of Hawkinsville, by whatever name known, to keep open and clean all sewerage and drainage systems, and drainage ditches, of said City of Hawkinsville, so that no water shall stand therein and all water shall flow freely therefrom; and the failure of the said governing body of said City of Hawkinsville so to keep open said sewerage and drainage systems, and drainage ditches, of the said City of Hawkinsville shall give a right of action against said City of Hawkinsville to any person, firm, or corporation, who may be injured by the failure or refusal of said City of Hawkinsville to keep open and clean said sewerage and drainage systems and drainage ditches so that the water shall not stand therein, and shall freely flow therefrom. Sewerage and drainage.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all ordinances and laws of said City of Hawkinsville shall be codified quinquennially, beginning January 1st, 1930; which said codification shall be done by the said city attorney of the City of Hawkinsville, who shall be paid therefor for such work not exceeding $50.00, in addition to his said salary as city attorney. Codification of ordinances and laws.Compensation.

Said ordinances, when codified, shall be kept permanently bound and open at all times to public inspection. The said governing body of said City of Hawkinsville may, in its discretion from time to time cause said codified ordinances
to be published in pamphlet form. The expense of which said codification and said publication shall be paid out of the general fund of said City of Hawkinsville. Publication.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that it shall be the duty of the governing body of said City of Hawkinsville to publish, annually, a copy of the ordinance, or ordinances, of said City of Hawkinsville fixing the amount of license and of franchise taxes to be paid to conduct business in said City of Hawkinsville. Same.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the city council, or commissioners, or the governing body of said City of Hawkinsville, by whatever name known, shall by ordinance declare what shall be nuisances in said City of Hawkinsville and shall declare, amongst other things, the following to be nuisances: Nuisances
1. Permitting any land in said City of Hawkinsville to grow up in weeds, bushes or other uncultivated natural growth.
2. Keeping any land in said City of Hawkinsville in a filthy and unclean condition.
3. Permitting within the fire limits of said City of Hawkinsville any land to be encumbered with rubbish or trash.

The naming herein of any specific nuisances shall not operate to deprive the said city council, commissioners, or governing body of said city, by whatever name known, of the right to declare by ordinance what may be other nuisances.

The said city council, or commissioners, or governing body of said City of Hawkinsville shall have authority to provide for the abatement of nuisances by ordinance, and the police court, or recorder's court of said city shall have concurrent authority with the said city council, or commissioners, or other governing body of said city, to abate nuisances.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the compensation of the mayor and aldermen, the city clerk, the city treasurer, the city attorney, the city commissioners, and of such other officers, servants or employees of said city, shall be such sums as the said council or said commissioners, or said governing body of said city may fix. Compensation of officers.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the same person shall not be qualified to hold the office of recorder of said city and of city attorney of said city at the same time. Same person not to be recorder and city attorney.
Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: HAWKINSVILLE; REPEAL OF COMMISSION GOVERNMENT; REFERENDUM.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act amending the charter of the City of Hawkinsville, to be found in Georgia Laws for the year 1923, beginning on page 671; to provide for a submission of this Act to a vote of the electors of said City of Hawkinsville for their approval or rejection; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that an Act approved July 27, 1923, to be found in Georgia Laws of 1923, beginning on page 671 and entitled: An Act to amend the charter of the City of Hawkinsville; to abolish the offices of mayor and aldermen and certain other offices in said city; to provide for a form of government in said city composed of commissioners and a city manager; to declare the rights and powers
of said government; to amend or repeal such sections of said charter as may be necessary to carry into effect said commissioner-city manager form of government; to create the office of recorder, and a recorder's court, and to provide for the compensation, powers, and term of office of said recorder and the jurisdiction and powers of said recorder's court; to provide for a submission of this Act to a vote of the electors of said city for their approval or rejection, and for other purposes, be and the same is hereby repealed, subject to the provisions of this Act hereinafter appearing. Repeal of commission government, etc.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that a special election in the City of Hawkinsville be held, under the same rules and regulations as to registration and qualification of voters and other conditions and requirements of the city elections of said City of Hawkinsville, on the second Wednesday in October, 1929, between the hours of 7:00 a. m. and 6:00 p. m. The tickets for said election shall have written, or printed thereon: For the repeal of Commission form of Government, or Against repeal of Commission form of Government; and if a majority of those voting in said election shall have voted for repeal of commission form of government, this Act shall be in full force and effect. Provided, however, that in the event this Act is repealed the same shall continue in force until the 31st day of December, 1929, when the same shall be null and void. Referendum as to repeal.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: HAZLEHURST; MAYOR'S DUTIES; ELECTION AND DISCHARGE OF OFFICERS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act creating by substitution a new charter of the City of Hazlehurst, in the County of Jeff Davis, approved August 18, 1919, and Act amendatory thereof; to provide for the disbursement of funds; right to discharge officers; to prescribe the duties of the mayor; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that section 32 of the Act creating by substitution a new charter of the City of Hazlehurst, in the County of Jeff Davis, approved August 18, 1919, and amendatory act thereof, approved July 9, 1924, be amended by striking the words mayor or between the words said council, in the ninth line of said section, and by adding a new sub-paragraph after said section 32, to be known as 32-A, so that when so amended said section shall read as follows: Amendment of Act of 1919 as amended.

Sec. 32. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that at the first regular meeting of the mayor and council each year they shall elect a city clerk, a treasurer, chief of police, a board of health, building inspector, chief of fire department, and city attorney, and such other officers and employees as the mayor and council may deem necessary for the government of said city. Each of said officers shall be elected for a term of one year unless sooner suspended, removed, or discharged by said council, and shall take and subscribe an oath for the faithful performance of their duties, that they are qualified to hold office, and give such bond as the mayor and council may by ordinance prescribe, except where otherwise provided. Said bond shall be made payable to the City of Hazlehurst, and shall be approved by the mayor and council, and recorded in the book kept for that purpose. Election and discharge of officers.

Sec. 32-A. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that it shall be the duty of the mayor of the City of Hazlehurst to keep the council advised from time to time as to the manner in which said officers and employees discharge their duties, and to call the council in special session whenever in his opinion any officer or employee of said city fails in the faithful discharge of duty, and in said meeting so called to present charges against such officer or employee. Mayor's duties.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: JEFFERSON AD VALOREM TAX LIMIT REPEALED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act incorporating the City of Jefferson, Jackson County, Georgia, approved December 12th, 1929, [?] also to amend the Act amendatory thereof, approved August 19th, 1929, so as to provide for making all property, both real and personal, returnable for taxation in said city, to provide for the assessment per hundred dollars; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of the Act the ad valorem tax on all property in the City of Jefferson shall be fixed by the mayor and aldermen of said city, and that there shall be no fixed amount as a maximum amount to be levied on the property therein.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the passage of this Act section one (1) of the Act amending the charter of the City of Jefferson, approved August 19th, 1919, limiting said tax
levy on all property in the City of Jefferson to (17) mills, be and the same is hereby repealed. Tax limit repealed.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved August 15, 1927, entitled an Act to incorporate the City of Kingsland in Camden County and State of Georgia, to define its limits and to define its municipal powers and privileges, and for other purposes, so as to authorize the mayor and councilmen of said city to appropriate from city funds for the support of the public schools of said city; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act that the above-recited Act be amended by adding to and incorporating in the same as follows: It shall be lawful for the mayor and councilmen of said city, by ordinance, to appropriate each year from funds derived from all sources a sum not to exceed one half of all the revenues of said city for the support and maintenance of the public schools located in said city. Annual appropriations of not more than half of revenues for schools.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the city charter of the City of Lakeland, Lanier County, Georgia, Acts of Georgia General Assembly of 1925, section 2, page 1220, approved August 11, 1925, by extending and describing the limits of said municipality; to repeal conflicting laws; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1.
