Be it further enacted, that if the mayor and council determine, in accordance with the provision hereinbefore made, to issue bonds for any of the purposes hereinbefore set out, then they shall have power and authority, in addition to all other taxes hereinbefore authorized, to levy and collect an additional tax not to exceed one per centum per annum, sufficient to pay off said bonds, with all interest and charges on the same within the period which said bonds have to run, and it shall be the duty of said mayor and council, in the published notice of any election for the issuance of any bonds for any of the purposes herein provided, to state the amount of annual tax it will be necessary to levy and collect to pay the same. Tax to pay bonds.

Sec. 40. Be it further enacted, that upon the approval of this Act, title to all property, property rights, easements, and all other property, immunities, and privileges held, owned, and controlled by Town of Montrose heretofore existing under a charter granted by the superior court of Laurens County, be vested in the Town of Montrose incorporated by this Act, so that the Town of Montrose will
succeed to all the rights, titles, immunities, and privileges of the Town of Montrose as it heretofore existed, and that the said Town of Montrose as now incorporated by this Act assume all liabilities and responsibilities of the Town of Montrose as it heretofore existed, and carry out and perfect all agreements made or assumed by the said Town of Montrose as it has heretofore existed, and is liable for its obligation, whether arising ex contractu or ex delicto, and if it becomes necessary to institute suits in law or equity to enforce any such obligations against said Town of Montrose on account of an obligation of the Town of Montrose as it heretofore existed, then such suits, either in law or equity, may be instituted against the Town of Montrose incorporated by this Act. Succession to rights and liabilities under former charter.
Sec. 41. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: MOUNTAIN CITY; ANIMALS AT LARGE; BOUNDARIES; COUNCIL COMMITTEES.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the Town of Mountain City, Georgia, so as to give the said town the right to regulate the running at large of domestic animals, the right to definitely locate the center of town and to change its boundary lines thereof; and for other purposes.
law.p: An Act to amend an act, to amend an act incorporating the Town of Mountain City, Georgia, in Rabun County, approved August 27, 1907, as appears in the Acts of 1907, on pages 827 to 833, inclusive.

Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that section 1 of the Act approved August 22, 1927,
entitled An Act to incorporate the Town of Mountain City and to grant certain powers and privileges to said town, and for other purposes, be amended by striking and repealing from said section 1 of id Act and inserting in lieu thereof the following as section 1 of said Act, which will read as follows: Act of 1927 amended.

Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that the village now known as Mountain City, formerly known as Passover, located in Rabun County, Georgia, be and the same is hereby incorporated under the name and style of the Town of Mountain City, and that the corporate limits of the same shall extend three fourths of a mile, which shall include a circle with a radius of three fourths of a mile from the center of Park Street, beginning at a point in the center of said street between the main tract of Tallulah Falls Railway, which said street intersects with Stecoa Avenue, both of said names and streets being shown in a plot of the Town of Mountain City, Georgia, and recorded in the clerk's office of Rabun superior court in Deed Book U, at page 640. To read.Corporate name and limits.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that section 17 of said Act be and the same is hereby amended by striking from said section the words greater than $10,000.00, and inserting in lieu thereof the following: For such amount or amounts as will not conflict with the constitution and laws of the State of Georgia, then when so amended will read as follows: Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said mayor and council shall not for any one item hereinbefore named bond said town for such an amount or amounts as will not conflict with the constitution and laws of the State of Georgia, and they are hereby authorized and empowered with the right and privilege to enact ordinances under which the interest on said bond shall be duly paid, and the principal thereof when same becomes due. Bonds.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act that said mayor and council shall have the power and authority to prevent horses, mules, cattle, hogs, sheep, dogs, goats, and any and all other animals or fowls from running at large in said town, and to prevent and prohibit the keeping of hogs within the town limits or regulate the manner in which they must be kept if allowed to remain; also to impound such animals when found running at large in said town, and to charge such fees and costs for same as they may prescribe; also when the owner or owners of such animals shall fail or refuse to pay the impounding fee and cost of keeping such animal or animals, the same may be sold at public outcry and the proceeds applied to the payments of said fees and cost of keeping such animal or animals, under such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by said mayor and council. Animals running at large.

Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and thereafter the passage of this Act that the ensuing mayor and council of said Town of Mountain City, as soon as they have taken the oath of office, it shall be the duty of the mayor at the first meeting thereafter to appoint from the members of the council the following committees: finance, street and road, water and sewerage, electric light, sanitary. If any member or members of said council shall fail and refuse to accept the appointment by the mayor to serve on said committee, he or they are guilty of malpractice of office. Council committees.Malpractice in not accepting appointment.

It shall be the duty of the mayor and councilmen to set out the duties of said committees by proper ordinances, and in said ordinance requiring that each committee make a written report at the end of each year, to be filed with the mayor and council. Committee reports.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the passage of this act it shall be the duty mayor and council to file in the council hall an itemized and detailed statement of all receipts
and disbursements of the Town of Mountain City and showing the amount in the city treasury at the time of filing said statement, to show to whom, in what amount, and for what purpose each expenditure was made. It shall be the duty of the clerk and treasurer said city to furnish the council with all books and papers kept by him necessary to make up said statement. That if the mayor or any member or members of said council should fail and refuse to make said report and file same in said council hall, he or they are guilty of malpractice in office. Financial statements.
Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws that conflict with this act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to create a new charter for the City of Newnan in the County of Coweta, approved December 8th, 1893, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, by adding thereto a provision conferring upon the said City of Newnan authority to purchase, own, lease and operate solely for itself, or jointly with the County of Coweta, a municipal landing field within or without the corporate limits of the City of Newnan, for the reception, storage, and operation of airplanes; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that an Act to create a new charter for the City of Newnan in the County of Coweta, approved December 8th, 1893, and the several acts amendatory thereof, be and the same are hereby amended as follows:

Section 1. The City of Newnan in the County of Coweta is hereby authorized and empowered to purchase, own, lease, and operate, solely for itself or jointly with the County of Coweta, a municipal landing field within or without the corporate limits of the City of Newnan, for the reception, storage, and operation of airplanes; also for the use of the government in the air-mail service, and such field or fields may be located either within or without the corporate limits of said city, and when so purchased, leased, or defined, the City of Newnan is given police jurisdiction over the land so acquired. Landing field, authority to operate, etc.; police jurisdiction.

Sec. 2. The said City of Newnan shall have the right and power to purchase or lease land to be used for a municipal landing field, jointly with the County of Coweta, but the said City of Newnan shall not be required to purchase or lease land for such use jointly with said County of Coweta; provided, however, that any land or locations purchased or operated by the City of Newnan as a municipal landing field for the storage and operation of airplanes or for the use of the government in the air-mail service shall be under the exclusive jurisdiction and control of said city, and the said City of Newnan shall have exclusive right and power to pass ordinances regulating the operation and use of said landing field. Authority to purchase landing field jointly with county.

Sec. 3. If the said City of Newnan purchases or leases property for a municipal landing field jointly with the County of Coweta, the said County of Coweta shall have no right or authority to charge or exact any license-fee or occupation taxes for the operation of said landing field or for the operation or conduct of any business or occupation thereon. County not to charge license fee or occupation tax.

Sec. 4. That the City of Newnan is given the full jurisdiction over any lands it may own or lease for such landing field, and such landing field shall be under the exclusive control and jurisdiction of said city, and it alone shall have the right to pass ordinance regulation provisions on said landing field or property so owned or operated or leased. City's jurisdiction over landing field.
Sec. 5. That all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to create a new charter for the City of Newnan, in the County of Coweta, approved December 8th, 1893, and the several acts amendatory thereof, so as to authorize and empower the City of Newnan to condemn private property for any public use of said city; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act an Act creating a new charter for the City of Newnan, in the County of Coweta, approved December 8th, 1893, and the several acts amendatory thereof, be and the same are hereby amended so as to authorize and empower the City of Newnan, acting by and through its mayor and aldermen, in their discretion to condemn private property for any public use of said city as prescribed in general laws of the State of Georgia. Power to condemn property.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that the said City of Newnan, acting by and through its mayor and aldermen in their discretion, shall have full power and authority to condemn property for any public use of said city, whether the said property desired to be condemned for use of said city is in the corporate limits of said city, or adjacent to but without the corporate limits of city. Whenever the City of Newnan shall desire to exercise the power and authority to condemn property for public use as granted and conferred herein, the said power and authority shall be exercised as provided in article 1, chapter 9, of the 1910
Code of Georgia, beginning with section 5206 and embracing all sections having reference to the condemnation of private property for public use and also as provided in the acts amendatory thereof. The said City of Newnan shall have the right and power to condemn property for public uses whether the property sought to be condemned is vested or contingent, and whether the said property sought to be condemned is in the hands of the owner or trustee, executors, administrator, guardian, life tenant, agent, or other persons holding said property for the use of himself or for the use of another. If the said right and power to condemn property for public uses is exercised by the said City of Newnan and the assessors find it necessary to protect the rights of a vested or contingent remainderman or remaindermen, then and in that event the said assessors shall be authorized to impound the fund awarded for the value of the property condemned or for the consequential damage, if any; and if said assessors find that no provision is made for the impounding the funds awarded as aforesaid under the general laws of the State of Georgia, then said assessors shall have the right and authority to order that the total funds awarded in such condemnation proceedings be impounded and paid over to the ordinary or the clerk of the superior court of Coweta County, Georgia, as the case may be, which said ordinary or said clerk, designated by said assessors, shall hold and use the said funds for the use of the life-tenant and preserve the corpus for the use of the vested or contingent remainderman, and during the use aforesaid shall pay over to the life-tenant the net income therefrom, provided that the said ordinary or the said clerk, as the case may be, shall be and is hereby authorized to invest any such proceeds in anything in which trustees may invest funds under the laws of the State of Georgia; and from and after the investment of said funds as aforesaid, the said ordinary or the said clerk and their official bondsmen, as the case may be, shall not be liable to the life-tenant or to the vested or contingent remainderman, if the said funds invested as aforesaid should be impaired or lost, provided further that the said ordinary or the clerk,
as the case may be, shall not be liable to the life-tenant, the vested or contingent remainderman, for any income return thereon in excess of the net income received on the investment as aforesaid. Same.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authorities aforesaid that all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this law be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to create a new charter for the City of Newnan, in the County of Coweta, approved December 8th, 1893, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, to authorize the City of Newnan to pass zoning and planning laws whereby said city may be zoned or districted for various uses, and other or different uses provided therein, and regulating the use for which said zones or districts may be set apart, and regulating the plans for the development of the real estate therein and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the act establishing a new charter for the City of Newnan, in the County of Coweta, approved December 8th, 1893, and the several acts amendatory thereof, be and the same are hereby amended as follows:

Section 1. That the City of Newnan is hereby authorized, by and through its mayor and aldermen, to pass zoning and planning laws whereby said city may be zoned or districted for various uses and other or different uses, and shall be further authorized to pass laws regulating uses for which said zones or districts may be set apart, and to regulate the
plans for developing and improving the real estate within corporate limits of said city. Zoning, planning, building regulations.

Sec. 2. The mayor and aldermen may, in the interest of the public health, safety, order, convenience, comfort, prosperity, or general welfare, adopt by ordinance a plan or plans for the districting or zoning of the city for the purpose of regulating the location of trades, industries, apartment houses, dwellings, or other uses of property, or for the purpose of regulating the height of the buildings or other structures, or for the area or dimensions of the lots, or of the yards used in connection with buildings or other structures, or for the purpose of regulating the alignment of buildings or other structures near street frontages. The zoning regulations may be based upon any one or more of the purposes above described. The city may be divided into such number of zones and districts, and such districts may be of such shape and area, as the mayor and aldermen shall deem best suited to accomplish the purposes of the zoning regulations. In the determination and establishment of districts and regulations, classifications may be based on the nature or character of the trade, industry, profession, or other activity conducted or to be conducted upon the premises, the number of persons, families, or other group units to reside in or use buildings, the public, quasi-public, or private nature of the use of premises, or upon any other basis or bases relevant to the promotion of the public health, safety, order, morals, conveniences, prosperity, or welfare. The said mayor and aldermen shall not have the right by ordinance or law to authorize any filling station to be installed or used on any of streets known as Court Square. Same.

Sec. 2(a). For the reasons above stated, said mayor and aldermen shall have the further right and power, in any districts proposed to be set aside primarily for residence purposes, to further classify the use thereof, and to provide therein the class or classes of residents to be housed therein, and to provide therein such other and similar regulations and restrictions as shall secure the peace and good order of the
city and the residents thereof. No such ordinance or amendment thereto, authorized by either of the above sections, shall be adopted except by three fourths vote of the mayor and aldermen. Classification of uses of property.Three-fourths vote required to pass ordinance.

Sec. 3. The City of Newnan, by and through its mayor and aldermen, may from time to time amend or change the regulations or districts established by the zoning ordinance. Whenever the owners of fifty per cent. of the land in any district shall present a petition duly signed and acknowledged to the mayor and aldermen, requesting an amendment of the regulations prescribed for such area or district, it shall be the duty of the mayor and aldermen of said city to vote upon such an amendment within ninety days of the filing of same by the petitioners with the city clerk. Change of regulations.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted that all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to incorporate the Town of Oak Park, in the County of Emanuel, to fix the corporate limits thereof, to provide for the mayor and aldermen and other officers, to define their powers and duties, to define the powers of the said town, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that Oak Park, located in the County of Emanuel, State of Georgia, be and the same is hereby incorporated as a town under the name of Oak Park. Incorporation.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that the corporate limits of said town shall be as follows: One half of one mile in
all directions from the center of Main Street directly in front of the building now occupied by Oak Park post-office in said Town of Oak Park, that is, from the point in the center of Main Street in said town described by the crossing of the two lines, one line marking the middle of said street and the other running from the middle of said building parallel with the north and south sides of said building. The center of said town shall be the point where the said two lines intersect. Corporate limits.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted that the municipal government of the said town shall consist of a mayor and five aldermen, who are hereby constituted a body corporate under the name and style of the mayor and council of the Town of Oak Park, and by that name and style shall have perpetual succession and do all acts relating to their corporate capacity, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded. Mayor and council; powers.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted that on the first Tuesday in October, 1929, and annually thereafter an election shall be held in the Town of Oak Park for mayor and aldermen, whose terms of office shall begin immediately upon their qualification. Said election shall be held and conducted in the same manner as elections for State and county officers and the certificates of the managers shall be sufficient authority for the officers elected to enter upon the discharge of their duties. The term of office shall be for one year and until their successors are elected and qualified. Elections for mayor and aldermen.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted that all bona fide residents of said town eligible to vote for members of the General Assembly at the time of the passage of this Act shall be qualified to vote in said election. Voters.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted the mayor and council before entering upon the discharge of their duties, shall take the usual oath of office before some officer qualified to administer oaths. Oath of mayor, etc.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council shall elect a marshal and clerk and prescribe their duties
and require of them such bonds as may be necessary, and to fix such compensation as may be just and proper. Marshal and clerk.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council are authorized and empowered to pass ordinances, by-laws, and regulations necessary for the government, peace, order, and health of said town. Power as to ordinances, etc.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted that said town authorities are empowered to levy taxes not to exceed one half of one per centum on all property, real and personal, subject to the State and county tax within the limits of said town, and also to require all persons subject to road duty under the State laws to work on the streets and sidewalks in said town, or in lieu of said work to collect a reasonable commutation tax. Taxes.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted that said authorities are empowered to provide for the arrest and punishment of offenders against the laws or ordinances of said town, and may fine said offenders or imprison, or cause them to work on the public works of the said town, provided that no one shall be fined exceeding fifty dollars nor imprisoned or caused to work upon the public works of the said town for a longer period than ninety days. Punishment.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted that the said authorities are empowered to elect a mayor pro tem. who will perform all the duties of mayor in the absence or disability of that officer, and also to fill vacancies which may occur in the office of mayor, aldermen, or any other officer of said town. Mayor pro tem.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted that said mayor and council shall provide for the collection of taxes, fines, and all monies due said town, and to this end the mayor shall issue his executions and the same shall be executed by the marshal. Executions for taxes, etc.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted that the mayor, or mayor pro tem. when acting as mayor, may compel the attendance of witnesses, examine them under oath, admit offenders
to bail or commit them to guard-house or county jail for the violation of any of the ordinances of the said town. Mayor's powers as committing magistrate.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted that the mayor shall be the chief executive officer. He shall see that all ordinances and laws are faithfully executed and obeyed, appoint special police when necessary, over whom he shall have full control. He shall issue executions for all fines and costs imposed by him, or, in default of immediate payment, without execution, may imprison offenders not exceeding ninety days. Duties of mayor.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council of said town are prohibited from in any manner whatever directly or indirectly authorizing or permitting any person or corporation from engaging in any business within the limits of said town, which business is prohibited by the laws of the State of Georgia or of the United States of America. Unlawful business, prohibition of.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted that in addition to ad valorem tax the mayor and council of said town shall have authority to levy special taxes on all businesses, trades, hotels, and boarding houses, to provide by ordinances for the return of all real and personal property for taxation, prescribe the time when same shall be due, to double tax defaulters and enforce the same by execution, levy, and sale, to try nuisances and abate the same, and to define what shall constitute a nuisance, to take up and impound dogs, horses, cattle, mules, and hogs running at large in said town, and to pass necessary ordinances for the regulation of stock and other animals in said town, and to require owners of lots to drain the same and to fill excavations or depressions, and to otherwise enact and enforce regulations as to sanitation; provided, however, that as to stock running at large in said town the foregoing provisions shall apply solely to stock owned by the residents of said town. Stock of non-resident farmers, while fence law prevailed in the adjacent territory, which may wander into said town shall not be taken up and impounded, but,
non-residents who wilfully put stock within the limits of said town may be fined by the mayor of said town for disorderly conduct against said town. Taxes.Nuisances.Animals at large.Sanitation.

Sec. 17. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council shall have authority to lay off and to open up streets and alleys and to condemn the property and lands of any person for this purpose, and to vacate, close, and open streets and alleys, to prohibit any one from laying out any new street or alley except by the consent of the mayor and council, to regulate the width of the sidewalks and to pave and repair the pavements at cost of the owners of adjoining real estate, and to enforce the payment of said cost by execution against the property and the owner of the same. Streets.

Sec. 18. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council are empowered to remove obstructions from the streets or sidewalks, to make official survey of the town and the corporate limits thereof, to organize a chain-gang and to put at compulsory labor thereon all persons convicted of violating any of the ordinances of said town, and punish persons for vagrancy, and to bind over to the proper State courts, in default of bail, all offenders demanding the right of trial by jury, to commit to jail all offenders against the laws of the State of Georgia. Street obstructions.Chain-gang.Vagrancy. Commitment of offenders.

Sec. 19. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council of the Town of Oak Park shall have the authority usually vested in the justices of the peace of said State, to hold courts of inquiry and to commit offenders to the State courts. Commitment.
Sec. 20. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

Sec. 21. Be it further enacted that the provisions of this Act shall not take effect unless and until the same is submitted to the legally qualified voters residing within the limits of the said Town of Oak Park, which limits are defined herein, and unless at such election two thirds of the
voters who vote in said election vote in favor of the adoption of this charter. The said election shall be held within fifteen days from the date this Act is approved by the Governor, notice of which election shall be given by posting a notice of same at three public places within the limits of said town, one of which notices shall be at the door of the post-office in said town, and said notices shall be posted for ten days before the date of said election. Said election shall be by ballot and shall be held as elections are usually held, and the voters shall write upon their ballot the words For Charter or Against Charter. If two thirds of the votes cast in such election shall be For Charter, then the provisions of this Act shall take effect immediately on the declaration of the managers of said election that two thirds of the votes cast were in favor of the charter. If less than two thirds of the votes cast in said election are for the charter, then the provisions of this Act shall not take effect but shall be null and void. Referendum.

law.shorttitle: OCHLOCKNEE; ANIMALS RUNNING AT LARGE; ELECTION AS TO.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act approved August 22d, 1907, incorporating the Town of Ochlocknee in Thomas County, Georgia, which aforesaid Act created a new charter and municipal government for said corporation, by amending the aforesaid Act so as to confer upon said Town of Ochlocknee the full power and right to enact any and all ordinances to prevent the running at large in said town or any portion thereof horses, mules, cattle, hogs, sheep, goats, dogs, and fowls; to prevent the keeping of hogs in the town limits, with full power to impound any such animal or fowl and punish all owners of such animals or fowls who refuse to obey any lawful ordinances
passed in pursuance of this power, and to further authorize and empower said Town of Ochlocknee to hold once in every two years an election by the qualified voters therein to determine the question whether or not said animals shall be permitted to be at large in said town limits; to prescribe for the taking up and impounding of such animals, their sale and disposition; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority thereof, that the municipal charter of the Town of Ochlocknee in the County of Thomas, State of Georgia, be and the same is hereby amended as follows:

First. The said mayor and councilmen shall have full power and authority to prevent horses, mules, cattle, hogs, sheep, goats, dogs and fowls from running at large in said city or any portion thereof and to prevent and prohibit the keeping of hogs in said town limits, and shall have full power to take up and impound any such animal or fowl and punish all owners of such animals who refuse to obey any ordinance passed by said mayor and councilmen to carry this authority to effect. Authority as to animals running at large.

Second. The said mayor and councilmen shall have authority, whenever requested so to do by 50% of those qualified to vote in elections for officers of said town, to order an election to determine whether or not the animals referred to in section one of this amendment shall be permitted to run at large upon the streets of said town. Said election to be held under the same rules and regulations as are now prescribed by law for holding elections for officers of said town. The aforesaid elections to be held not oftener than once in every two years. The tickets to be voted in said election shall be as follows: For allowing animals to run at large on the streets, Against animals being allowed to run at large on the streets. Election as to animals at large.

Third. Should the result of any such election result in a vote of the majority of those voting against allowing said
animals to run at large on said streets, the said mayor and councilmen shall have full power to pass any and all ordinances necessary to carry out the provisions of this amendment. Same.

law.shorttitle: RANGER; AUTOMOBILE SPEED, FINE FOR EXCEEDING LIMIT; STREET-TAX; AD VALOREM TAX.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the Town of Ranger, in Gordon County, Georgia, approved August 15, 1910, to provide for the fixing and collecting of collection of a street-tax in the Town of Ranger and the punishing of defaulters; for the regulation of the use of automobiles over and upon the streets of said Town of Ranger and the punishment of reckless drivers; amending sections 5 and 7 of said charter of Ranger.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, as follows:

Section 1. That the mayor and aldermen of the Town of Ranger shall have the power to regulate the speed of automobiles within the corporate limits of said Town of Ranger; and any person, either by himself or any person acting for the owner of such automobile, violating the speed limit shall forfeit and pay, on being convicted thereof, the sum of twenty-five dollars to the Town of Ranger. Speed of automobiles; penalty.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by the same, that the mayor and aldermen shall have power and authority to pass all laws and ordinances concerning the streets in said town; to prescribe who shall be liable to street-work or duty; to provide for the levying and collecting of a street-tax in
lieu of said work; and to provide a penalty against persons failing or refusing to work said streets or pay the tax instead of such work. Authority as to streets.Street-work or tax.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by the same, that section five of the original charter of said town is hereby amended as follows: By substituting for the words town jail, wherever the same occurs in said paragraph, the words county jail. Charter amended by substituting town jail for county jail.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that section 7 of the said charter of the Town of Ranger be and the same is hereby amended by striking out the words ten cents on one hundred dollars worth of property, where the same occurs in line four of said section seven, and substituting in lieu thereof the following, fifty cents on one hundred dollars worth of property, so that said section when amended, shall read as follows: That the mayor and aldermen shall have authority to levy and collect taxes for the support of the government of said town, not to exceed fifty cents on one hundred dollars worth of property, in the Town of Ranger. And they shall fix the compensation of the mayor, aldermen, and all other employees of said town. Tax rates increased.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that all laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act creating a new charter for the Town of Rockledge in the County of Laurens, approved August 21, 1916; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that that certain Act which creates a new charter for the Town of Rockledge, in the County of Laurens, approved August 21st, 1916, be and the same is hereby repealed; so that after the passage of this Act the Town of Rockledge in the County of Laurens shall no longer exist as an incorporated town of this State. Repeal of charter.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved August 15, 1904, incorporating the City of Rockmart, Georgia, as amended by an Act approved August 8th, 1917, by striking therefrom section 15, as amended, and by inserting in lieu thereof another section, to be numbered 15, prescribing and fixing the corporate limits of the City of Rockmart, so that the corporate limits may be extended to include certain additional territory annexed upon petition of taxpayers; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of same, that an Act approved August 15th, 1904, incorporating the City of Rockmart, Polk County, Georgia, as amended by an Act Approved August 8th, 1917, be amended by striking therefrom section 15 as so amended, and by inserting in lieu thereof another section, to be numbered 15, prescribing and fixing the corporate limits of the City 15, prescribing and fixing the corporate limits of the City of Rockmart as follows: Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, that the corporate limits of the City of Rockmart, in the
County of Polk, shall extend to and embrace all the territory within the boundary lines described as follows: Land lot numbers 793, 794, 863, 864, 865, and 866 in the eighteenth district and third section of Polk County, Georgia, also beginning at the southeast corner of land lot number eight hundred and sixty-six (866), being the southeast corner of the city limits of the said City of Rockmart, and running east along the south line of land-lot number eight hundred and sixty-seven (867), a distance of 500 feet; thence north parallel with city limits as existing prior to Act 1917, through land-lot numbers 867, 862, and 795, to the point of intersection of said line with the right of way of the Southern Railway Company; thence east along the south side of the right of way of the Southern Railway Company a distance of 200 feet; thence north through land-lots numbers 795 and 790 to a point 700 feet north of Walnut street; thence due west parallel with Walnut Street through land-lot numbers 790, 791, and 792, all of above described land-lots lying and being in the eighteenth district and the third section of Polk County, Georgia; also extending said line west, parallel with the city limits as existing prior to Act of 1917, and 700 feet north thereof, through land-lot number 778 in the twenty-first district and third section of Polk County, Georgia, to the intersection of said line with Euharlee Creek, thence south along Euharlee Creek to the intersection of said creek with the city limits as existing prior to Act of 1917, on the north line of land-lot number 851; also land-lots numbers 849, 850, 851, 852, 853, 854, 923, 924, 925, all lying and being in the twenty-first district and third section of Polk County, Georgia. And in addition to the territory above described, as set forth in the Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved August 8th, 1917, the following territory annexed and included within said city limits upon petitions of taxpayers, as provided by law, since the amending Act of 1917, is hereby added to and included within the corporate limits of the City of Rockmart, Georgia, and made a part thereof, as follows: Vacant lot owned by J. F. Brooke on the east side of Jones Avenue, fronting on said avenue
or street sixty-six (66) feet, and running back, of uniform width, 350 feet, and lying just north of former city limits of the City of Rockmart, Georgia; also the home place of W. B. Cochran on said Jones Avenue, said tract of land fronting on said Jones Avenue two hundred and fifty-seven feet, and running back, of uniform width, 350 feet, and lying just north of the tract above described belonging to J. F. Brooke, and being the home place where W. B. Cochran resided; also two vacant lots owned by O. F. Morris, lying just north of the former city limits, fronting fifty feet each on Jones Avenue on the west side, and running back, of uniform width, 200 feet; also two lots lying at the rear of the O. F. Morris lots above described, and lying just north of the former city limits of the City of Rockmart, and fronting fifty feet each, and running back, of uniform width, two hundred feet, more or less; also two lots formerly owned by Hugh F. VanDeventer, fronting fifty feet each on Wilson Street, and running back, of uniform width, 200 feet, and lying just north of the former city limits of the City of Rockmart, Georgia; also two lots known as the P. H. Durham property, lying just behind the Hugh F. VanDeventer lots as above described, and lying just north of the former city limits of the City of Rockmart, and being known as city lots numbers 54 and 55 of the Jones Subdivision; all the above-described property being part of land lying in 18th district and 3d section of Polk County, Georgia, and being the territory annexed upon petition of taxpayers by ordinance of the mayor and council of City of Rockmart, September 7th, 1926. Also a tract of land annexed upon petition of Mrs. P. H. Durham, as follows: Beginning at the northwest corner of Heard Street and Forrest Avenue, and running north along Forrest Avenue sixty feet; thence running due west two hundred and ten feet; thence running south to former city limits, and upon which tract is located the Mrs. P. H. Durham dwelling. Also the following additional territory annexed by the mayor and council upon petition of Goodyear Clearwater Mills, to wit: Beginning at a point where the present city-limits line intersects the north right of way line of the
Southern Railway, thence running east a distance of approximately 1,418 feet, following the said right of way line of the Southern Railway to a steel fence-corner near the southeast corner of the Goodyear Clearwater Mill No. 2 site; thence along said fence in a northerly direction to a fence-corner on the south side of Goodyear Avenue; thence along the southeast side of Goodyear Avenue to the west side of Cartersville road; thence along the west side of Cartersville road to the northwest side of Goodyear Avenue; thence in a southwesterly direction along the northwest side of Goodyear Avenue to the south side of B Street; thence in a westerly direction along the south side of B Street to the west side of Piedmont Avenue; thence along the west side of Piedmont Avenue in a southwesterly direction to the north side of C Street; thence in a northwesterly direction along the north side of C Street to the western property line of the Goodyear Clearwater Mill No. 2; thence south along said property line to its intersection with the present city-limits line; thence east and south along said present city-limits line to the point of beginning; all in accordance with plat showing development of the Goodyear Clearwater Mill No. 2, as prepared by Robert and Company, engineers, a copy of which is attached to petition of Goodyear Clearwater Mills for annexation of this territory, and of file in office city clerk of City of Rockmart, all said territory referred to as Goodyear tract being in 18th district and third section of Polk County, Georgia. It is the purpose and intent of this Act to include all the territory described in Act approved August 8th, 1917, and also to add thereto and to include within the corporate limits all territory added thereto upon petition of taxpayers as described and set forth herein. The city limits may be extended at any time upon petition of two thirds of the taxpayers of the territory sought to be included; and any part of the territory inside the city limits may be excluded upon a two thirds vote of the qualified voters of said city voting at a regular election or at an election to be called for that purpose; said election to be called by the mayor and council. New territory.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: ROME CORPORATE LIMITS EXTENDED; NEW WARDS; TAX RATES; IMPROVEMENTS; CITY MANAGER'S SALARY; AIRPORT.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to create a new charter and municipal government of the City of Rome, to define the rights and powers of the municipality, to define the corporate limits thereof, and to repeal all former charters and all laws in conflict therewith, approved August 19, 1918, as amended; to provide for annexation of new territory and the extension of the corporate limits of said city; creation of new wards out of parts of such territory so annexed; to provide for improvement of parts of the annexed territory; to provide for taking over the schools in the annexed territory and the assumption of the bonded debt incurred in the improvement of the same; and to provide for the assessment of farm lands therein, to authorize the Rome City Commission to determine to permanently or temporarily abandon, close, lease, sell, convey, or otherwise dispose of streets, lanes, alleys, avenues, and sidewalks in said city; to authorize a greater rate of tax and apportion same; to authorize curbing and guttering and paving; to provide assessment for sewers; to provide for publication of notice of local improvements; to authorize salary for city manager; to safeguard the constitutionality of this Act; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that an Act entitled An Act to create a new charter and
municipal government of the City of Rome, to define the rights and powers of the municipality, to define the corporate limits thereof, and to repeal all former charters and all laws in conflict therewith, approved August 19, 1918, as amended, be and the same is hereby amended as follows: Act amended.

item.p: Section 1. (A) That the limits of the City of Rome are hereby changed, enlarged, and extended on September 1, 1929, to take in and add to said City of Rome the following territory adjacent to the present city boundary, described as beginning where the present city boundary line crosses Hill Street or Avenue, east of Second Avenue in the Seventh Ward; thence southerly along a street or alley two hundred feet, more or less, east of Second Avenue to Archer Street; thence westerly along said Archer Street so far as it goes, and then due west to a point two hundred feet east of the east side of Dean Street or the Chulio Road; thence southerly two hundred feet from the east side of Dean Street to a point two hundred feet south of East Twentieth Street; thence west two hundred feet south of East Twentieth Street so far as it goes; thence west to Silver Creek; thence northerly down Silver Creek to south line of property of Anchor Duck Mills where it crosses said creek; thence westerly along said property line crossing Cave Spring Road, and then, following the said property line of said Anchor Duck Mill touches the present city boundary near the powder houses on Blanche Street; thence easterly along the present city boundary to beginning point at Hill Street or Avenue. Reference is hereby made to Adolph and C. O. Deitz revised map of the 1922 of Deitz Brothers map of the City of Rome of 1890, for names and location of streets, and other facts to identify and locate the lines above stated. To read; New territory.

(B) The territory described in paragraph (A) of this section shall constitute a separate ward of the City of Rome, to be known as the Eighth Ward; and it shall be the duty of the Rome City Commission to call an election, to be held within thirty days after September 1st, 1929, for the election
of a commissioner to represent said ward as a member of said Rome City Commission, at which election only residents of the territory embraced within said Eighth Ward shall be entitled to vote. The commissioner so elected shall serve until the next regular election for commissioners as provided in the charter of the City of Rome. At such special election the provisions of the charter of the City of Rome as to registration of voters and the holding of elections shall apply. At all elections thereafter the commissioner to represent said ward shall be selected in the manner provided by the charter of the City of Rome then in force for the election of city commissioners. Eighth Ward.Commissioner to represent ward.

(C) Immediately after September 1st, 1929, it shall become the duty of the Rome City Commission to cause an immediate survey to be made, and to determine the watermains, street lights, fire-plugs, signal system, and all other protection necessary to, and with a view of bringing this territory to the same standard of improvements as other wards of the City of Rome now have. The said commission shall also have a survey of the school population made of said territory; and shall immediately provide and continuously maintain, within the limits of said territory, adequate school buildings, equipment, and other facilities, for children up to and including the sixth grade; provided, however, that any children residing in said ward shall have the privilege of attending schools in other wards of the city, including the high schools, subject to the reasonable rules and regulations of the board of education of said city with respect thereto. Survey of new territory.

Sec. 2. (A) That the limits of the City of Rome are hereby changed, enlarged, and extended on September 1st, 1929, to take in and add to said City of Rome the following territory adjacent to the present city boundary, described as beginning on the south bank of the Coosa River where the present city boundary line crosses said river; thence on a straight line to the north or west bank at the mouth of Horseleg Creek; thence along the south bank of Horseleg Creek to a point eleven hundred feet due west
air-line of the line between the 23d District, 3d Section and the 4th District, 4th Section, Floyd County; thence due north to a point six hundred feet south of the south line of the Alabama Road or Shorter Avenue; thence westerly six hundred feet south of said road to the Burnett's Ferry Road; thence on shortest straight line to the line of George C. Stiles' property; thence northerly along the east line of said Stiles property to Alabama Road; thence across said road north to north line of right of way of Southern Railway Company; thence easterly along said right of way line to west line of property of Standard Stove and Range Company; thence northerly along west line of said property to northwest corner of said property; thence easterly along line to northeast corner of said property; thence due east to west line of Carsen or Garsen Street; thence northerly along said street to its north end; thence east to Fortune Street; thence northerly along Fortune Street to property of the W. S. Dickey Clay Products Company; thence easterly along the line of the property of said company to the Central of Georgia Railway Company; thence east across the right of way of said railway company to the northeast line of said right of way; thence southeasterly along said northeast line of said right of way to property of Romega Clay Products Company; thence easterly and southerly along the line of said company to the right of way of Southern Railway Company and the present city limits; thence along present city boundary line to the beginning point on the Coosa River. Reference to streets, distances, locations and directions is hereby made to Adolph and C. O. Dietz's revised map of 1922 of Dietz Brother's map of the City of Rome of 1890, for names of streets and other information to indentity and locate lines above stated. New territory.

(B) The territory described in paragraph (A) of this section shall constitute a separate ward of the City of Rome, to be known as the Ninth Ward; and it shall be the duty of the Rome City Commission to call an election to be held within thirty days after September 1st, 1929, for the election
of a commissioner to represent said ward as a member of said Rome City Commission, at which election only residents of the territory embraced within said Ninth Ward shall be entitled to vote. The commissioner so elected shall serve until the next regular election for commissioner as provided in the charter of the City of Rome. At such special election the provisions of the charter of the City of Rome, as to registration of voters and the holding of elections, shall apply. At all elections thereafter the commissioner to represent said ward shall be selected in the manner provided by the charter of the City of Rome then in force for the election of city commissioners. Ninth Ward.Commissioner to represent ward.

(C) Immediately after September 1st, 1929, it shall become the duty of the Rome City Commission to cause an immediate survey to be made, and to determine the watermains, street lights, fire-plugs, signal system, and all other protection necessary to, and with a view of bringing this territory to the same standard of such improvements as other wards of the City of Rome now have. The said commission shall also have a survey made of the school population of said territory, and shall immediately provide and continuously maintain, within the limits of said territory, school facilities equal to those enjoyed by other wards of the City of Rome. Survey of water-mains, lights, school population, etc. in new territory.

(D) The City of Rome shall take over and maintain the public schools and be vested with title to the property thereof now located in said territory, and shall assume and pay off, according to their terms, any bonds outstanding for same, principal and interest, and for the five-year period after said annexation becomes effective the same shall be paid out of the taxes allocated to said ward as provided in section four of this Act. City to take over school property in new territory and assume bonds.

(E) The territory embraced within the present West Rome School District, and not in the territory annexed to the City of Rome, as hereinbefore described, shall remain as the West Rome School District, unless otherwise changed or provided for by the Floyd County Board of Education;
and the Floyd County Board of Education shall pay to the City of Rome three-sevenths of per capita part of the school funds of Floyd County for the school children living in the above-described territory, both from the State and county-wide school tax, levied and collected in 1929; and all of the above-named taxes collected after 1929, so long as the children in said territory are allowed to attend the city schools; and the trustees of the West Rome School District shall assess and pay to the City of Rome all of the special present rate West Rome School District tax collected on the property outside of the annexed territory. The said special district tax shall be levied and collected for the year 1929 both for the territory annexed and not annexed, and paid to the City of Rome; and the children of school age residing in said territory outside of annexed part shall be allowed to attend the public schools of the City of Rome for a period of five years from the date this annexation becomes effective, without cost of tuition, unless other arrangements are made by the Floyd County Board of Education. School funds.Special district tax.

law.p: Sec. 3. The taxable property in the Eighth and Ninth Wards, as herein provided, shall be assessed at the same value by the City of Rome that it was returned at to Floyd County for the year 1928. In case the said property was improved during 1928, then the assessment by the city shall be the same as the 1929 county assessment; and in case any substantial improvement occurs after the 1929 tax-valuation date, then the property shall be assessed by the city as any other city property is assessed; provided, however, that ordinary repairs and minor additions shall not be considered such an improvement. When the property is not assessed or returned for taxes in 1928 or 1929, then the same shall be assessed by the city as any other property is assessed. Assessment for taxation.

When the property is assessed by the city on the 1928 or the 1929 county basis, as required above, the said assessment shall not be raised by the city for a period of five years, unless the property is improved, in which event the
same shall then be assessed as any other property of the city is assessed. And land in such territory used only for farm purposes shall be assessed only on the farm value by the city so long as so used.

Sec. 4. All property in said Eighth and Ninth Wards shall pay the same rate of tax as other property in the City of Rome. But all taxes collected on property assessed on the basis of the 1928 or the 1929 county assessments shall, so long as the same remains on that basis, be collected by the city and covered into separate special accounts; the taxes collected on such property in the Eighth Ward shall be placed in a special account for that ward, and the taxes collected on such property in the Ninth Ward shall be placed in a special account for that ward. Tax rate.Separation of tax funds, and use of funds.

One half of the special account or fund for the Eighth Ward shall be subject to the general draft of the city, and may be used by the city for its general purposes, but the other half shall be drawn and expended only for permanent improvements in that ward, such as waterworks extension, street improvement, fire-plugs, fire hall and equipment, schoolhouse and equipment, and other permanent improvements.

All of the special account or fund for the Ninth Ward shall be drawn and expended only for permanent improvements in that ward, such as waterworks extension, street improvements, fire-plugs, fire hall and equipment, West Rome school bonds and interest, school building and equipment, and other permanent improvements in said ward.

Sec. 5. When property in said Eighth or Ninth Wards is built on, improved, or developed after January 1st, 1929, or other property brought into the ward, it shall be assessed as other property of the city is assessed, and the taxes therefrom, together with street taxes, police fines, State school fund, county wide or district school taxes, business licenses and other special taxes, assessments, or licenses shall go to the City of Rome for its general accounts, and shall not have to be expended in the wards, except that the
City of Rome shall operate the schools in said wards, provide police protection, operte the fire halls when built and equipped, from the special funds, furnish fire protection from existing stations, so far as possible, till special ward protection can be secured from the special funds, furnish garbage collection, street maintenance, sanitary inspection, street lighting, and other current operations. Same.

Sec. 6. Immediately after the annexation of said wards becomes effective, a survey of all streets and sidewalks shall be made, and a map thereof made and filed in the office of the secretary of the Rome City Commission, the expense thereof to be paid out of the general funds of the City of Rome. Survey and map of annexed territory.

Sec. 7. If the owner of any property in said annexed territory owns or has put in any water-mains or water-pipes that would have been a charge against or should have been paid for by the City of Rome had said territory been within the corporate limits thereof, said property owner shall be paid the reasonable value thereof by the City of Rome; and if an agreement as to the amount to be so paid cannot be reached by said property owner and said City of Rome, the same shall be arbitrated in the manner and subject to all the rules of procedure as provided by sections 5030 and 5054, inclusive, of the Code of Georgia of 1910, with the right of appeal from the award by either party to the superior court of said County of Floyd; provided, however, that the city shall not be required to pay for any such improvement as has become obsolete or useless, and any payment made shall be from the special ward fund. Reimbursement of property owners for expense of water-pipes, etc.

Sec. 8. If, within said annexed territory, any person or corporation operates on September 1, 1929, an ice plant, laundry, wood or coal yard, or similar enterprise, selling to or serving only its own employees, no license-tax or assessment on account thereof shall be levied or required to be paid by the City of Rome, so long as same is so operated. License-tax exemption as to certain businesses operated on Sept. 1, 1929.

Sec. 9. Assessments for local improvements, as provided by the city charter, and any amendments thereto, shall apply in all annexed territory, and the liability of property owners in said territory to such assessment shall be the same as in other ward of the city. Assessments for improvements.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, that section three of an Act of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, approved August 18, 1927, entitled An Act to create a new charter and municipal government of the City of Rome, to define the rights and powers of the municipality, to define the corporate limits thereof, and to repeal all former charters and all laws in conflict therewith, approved August 19, 1918, as amended; to provide for annexation of new territory and the extension of the corporate limits of said city, creation of new wards out of such territory so annexed, to provide elections for such extensions and annexations and the registration of voters therefor; to provide for improvement of the annexed territory; to provide for taking over the schools in the annexed territory and the assumption of the bonded debt incurred in the improvement of the same; to provide for the assessment of farm lands therein; to authorize the Rome City Commission to fix times of meeting, to authorize the Rome City Commission to determine permanently or termporarily abandon, close, lease, sell, convey or otherwise dispose of streets, lanes, alleys, avenues, and sidewalks in said city; to safeguard the constitutionality of this Act; and for other purposes, be and the same is hereby amended by inserting a proviso at the end of such section as follows: Provided that before any street, lane, alley, avenue or sidewalk or any part of the same is closed, sold, conveyed, or otherwise disposed of, or leased, a resolution shall be adopted at a regular session of the Rome City Commission, accurately describing such street, lane, alley, avenue, or sidewalk or any party of the same, together with the intentions of the Rome City Commission in regard to the same, and as to the disposition of the same, together with the name of the person, firm, or corporation to whom it is to be disposed,
and the terms and conditions upon which the same is to be disposed of, which resolution shall thereupon be published in the newspaper in which marshal's sales are advertised, once a week for four weeks. Thereupon, if at the end of such publication no objection is made, the said Rome City Commission can proceed by ordinance to make such disposition. If, however, objection is made by any citizen or property owner of the City of Rome, full hearing shall be given such objection before such ordinance is introduced. And provided further that in case the closing, selling, conveying, leasing, or otherwise disposing of any such street, lane, alley, avenue or sidewalk, or any part of the same, shall result in special damage to any citizen or taxpayer of the City of Rome, the said City of Rome shall be liable therefor. Act of 1927, Sec. 3, amended by adding proviso.To read.Resolution to authorize closing of street, etc., and disposition of property.Hearing of objection.

Sec. 11. Be it further resolved that section 42 of an Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved August 19, 1918, be and the same is hereby repealed and stricken, together with all amendments thereto, the title of said Act being An Act to create a new charter and municipal government for the City of Rome, to define the rights and powers of municipality, to define the corporate limits thereof, and to repeal all former charters and all laws in conflict therewith. That in lieu of said section and amendments thereof, so repealed, the following be and the same is hereby enacted. Sec. 42. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that for the purpose of raising revenue for the support and maintenance of the government of said City of Rome, including the payment of bonds, interest on the bonded debt, and the creation of a sinking fund for the extinguishment of said bonded debt, and for paving and macadamizing streets, and for all other purposes, the said City Commission shall have full power and authority for the assessment, levy, and collection of ad valorem taxes on all real and personal property owned or held within the corporate limits of said city which, under the laws of the State, is subject to taxation, not to exceed 2% of the assessed value of all such property, provided one half of
one per cent. of the assessed value of all such property shall be used only for the support and maintenance of the public-school system of said City of Rome, including buildings, repairing buildings, and improving school grounds. And provided further that it shall not be mandatory on the governing authorities to levy the full amount of said school-tax or the full amount of taxes provided for all purposes, but if the full amount of taxation provided for, amounting to 2%, is levied, one half of one per cent. shall be for school purposes. Substitute for Sec. 42 of Act of 1918.To read.Tax rate; percentage for school purposes.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authorities aforesaid, that section 3 of an Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved August 7, 1925, and entitled An Act to create a new charter and municipal government for the City of Rome, to define the rights and powers of the municipality; to define the corporate limits thereof, and to repeal all former charters and all laws in conflict therewith, approved August 19th, 1918, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, and to provide for a change in the city limits and a change in the qualification of city manager; to provide for the improvement, grading, paving, macadamizing, and draining of any streets, avenues, alleys, lanes, and other public places, and the making and collecting of assessments for the same; to provide for the laying of sidewalks, curbs, and gutters, and to make assessments for the same; to create sewerage districts, both within and outside of the city limits, and to provide for assessments to build sewers; to authorize the issue of executions for all assessments for such improvements, and the issue and sale of bonds covering said sewer and street improvements; to provide an age limit and pensions for officers, agents, and employees of the city; to provide for creation of a city planning commission, and appropriations for the same, to provide for registration of voters of the city; to authorize condemnation by the city, of property inside or outside of the city limits, for the laying out of sewers or creation of sewer districts; to authorize the purchase of property outside the city limits for schools or parks or playgrounds, and the incorporation of
the same into the city limits; to authorize an additional tax levy for purchasing and acquiring, equipping and maintaining public parks and playgrounds, the payment of the floating debt, the extension and improvement of the waterworks system, for street improvement and the permanent improvement of the public-school system; and for other purposes, be and the same is hereby amended, so as to read as follows:

Sec. 3. Sections 77 and 78 of said Act approved August 19, 1918, are hereby stricken and repealed and in lieu thereof, the following is inserted as section 77 of said Act: Sec. 77. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, that: Substitute for Section 77 of Act of 1918.

item.p:
(a) Whenever the said Rome City Commission shall deem it necessary to grade, pave, macadamize, drain, or otherwise improve any street, avenue, alley, lane, or any part thereof within the limits of the City of Rome, said commission shall by resolution declare such work or improvement necessary to be done, and such resolution shall be published at least once in a daily newspaper published and having a general circulation in the City of Rome, and a copy of said resolution shall be served personally or by mail upon the owners of the land liable to assessment to pay for said improvements, if resident in the City of Rome, or upon their agent if not resident in the City of Rome, and if no agent, service shall be perfected by mailing a copy to said owners direct, to the last known address of such owners; then said commission shall have power to cause said improvement to be made and to contract therefor, and to levy assessments or liens hereinafter provided for. Any number of streets, avenues, alleys, lanes, or other public places or parts thereof, to be so improved, may be included in one resolution, but any protest or objection shall be made as to each street, avenue, alley, lane, or other public place, or other highway separately; provided, however, that if a majority of the owners of the land liable to assessment for any such improvement shall petition the Rome City Commission for such improvement of any street or part of street, alley, lane, or avenue or other
public place described in such petition, the character of the improvement so desired, the width of the same, and the materials preferred by the petitioners for such improvements, it shall thereupon be the duty of said commission to promptly cause the said improvement to be made, in accordance with the prayer of said petition, and in such cases the resolution and the publication and service of the same hereinbefore mentioned shall not be required. To read.Resolution declaring necessity for street improvement; notice.

(b) The lots, pieces, or parcels of land fronting and abutting on both sides of said improvements shall be charged with the cost thereof according to the just pro rata of the entire cost of said improvement for the said frontage on basis of lineal-foot frontage; provided that the frontage of intersecting streets, avenues, lanes, or alleys, including headers, aprons, and intakes, shall be assessed to real estate abutting upon the street, lane, alley, or avenue paved or otherwise improved pro rata on the basis of lineal-foot frontage; and provided further that street-railway companies now having or which may hereafter have tracks running through the street, lane, alley, or avenue paved or otherwise improved, shall be assessed so much of the cost of said paving, macadamizing, or other improvement as is occupied by its tracks and two feet on each side of the rails thereof, and in case there are two or more tracks on the same street said street-railway company shall pay the cost of paving, macadamizing, or other improvement for not more than four and one half feet between such tracks, except in cases where such street-railway companies voluntarily locate their tracks wider apart than four and one half feet; in which event they shall pay for the paving, macadamizing, or other improvement of all space between said tracks and the pro rata to be paid by said street-railway companies, to be deducted from the total cost and balance to be paid by the abutting property owners, as hereinbefore provided. Assessment.

(c) Upon the completion of one or more sections of paving, macadamizing, or other improvement, between any one or more intersecting streets of said city, the city commission shall ascertain the proportional cost of such
pavement, including street intersection, headers, curbing, and intakes, chargeable to abutting owners, street-railways, or other public-service corporations, or other persons occupying or using said streets, and shall cause the secretary of said commission to give written notice of such result to said abutting owners, public-service corporations, or other persons, and the amounts so assessed shall be and become immediately due and payable; a copy of which notice shall be served upon the owner, agent, or occupant thereof by any officer of the city, and return thereof made on the original, which original shall be kept in the secretary's office and recorded on the minutes, together with the entry of service thereon, and the city shall proceed immediately to collect the same; provided such abutting owners, street-railway, or other public-service corporations, or such other persons, may, at their election, pay one tenth of the amount assessed against them in cash within thirty days from date of the notice served upon them, and the remaining nine tenths in nine equal annual installments, with interest thereon at 7 per cent. per annum, payable annually from the date of such notice; provided further that on default of any one of the said installments, the remaining installments shall become immediately due and payable and may be immediately collected as herein provided. Same.Notice.Option to pay in installments.

(d) A special lien is hereby created on and against the land of abutting owners and on and against the land and property of such street-railway companies or public service corporations and others for assessments so made against them, and on failure to pay the full amount of such assessment in cash within thirty (30) days after the service of such notice, the city commission shall, by its secretary, cause executions to be issued against such abutting owners, street-railways, or other public-service corporations or others for the amount of such assessment or assessments, bearing seven per cent. interest from date of such notice; but if such abutting owners, street-railway, or public-service corporations, or others, shall elect to pay their
assessment on the installment plan, then in that event the secretary shall issue executions for the unpaid installments, to be held in abeyance, subject to transfer to contractors or others, as part payment of the contract price, or to be held by the city, should the city on any account be entitled thereto, but not to be levied or collected unless and until default shall be made in the payment of any one or more of said installments. Lien for assessment.Executions.

(e) All executions authorized to be issued under this Act or under any provisions of the charter of the City of Rome relating to the subject-matter herein referred to shall be levied and collected as other tax executions in favor of said city are now levied and collected. Same.

(f) The secretary of said commission may, by direction of said commission, transfer said executions to contractors or others by suitable entry thereon, and they shall be docketed as State and county tax executions are docketed when transferred under the laws of this State, and the liens herein created thereby preserved. On the payment of all installments said executions shall be fully satisfied by the holders thereof. Transfer of executions.

(g) Should any abutting owner, street-railway company or public-service corporation or other person desire to contest the amount of their assessment, or the illegality of any proceeding growing out of or connected with the paving, macadamizing, or other improvement of the streets of the city, they may do so by filing with the levying officer an affidavit of illegality and stating therein the cause of such illegality and the amount which he admits to be due, which amount so admitted to be due shall be paid to the levying officer before the affidavit shall be received, and the affidavit shall be returned to the superior court of Floyd County, Georgia, and there tried and the issue determined as in the cases of illegality, subject to the penalties provided as in cases of illegality filed for delay, and it shall be the duty of the judges of the superior court to give preference to these cases over all other cases pending in said court. Affidavit of illegality.

(h) The method herein provided for the collection of the proportionate parts of paving accounts from any and all persons and corporations liable therefor in favor of contractors and other transferees of executions is for their use and benefit, and shall not be held or taken in any event to make the city liable on account thereof, or for court costs in contested case, or on any claim. Collection of transferred executions.

(i) The secretary of the commission may transfer and assign, without recourse on the city, any execution or executions issued under this Act or the Acts of 1909 and 1918, creating a new charter for said City of Rome; and in that event the owners of such executions shall be entitled to any and all the remedies herein provided for levy and collection of such executions by and through the officers of the city as though no transfer or transfers had been made, and all rights and remedies heretofore existing in favor of such owners prior to the passage of this Act are herein expressly preserved. Same.

(j) Whenever in the judgment of said city commission it shall be deemed necessary to construct curbing and guttering or curbing and guttering on any street of said city, said commission may be resolution or ordinance order such curbing and guttering to be constructed. Said commission shall have the rights and powers to fix by ordinance, and collect as other taxes are collected, the cost of such curbing and guttering or curbing and guttering, the total of which shall be assessed against the abutting property owners only, and when the cost of such curbing and guttering or curbing or guttering has been ascertained, the city shall, through the city manager, give ten days' notice to the abutting property owners, of the amount that will be due by them for such curbing and guttering or curbing or guttering. The abutting property owners may, at their discretion, pay one fourth of the amount assessed against them in cash within ten days from the completion of such curbing and guttering, or service of said notice, and the remaining three fourths in three annual installments, with interest thereon at the rate of seven
per cent. per annum, payable from date of service of such notice; provided that on default in the payment of any one of the said installments the remaining installments shall become immediately due and payable and may be immediately collected. When sidewalks are laid under requirements of the city the adjacent property owners have the right to pay for the same in installments as herein provided for payment of curbs and gutters. The rights and remedies of abutting property owners and of the City of Rome, as laid down and provided in subsections e, f, g, h, i, j, of this section of this Act shall apply to and be in force in regard to the curbing and guttering provided for in this Act. Curbing or guttering.

(k) The City of Rome shall have power and authority to create, survey, and define special districts for the purpose of constructing trunk or main sewers, and to include in such districts all property that will or may be served by such sewers either directly or by lateral sewers to be built and connected therewith. Such districts shall be created by ordinance defining the limits and boundaries thereof, after such survey is made. Sewer districts.
