(l) When such a district is so laid out by ordinance, the city shall cause plans and specifications for trunk or main sewers, and such secondary sewers as may be necessary, to be made, and the cost thereof estimated, all of which shall be filed in the office of the clerk or secretary; and notice thereof, showing the general location of the district, and that such plans and specifications are on file, shall be published at least twice in two separate weeks in a newspaper published and having a general circulation in the City of Rome. Any person specially affected may present written objections within one week from the date of the last publication, which shall be heard and determined by the city commission. Ordinance as to sewers.Notice.

(m) After all objections have been heard and determined, the city may advertise for bids for the work proposed or such part thereof as may be desired. Upon receiving
bids it may accept the best bid, or may reject them all, and if no reasonable bid can be obtained may do the work without contract. Bids for work.

(n) When the work determined on has been done, assessment shall be made on all the real property in the district to pay the cost thereof, such assessment to be made on the assessed tax value thereof. Each property owner's part thereof shall be calculated and notice shall be published at least twice in two weeks, notifying all persons to appear and object or assessment will be confirmed. Any person objecting to same in writing shall be heard and his objection determined, and the assessment thereupon shall be confirmed and definitely fixed by ordinance. Assessment for sewers.Notice and hearing.

(o) The property owners shall pay their respective assessments within thirty days from date of the ordinance fixing same, except that upon the written request of the property owners and payment of one tenth of the amount assessed, executions for the balance may be issued, payable one tenth a year for nine years with interest at 7 per cent. from date of the passage of said ordinance, payable annually, and in case of default of any installment or interest the whole may be declared due and collectible. Payment in installments.

(p) The city shall have the right to run such sewers outside the corporate limits of the city as may be determined, and power is hereby conferred on said city to condemn any land in or out of the city for such purposes by proceedings duly had, as provided by the charter of the City of Rome and the laws of Georgia, the cost to be assessed as part of the cost of the work. Condemnation of land.

(q) Lateral or secondary sewers may be built as above provided except that the costs thereof shall be assessed against the owner of the particular property served and to be served by such sewers on the basis of front footage of the property served or to be served, but no property already served by a sewer shall be assessed for the building of another sewer, nor shall any property be assessed except on one frontage. In case the sewer is laid or run by or along
property which is for the reasons aforesaid not assessed, the necessary part of the sewer so run or laid shall be assessed pro rata on a front-footage basis against the property served by such sewer which is subject to assessment. Lateral or secondary sewers.

(r) For the purpose hereinbefore set out, the city may include any property adjacent to and within one mile of the city limits in any sewerage district, and may assess the same its proportionate cost of such district at value to be shown by county tax-books, and if not so shown, then at value to be fixed by city tax-assessors after notice and opportunity for hearing. But in such case the notice of the inclusion of such property in any sewerage district and that such property will be assessed its proportionate part of the cost shall be given the owners of such property outside the city by serving them personally, or if they are nonresidents, by serving them, resident agent, or party in actual possession, personally. Such service to be made by the sheriff or his deputy, and his return in writing made, for which he shall receive a fee of $1.00, to be paid by the city, and it is hereby made the duty of the sheriff to serve same. If there is no agent, or party in actual possession, service may be made by registered mail, directed to the owner at the last known address. Within two weeks after service such owners shall proceed by injunction to prevent the inclusion of this property in such district, or he shall not thereafter be allowed to contest the legality of such inclusion, nor any assessment thereafter made, on the ground that such inclusion was illegal. Inclusion of property outside city in sewerage district.Notice and hearing.Injunction.
If this subsection is held illegal, it shall not affect any other paragraph or subsection of this Act.

(s) Any person dissatisfied with the assessment either for trunk sewers or for lateral sewers may be authorized to contest the same as is provided for contesting paving or other improvement assessments by illegality. Objection to assessment.

(t) The Rome City Commission, after the expiration of thirty days from the passage of the ordinance confirming and levying said assessments for the paving, macadamizing,
or otherwise improving the streets, avenues, alleys, lanes, or any parts thereof, and for the laying of sewers as in this Act provided, may by resolution provide for the issuance of bonds in the aggregate amount of such assessments remaining unpaid, bearing date fifteen days after the passage of the ordinance levying said assessments, and of such denominations as said commission may determine, which bond or bonds shall in no event become a liability of the City of Rome. One tenth in amount of any such series of bonds, with the interest upon the whole series to day, shall be payable one year after date thereof and one tenth, with yearly interest on the whole amount remaining unpaid, shall be payable annually in each succeeding year until all shall be paid. Such bonds shall bear interest at a rate not exceeding six per cent. per annum from their date until maturity, payable annually, and shall be designated as street-improvement bonds or sewer bonds, and shall on the face thereof recite the street or streets, part of street or streets, or other public places for the improvement of which they have been issued or along which sewers have been laid or sewer districts as herein provided, and that they are payable solely from assessments which have been levied upon the lots and tracts of land benefited by said improvement, under authority of this Act. Said bonds shall be signed by the chairman of the Rome City Commission and attested by the clerk of the commission, and shall have the impression of the corporate seal of such city thereon, and shall have interest coupons attached, and all bonds issued by authority of this Act shall be payable at such place either within or without the State of Georgia as shall be designated by said Rome City Commission. Said bonds shall be sold at not less than par and the proceeds applied to the payment of the contract price or other expenses by said Rome City Commission, or such bonds in the amount that shall be necessary for that purpose may be turned over and delivered to the contractor at par value in the payment of the amount due him on his contract, and the portion thereof which shall be necessary to pay other expenses incident to and incurred
in providing for said improvements shall be sold or otherwise disposed of as the said Rome City Commission shall direct. Said bonds shall be registered by the clerk of the commission in a book to be provided for that purpose, and certificates of registration by said clerk of the commission shall be endorsed upon each of said bonds. Such bonds shall be validated by proceedings in the superior court held for that purpose, and shall be incontestible after such validation. Bond issue for sewers.

(u) The assessments provided for and levied under the provisions of this Act, whether or not executions have been issued thereon, shall be payable by the persons owning the said lots or tracts of land, as the several installments become due, together with interest thereon, to the clerk of the commission, who shall give proper receipts for such payments. It shall be the duty of the clerk of the commission to keep an accurate account of all such collections made by him, and such collections shall be kept in a special fund to be used and applied for the payment of such bonds, and the interest thereon and expenses incurred in connection therewith and for no other purpose. Collections, accounts.

(v) In all cases where said Rome City Commission shall deem it necessary to repave, redrain, remacadamize, or otherwise improve any street, alley, avenue, lane, or other public place, which had been paved or improved prior to the passage of this Act, or which shall hereafter be paved, macadamized, or drained under the provisions of this Act, such pavement or improvement is hereby authorized to be done under and in pursuance of the provisions of this Act, and in such cases, all provisions of this Act providing for making such improvements and levying assessments therefor and the issuance of bonds shall apply. Repaving, etc.

law.p: Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that in lieu of the maximum salary now provided for by the charter of the City of Rome that may be paid to the city manager at any sum that the Rome City Commission may determine, not to exceed six thousand dollars per year. Salary of city commissioner not to exceed $6,000.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authorities aforesaid, that the limits of the City of Rome shall be further enlarged and extended so as to include that area or property described as beginning at the southwest corner of lot No. 233 in the 23d District and 3d Section; thence east on south line of said lot to center of said lot; thence north through middle of said lot and of lot No. 208 to center of lot No. 193, thence west to line of American Chatillon Corporation, thence southerly following line of American Chatillon Corporation to southeast corner of tract bought by American Chatillon Corporation from Mrs. C. A. Hogg, thence westerly along right of way of Southern Railway Company to point north of extreme west end of property of Vaughn, thence following line of American Chatillon Corporation so as to exclude property of American Chatillon Corporation, southerly thence easterly, then as the line may run to southeast corner of back of Oostanaula River, to present city boundary, thence southerly, northerly, easterly, and southerly as the present city boundary line may run to southwest corner of land lot No. 233 in 23d District and 3d Section, the beginning point, the property within these lines being annexed to the City of Rome as part of the Sixth Ward. New territory.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the city limits of the City of Rome be further extended and enlarged to include that property or area described as follows: Beginning at a point on the present boundary ten feet east of the property line on the west side of the Summerville Road; thence northerly ten feet east of the property line on the west side of said Summerville Road to a point opposite the southerly boundary of the property of the Berry Schools; thence westerly along the southerly line of the property of the Berry Schools to a point opposite the northwest corner of the property formerly owned by Wright Willingham; thence southerly and westerly along the line between said former Willingham property and the property of Miss Martha Berry, as said line may run, to the east side of the new Redmond Gap Road;
thence southerly along said road to north line of the right of way of Southern Railway Company; thence along said right of way and the line fixed by this act as the boundary of the Ninth Ward to the present city limits; thence easterly along the present city limits to point of beginning; the property herein bounded being annexed to the City of Rome and to be a part of the Fourth Ward of said city. Same.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid that in case any part of any boundary of any of the territory annexed by this act is not clearly or completely described, then the same shall be determined and located by describing a straight line from the last point clearly located or described to the next point clearly located or described. Insufficient description of boundary.

Sec. 17. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, that the City of Rome is hereby authorized and empowered to acquire by purchase or otherwise lands within or without the city, separately or in conjunction with Floyd County, for an airport, and to improve and maintain same separately or in conjunction with Floyd County, and to appropriate money therefor. And the City of Rome is given full jurisdiction to police said airport as though same were a part of the city. Authority to acquire land for airport.

Sec. 18. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that in case any section or paragraph of any section of this Act shall be declared illegal or unconstitutional by the courts, the same shall not affect the provisions of this Act not declared to be illegal or unconstitutional. Invalidity of part of Act not invalidate other part.
Sec. 19. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act, be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the Town of Rutledge, in Morgan County, Georgia, granted by Act of the General Assembly approved August 13th, 1909 (Georgia Laws 1909, page 1345), by adding to section twenty-seven of said Act, between lines three and four as printed in said Georgia laws the following paragraph, to wit: They shall have full power and authority to grant franchises to public utilities, in, on, over or along the streets, lanes, sidewalks, alleys, parks, and other public places or property in said town, upon such terms and conditions as they may see proper.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the charter of the Town of Rutledge, in Morgan County, Georgia, granted by Act of the General Assembly approved August 13th, 1909 (Georgia Laws 1909, page 1345), be and is hereby amended by adding to section twenty-seven of said Act, between lines three and four as printed in said Georgia Laws, the following paragraph, to wit: They shall have full power and authority to grant franchises to public utilities, in, on, over, or along the streets, lanes, alleys, sidewalks, parks, and other public places or property in said town, upon such terms and conditions as they may see proper; so that section as amended shall read as follows: Sec. 27. Be it further enacted, that the mayor and town council of Rutledge shall have power to remove all obstructions upon the streets and sidewalks in said town. They shall have full power and authority to grant franchises to public utilities, in, on, over, or along the streets, lanes, alleys, sidewalks, parks, and other public places or property in said town, upon such terms and conditions as they may see proper. They shall have the power and authority to abate or cause to be abated anything which in their opinion is a nuisance, whether the same be in the streets or on the lots of individuals, firms, corporations,
or institutions in said town, and they shall have power and authority to pass all necessary laws and ordinances to enforce this provision and provide for the mode and manner of abating such nuisances, not inconsistent with the constitution and laws of the State of Georgia. They shall also have the power and authority to provide, own, and furnish in and near the said Town of Rutledge cemeteries for the burial of the dead, to regulate and control the interments in the same, to exercise police control over and to care for lots in said cemeteries. Act of 1909, Sec. 27, amended.To read.Franchises in streets, etc.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and they are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the Act of 1880-1, which is entitled An Act to authorize the corporation of the City of Sandersville to levy a tax for establishing and maintaining public schools in said city, and to authorize the county school commissioner of Washington County to pay over to the board of education of said public schools such part of the school fund as may be their pro rata thereof * * * and for other purposes, by striking the words one half of from section five of said act where these words appear between the words exceed and one in said section, so as to allow the city council of City of Sandersville to levy one per centum upon the taxable property of said city for school purposes instead of one half of one per centum as at present; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority
of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act that section five of an act entitled An Act to authorize the corporation of the City of Sandersville to levy a tax for establishing and maintaining public schools in said city, and to authorize the county school commissioner of Washington County to pay over to the board of education of said public schools such part of the school fund as may be their pro rata thereof and to authorize the city council of said city to appropriate the proceeds from the grant of licenses to retail spirituous liquors in said city; and also the interest on dividends from the city's investment in the Sandersville Railroad, to said public-school purposes, adopted in 1880-1, is amended by striking from section five of said Act the words one half of, where these words appear in said section between the words exceed and one, so as to allow the city council of the City of Sandersville to levy not to exceed one per centum upon the taxable property of said city for public-school purposes instead of one half of one per centum as at present; so that said section five of said act when amended shall read as follows: Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the revenues derived by the corporation of the City of Sandersville from the following named sources be and they are hereby appropriated for the maintenance of said public schools in said city: 1st. All the proceeds from grants of licenses to retail spirituous liquors in said city. 2d. All the interest and dividends derived annually from the city's investment in the Sandersville and Tennille Railroad Company. 3d. The city's pro rata share of the State school fund. 4th. Whenever the board of education of said city shall deem it necessary to increase the funds for the maintenance of said public schools, the mayor and council of the City of Sandersville be and they are hereby authorized and required to levy, impose, and collect such tax upon the taxable property of the city as will be necessary to carry out the provisions of this act, but such tax shall not exceed one per centum per annum upon said taxable property. But no tax shall be levied and collected under and by virtue of this act unless the question has been
submitted to the qualified voters resident within the corporate limits of the City of Sandersville, and two thirds of the same have voted for taxation. All such elections shall be conducted as other elections are now held in said city for corporate officers, and voters shall have written or printed on their ballots, For Taxation or Against Taxation. If two thirds of the voters do not vote in favor of the proposed taxation, it shall not be legal to have another election upon this subject until after the expiration of two years from the date of said last election. Act of 1881 (Ga. L. 1880-1, p. 429, Sec. 5, amended.To read.School-tax not to exceed 1%.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: SAVANNAH AND CHATHAM COUNTY EDUCATIONAL FUNDS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to provide that when and if the General Assembly shall remove or change the limitation of the use of public educational funds to the education of children between the ages of six and eighteen years, that the provisions in the charter of the Board of Public Education for the City of Savannah and the County of Chatham, containing a similar limitation, shall be ipso fact changed to accord with the provisions of the general law on this subject.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that when and if the General Assembly shall remove or change the limitation of the use of public educational funds to the education of children between the ages of six and eighteen years that the provisions in the charter of the Board of Public Education for the City of Savannah and the County of Chatham, containing a similar limitation,
shall be ipso facto changed to accord with the provisions of the general law on this subject. Limitation of fund to use of children of certain age removed.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: SAVANNAH AND CHATHAM BOARD OF PUBLIC EDUCATION; TEACHERS' PENSIONS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the Board of Public Education for the City of Savannah and the County of Chatham to administer any and all funds appropriated for or contributed towards teachers' retirement allowance or pensions.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the Board of Public Education for the City of Savannah and the County of Chatham is hereby authorized and empowered to administer any and all funds which may be appropriated for and contributed toward teachers' retirement allowances or pensions. Board to administer funds for pensions.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: SAVANNAH; RECORDER'S SALARY; WATER; FIRE EXTINGUISHING OUTSIDE CITY; FLYING FIELD; APPRAISERS; ZONING; PAY OF COMMISSIONERS; FEES.
law.fulltitle: An Act to alter, revise, and amend the several acts relating to and incorporating the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is enacted by the authority of the same, that the salary of the recorder of the police court of the City of Savannah, beginning with the term of the said official when elected at the regular municipal election to be held in said city in January, 1930, shall not be less than $3,600.00 per year. Salary of recorder $3,600.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah is hereby authorized and empowered to build or construct an aqueduct, or conduit, or lay pipes for the purpose of conveying water from any point within Chatham County which they may select beyond the limits of the City of Savannah, except in the Towns of Thunderbolt and Tybee, as they may think proper; and, further, to erect, build, or construct, and do such things as necessary for the construction or erection of artesian wells, or to establish, construct, own, or operate a system of waterworks at any point within Chatham County, other than within the Towns of Thunderbolt, and/or Tybee; and, for the purpose of building or constructing an aqueduct or conduit, or for the purpose of laying pipes, they shall have the authority to and use as a right of way for such aqueduct, or conduit, and for such pipes any land not exceeding thirty (30) feet in width between such points, and for the purpose of establishing said artesian wells, or waterworks system, to take and use such land as they may deem necessary within the limits of the County of Chatham, other than within the Towns of Thunderbolt, and/or Tybee, provided that before such land shall be taken for either purpose and used, the owner or owners of such land or lands shall be notified in writing of the amount and location of the land which it is desired to use, and if such owner or owners and said Mayor and Aldermen cannot or do not agree at once upon the terms and conditions upon which such land shall be taken as a right of way as aforesaid, the mayor of said city shall appoint an assessor, and the owner, or owners, of such land shall appoint another, and the two so appointed shall appoint
a third, or if they cannot or do not agree upon a third within five (5) days after being notified of their selection, then the ordinary of Chatham County shall appoint such third assessor; and if the owner or owners of such land does or do not appoint an assessor as aforesaid within five (5) days after he, or they, is or are so notified as aforesaid, the said ordinary shall appoint two assessors; and the three assessors so appointed by any of the foregoing methods shall determine and assess the amount of money to be paid by said city for such right of way through the tract of land for which they are appointed, and the decision of any two of such assessors shall be final and binding on the parties, except that in all cases there may be an appeal by either party to the superior court of Chatham County, under the usual rules governing appeals to that court, and such decision shall describe the land taken as a right of way, and/or for a well or waterworks site, and the amount of money to be paid for same, and shall be made in duplicate, and one original given to the said owner, or owners, and the other to said Mayor and Aldermen, and upon the payment by said Mayor and Aldermen of the sum awarded, and a receipt therefor, being written of such award, such award shall convey said land so awarded to the said Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah, which shall be in fee simple. The powers, remedies, and procedure herein set out shall be in addition to, and cumulative of, those now or hereafter conferred by other laws. Waterworks, pipes, etc.Condemnation of property.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the fire department of the City of Savannah shall have power and authority, after the approval of this Act, to go beyond the limits of the City of Savannah to any place within Chatham County, Georgia, for the purpose of extinguishing fires, and while going to and coming from or attending such fires the officers and men of the said department shall have the same authority and control as they have in the City of Savannah while acting in their official capacities, and the said officers and men shall be exempt from civil or criminal liability while acting in their
official capacities beyond the limits of the City of Savannah, within the County of Chatham, to the same extent as they are now exempted while in the course of duty within the City of Savannah. It is further provided that the fire department of the City of Savannah can be sent beyond the limits of the County of Chatham when, in the discretion of the mayor or acting mayor it shall be necessary so to do for the purpose of preventing a conflagration or calamity in any other town or city, and only when the services of the said department are requested by the authorized authorities of such city or town desiring their aid or assistance. The powers, remedies, and procedure herein set out shall be in addition to and cumulative of those now or hereafter conferred by other laws. Fire extinguishing outside city.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah are hereby authorized and empowered to take, use, and condemn such land beyond the limits of the City of Savannah, in Chatham County, Georgia, as they shall see fit and deem necessary for the purposes of constructing, building, preparing, or extending a landing field, or flying field, for aeroplanes thereon, or the erection of hangars and/or the doing of such things as are necessary to provide a landing or flying field for aeroplanes, provided, nevertheless, that before such land shall be taken or used, the owner or owners of such land or lands shall be notified in writing of the amount and location of the land which it is desired to use, and if such owner or owners and said Mayor and Aldermen cannot or do not agree at once upon the terms and conditions upon which such land shall be taken for such purpose or purposes as aforesaid, the mayor of said city shall appoint an assessor, and the owner or owners of such land or lands shall appoint another, and the two so appointed shall appoint a third, or if they cannot or do not agree upon a third within five (5) days after being notified of their selection, then the ordinary of Chatham County shall appoint such third assessor, and if the owner or owners of such land does or do not appoint an assessor
as aforesaid within five (5) days after he, or they, is or are so notified as aforesaid, the said ordinary shall appoint two assessors, and the three assessors so appointed by any of the methods aforesaid shall determine and assess the amount of money to be paid by said city for such land or lands for which they are appointed, and the decision of any two of such assessors, shall be final and binding on the parties, except that in all cases there may be an appeal by either party to the superior court of Chatham County, Georgia, under the usual rules governing appeals to that court, and such decision shall describe the land taken for such purposes aforesaid, and the amount of money to be paid for same, and shall be made in duplicate, and one original given to the said owner, or owners, and the other to said Mayor and Aldermen, and upon the payment by said Mayor and Aldermen of the sum awarded and a receipt therefor being written of such award, such award shall convey said land so awarded to the said Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah, which shall be in fee simple. The powers, remedies, and procedure herein set out shall be in addition to and cumulative of those now or hereafter conferred by other laws. Condemnation of land for aeroplane field.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that whenever this Act of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, approved August 18th, 1919, and found in Georgia Laws of 1919, page 1294, et seq., entitled An Act to alter, revise and amend the Act relating to and incorporating the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah, and for other purposes, as well as the Acts amendatory thereof, provide for an appraisement and apportionment of the cost of any street improvement by a board of appraisers, consisting of the chief engineer or his assistant, and the director of public works, and the chairman of the board of tax-assessors, and any one of the said board is absent from the city, or disqualified, or may not act for any reason, then the said apportionment and appraisement may be made by the remaining two officers of said board, and their action shall be as binding and effective as if made by the entire board. Board of appraisers of cost of street improvements.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah shall have authority to enact zoning and planning laws whereby such city, and also its environs within the limits of Chatham County, may be zoned or districted for various uses and other or different uses prohibited therein, and regulating the uses for which said zones or districts may be set apart, and regulating the plans for development and improvement of real estate therein; it being nevertheless provided that these provisions of the within Act shall only become effective if, when, and upon the passage and ratification of that certain proposed constitutional amendment entitled An Act to propose to the qualified voters of Georgia an amendment to article 3, section 7, of the constitution of said State, by adding thereto an additional paragraph numbered 25, which shall authorize the General Assembly of said State to grant to the governing authorities of the cities of Atlanta, Savannah, Macon, Augusta, Columbus, LaGrange, Brunswick, Waycross, Albany, and cities having a population of 25,000 or more inhabitants, according to the United States census of 1920 or any future census, authority to pass zoning and planning laws where such cities may be zoned or districted for various uses and other or different uses provided therein, and regulating the use for which said zones or districts may be set apart, and regulating the plans for development and improvement of real estate therein. The General Assembly is given general authority to authorize said municipalities to pass zoning and planning laws, or other constitutional amendment of like purport. Zoning and planning laws.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah shall pay to the commissioners of Chatham County, Georgia, the sum of $600.00 per annum, in twelve (12) equal installments, same to be paid as compensation for work in connection with registration of voters, the proposed voters' lists for municipal primaries and elections. Pay of county commissioners for work in connection with registration of voters.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah is hereby given exclusive jurisdiction over any tree whose body or trunk at or near the bottom thereof is located wholly or partially within the street curb line of any lane or street of the City of Savannah, provided that such jurisdiction shall extend only to the cutting down or removal of such tree whenever in the judgment of said Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah the said tree in whole or in part is an obstruction to street traffic. Tree cutting
Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act or any other section thereof be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to incorporate the City of Silvertown, in Upson County, Georgia; to define the corporate limits, provide for a government by three commissioners, define their duties, fix the punishment of violators of the ordinances, establish a recorder's court, provide for the appointment of tax-assessors, provide for the collection of taxes, to allow said city to own, condemn, and appropriate private property for public use, to lay out and open up streets, or close streets and roads, to widen, grade, pave and macadamize the streets and sidewalks, to assess abutting property for the payment of street work and improvements and collect same, to provide for a system of waterworks, sewerage, and electric lights, to provide a system of public schools and finance same, to provide for all matters of public concern and welfare; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act there shall be created within Upson County, Georgia, a municipality which shall be known as Silvertown, which municipality is made a body corporate and politic, and shall embrace the inhabitants and the territory included within the following limits, to wit: Beginning at a point on the east side of Payne's Mill Road where the south property line of Martha Mill's south village intersects with the Payne's Mill Road, and then run west along said south property line to a point on the east side of the old Sandwich Road, then run in a southerly direction along the east side of the old Sandwich Road to the corporate limits of the City of Thomaston, then run in a southwesterly direction along the corporate line of the City of Thomaston to the north line of the east and west highway from Thomaston to LaGrange, said highway being located on the north side of the old Macon Birmingham Railway Company's right of way, then run west along the north side of highway to a point which is due south from the present intersection of the west side of the Emmeas Church Road and the highway, then run due north from said point to the west or farthest bank of Potato Creek, then run up said Potato Creek along the west and north bank of same to a point where the original land-lot line dividing lots of land numbers 230 and 213 crosses said creek, then run south along said original land-lot line to a point where said line intersects with the north property line of the Martha Mill, then run east along the north property line of the Martha Mill land to the Payne's Mill Road, then cross the road to the east side, then run in a southerly direction along the east side of said road to the beginning point. Territory included in city.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that the municipal government of said town shall be vested in three commissioners who shall be known as commissioners of said town, and under the corporate name of the City of Silvertown as aforesaid, said commissioners shall have perpetual succession,
and the right and title to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, contract and be contracted with, and to purchase, hold, sell, or otherwise dispose of such real and personal property, both tangible and intangible, as may be needful for the good order, government, and welfare of said city, and exercise such other rights, functions, privileges, and immunities as belong to municipal corporations generally under the law of the State of Georgia. Government by three commissioners.General corporate powers.

Said commissioners shall be appointed by the judge of the superior court of Upson County, Georgia, one of said commissioners to be appointed for one year, one for two, and one for three. All subsequent appointments, except to fill vacancies for an unexpired term, shall be for a term of three years, and each commissioner shall hold office until his successor is appointed and qualified. Appointments for vacancies in the office of commissioner shall be only for an unexpired term. No one shall be eligible to appointment as commissioner who is under twenty-one years of age and who does not either reside or work within the corporate limits of the City of Silvertown. Commissioners appointed by judge; terms, qualifications.

The commissioners shall, before entering upon their duties, take and subscribe to an oath before some duly qualified officer that they will faithfully execute and discharge all duties devolving upon them as said commissioners, and faithfully enforce all laws and ordinances of said municipality, the State of Georgia, and the United States, and will to the best of their ability promote the general welfare of said municipality. The commissioners shall, after their appointment, appoint from their number a chairman and a chairman pro tem. of the commissioners. Each of said commissioners shall receive as compensation the sum of $60.00 per year, and the chairman and the chairman pro tem. shall receive additional compensation such as shall be fixed by ordinance of commissioners. Oath of commissioners.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, that said commissioners shall have full authority to pass all ordinances that may be deemed necessary for the procedure of the commissioners,
the government, management, and control of Silvertown, the protection of life, liberty, security, and prosperity of the inhabitants thereof, and for preservation of peace, and good order, temperance, and morality, and to pass all other ordinances which they may deem needful and necessary, not contrary to the laws of the State of Georgia or of the United States. Powers as to ordinances.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, that said commissioners shall appoint a recorder for said municipality, who shall have jurisdiction to try all offenders against the ordinances of said town and hold his court as often as may be necessary for that purpose. Said recorder shall have authority to impose fines not exceeding $100.00 upon, or imprison, offenders, in the town prison or common jail of Upson County, or labor on the streets of said town not exceeding ninety days, to punish witnesses for non-appearance or disobeying the processes of said court. Said recorder is hereby authorized to issue warrants for the arrest of all persons charged, upon affidavits made before him, with having committed offenses within the limits of said municipality against ordinances of the said municipality and the penal laws of the State of Georgia, to take examination of such persons and to discharge or commit said persons to prison, or let on bail according to law, to answer such charges before the court having jurisdiction, in the same manner as justices of the peace of the State of Georgia now have or may have by law, which warrants shall be addressed to the marshal, deputy marshal of Silvertown, the sheriff, deputy sheriff, or constable of the State of Georgia, to execute the same. Said recorder shall be over 21 years of age and must work or reside in Silvertown and be of good moral character and reputation, and shall, before entering upon his duties of said office, take oath to honestly, faithfully, and impartially discharge the duties of said office to the best of his ability, without fear, favor, or affection. In the event of the absence or disqualification of the recorder, the chairman or chairman pro tem. of the commissioners shall act in the place and stead of the recorder, and shall have the
same powers as those given to the recorder herein and by law. Any person convicted before the recorder, chairman, or chairman pro tem. of the commissioners, acting for the recorder, shall have the right to enter an appeal instanter to the commissioners, the majority of whom shall constitute a quorum, and shall have the right to post a bond to abide the decision of the commissioners. In the event such person was convicted while or at such time as the chairman or chairman pro tem. of the commissioners was acting for the recorder, such chairman or chairman pro tem. of the commissioners shall be disqualified to hear any appeal filed with the commissioners. Any person convicted by the commissioners, on appeal to them from the decision of the recorder, or some person acting for said recorder, shall have the right of certiorari to the superior court of Upson County, upon complying with the rules of law applicable to certiorari from municipalities to State courts. Recorder.Punishments.Warrants for arrest.Qualifications of recorder.Absence of recorder.Appeal.Certiorari.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, that said commissioners shall have a right to appoint a treasurer of said municipality, who shall be the custodian of all monies and securities of the municipality and shall keep and preserve the same in such place or places as shall be determined by the commissioners. He shall pay out monies by warrants signed by the town clerk and countersigned by the chairman or chairman pro tem. of the commissioners. In addition to these duties, he shall perform such other duties for his office as may be prescribed by the commissioners. Treasurer.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, that the commissioners shall have the right to appoint some proper person as town clerk, whose duties shall be to keep an accurate record of minutes of all meetings of the commissioners and committees appointed by said commissioners, and shall perform all other duties prescribed by the commissioners for him. Clerk.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, that the commissioners shall have the right and power to appoint a marshal, deputy marshal, town health officer, tax collector, tax assessor,
and such other officers or employees which the commissioners may deem needful or necessary for the management and operation of the business of the City of Silvertown. City officers and employees.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, that all officers and employees to be appointed by the commissioners shall continue in office during the pleasure of the commissioners, and shall, when so required by the commissioners, before entering into the duties of said offices, execute a bond in a form and amount and upon the terms and conditions satisfactory to the commissioners. Said commissioners shall have the right and power to fix the wages, salaries, and compensation of all officers or employees in the City of Silvertown. Same.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, that the commissioners shall have a right and power to levy and collect an ad valorem tax for general and special purposes on all property, both real and personal, within the corporate limits of Silvertown, which levy shall not exceed one half of one per cent. per annum for general and ordinary expenses, and three fourths of one per cent. per annum for extraordinary or special expenses. Said commissioners shall have a right to borrow money to be used in defraying either ordinary or general, or extraordinary or special, expenses of said municipality, and to repay the same from taxes to be levied and collected. Ad valorem tax.Authority to borrow.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, that all ad valorem taxes shall be due and payable to said municipality on or before January 1st of each year; and within ninety days after January 1st each year the town clerk or such person whose duty it is to collect taxes shall issue tax execution against all delinquent property owners, and shall record such executions on the general execution docket of the County of Upson, and such execution shall bear interest from January 1st at the lawful rate of interest, and said ad valorem tax shall be a lien against the property against which it is levied, and the execution issued as provided herein shall be directed to the marshal of said municipality, his lawful deputies, and to all and singular the sheriffs of said State or their
deputies, and all constables; and further that said municipality shall have the right to issue executions directed as aforesaid, to be a lien as aforesaid, for any and all debts that may be owing to said municipality by any of the owners of property in said municipality or otherwise. Time for paying taxes.Executions for taxes.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, that the commissioners shall have the right and authority to require a license, business, or occupation tax to be paid by all persons, firms, or corporations, engaging or attempting to engage in any kind of retail mercantile business or for the operation of any place of pleasure, amusement, exhibition, or recreation within the corporate limits of said city, and to punish, in accordance with the ordinances of Silvertown and the laws of Georgia, any and all persons, firms, or corporations who fail or refuse to pay said license, business, or occupation tax; and such license, business, or occupation tax shall constitute a lien upon all the property of the taxpayer or person liable, and shall take rank as provided by law for municipal taxes; provided that no license, business, or occupation tax shall be required of persons raising or growing their own produce and peddling the same to said municipality. License tax.Lien of tax.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted that said commissioners shall have the power to compel the persons who are subject to road duty under the general laws of this State, who are residents of said municipality, to work on the public streets of the City of Silvertown not exceeding ten days in each year or to pay in lieu of such work a commutation tax not exceeding $5.00 per year, and shall have the power to summon such persons to perform such work under the rules and regulations which the commissioners may adopt, and, on failure of any person to appear at work as required by the ordinances of said commissioners, the marshal of Silvertown or his deputies shall prefer charges against such person or persons, requiring them to appear before the recorder of said city, and such recorder shall impose such fines as may be reasonable and just for contempt, or may for such contempt imprison said persons or work them on the streets
of Silvertown for a period not exceeding sixty days, or impose a fine not exceeding $100.00, or either or both in the discretion of said recorder. Commutation tax.Penalty.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, that said commissioners shall have the right to appoint one or more persons familiar with values of property within the corporate limits of Silvertown, who shall, for tax purposes, value and assess all the property within said municipality, liable for taxation. Any person dissatisfied with the assessment placed on his property for taxation purposes may appeal to the commissioners, and the decision of the commissioners shall be final. Tax-assessors.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, that the marshal of Silvertown or his deputies, or any officer who has levied any execution issued by said town, shall, after making any levy, advertise said property, if it be real property, once a week for four weeks in the paper in which sheriff's advertisements are made, and shall put up and expose said property for sale to the highest bidder for cash, in front of some place designated by the commissioners as their office on the first Tuesday in the month following the advertisement, and, after selling said property, said marshal or other officer making the sale shall make and execute to the purchaser thereof a marshal's deed. If said marshal or other officer shall levy an execution issued by said city on personal property, the same shall be advertised for sale at three public places in said city by written notice for ten days, and such sale shall be had in front of the place designated by the commissioners as their office, on any date after having advertised the same as provided above. Tax sales.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, that the commissioners of the City of Silvertown shall have the police powers of regulation as authorized by the general laws of the State of Georgia to municipalities, including the passing of all ordinances and prescribing the penalty for violation thereof. Police powers.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted, that the commissioners of the Town of Silvertown shall have the power to define
and abate nuisances within said town and within the watershed within said town from which the source of the town's supply of water is obtained; provided, however, that the persons interested shall have ample notice of such hearing, including the right of counsel and certiorari to the superior court of Upson County, providing that in the case of certiorari under this section the property owner shall give a bond as security, with condition to pay all damages that may be sustained, in such amount as may be fixed by the commissioners, before said certiorari will lie; provided further that after the nuisance has been so declared by the commissioners and its abatement ordered, that the town shall have a right to destroy or remove or otherwise abate said nuisance at the expense of the property owner, provided said property owner fails to abate such nuisance within five days from the order, unless certiorari is asked for and granted. Nuisances.

Sec. 17. Be it further enacted, that said commissioners shall have the power and authority to condemn private property for any public use of said town as provided by the general laws of the State of Georgia, and said commissioners shall have full power and authority to grant franchises, permits, easements, and right of way over and among any of the property belonging to said town. Condemnation of property.Franchises.

Said commissioners shall have the right and power to lay out fire limits in said town and by ordinances, prescribe the kind and manner of buildings constructed on any property, public or private, within said fire limits, and shall have the right to authorize by permit the construction of such buildings as are by ordinance authorized, and shall by ordinance prevent construction of such building in said fire limits as they deem dangerous or that they may be a detriment to the health of the citizens of said municipality; provided further that the right of condemnation granted to said commissioners in this section shall include the right condemn watersheds and streams for sewerage within the limits of said city. Fire limits and regulations.Condemnation of property.

Sec. 18. Be it further enacted, that the commissioners shall have a right and authority to purchase, operate, and maintain, or enter into a contract for the operation and maintenance of, a system of lighting for said town, and shall have authority to operate and maintain a public lighting system, and shall have the right and power to sell to the public or cause to be sold to the public, including citizens or enterprises within said town, electric current, gas, or other lighting or power methods; and the commissioners shall prescribe by ordinance the rules, regulations, and rates covering the operation of such lighting and power system or systems. Lighting.

And said commissioner shall have the right to own and operate and maintain, or enter into a contract for the operation and maintenance of, a system of water supply in said City of Silvertown, and the commissioners shall have a right and power to regulate the sale and use of such water supply to the inhabitants of said city or to other persons or corporations within or without said city. Water supply.

And said commissioners shall have the right to construct, maintain and operate, or to enter into a contract for the construction and operation of, a system of sewerage for the benefit of said town, and the commissioners shall have a right to prescribe rules and regulations governing the tapping of said sewer system, and shall prescribe the rates to be charged for the use of said sewerage system. Sewerage.

And the commissioners shall have the right to supervise the wiring of any building for any electrical purpose, or the plumbing or piping for gas in any building, and they shall have the right to provide for the inspection, at such time as they may deem best, for such wiring and such plumbing, and shall have the power and authority to prescribe the method and manner of construction and the locations of cesspools or septic tanks or other like receptacles in said city. Wiring and plumbing.

Sec. 19. Be it further enacted, that the commissioners shall have full power and authority, by and through ordinances,
to require and provide for the grading, curbing, macadamizing, or otherwise improving of streets, sidewalks, lanes, and alleys of said city, and to prescribe the materials to be used in the character of such pavement, and said commissioners shall have the authority and power to assess one third of the cost of grading, paving, curbing, macadamizing, or otherwise improving of streets, sidewalks, lanes, and alleys against the real estate abutting on each side of the streets, sidewalks, lanes, and alleys to be graded, paved, curbed, macadamized, or otherwise improved. The cost of said improvement shall be a lien upon said abutting property prior to all lines except liens for taxes for preceding years, and such costs may be collected by the issuance of executions in the same manner as taxes are collected; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be construed to require said commissioners to grade pave, curb, macadamize, or otherwise improve any streets, roads, alleys, and lanes, unless said commissioners deem such improvement to be necessary. Street improvements.Lien for cost of improvements.

Sec. 20. Be it further enacted, that the commissioners of Silvertown shall have the power and authority to provide for the establishment of a system of public schools in said municipality, the cost of the operation of which shall be paid out of the funds received by the town from the State common-school fund and such other funds as may come into the hands of the commissioners, which shall by the commissioners be designated school funds. Said public schools shall be maintained for a period of eight months in each year. Schools.

Said commissioners shall have the power and authority to appoint a board of education for said city, consisting of not less than three and not more than five members, to serve for such terms and upon such conditions as the commissioners may determine, or to contract with the board of education of Upson County or the trustees of the R. E. Lee Institute to establish and maintain the schools within said municipality, upon such terms and conditions as may be deemed needful or necessary by said commissioners.
Said commissioners shall have the power and authority to select and employ, or cause to be selected and employed, and compensate for their services out of the school funds of said town, teachers. Board of education.

Sec. 21. Be it further enacted, that said commissioners shall, prior to the beginning of any school year, make an estimate of the amount required for the maintenance of said schools for the ensuing school year, and may, if no other funds are available, levy a special ad valorem tax upon all property in said town for the maintenance of such school system. Tax for schools.

Sec. 22. Be it further enacted, that the State school commissioner shall, through the county school commissioner of Upson County, pay to the commissioners of Silvertown Silvertown's pro-rata share of the State and county school funds to which it is entitled. Payment of share of State and county school funds.

Sec. 23. Be it further enacted, that said commissioners shall have power and authority to rent, build, or otherwise acquire suitable school buildings for said city, and shall have the power and authority to condemn land to be used for school purposes, by complying with the law of Georgia covering such proceeding. School buildings.

Sec. 24. Be it further enacted, that the City of Silvertown created by this charter shall be invested with the rights, powers, and authority that are granted and given to municipalities by the general law of the State of Georgia, or that hereafter may be given to municipalities by the laws of this State, which rights, powers, and authority shall be executed for and on behalf of the City of Silvertown by its commissioners. General powers of municipality.
Sec. 25. Be it further enacted that all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the Act incorporating the City of Social Circle, Georgia, in the County of Walton, approved August 4th, 1904, so as to authorize the mayor and council of Social Circle, Georgia, to establish and change the grade of any street, avenue, lane, alley, or other public place in the City of Social Circle; to provide for the paving and otherwise improving such public street, avenue, lane, alley or other public place; to provide for assessing the cost of such paving entirely abutting against property owners on petition of the owners of 51% of the abutting property, or to assess two thirds of the cost of such paving and improving without petition; to provide for the issuance of street improvement bonds against any assessments that may be due the City of Social Circle by abutting property owners; to provide for the lien of such assessment and how the same shall be enforced, to provide for the paving of any sidewalk at the expense of the abutting property owners; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Act of 1904 Amended. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act the Act incorporating the City of Social Circle, Georgia, approved August 4th, 1904, be and the same is hereby amended by adding thereto the following sections. Act amended.

Sec. 2. Authority as to Street Improvements. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the passage of this Act the mayor and council of Social Circle, Georgia, shall have full power and authority to establish, to change the grade of, to pave, drain, macadamize, curb, and otherwise improve any street, lane, alley, avenue, sidewalk, or other public place in the corporate limits of the City of Social Circle, Georgia, or any part thereof, in accordance with the provisions of this Act,
whenever in the judgment of the mayor and council of Social Circle the public convenience and welfare may require that such improvement be made. Street improvements.

Sec. 3. Authority for Assessment. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the mayor and council of Social Circle shall have full power and authority to provide by proper ordinance for the paving or improving as provided for in section two of this act, and for the assessment of the cost and expenses of such improvement to the abutting property owners, on the basis of one third of such cost and expenses to be paid by the City of Social Circle and two thirds of such cost and expenses to be paid by abutting property owners. And the ordinance may also provide for the apportionment of the cost of paving or improving any street or intersection, and the assessment of such cost against abutting property owners. The mayor and council of Social Circle shall have power to assess the cost in whole or in part, or any intersection, to the abutting property owners along such street. No petition from abutting property owners shall be necessary before the ordinance provided for in this section shall be passed. Assessment.

Sec. 4. Petition for Paving on Oklahoma Plan. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that when the owners of fifty-one per centum of the lineal front footage abutting on any street, or part thereof, or other public place, shall file with the mayor and council of Social Circle a petition, signed by such property owners, asking that such designated street be paved or otherwise improved on what is known as the Oklahoma Plan, that is the abutting property owners on both sides of the street paying the whole cost of such improvements, then the mayor and council of Social Circle shall be authorized to pass proper ordinance to provide for such improvements and the assessment for the same entirely against the abutting property owners, and the same mayor and council is authorized to include in the cost of such assessments the whole or any part of the street intersections. The ordinance providing for such improvements shall set forth how said street intersections
are to be paid for, whether by the city in whole or in part, or by abutting property owners in whole or in part. Paving.

Sec. 5. Contents of Ordinance under Section 3 and 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that whenever the mayor and council of Social Circle shall pass any ordinance for the paving or otherwise improving any street or other public place, as provided by section three, such ordinance shall designate the street or portion thereof to be paved and improved, and the basis of assessing the cost of the same against abutting property owners. And likewise, whenever any ordinance is passed for the paving or otherwise improving any street or other public place, as provided by section four of this Act, such ordinance shall recite that same is to be paved on the Oklahoma Plan, and that petition for such paving has been filed by fifty-one per centum of the lineal footage of property owners of said street; such ordinance shall designate the street or portion thereof to be paved and improved, and the manner of assessing the cost thereof, and shall also provide how the street intersections shall be assessed. Ordinance providing for paving.

Sec. 6. Expenses Included in Assessment. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all curbing, excavating, grading, drainage, manholes, catch basins, sewers, etc., made necessary by any paving or other improvements on any of the streets in the City of Social Circle, and the cost of the same, together with all necessary expenses, including engineers fees, advertising, printing, etc., shall be deemed and considered part of the total cost of such paving or other improvements, and the cost of same shall be assessed in accordance with the plan under which said paving or other improvement is to be done. Matters included in assessment.

Sec. 7. Publication of Ordinance. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that whenever any ordinance is passed by the mayor and council of Social Circle under the provisions of this Act, for the paving or otherwise improving any street or other public place, that such ordinance shall, before the same becomes of full force and
effect, be published in at least two issues of the official gazette of Walton County, that is the newspaper in which the sheriff's advertisements are published; and in connection with such publication of said ordinance a notice shall be given, setting forth the time and place for a hearing upon the same, and any citizen of the City of Social Circle or other interested party may appear before the mayor and council of Social Circle and make any objections or protest against the passage of such ordinance, for any legal reason they might have to the same. The mayor and council of Social Circle at such meeting shall have the right to amend the ordinance, or make such changes in the same as may appear to be necessary; should no objectioins be filed, or should objections be filed and the same overruled by the mayor and council of Social Circle, then the said ordinance shall be of full force and effect. And should any person or corporation, or other owner of abutting property, not begin legal proceedings within twenty days from the date of said meeting, to prevent such paving or other improvements from being made, then such property owners will be presumed to have agreed to such ordinance and the consequent assessment to be made. Publication of ordinance.

Sec. 8. Plans and Ascertainment of Cost. That whenever the mayor and council shall pass any ordinance to provide for the paving of any street or other public place, and the same shall become of force, the said mayor and council of Social Circle shall have authority to proceed to have work done or improvement made, and to ascertain the cost thereof. And in arriving at the cost of such paving or other improvement the said mayor and council may employ an engineer to lay out the plans and specifications, subject to the approval of the mayor and council of Social Circle, under which said improvement shall be made, and the said mayor and council shall have the right at all times to designate the kind of material to be used for such improvement, and the character of the improvement, and when the plans for such improvement have been approved by the mayor and council of Social Circle, the cost thereof may be
ascertained by bids to be submitted in the manner prescribed by the said mayor and council of Social Circle; and should any work be let out to contractors, the said mayor and council shall have the right to prescribe the amount and kind of bond required of such contractors, and may prescribe that the condition of such bond shall require that the paving or other improvement be kept up by said contractor for a period of five years. In ascertaining the cost and expense of such paving or other improvement, the mayor and council shall designate how the same shall be paid for, what portion is to be paid by abutting property owners, and how the said property owners may pay for same, so that bidders on said work may have full knowledge of how the contracts for same will be paid. Contract for improvements; bond of contractor.

Sec. 9. Appraisement of Cost; Assessment. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that whenever the cost of any paving or other improvement is ascertained by the mayor and council of Social Circle, the mayor and council shall then appoint a committee from its own body, who shall in conjunction with the engineer in charge of supervising said work, should such engineer be employed, apportion and appraise the cost of such paving or other improvement and expenses thereof to the several tracts of land abutting on said paving or other improvement, which apportionment and appraisement shall be in accordance with the ordinance providing for such paving or improvement. And when the committee thus appointed shall have completed their work, they shall file a written report with the clerk of the mayor and council, which report shall give the name of the owner, the amount of front footage assessed, and the total amount of the assessment against such property, and such report shall designate the street upon which such assessments are made, the basis upon which the same are made. Immediately after the filing of such report the clerk of the mayor and council of Social Circle shall notify each abutting property owner of the front footage and the assessment made against him, and after such notice has been given, which may be by mail or otherwise, the mayor
and council of Social Circle shall designate a time and place for the holding of a session of the mayor and council to hear objections to such assessments. Should the time of the meeting be designated before the notice of such assessments is given to the abutting landowners, such notice may include the time and place for hearing. Notice of the meeting shall be published in one issue of the official gazette of Walton County, prior to the date of same, which publication notice shall state the purpose and the time and place of such meeting. Any person on whom an assessment has been made may appear before the said mayor and council of Social Circle at the time and place designated in said notice, and file any objections to such report, or otherwise urge any protest which they might have against such report. The mayor and council of Social Circle at such meeting shall have full power and authority to review the assessments and apportionments as made by said committee, to confirm the same, or correct or change the same, or otherwise disapprove the same, just as in its judgment and discretion may appear right and proper at the time. Apportionment of cost of improvement; report; notice to property owner.Hearing of objections.

Sec. 10. Levy of Assessments. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that when the report of the assessment committee has been confirmed, either as originally made or as corrected by the mayor and council of Social Circle, and such assessments may be made before, after, or during the time such improvements are being made, then the mayor and council of Social Circle shall by proper ordinance levy the assessments against each owner and his abutting property, in the amount set out in said report, and said ordinance shall provide that said assessment shall be paid in ten equal installments, which said installments shall bear interest at the rate of 7% per annum. Said ordinance shall provide when said assessments shall mature, and shall provide that the interest on any unpaid portion shall be paid either annually or semiannually, and shall also provide that any assessment may be paid in full within thirty days from the passage of the ordinance levying the same, and upon such payment in full the property
shall be relieved from such assessment. All assessments, when paid or as paid, shall be kept in a separate fund, and shall be used only for the purpose of paying for such improvement or any obligation incurred in making the same. Such ordinance levying the assessment and setting out the terms of payment upon the same shall be published in one issue of the official gazette of Walton County, and each abutting property owner shall be notified of the levy of such assessment and the terms under which the same may be paid. Levy.Payment in installments.Separation of assessment funds.Notice of levy.

Sec. 11. Street Improvement Bonds. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that immediately after the expiration of 30 days from the passage of the ordinance levying the assessments as provided in section ten of this Act, the mayor and council of Social Circle may by proper resolution provide for the issuance of of bonds in aggregate amount of such assessments remaining unpaid at the end of 30 days, such bonds to be in such denominations as the mayor and council may determine, and shall be known as street-improvements bonds, and shall bear interest at the rate of 6% per annum, which may be paid semiannually if so provided, but in any event to be paid annually, one tenth of which bonds shall mature annually each year, together with the interest thereon, and interest coupons shall be attached to said bonds, and the maturity date of such bonds and interest coupons shall be not more than one month after the maturity date of the assessments against which said bonds are issued. The said bonds shall be signed by the mayor and clerk, and shall have the corporate seal impressed thereon, and shall recite that same are issued against paving assessments which have been assessed and levied by the City of Social Circle, and shall further recite that the same are to be paid out of the proceeds collected from such assessments, and said bonds when so issued shall be sold at not less than par, and the proceeds realized from such sale applied to the payment of the amount due for such paving or other improvement; provided that said bonds when issued shall in no event be an obligation binding
upon the City of Social Circle, except as against the paving assessments when collected by the said city. Said bonds may be sold to the contractor for any amount due on the contract for such work. The City of Social Circle shall not be authorized to appropriate any funds, other than those collected from assessments, to the payment of said bonds. Bond issue.

Sec. 12. Execution, Levy and Sale. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that whenever any assessment against any abutting property and the owner thereof shall mature, or any installment thereof shall mature and remain unpaid for a period of ten days, that the clerk of the mayor and council shall issue an execution against the owner and the abutting property for such matured portion, which execution shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the clerk, which execution shall be placed in the hands of the chief of police of the City of Social Circle, who shall proceed immediately to levy the same upon said abutting property, and shall advertise said property for sale in the manner now provided by law for the sale of property under other tax fi. fa., and, when said property is sold, deed shall be executed to the same by said levying officer. Provided that if there is other outstanding installments to become due, that said property shall be sold subject to such unmatured installments and the interest, whom an execution has been issued and levied against, shall have the right to file an affidavit of illegality denying that the whole or any part of the amount of such installment is due, or set up any other legal defense which such property owner may have to said execution, provided that if any amount is admitted to be due, such amount shall be paid before said illegality shall be received. Such illegality shall be filed with the levying officer, and the same, together with the execution, shall be, returned to the court having jurisdiction thereof, that is to the justice court should the amount be less than $100.00, and to the superior court should the amount be more than $100.00, and the said illegality shall be subject to the same penalties as other
illegalities, and shall be tried in the same manner as other illegalities. Execution for assessment. levy and sale.Affidavit of illegality.

Sec. 13. Lien of Assessments. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all assessments made against abutting property and the owners thereof shall constitute a lien against said property for the principal and interest that may accrue, and such lien shall be a special lien against said property of equal dignity with that of State and county and municipal taxes, and superior to any other lien on said property, whether created before or after the levy of such assessment, and said lien shall attach to any and all abutting property, whether owned by individual, corporation, firm, church, county, city, or any other organization or legal entity capable of owning property; provided that such special lien shall not be enforced until the maturity of the same or some part thereof, and only for the amount that may be matured. Lien.

Sec. 14. Sidewalk Paving. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the mayor and council of Social Circle shall have full power and authority to provide for the paving of any sidewalk in the corporate limits of the City of Social Circle, and charge the entire cost thereof against abutting property and the owners thereof, and when any sidewalk is pavedand the cost thereof is not paid by the owners, the said mayor and council shall cause to be issued an execution against the owners and the abutting property for the cost of such sidewalk paving, which execution shall issue in the first instance for the whole amount due, and shall be due and payable immediately. Sidewalk paving.

Sec. 15. Power as to Ordinance, Etc. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said mayor and council of Social Circle, Georgia, shall have full power and authority to pass all resolutions or ordinances which may be necessary or proper to carry out the provisions of this Act. Ordinances, etc.
Sec. 16. Be it further ordained by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend, the charter of the City of Sparta in the County of Hancock, Georgia, by striking section five of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1910, pages 1160-1165, approved August 10th, 1910, amending section eighteen of the Acts of the General Assembly of Georgia of 1905, pages 1155-1162, approved August 7th, 1905, and inserting a new section by the same number in lieu thereof, so as to authorize the mayor and aldermen of the City of Sparata to assess and collect a tax not exceeding seven mills per annum on all the taxable property in said city for the support and maintenance of the public-school system of said city, to repeal conflicting laws; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act the charter of the City of Sparta, in the County of Hancock, Georgia, section 5 of the Acts of 1910, pages 1160-1165, approved August 10th, 1910, amending section 18 of the Acts of the General Assembly of Georgia of 1905, pages 1155-1162 approved August 7th, 1905, be and the same is hereby amended by striking the aforesaid section 5 and inserting in lieu thereof a new section, to be numbered and known as section 5 of said amending Act of 1910, which new section inserted in lieu of the aforesaid section so stricken shall be and read as follows: Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said mayor and aldermen aforesaid shall maintain in said city a public-school system,
