Be it further enacted, that the mayor and council of said city shall have the right, power, and authority to employ, at such times as they may deem necessary, an auditor to examine and audit the books of the city and each department thereof, and to pay a reasonable compensation therefor. Auditing.

Sec. 79. Be it further enacted, that whenever any real property is sold under any process of the City of Stone Mountain, the officer making the sale shall have the power and authority to convey the same by proper conveyance
to the purchaser, but all such property that may be sold under execution for city taxes shall be subject to redemption within the period allowed by law of property sold under execution for State and County taxes. Sales for taxes, redemption.

Sec. 80. Be it further enacted, that the mayor and council shall have the power and authority to recommend an extension of the corporate limits, to include any territory not now included in the city limits, where this is consented to by a majority of the qualified voters of the City of Stone Mountain, voting at an election held for that purpose. Said election shall be published at least thirty days prior to election, and said notice thereof shall describe fully the boundary lines of the territory to be so included in the extension. Extension of corporate limits.

Sec. 81. Be it further enacted, that the mayor and council of the City of Stone Mountain shall have full power and authority to issue street-improvement certificates or bonds (baby bonds) for the purpose of grading, draining, curbing, or paving the streets or sidewalks, or both, and may pass such laws, ordinances, and resolutions to effectuate the issuance of said certificates or bonds, provided they shall be in accordance with the laws of Georgia. Said street-improvement certificates shall be a lien on the property abutting on the streets so improved, and the mayor and council shall collect annually, at the same time and in the same manner as taxes are collected, a sufficient amount to pay off principal and interest at maturity and due date. Street-improvement certificates or bonds.

Sec. 83. Be it further enacted, that the mayor and council shall have full power and authority, by proper ordinances and resolutions, to lay out any street, block, or section for business districts, and to not allow residences to be erected in said district, and also to lay out any street, blocks, or sections for residential districts and not allow any business to be carried on or business houses erected in said district. Authority to lay out residence and business sections.

Sec. 84. Be it further enacted, that the mayor and council shall have full power and authority to segregate
the white population to any district or districts, and also to segregate the colored population to any district or any districts that they may deem to the best welfare of said city, and to pass such ordinances and resolutions to put into effect this section of this Act. Segregation of white and colored population.

Sec. 86. Be it further enacted, that this Act shall not affect the present officers of the City of Stone Mountain; that the present mayor and three of the present councilmen shall serve their full term, ending December 31st, 1929, and the remaining three councilmen shall serve their full term, ending December 31st, 1930, that the present city treasurer and city clerk shall also serve until December 31st, 1930; that the other officers of the city elected by the council for one year shall serve until December 31st, 1929; that the license and special taxes and the tax rate fixed by the ordinances of said city for the year 1929 shall not be altered by this act. Election of city officers; terms.

Sec. 87. Be it further enacted, that authority to carry out and effectuate by ordinance each and every power granted to the City of Stone Mountain in this Act is hereby expressly conferred on the mayor and council of said city; and said mayor and council shall have generally the power and authority to make and pass such rules, by-laws and ordinances as shall appear to them necessary or requisite for preserving or promoting the peace, dignity, health, good order, and welfare of said City of Stone Mountain. General corporate powers.

Sec. 88. Be it further enacted, that the mayor and council of said city shall have the right to elect such other municipal officers besides those herein specified, as to them seem necessary and proper therefor when necessary, by ordinance, and in the same manner prescribing their duties and compensation and fixing their compensation. Election of officers.

Sec. 89. Be it further enacted, that the City of Stone Mountain as created by this Act, shall succeed to all the rights, privileges, and remedies of, and is hereby made responsible as a body corporate for all the legal debts, liabilities, and undertakings of the present City of Stone
Mountain and its former governing authorities as heretofore incorporated. Succession to rights and liabilities

Sec. 90. Be it further enacted, that the officers of said city elected by the mayor and council thereof, shall not be disqualified from serving as a member of the board of education, or as a member of council of said city during their term of office, nor shall any of such officers vacate the office held by them by reason of such service. Service on board of education by mayor, etc.

Sec. 91. Be it further enacted, that the mayor and councilmen and any of the officers of said city who may be sued for any act done in his official capacity may justify under this charter; and the provisions of this charter may be pleaded and shall be full defense against such action for any act or acts done by them or either of them under and in accordance with the provisions of this charter, and the ordinances passed in the pursuance thereof. Charter as defense to officers sued.

Sec. 92. Be it further enacted, that all the Acts of the General Assembly of Georgia heretofore passed incorporating the City of Stone Mountain, and all Acts amendatory thereto, be and the same are hereby consolidated and superseded by this Act. Former laws consolidated and superseded by this Act.
Sec. 93. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an act entitled An Act to repeal the present charter of the Town of Talbotton; to provide a new charter for said town; to define its limits; to provide a mayor for same; to define his powers and duties; to provide a clerk, marshal, night marshal, and other
necessary officers for said town; to define their powers and duties; to provide how the revenue of said town shall be raised; to enable said town to levy special license taxes; to provide for the appointment of tax assessors; to enable said town to issue bonds; to define the power and authority of said town as a municipality; to provide for the maintenance of streets, cemeteries, and public schools; to provide water and lights for said town; to provide for the registration of voters in said town; to provide for election of officers; to regulate any and all businesses of any kind or nature within said town, and for other purposes, approved August 20th, 1913, by striking from section 22 of said act, in line 5 on page 1188 of the Acts of 1913, the words the rate provided by law in section 864 of Civil Code of 1911, exclusive of taxes for public schools authorized by law, and inserting in lieu thereof the words $1.00 on the hundred dollars, so as to make the tax rate of said town $1.00 on the hundred dollars; and to provide for submitting said amendment to the qualified voters of said town; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this act the act entitled An Act to repeal the present charter of the Town of Talbotton; to provide a new charter for said town; to define its limits; to provide a mayor for same; to define his powers and duties; to provide a clerk, marshal, night marshal, and other necessary officers for said town; to define their powers and duties; to provide how the revenue of said town shall be raised; to enable said town to levy special taxes; to provide for the appointment of tax assessors; to enable said town to issue bonds; to define the power and authority of said town as a municipality; to provide for the maintenance of streets, cemeteries, and public schools, to provide water and lights for said town; to provide for election of officers; to regulate any and all businesses of any kind or nature within said town, and for other purposes, approved August 20, 1913, be amended by striking from section 22
of said act, in line 5 on page 1188 of the Acts of 1913, the words: the rate provided by law in section 864 of the Civil Code of 1911, exclusive of taxes for public schools authorized by law, and inserting in lieu thereof the words: $1.00 on the hundred dollars, so that said section when amended shall read as follows: Sec. 22. Be it further enacted, that for the purpose of raising revenue for the support and maintenance of the Town of Talbotton and for keeping the streets and sidewalks in repair, and for other lawful purposes, the mayor and council of said town shall have full power and authority to assess, levy, and collect ad valorem tax on all real and personal property, and every other species of property in said town or owned or held therein subject to taxation; provided no tax shall be levied on any real estate used for farming purposes in excess of five acres in said town. Said tax not to exceed $1.00 on the hundred dollars. The ad valorem tax above authorized for general purposes and the public-school tax shall be levied under separate ordinances, each specifying the purpose for which levied, and all proceedings for collecting said taxes shall show the amount due on each of said tax levies. The said mayor and council shall have power and authority to provide by ordinance for the returns and assessments of all taxable property in said town, and to provide for neglect or refusal to comply with the same, as elsewhere provided in this act. Whenever the amounts raised by the above means are insufficient for the purposes for which they are raised, additional amounts may be raised as provided in sections 867, 869, 870, 871, of Civil Code of Georgia, 1911, and for the purposes specified in those sections. Those sections being made a part of this charter whenever necessary to proceed under them. Act of 1913, Sec. 22 (Ga. L. 1913, p. 1187), amended.Tax rate.

Sec. 2. This Act shall not go into effect until after it is submitted to the qualified voters of said town by the mayor and council, and be ratified by two thirds of those voting in said election, said two thirds to be a majority of the registered qualified voters of said town of Talbotton. The notice calling said election shall be published twice
in succession in the Talbotton New Era before the day of said election. Referendum.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to incorporate the City of Tallapoosa, in the County of Haralson, and to adopt a new charter for said city, approved December 23, 1896, and also to amend an Act amendatory thereof, approved August 16, 1915; so as to provide for the permanent registration of the qualified voters of said city.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the above-recited Acts of the General Assembly be and they are hereby amended as follows:

Section 1. It shall be the duty of the clerk of said city to provide a registration book, to be known as the Permanent Registration Book, in which all the qualified voters residing within the corporate limits of said city shall be allowed to register by signing their names therein, together with their ages and occupations. At the top of each page of said permanent registration book there shall be a written or printed form of an oath that the person signing said list had each and all of the qualifications required by the charter and laws of said city, naming them, which oath shall be administered to each and every person signing said list by the clerk of said city. Permanent registration.

Sec. 2. Any resident of said city who will have acquired the qualifications as to age and length of residence required by the charter and laws of said city, at the time fixed for any election in said city, shall be entitled and allowed to register for said election.
Sec. 3. When so registered the names of the voters shall remain on said book so long as they continue to be qualified voters of said city.

Sec. 4. On the twentieth day next preceding any general or special election in said city, it shall be the duty of the clerk of said city, together with three councilmen of said city, to be appointed by the mayor of said city, to revise said registration book, and strike therefrom the names of those not entitled to vote at said election, giving written notice to those whose names were so stricken. A failure to pay taxes due and owing to said city shall be sufficient cause for striking the names of the delinquent taxpayers.

Sec. 5. After said registration book is so purged, a list of those entitled to vote shall be made by the clerk and the three councilmen, and no one whose name does not appear on said list shall be entitled and allowed to vote at any election held in said city.
Sec. 6. All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to create a new charter for the Town of Tarrytown, in the County of Montgomery, State of Georgia, and to reincorporate said town and declare and consolidate the rights and powers of said corporation; to define the corporate limits of said town; to define the duties, powers, and liabilities of the incorporators and officers; to provide for matters of municipal concern to said town, and for other purposes connected therewith.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority
of the same, that the Town of Tarrytown, in the County of Montgomery, heretofore incorporated under the laws of Georgia, shall from and after the passage of this Act, be and the same is hereby incorporated under the corporate name and style of The Town of Tarrytown. Corporate name.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that the corporate limits of said town shall be a circle extending one half mile from the present depot of the Macon, Dublin, and Savannah Railway Company, located in said town, in every direction. Corporate limits.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, that the municipal government of said town shall be vested in a mayor and five councilmen, who are hereby constituted a body corporate under the above-mentioned name and style, and by that name shall have perpetual succession, be empowered to have a common seal, to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded in all the courts of law and equity in this State and elsewhere, and to have, purchase, hold, receive, possess, and retain to themselves and their successors for the use, benefit, and behoof of said town any property or estate, real, personal, or mixed, of whatever kind or nature, and to sell, lease, improve, or otherwise control the property of said town, or any part thereof, in any manner whatever that to them may seem fit and proper. Mayor and council.General corporate powers.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, that on the first Wednesday in December, 1929, and annually thereafter on the first Wednesday in December, an election shall be held in said town under the same laws, rules, and regulations that govern elections for county officers, at which time candidates for mayor and councilmen shall be voted for by the duly qualified electors of said Town of Tarrytown; the candidate for mayor receiving the highest number of votes shall be declared mayor of said town, and the five candidates for councilmen receiving the highest number of votes shall be declared councilmen of said town; these officers shall hold their respective offices for one year and until their successors are duly elected and qualified as specified and set forth in this Act. In case no election shall be,
for any cause, held on the day herein specified, such election may be held at any time thereafter by order of the mayor then in office, and in his absence or refusal or failure, by order of any two or more of the councilmen then in office, and in case of their absence, failure, or refusal, by order of any ten qualified voters of said town. Said election when not held at the regular time, to be advertised for twenty-one days by written notice placed at least in three public and conspicuous places within said town, one of said notices to be placed at the depot of said town or some other notorious and equally public place, should the said depot be removed. Election of mayor and council.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, that the mayor and councilmen and other officers now serving under the present charter of the said Town of Tarrytown shall continue to serve in said capacity as directed by the charter under which they were elected and under its supervision until new officers are regularly elected and duly qualified as provided in this charter. Same.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, that no person shall be eligible to vote or hold any office in said town who is not a resident or qualified voter of said town, who is not qualified to vote for members of the General Assembly of this State and who have not resided in said Town of Tarrytown for at least three months next preceding the election at which he offers to vote. Qualifications of voters.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, that the returns of elections held in said Town of Tarrytown for mayor and councilmen shall be made to the retiring mayor and councilmen of said town and they shall declare the result of said election. And before entering upon the discharge of their respective duties the mayor and councilmen shall subscribe to and take the following oath: I do solemnly swear that I will faithfully discharge all duties devolving upon me as mayor (or councilman) of the Town of Tarrytown, in Montgomery County, Georgia, according to the best of may ability and understanding; so help me God, which
oath may be administered by any person authorized by the laws of this State to administer oaths. These proceedings shall be properly recorded in the minutes of said town. Oath of mayor and council.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, that in the event the office of mayor shall become vacant for any reason, a majority of the board of councilmen shall select some qualified person to serve the unexpired term; and in the event of an vacancy for any reason in the office of any councilman, the mayor shall select and appoint a qualified person to serve the unexpired term. These officials must take the regular oath of office before entering upon the discharge of the duties of their office. Vacancies.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, that said mayor and council shall elect a clerk or recorder, a mayor pro tem. to discharge all the duties of mayor in the absence or disqualification of the mayor, a treasurer, and a marshal, and said mayor and council shall have full power and authority to fix their respective salaries and define their duties. These officers shall hold their office for one year and until their successors are duly elected and qualified. Officers elected by mayor and council.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, that the mayor of said town shall have all the powers of a justice of the peace, within his jurisdiction, so far as relates to criminal matters. Mayor's powers as justice.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, that the said mayor and councilmen shall have full and ample powers to pass and enforce all needful laws, ordinances, rules, and regulations for the preservation of the peace and good order and the advancement of the welfare of said town, not inconsistent with the constitution and laws of the land. They shall have full power and authority to put and keep in good order any and all streets of said town, and open new ones, at their discretion; and in conformity to law, to work, or cause to be worked, on the streets, all parties subject to street duty within the corporate limits of said town for such length of time as road hands are liable to work, under the supervision of the marshal or overseer, or to accept from them
such commutation in lieu of said work as they in their discretion may deem right, fit and proper, such commutation to be fixed and uniform, operating upon all alike. In addition to this they may levy such commutation tax upon persons liable to street duty, or such ad valorem tax upon property located in said town as may, in their judgment, be necessary to put and keep the streets in good condition, and they may have full power to use the common jail of the county for the enforcement of any and all offenders. General powers.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, that the mayor's court shall be separate and distinct from the meetings of the mayor and council, and shall be held by the mayor, or in case of his absence or disqualification by the mayor protem., or, in his absence or disqualification, by any two members of the council; and its object and jurisdiction shall be the enforcement of the laws and ordinances of said town, as a criminal court, by fine or imprisonment in the common jail of the county or the calaboose of said town; and all such offenders shall be brought before said court and not before the council. Mayor's court; recorder.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, that all the provisions of the Code of Georgia, of the compilation of 1882, from section 783 to section 797 (b) inclusive, and all amendments thereto be and the same are hereby included in and made a part of this Act, if not in conflict or inconsistent with the same, and in case of conflict the provisions contained in this Act shall prevail. Code provisions applicable.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, that all provisions of former Acts of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia pertaining to the incorporation of the Town of Tarrytown, in and under whatever name the same may have been done or in whatever way or manner said town may have been incorporated, which may now be in effect and at variance or in conflict with the provisions of this Act are repealed when this Act is duly enacted and becomes operative
; and be it further enacted that all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed. Conflicting laws repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to create a recorder's court for the City of Tennille, County of Washington; prescribe the jurisdiction thereof, and powers; to provide for a recorder for said court, and the manner of his election; to provide for the compensation of said recorder; to provide that the clerk of council of said city shall be the clerk of said recorder's court; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that a recorder's court for the City of Tennille, County of Washington, to be known as the recorder's court of the City of Tennille, with jurisdiction and authority and powers as hereinafter provided, is hereby established. Recorder's court.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said recorder's court shall be presided over by a recorder, to be elected as is hereinafter provided.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, that said recorder shall hold such recorder's court, which said court shall have exclusive jurisdiction to try and punish within the limits prescribed by law all violations of the municipal ordinances or laws of said City of Tennille and any penal ordinances that the mayor and council of said City of Tennille may pass. The said recorder's court shall have full jurisdiction to try and punish all offenders who may be charged with violations of such ordinances. Said recorder's court shall be held at the council chamber of said City of Tennille, and shall be held at such stated times as may be determined upon by said recorder, and said
recorder may hold his court at any time when in his opinion it may be necessary to clear the city jail or to dispose of cases pending in his said court. In the event of the sickness, absence from the city, or disqualification of the recorder, the mayor of said city may act as recorder pro tem., or if said mayor shall be similarly disqualified or unable to act, then the mayor pro tem. or an alderman may so preside. Jurisdiction.Absence or disqualification of recorder.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said recorder shall take cognizance of all violations of city ordinances, and all persons who may be convicted in the recorder's court of violating any municipal ordinance shall be fined not more than $100.00, or shall be imprisoned in the city jail for not more than ninety days, or shall be confined in the city chain-gang and forced to compulsory work for not longer than ninety days. Any or all of the above punishments may be inflicted in the discretion of the recorder or acting recorder, or they shall have authority to impose any of the above punishments in the alternative. Punishments.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the recorder shall have power, in his court, if the offense be beyond the jurisdiction, to examine into the facts of the case and commit the offender to jail, or bail if the offense be bailable by a justice of the peace under the laws of this State, to appear before the superior court of Washington County if committed upon a felony charge, and to the city court of Sandersville if committed upon a misdemeanor charge. Commitment of offenders, bail.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the recorder shall have the right to subpoena witnesses and punish by attachment for contempt by fine not exceeding twenty-five dollars, for which the clerk of council may issue fi. fa., or shall have the right to imprison in the city jail not exceeding ten days for all cases of contempt of court or failure to obey its processes. A written accusation in form substantially as follows shall be preferred against all persons who may be charged with violating
the city ordinances: State of Georgia, City of Tennille, I,.....marshal of said city, in the name and behalf of the City of Tennille, charge and accuse.....of the offense (here state the offense), contrary to the laws of said city, the peace, good order and dignity thereof, this.....day of.....; and shall be signed by the marshal or deputy acting marshal as prosecutor; and when such accusation is preferred the same shall be sufficient authority to hold and accuse until final trial of the case; but the accused may give bond and security to appear at any time that may be fixed by the recorder. Said bond to be approved by the marshal or recorder. Contempts.Form of accusation.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all cases in said recorder's court shall be tried without written pleadings of any kind unless the defendant, upon the call of the case, shall file written demand with the clerk that an accusation in writing shall be preferred against him, in which event a written accusation, plainly and distinctly setting forth the offense charged, shall be drawn against such defendant, signed by the marshal, deputy, or assistant marshal, and filed with clerk before the trial shall proceed, and to such accusation the defendant shall plead in writing, which shall then form the issue to be tried. Demand for written accusation.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the clerk of council of the City of Tennille shall be the clerk of said recorder's court, shall keep the dockets thereof, issue subpoenas and other writs as may be necessary or required of him. Clerk of recorder's court.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the marshal of said City of Tennille, shall attend upon the sessions of said recorder's court, shall serve all subpoenas and writs issuing therefrom, and shall perform such other duties in connection therewith as may be usual or required of him by the proper authorities of said City of Tennille. Marshal.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all matters pending in the mayor's court of said city at the time of the ratification of this Act shall stand for trial in the recorder's court herein provided for, and such court shall have full and complete jurisdiction to take all necessary steps therein and to try and dispose of any such matters. Pending cases.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the recorder of said court shall be elected by the mayor and council of the City of Tennille for such term as may be provided by such mayor and council, and said mayor and council shall have the authority to remove such recorder. The said mayor and council shall have authority to prescribe the compensation of such recorder, provided that such compensation shall at no time exceed the sum of two hundred dollars per annum. Such recorder shall be a resident of said City of Tennille and a qualified voter therein, but no other officer of said City of Tennille shall be qualified to hold such office. Election of recorder.Salary.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and ordinances of the City of Tennille now existing with reference to the mayor and mayor's court of said city, so far as same can be made applicable, consistent with the terms of this Act, shall apply to the recorder and the recorder's court. Existing laws applicable.
Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to create and establish the board of water commissioners of the City of Tennille, Georgia, to provide
for the election of the members of said board and for the terms of office and compensation of the members thereof, for the filling of vacancies on said board, and for the removal for cause of members thereof; to prescribe the rights, powers, and duties of said employees thereof; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted that a board of water commissioners of the City of Tennille is hereby elected in and for said city. Said commission shall be composed of three (3) members, to be elected by the qualified voters of the city, except that the said commission as presently constituted shall be and constitute such commission under the terms of this act, the members thereof to be and shall hold term as follows One to serve two years; one four years, and one six years. Successors to be elected every two years to take the place of the one retiring, said election to be held at the same time and place as mayor and council election. Each member to hold office until said successors are elected and qualified. All vacancies in said commission occurring from any cause whatever, the commission and council shall proceed in not more than fifteen days after said vacancy occurs to call an election for the election of another member of said commission to fill out the unexpired term. Said commission shall govern, control, and operate the water system for this city, hereinafter set out. Board of water commissioners created.Election and terms.

Sec. 2. The members of said commission shall, before entering upon their duties, take and subscribe an oath to faithfully and impartially discharge their duties during their continuance in office, and shall keep a record, in books to be kept for the purpose, of the acts and doings of said commission, a full report of which shall be made semiannually to the mayor and council of said city; provided, however, the mayor and council, by ordinance, may change the time for making said reports. The said commission shall keep a book showing a record of all monies received by them from all sources, and of all monies and funds paid out for any and all purposes, and shall make a written report thereof to the mayor and council semiannually
or at such times as the mayor and council may be ordinance prescribe. All books, vouchers, and papers of said commission shall at all times be open and subject to inspection by the mayor and council and such persons authorized by the mayor and council to inspect the same. Oath.Reports.Records.

Sec. 3. That a majority of said commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and all contracts and engagements, acts, and doings of said commission within the scope of their authority shall be obligatory upon and considered as if done by the mayor and council. Upon organization the commission shall elect one of their number as chairman of said commission, who shall preside over the meetings or sessions of the commission and be governed by such rules and regulations as the said commission may prescribe; provided that no election of chairman shall be valid unless all three members of said commission are present and vote in said election. Quorum.Chairman.

Sec. 4. That the said commission shall employ a competent and skilled machinist, who has had actual experience in operating and managing waterworks systems and machinery operated by steam and electricity, as superintendent of the water and sewerage system of the City of Tennille for such terms as the commissioners may deem proper, provided that no contract with the superintendent shall be made for more than one year; and provided further that the present superintendent shall continue as such until the expiration of his contract of employment. The compensation of the superintendent shall be fixed by the commission. The superintendent of the water and sewerage system of said city shall, before entering upon his contract of employment, give a bond with good and sufficient security, payable to the City of Tennille, for the faithful performance of his duties as such superintendent, and the proper delivery of all money belonging to said city, coming into his hands during his employment. In addition, the said commission shall have the power and authority to employ such other persons as help as may from time to time be necessary in the management, control, and operation
of systems, but no such employment shall be for more than one year. The compensation of all employees shall be fixed by the commission. The said commission shall have the power to discharge the superintendent at time for incompetency, insufficiency, or neglect of duty, or other good and sufficient reason therefor, to be adjudged by the commission. All contracts made with the superintendent shall be made subject to this provision. Superintendent.Pay of superintendent and employees.Discharge of superintendent.

Sec. 5. That said commission shall have the authority to fix and establish and put into effect a scale of water rates, and make and enforce rules for the collection of same; adopt rules and regulations respecting the introduction of water and sewerage into or upon any premises; and from time to time regulate the use of water and sewerage in such manner as shall seem to them necessary and proper; and shall have, under the authority vested in them by mayor and council, further power to furnish at such price as fixed by commission, place and compel the use of meters, and prescribe the kind and make, the use of the same as condition precedent to furnishing premises with water, and to prescribe how and where such meters shall be placed, and the members of said commission, the superintendent, and all inspectors in their service are hereby authorized and empowered to enter, at all reasonable hours, any dwelling or other place where said water or sewerage is taken or used, and where unnecessary waste thereof is known or suspected, and examine and inquire into the cause thereof. They shall have full power to examine all surface pipes, stop-cocks, and other apparatus connected with said waterworks, and for the purpose of ascertaining whether the same are of the character and dimensions, and fixed in the same manner directed in the permits issued therefor; and if any person refuses to permit such examination or opposes or obstructs such officer or employees in the performance of such duties, such person so offending shall, upon conviction in the police court of said city, be punished as the mayor and council shall by ordinance prescribe. In addition the commission shall discontinue the supply of water
until the required examination is made and such alteration and repairs are completed as necessary. Powers of commission.

Sec. 6. The said commission shall not have the power or authority, except upon express authority from the mayor and council, granted by resolution regularly adopted, to make any further extensions of the water-mains of said system. The mayor and council shall have the exclusive right and authority to make all additions to the water-main, provided they may authorize the same to be done by the said commission, as hereinabove provided. Same.

Sec. 7. The said commission shall have full power and authority to require the payments in advance for the use or rent of water furnished by them in or upon any building, place or premises, when payment in advance is not required, for non-payment they may shut off the water from said building, place or premises, and shall not be compelled to again supply said places or premises with water until the arrears with interest thereon are fully paid. In addition thereto, the collection thereof may be enforced by execution, levy, and sale in the same manner as the collection of city taxes is enforced. Same.
Sec. 8. The said commission shall hear all complaints regarding irregularities in the rates, and their decision shall be final. Same.
Sec. 9. The members of said commission shall each receive as compensation for their services the sum of ($2.00) dollars per month. Per diem of commissioners

Sec. 10. That no funds or monies shall be paid out by said commission except upon a check drawn by the chairman of commission thereof on the funds of water commission, to which check there shall be attached a voucher showing for what purpose said check is drawn. Said check shall be signed by the chairman of the commission. Payments and vouchers.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, that the mayor and council of said city shall have the right, power, and authority to remove at any time the members of said commission,
or any member thereof, for any wilful neglect of duty, malpractice, or abuse of power conferred upon him. Removal of commissioners.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, that all money owed water commission shall be collected as heretofore by the clerk of the City of Tennille, and turned over each month of the commission. Collections by clerk.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, that said board of water commission shall have full charge of all funds received from revenue of water system, after paying expenses of same and such as necessary for the upkeep of the system. Custody of funds.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, that said commission shall have the right and authority to adopt, from time to time, such rules and regulations for their government as they may deem proper, not inconsistent with this Act nor inconsistent with the laws and ordinances of the City of Tennille. Rules and regulations.
Sec. 15. Be it further enacted that all surplus money shall be set aside in sinking fund to meet interest on bond issue by the City of Tennille. Sinking fund.
Sec. 16. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict of this ordinance be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to incorporate the City of Thomaston * * * and for other purposes (Acts of General Assembly of 1897, pages 318 et seq.), approved December 2, 1897, as follows: To provide for the condemnation of land and other property by said city for school purposes, for public streets, sidewalks, parks, and playgrounds; for rights of way for electric
light, water supply, and sewer lines; for sites for any public building of said city; for public hospitals and libraries; for any public use whatsoever; to provide for procedure in such condemnation proceedings under general law of Georgia regulating condemnation; and for like purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of same, that the Act creating and incorporating the City of Thomaston, and for other purposes, approved December 2, 1897 (Acts of 1897, pages 318 et seq.), be and the same is hereby amended by adding, just after section 33 of said Act and just before section 34 of said Act, the following sections, to wit: Act amended.

Sec. 33-A. That said city council of the City of Thomaston shall have the right to condemn land and other private property: for school purposes, and for the enlargement of school-grounds, and for the purpose of enlarging and improving the schools of said city or for their benefit; for public streets, sidewalks, parks, and playgrounds; for rights of way for any electric light, water supply, or sewer line; for sites for the building or enlarging of any public building, reservoir, or structure necessary for the operation and conduct of the fire department, water, and light department, or any other department of said city; for public hospitals and libraries; and for any other public use whatsoever, whenever same is necessary in their opinion and within the meaning of the law. Condemnation of property.

Sec. 33-B. That if the said city cannot by contract procure the land or property, easement, right of way, or other property necessary for such uses, then it shall be lawful for said city to take or damage said property, upon paying or tendering to the owner thereof just and adequate compensation for the land or other property so to be taken or used. Same.

Sec. 33-C. That the general law of Georgia regulating the condemnation of private property for public use, as embodied in the Code of Georgia (1910), in sections 5206
et seq., shall apply to the procedure in all condemnation proceedings by said city for the purposes above authorized in section 33-A. Same.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that nothing in the words of this Act shall be construed as attempting to give said city authority to condemn the fee-simple estate in any land or property; further that if the condemnation of private property for any one or more of the purposes enumerated in this Act shall be held invalid or unconstitutional, that this shall in no wise invalidate the authority herein given to condemn private property for the other purposes herein enumerated. Same.Invalidity of part of Act not invalidate other part.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act incorporating the City of Thomaston, Georgia, approved December 2d, 1897 (Georgia Laws of 1897, pages 318 et seq.), by extending the corporate limits of said City of Thomaston, and by defining and describing the territory added to the corporate limits of said city; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of same, that the Act incorporating the City of Thomaston, Georgia, approved December 2d, 1897 (Georgia Laws of 1897, pages 318 et seq.), be and the same is hereby amended by adding just after section 1 of said Act and just before section 2 of said Act the following section, to wit: Sec. 1-A. That from and after the passage of this Act the corporate limits of the City of Thomaston, Georgia, be and the same
are hereby extended so as to include the territory in the County of Upson as described in the following boundaries: Beginning at a point on the east side of the public road leading from Thomaston to Payne's Mill where it intersects with the present city limits of the City of Thomaston, and running thence along the east side of said public road a distance 1419.49 feet to a point on the east side of said public road opposite a concrete monument on the west side of said public road; thence west 1834.9 feet to a concrete monument on the east side of the public road running north from Thomaston between the lands formerly owned by James R. Atwater and the lands formerly owned by Mrs. Martha F. Weaver (said public road between the Atwater and Weaver lands being that road which branches off from State Highway No. 3 at a point within the City of Thomaston which is approximately 362 feet south of the present corporate limits of said city); thence south along the east side of said public road a distance of 1253.9 feet to the point where the east side of said public road intersects the present corporate limits of said City of Thomaston; and thence easterly, curving and following the present corporate limits of said City of Thomaston around to the starting point. New territory.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: THOMASVILLE; AUTHORITY TO ACQUIRE LAND FOR AIRPORT PURPOSES, ETC.; BOND ISSUE.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend the charter of the City of Thomasville, in the County of Thomas; granting to said municipality authority to acquire by lease, gift, or purchase, whether within or beyond its present corporate limits, land necessary
for airplane landing fields or airport purposes, and to provide the necessary funds for purchase, equipment, and maintenance, and to provide for the exercise of municipal authority over the same; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it further enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same:

Section 1. That the City of Thomasville in the County of Thomas, through its duly constituted governing authorities, be and they are hereby authorized to acquire by purchase, lease, or gift, whether within or without the present corporate limits of said city, but within the County of Thomas and within reasonable distance of said city, sufficient land for the establishment and operation of a municipal airport as may be needed in the conduct and advancement of aviation. Authority to acquire land for airport.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that said City of Thomasville by its governing authorities shall have the right if found necessary to carry into effect the provisions of section one of this Act to issue bonds in such amounts as may be necessary for the purchase, equipment, and operation of said municipal airport by complying with the laws of the State of Georgia relative to the issue of bonds by municipalities. The amounts, date of maturity, and rate of interest thereon to be fixed by the governing authorities of said city. Bond issue.

Sec. 3. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid that said City of Thomasville by its governing authority shall have and exercise entire control in the matter of constructions, operation, police government, and rules and general management of said airport, whether located within or without the present corporate limits of said city. Control over airport.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that the adoption of this Act shall have the same force and effect as an amendment to the present charter of said City of Thomasville. Act to operate as amendment to charter.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: THOMASVILLE CITY OFFICERS; ELECTION, SALARIES, ETC., REFERENDUM.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act establishing a new charter for the City of Thomasville, approved October 3, 1889, and the several acts amendatory thereof, so as to provide for the election of the city clerk, the city treasurer, the city marshal and city sexton, any one or all of them, by the mayor and board of aldermen of said city; to provide the terms of office, the duties, and the salaries of such officers; that the city treasurer and city clerk may be one and the same person; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same that the Act approved the 3d day of October, 1889, creating a new charter for the City of Thomasville, and the Acts amending the same, be and are hereby amended in the following particulars: all provisions of said charter providing for the election by vote in the regular city elections of the city clerk, the city treasurer, the city marshal, and the city sexton, in said Act approved the 3d day of October, 1889, and any Acts amendatory thereto, or previously passed and not repealed by said Act, are hereby expressly repealed. Act amendedRepeal of provisions as to election of officers.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that in lieu of the charter provisions repealed in the preceding section, at the first regular meeting after the qualification of a newly elected mayor and board of aldermen for said City of Thomasville, or as soon thereafter as possible, the mayor and board of
aldermen shall elect by ballot a city clerk, a city treasurer, a city marshal and a city sexton. Their terms of office shall be the same as that of the mayor and aldermen; they shall take such oaths of office as is prescribed by the charter of said City of Thomasville and any other that the mayor and board of aldermen may prescribe, and shall give such bonds as are required by the charter of said city and any other that the mayor and board of aldermen may prescribe. Their duties shall be those specified in the charter and ordinances of said city and any other duties that may be prescribed by the mayor and board of aldermen of said city. Each and every one of said officers elected by the mayor and board of aldermen as herein provided shall be directly responsible to the mayor and board of aldermen for the proper conduct of their respective offices. Their respective salaries shall be fixed by the mayor and board of aldermen before their election. The mayor and board of aldermen may, if they see fit, elect one person to be both city treasurer and city clerk. Election of city officers.Duties of officers.Salaries.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, that this Act shall not go into effect and become operative until the same shall have been ratified at an election to be called and held as provided in an Act of the General Assembly of Georgia approved August 22, 1925, Georgia Laws 1925, page 136; provided, however, that if this Act is so ratified at such election, then this Act shall go into effect on the third Monday in January, 1931, and thereafter. Said election shall be held as provided by the laws of the State and the provisions of the charter of said city. Referendum.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that in the referendum election provided for in the preceding section the form of the ballots used shall be such that the voter can cast his ballot for or against this amendment as to either the city clerk, the city treasurer, the city marshal or the city sexton, or the provision that one person can be both city treasurer and city clerk. And should a majority of the ballots cast be in favor of this amendment as to one or more of said officers and against the amendment
as to others, then this Act shall go into effect with respect only to those of said officers whose change or manner of election as herein provided was favored by a majority of the voters in said election. Same.
Sec. 5. All laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: THOMASVILLE; PENSIONS FOR CITY EMPLOYEES; REFERENDUM.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the City of Thomasville, Georgia, so as to provide a way by which may be retired from active service, on part pay, any employee of the City of Thomasville, Georgia; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Sec. 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the city charter of the City of Thomasville, Georgia, be amended as follows: that when any employee has been regularly, continuously, and uninterrupedly employed by said city for a period of twenty-five years, and has attained the age of sixty years, he shall be permitted to retire from active service, on his own motion, or on motion of council, upon half pay of which he may be receiving at the time of his retiring, and shall be continuously paid same for and during the term of his natural life. Provided, however, that in event any employee having served twenty-five years regularly, continuously, and uniterrupedly, and then for any cause charges are preferred by the city council and pending against any such employee at the time he moves to be retired, such employee shall not be entitled to receive such benefits as are provided herein. This Act is intended to include all employees of the City of Thomasville who have regularly, continuously, and uninterrupedly
been employed by the City of Thomasville for a period of twenty-five years, and have attained the age of sixty years to participate in the benefits provided for in this Act, after this Act has been ratified by a majority of the voters of the City of Thomasville in an election for the ratification of same as herein provided, and in accordance with the other provisions of this Act. Pensions for employees.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that this Act shall not go into effect and become effective until the same shall have been ratified at an election to be called and held as provided in section 913 (tt) of Park's Annotated Code of Georgia; provided, however, that if this Act is so ratified at such election, then the Act shall go in effect the first day of January succeeding said election, and be effective on said date and thereafter. Said election shall be held as provided by the laws of the State and provisions of the charter of the City of Thomasville. Referendum.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: THOMASVILLE; POWER AS TO STREETS, NUISANCES., ETC.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the Act approved October 3, 1889, entitled An Act to reincorporate the Town of Thomasville as the City of Thomasville, and creating a charter therefor, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, so as to give to the mayor and aldermen additional authority with reference to streets, lanes, and alleys, the removal of obstructions and the abatement of nuisances; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the Act recited in the foregoing caption, and the several acts amendatory thereof, be and the same are hereby amended by incorporating therein as a part of the charter of the City of Thomasville the following: (a) The mayor and aldermen of said city are hereby vested with power and authority to lay out, open, close, change the location of, and change the grade of any of the streets, avenues, lanes and alleys, public or private, within the city, whenever in their discretion the welfare of the public seems to demand it; and in their discretion they shall have power and authority to abate or cause the removal of any obstruction or nuisance in or upon such streets, avenues, lanes and alleys, and to prevent or regulate the crossing of sidewalks by vehicle entering upon or emerging from private property; provided, however, that before any such street, avenue, lane, or alley is laid out, opened, or closed, and before any such nuisance is abated, the adjacent owners and parties directly interested shall be given ten days' notice, by the publication of such notice twice in the newspaper in which the official citations of the city are published, and in pursuance of such notice shall be given an opportunity to be heard. Power as to streets and nuisances.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and they are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: THOMASVILLE; POWER AS TO STREETS, NUISANCES, ETC.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend the Act approved October 3, 1889, entitled An Act to reincorporate the Town of Thomasville as the City of Thomasville, and creating a charter
therefor, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, so as to give to the mayor and aldermen additional authority with reference to streets, lanes and alleys, the removal of obstructions, and the abatement of nuisances; and for other purposes;
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the Act recited in the foregoing caption, and the several acts amendatory thereof, be and the same are hereby amended by incorporating therein as a part of the charter of the City of Thomasville, the following: (a) The mayor and aldermen of said city are hereby vested with the power and authority to lay out, open, close, change the location of, and change the grade of any of the streets, avenues, lanes, and alleys, public or private, within the city, whenever in their discretion the welfare of the public seems to demand it; and in their discretion they shall have power and authority to abate or cause the removal of any obstruction or nuisance in or upon such streets, avenues, lanes, and alleys, and to prevent or regulate the crossing of side-walks by vehicles entering upon or emerging from private property; provided, however, that before any such streets, avenue, lane, or alley is laid out, opened or closed, and before any such nuisance is abated, the adjacent owners and parties directly interested shall be given ten days' notice, by the publication of such notice twice in the newspapers in which the official citations of the city are published, and in pursuance of such notice shall be given an opportunity to be heard.This Act is a duplicate of the preceding Act (No. 335).This Act is a duplicate of the preceding Act (No. 335.)
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and they are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend section 12 of an Act approved August 14th, 1920 (Acts 1920, page 1625), entitled An Act to repeal the present charter of the City of Tifton; to provide a new charter for the City of Tifton; to provide for a commission form of government, a city manager and other officers; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of same, that from and after the passage of this act section 12 of an Act approved August 12, 1920 (Acts 1920, page 1625), entitled An Act to repeal the present charter of the City of Tifton; to provide for a commission form of government, a city manager, and other officers; and for other purposes, be and the same is hereby amended by striking therefrom all of said section following the words at any time, in the tenth line thereof; so that as amended, beginning at the period in the eighth line, it shall read as follows: Act amended.To read.

Section 1. The city manager shall be chief executive officer of the city and shall be elected by the city commission, and shall be subject to removal at the discretion of the city commission at any time upon thirty days' notice. Said city manager's salary shall be fixed each year at the regular January meeting of the city commission, and shall not be either increased or decreased during the ensuing twelve months. The present term of the city manager shall expire on the 15th day of January, 1930, and his successor shall be elected by the city commission at the regular January, 1930, term. The city manager shall submit the names of all proposed employees of the city, together with the salary to be paid to each, to the city commission for confirmation, and until confirmed no person shall receive compensation for any services rendered to the city. City manager, election, removal, salaries.

Sec. 2. Neither the city manager nor any other officer, or employee of any department under him, shall campaign or
solicit votes, for, or contract any money towards the election or nomination of, any person as commissioner of the city, except to answer such questions as may be put, and that they may desire to answer. Any violation of this section shall subject offender to removal of office. Unlawful solicitation of voters or contribution of money.
Sec. 3. Be it enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this act be and the same is hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend the charter of the Town of Toomsboro in Wilkinson County, by amending an Act entitled An Act to incorporate the Town of Toomsboro, in the County of Wilkinson; to provide for a mayor and council, prescribe their powers and duties; to define the corporate limits of said town, and for other purposes, approved August 15, 1904, the amending Acts approved August 17, 1906, and August 13, 1927, said Act of 1904 be amended by adding to section 10 of said Act the following: The board of council may make and establish all necessary and reasonable rules and regulations governing the city chain-gang, and said board is hereby authorized to contract with the county authorities of Wilkinson County to work the convicts, convicted in the police court of Toomsboro, in the Wilkinson County chain-gang; provided, however, that the said authorities of the Town of Toomsboro shall at all times retain and exercise such control of such convicts as may be necessary to insure proper and humane treatment; that section one of the Act approved August 13, 1927, be stricken, and inserting in lieu thereof the following: All that territory lying on the south and west side of Commissioner Creek, embraced within a line starting on Commissioner Creek, one mile from where the public street crosses the Central of Georgia
Railroad, at its crossing just east of the depot of the Central of Georgia Railway Company at Toomsboro, said line following said stream and touching the south end of the bridge known as the Commissioner Creek bridge at Toomsboro, thence along said stream until it touches another point on said stream one mile from said railway crossing, thence a circular line one mile distant from said railway crossing until it again intersects the line at Commissioner Creek, is hereby incorporated in said town, and the limits of said town shall be a circular line one mile distant from said crossing until it touches Commissioner Creek, and thence along said creek and end of said bridge as aforesaid; and other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that section 10 of the Act approved August 15, 1904, be amended by adding to and at the end of said section the following: The board of council may make and establish all necessary and reasonable rules and regulations governing the city chain-gang, and said board is hereby authorized to contract with the authorities having charge of county matters of Wilkinson County, to work the convicts, convicted in the police court of the Town of Toomsboro, in the Wilkinson County chain-gang; provided, however, that the said authorities of the Town of Toomsboro, shall at all times retain and exercise such control of such convicts as may be necessary to insure proper and humane treatment. So that when said section shall have been amended, to read as follows: Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, that said town shall have the power and right to organize work-gangs and to confine at labor therein, for a term not exceeding twenty days, persons convicted of violating the ordinances of said town; provided that said penalty shall be inflicted only as an alternative for failure or refusal to pay fine imposed for such violation. The board of council may make and establish all necessary and reasonable rules and regulations governing the city chain-gang, and said board is hereby authorized to contract with
the county authorities having charge of county matters of Wilkinson County, to work the convicts, convicted in the police court of the Town of Toomsboro, in the Wilkinson County chain-gang; provided, however, that the said authorities of the Town of Toomsboro shall at all times retain and exercise such control of such convicts as may be necessary to insure proper and humane treatment. Addition to Sec. 10 of Act of 1904.To read.Chain-gang.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that section one of the Act entitled An Act to amend an Act incorporating the Town of Toomsboro, approved August 13, 1927, be amended by striking all of said section and inserting in lieu thereof the following: All that territory lying on the south and west side of Commissioner Creek, one mile from where the public street crosses the Central of Georgia Railroad at its crossing, just east of the depot of the Central of Georgia Railway Company at Toomsboro, said line following said stream and touching the south end of the bridge known as the Commissioner Creek Bridge at Toomsboro, thence along said stream until it touches another point on said stream, one mile from said railway crossing, thence a circular line one mile distant from said railway crossing, until it again intersects the line at Commissioner Creek, is hereby incorporated in said town, and the limits of said town shall be a circular line one mile distant from said crossing until it touches said Commissioner Creek, and thence along said creek and end of said bridge as aforesaid. So that when said section shall have been amended to read as follows: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that on and after the passage of this act the corporate limits of said Town of Toomsboro shall be as follows: All that territory lying on the south and west side of Commissioner Creek one mile from where the public street crosses the Central of Georgia Railroad at its crossing just east of the depot of the Central of Georgia Railway Company at Toomsboro, said line following said stream and touching the south end of the bridge known as the Commissioner
Creek Bridge at Toomsboro, thence along said stream until it touches another point on said stream one mile from said railway crossing, thence a circular line one mile distant from said railway crossing until it again intersects the line at Commissioner Creek, is hereby incorporated in said town, and the limits of said town shall be a circular line one mile distant from said crossing until it touches said Commissioner Creek, and thence along said creek and end of said bridge, as aforesaid. Act of 1927, Sec. 1. amended.To read.New territory.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: TYBEE; CORPORATE NAME CHANGED TO SAVANNAH BEACH, TYBEE ISLAND; CORPORATE LIMITS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to revise, alter and amend the several acts incorporating the mayor and councilmen of the Town of Tybee, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act the name of that certain body corporate created by the Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved August 21, 1922, and contained in the Acts published in Georgia Laws of 1922 on page 987, under the name and style of the mayor and councilmen of the Town of Tybee, be changed to Savannah Beach, Tybee Island, and by that name and style shall have and enjoy all of the rights, powers, and privileges under said above recited Act and any amendments thereof. Change of name of Town of Tybee.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the corporate limits of the Town of Tybee, as defined in section 1 of the Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved August 21, 1922, and contained in Georgia Laws of 1922, upon page 987, be and they are hereby changed, altered, and amended by adding the following words at the conclusion of said paragraph, to wit: except all of the land and territory lying west of the course of Chimney Creek and south of the right of way of the Central of Georgia Railroad, so that the corporate limits of said Town of Tybee, from and after the passage of this Act shall embrace the entire Island of Tybee as shown by the map of Chatham County, Georgia, adopted by the Commissioners of Chatham County, Georgia, and ex-officio judges, April 11, 1906, except all of that portion of land and territory lying west of the course of Chimney Creek and south of the right of way of the Central of Georgia Railroad. Corporate limits.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act or any section hereof be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the Act granting to the City of Valdosta a charter, approved November 21st, 1901, and the several acts amendatory thereof; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that an act granting to the City of Valdosta a charter, approved November 21st, 1901, and the several acts amendatory thereof, be and the same is hereby amended as follows:

Section 1. Grant of Power. For the purpose of promoting health, safety, morals, or the general welfare of the citizens of the City of Valdosta, the mayor and council of said city is hereby authorized to regulate and restrict the height, number of stores, and size of buildings and other structures, the percentage of lot that may be occupied, the size of yards, courts, and other open spaces, the density of population, and the location and use of buildings, structures, and land for trade, industry, residence, or other purposes. Authority as to building regulations.

Sec. 2. Districts. For any or all of said purposes the mayor and council of said city may divide the City of Valdosta into districts of such number, shape, and area as may be deemed best suited to carry out the purposes of this act; and within such districts it may regulate and restrict the erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair, or use of buildings, structures, or land. All such regulations shall be uniform for each class or kind of buildings throughout each district, but the regulations in one district may differ from those in other districts. Same.Districts.

Sec. 3. Purposes in View. Such regulations shall be made in accordance with a comprehensive plan and designed to lessen congestion in the streets; to secure safety from fire, panic, and other dangers; to promote health and the general welfare; to provide adequate light and air; to prevent the overcrowding of land; to avoid undue concentration of population; to facilitate the adequate provision of transportation, water, sewerage, schools, parks, and other public requirements. Such regulations shall be made with reasonable consideration, among other things, to the character of the district and its peculiar suitability for the particular uses, and with a view to conserving the value of buildings and encouraging the most appropriate use of land throughout such city. Plan and purposes.

Sec. 4. Method of Procedure. The mayor and council of said city shall provide for the manner in which such regulations and restrictions and the boundaries of such districts
shall be determined, established, and enforced, and from time to time amended, supplemented, or changed. However, no such regulation, restriction, or boundary shall become effective until after a public hearing in relation thereto, at which parties in interest and citizens shall have an opportunity to be heard. At least fifteen (15) days' notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be published in an official paper, or a paper of general circulation in said city. Notice and hearing before regulations become effective.

Sec. 5. Changes. Such regulations, restrictions, and boundaries may from time to time be amended, supplemented, changed, modified, or repealed. In case, however, of a protest against such change, signed by the owners of twenty (20) per cent. or more either of the area of the lots included in such proposed change, or of those immediately adjacent in the rear thereof, extending two hundred (200) feet therefrom, or of those directly opposite thereto, extending two hundred (200) feet from the street frontage of such opposite lots, such amendment shall not become effective unless it be adopted by the mayor and council of said city in the same manner as ordinances are passed under the present provisions of the charter of said city. The provisions of the previous section relative to public hearings and official notice shall apply equally to all changes or amendments. Changes of boundaries and regulations, when effective.

Sec. 6. Zoning Commission. In order to avail itself of the powers conferred by this Act, the mayor and council of said city shall appoint a commission, to be known as a zoning commission, to recommend the boundaries of the various original districts and appropriate regulations to be enforced therein. Such commission shall make a preliminary report and hold public hearings thereon before submitting its final report, and the mayor and council of said city shall not hold its public hearings herein provided for, or take action as herein provided for, until it has received the final report of such commission. Such commission shall be composed of such number of persons as may be determined by the mayor and council of said city
and of such persons as may be elected to serve on such commission by the mayor and council of said city, and such commission shall be composed of not less than three or more than five persons, and shall receive such compensation for their services as such members as may be fixed by the mayor and council of said city. Zoning Commission.

Sec. 7. Board of Adjustment. The mayor and council of said City of Valdosta may provide for the appointment of a board of adjustment, and in the regulations and restrictions adopted pursuant to the authority of this Act may provide that the said board of adjustment may, in appropriate cases and subject to appropriate conditions and safeguards, make special exceptions to the application of terms of the ordinance in harmony with its general purpose and intent and in accordance with general or specific rules therein contained. Board of Adjustment.

The board of adjustment shall consist of not less than three or more than five members, each to be appointed for a term of two years and removable for cause by the mayor and council of said city upon written charges and after public hearing. Vacancies shall be filled by the mayor and council of said city for the unexpired term of any member whose term becomes vacant. The compensation to be paid the members of such board of adjustment shall be fixed by the mayor and council of said city. Membership of board, terms of office, pay.

The board shall adopt rules in accordance with the provisions of any ordinance adopted pursuant to this act. Meetings of the board shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such other time as the board may determine. Such chairman, or in his absence the acting chairman, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses by subpoenas issued in the name of the board by him as chairman. Such subpoenas may be served by the marshal of said city or any policeman of said city. If any person, or persons, who has been served with such subpoena fails to attend the hearing as required of him by such subpoena, the chairman of such board shall certify such facts to
the judge of the superior court of Lowndes County, Georgia, and it shall then become the duty of the judge of such superior court to issue a rule nisi and have same served on the defaulting witness, requiring him to show cause why he should not be punished for his failure to attend such hearing, or hearings, as required by such subpoena, and, unless such witness can show to the satisfaction of the court that he had a legal excuse for not attending such hearing, or hearings, as required by him by such subpoena, the judge of said court shall thereupon fine such defaulting witness not less than five dollars ($5.00), and payment of which fine shall be enforced in the same manner as fines in contempt cases are enforced in the superior courts of this State. Meetings, hearings.

All meetings of the board shall be open to the public. The board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon each question, or, if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall be immediately filed in the office of the board and shall be a public record.

Appeals to the board of adjustment may be taken by any person aggrieved by any decision of the administrative officer. Such appeal shall be taken within a reasonable time, as provided by the rules of the board, by filing with the officer from whom the appeal is taken and with the board of adjustment a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The officer from whom the appeal is taken shall forthwith transmit to the board all the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. Appeals.

An appeal automatically stays all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the officer from whom the appeal is taken certifies to the board of adjustment after the notice of appeal shall have been filed with him that by reason of facts stated in the certificate a stay would in his opinion cause imminent peril to life or property.
In such case proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by a restraining order, which may be granted by the board of adjustment or by the superior court of Lowndes County, Georgia, on application on notice to the officer from whom the appeal is taken and on due cause shown.

The board of adjustment shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal, give public notice thereof in a newspaper of general circulation in the City of Valdosta, as well as due notice to the parties in interest, and decide the same within a reasonable time. Upon the hearing any party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney.
The board of adjustment shall have the following powers: Powers of board.

1. To hear and decide appeals where it is alleged there is error in any order requirement, decision, or determination made by an administrative official in the enforcement of this Act or of any ordinance adopted pursuant thereto.
2. To hear and decide special exceptions to the application of the terms of the ordinance upon which such board is required to pass under such ordinance.

3.
