Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the lots, pieces, or parcels of land fronting and abutting upon both sides of said improvements shall be charged with the cost thereof according to the just pro rata of the entire cost of said improvement for the said frontage on basis of lineal-foot frontage; provided that the frontage of intersecting streets, avenues, lanes, or alleys shall be assessed as real estate abutting upon the street, lane, alley, or avenue paved or otherwise improved, and the said mayor and council shall be, for all the intents and purposes of this Act, an owner or legal representative of real estate abutting on any street, lane, alley, or avenue, shall possess the same rights and privileges as all other owners of real estate abutting on any street, lane, alley, or avenue, and shall pay from the city or town treasury the just pro rata of the entire cost of said work or improvement for the said frontage, unless the owners of a majority of the aforesaid frontage in the petition hereinbefore provided for, shall agree to pay the entire cost of said improvement, or unless in the resolution hereinbefore provided for it shall be stated that the entire cost of the improvement is to be paid by the abutting property owners. Apportionment of cost.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that whenever the petition provided for in section six of this Act is presented, or when the said mayor and council shall have determined to pave or improve any street, avenue, lane, alley, or other public place, and shall have passed the resolution provided for in said section six of this Act, the said mayor and council shall then have the power to enact all ordinances and to establish all such rules and regulations as may be necessary to require the owners of all property subject to assessment to pay the cost of such
improvement, and to cause to be put in and constructed all water or sewer-pipe connections to connect with any existing water or sewer pipes in underneath the streets, avenues, lanes and alleys, and other public places where such improvements are made, and all costs and expenses for making such connections shall be taxed against the property and shall be included and made a part of the general assessment to cover the cost of such improvement, in addition to the basis of said lineal-foot frontage. Assessment.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that after the expiration of the time for objection or protest on the part of the property owners, if no sufficient protest be filed, or no receipt of a petition for such improvement signed by a majority of the owners of such land to be assessed, if such petition shall be found to be in proper form and properly executed, the said mayor and council shall adopt a resolution reciting that no such protest has been filed, or the filing of such petition, as the case may be, and expressing the determination of said mayor and council to proceed with the said improvement, stating the material to be used and the manner of construction, and defining the extent, character, and width of the improvement, and other such matters as may be necessary, to instruct a competent engineer employed for such purpose in the performance of his duties in preparing for such improvement the necessary plans, plots, profiles, specifications, and estimates. Said resolution shall set forth any and all such reasonable terms and conditions as said mayor and council shall deem proper to impose with reference to the letting of the contract and the provisions thereof, and the said mayor and council shall by said resolution provide that the contractor shall execute to the town a good bond in an amount to be stated in such resolution, conditioned for the full and faithful performance of the contract, and for the protection of the town and all property owners interested against any loss or damage by reason of the negligence or improper execution of the work, and may require a bond, in an amount to be stated in such resolution, for the maintenance of good
conditions of such improvements for a period of not less than five years from the time of its completion or both, in the discretion of said mayor and council. Said resolution shall also direct the mayor of said town to advertise for sealed proposals for furnishing the materials and performing the work necessary in making such improvements. The notice of such proposals shall state the street, streets, or other public places to be improved, the kinds of improvements proposed, what, if any, bond or bonds will be required to be executed by the contractor aforesaid, and shall state the time when and the place where such sealed proposals shall be filed, and when and where the same will be considered by said mayor and council. Said notice shall be published in four consecutive issues of a weekly newspaper of general circulation in the Town of Watkinsville. At the time and place specified in such notice the mayor and council shall examine all bids received and without unnecessary delay award the contract to the lowest and best bidder, who will perform the work and furnish the materials which may be selected and perform all the conditions imposed by the said mayor and council as prescribed in such resolutions and notice for proposals, which contract shall in no case exceed the estimate of cost submitted by said engineer with the plans and specifications, and the said mayor and council shall have the right to reject any and all bids and readvertise for other bids when any such bids are not in its judgment satisfactory. Notice of resolution.Award of contract.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that after the said contract is let the and the cost of such improvement, which shall also include all other expenses incurred by the town incident to said improvement in addition to the contract price for the work and materials, is ascertained, the said mayor and council shall by resolution appoint a board of appraisers, consisting of three members, who are freeholders of the town, to appraise and apportion the cost and expense of the same to the several tracts of land abutting on said improvements as hereinbefore provided. Within ten days from the date of the resolution
appointing the board it shall file with the mayor of said town a written report of the appraisal and the assessment and apportionment, in the manner and on the basis herein provided, of such expenses and cost, upon the several lots and tracts of land abutting on said street. When said report shall have been returned and filed, the said mayor and council shall appoint a time for the holding of a session or shall designate a regular meeting of their body for the hearing of any complaints or objections that may be made concerning said appraisement, apportionment, and assessment as to any such lots or tracts of land abutting on said improvement, and notice of such session for the said hearing shall be published by the mayor of said town once a week for four weeks in the paper where the sheriffs advertisements for the county are published, and said notice shall provide for an inspection of such return by any property owner or other party interested in such return. The time fixed for said hearing shall not be less than five nor more than ten days from the date of the last publication. The said mayor and council shall have power, and it shall be their duty, to review and correct said appraisement, apportionment, and assessment, and to hear objections to the same, and to confirm the same either as made by said board or as corrected by said governing body. Assessments in conformity to said appraisement and apportionment as confirmed by said council shall be payable in ten equal installments, and shall bear interest at the rate of not exceeding seven per cent. per annum until paid, payable in each year at such time as the several installments of the assessments are made payable each year. The said mayor and council shall by ordinance levy assessments in accordance with said appraisement and apportionment as so confirmed against the several tracts of land liable therefor; provided, however, that the rate of interest to be taxed shall not exceed one per cent. over and above the rate of interest stipulated in the bonds herein provided for. Board of appraisers.Hearing to property owners.Payment in installments.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the first installment of said assessment, together
with interest to that date upon the whole, shall be due and payable on the first day of September next succeeding the passage of said ordinance, and one installment, with the yearly interest upon the amounts remaining unpaid, shall be payable on the first day of September in each succeeding year until all shall be paid; provided that if such assessing ordinance shall be passed after the first day of August in each year, the first installment of such assessment and interest shall be due and payable on September first of the following year. Said ordinance shall also provide that the owners of the property so assessed shall have the privilege of paying the amounts of their respective assessments within thirty days from the date of the passage of said ordinance. The owners of the property so assessed shall be allowed to make payment of their respective assessments without interest within said period of thirty days to the mayor of said Town of Watkinsville, and relieve their property from the lien of said assessment, which money so paid to said mayor shall be disbursed pro rata between the contractor and the town in proportion to the respective interest. Same.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that such special assessment and each installment thereof, and the interest thereon, are hereby declared to be a lien against the lots and tracts of land so assessed from the date of the ordinance levying the same, coequal with the lien of other taxes and prior to and superior to all other liens against such lots or tracts, and such lien shall continue until such assessment and interest thereon shall be fully paid, but unmatured installments shall not be deemed to be within the terms of any general covenant or warranty. Lien of Assessment.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said mayor and council, after the expiration of thirty days from the passage of said ordinance confirming and levying said assessment shall by resolution provide for the issuance of bonds in the aggregate amount of such assessment remaining unpaid, bearing date fifteen days after the passage of the ordinance levying the said assessment, and of such denominations as the said mayor and
council shall determine, which bond or bonds shall in no event become a liability of the mayor and council of the Town of Watkinsville issuing same. One tenth in amount of any such series of bonds, with the interest upon the whole series to date, shall be payable on the fifteenth day of September next succeeding the maturity of the first installment of the assessments and interest, and one tenth thereof, with the yearly interest upon the whole amount remaining unpaid, shall be payable on the fifteenth day of September in each succeeding year until all shall be paid. Such bonds shall bear interest at a rate not exceeding six per cent. per annum from their date until maturity, payable annually, and shall be designated as street improvement bonds, and shall on the face thereof recite the street or streets, part of street or streets, or other public places, for the improvement of which they have been issued, and that they are payable solely from assessments which have been levied upon the lots and tracts of land benefited by said improvements under authority of this Act. Said bonds shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the clerk of council, and shall have the impression of the corporate seal of such town thereon, and shall have interest coupons attached, and all bonds issued by authority of this Act shall be payable at such place either within the State of Georgia or without the State as shall be designated by said mayor and council. Said bonds shall be sold at not less than par, and the proceeds thereof applied to the payment of the contract price and other expenses, by the said mayor and council, or such bonds in the amount that shall be necessary for that purpose may be turned over and delivered to the contractor at par value in payment of the amount due him on his contract, and the portion thereof which shall be necessary to pay other expenses incident to and incurred in providing for said improvements, shall be sold or otherwise disposed of as the said mayor and council shall direct. Said bonds shall be registered by the clerk of council in a book to be provided for that purpose, and certificates of registration by said clerk of council shall be endorsed upon each of said bonds. Bond issue.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the assessments provided for and levied under the provisions of this Act shall be payable by the person owning the said lots or tracts of land as the several installments become due, together with the interest thereon, to the mayor of the Town of Watkinsville, who shall give proper receipts of such payments. It shall be the duty of the mayor to keep an accurate account of all such collections by him made, and such collections shall be kept in a special fund to be used and applied for the payment of such bonds and the interest thereon and expenses incurred thereto, and for no other purposes. Collection of assessment.

It shall be the duty of said mayor, not less than thirty days and not more than forty days before the maturity of any installment of such assessment, to publish in two successive issues of a weekly newspaper having a general circulation in the Town of Watkinsville a notice advising the owner of the property affected by such assessment of the date when such installment and interest will be due, and designate the street or streets, or other public places for the improvements of which such assessments have been levied, and that unless the same shall be promptly paid, proceedings will be taken to collect said installment and interest. And it shall be the duty of said mayor promptly after the date of maturity of any such installment or assessment and interest, and on or before the (15th) fifteenth day of September of each year, in case of default of payment of such installment or assessment with interest to issue an execution against the lot or tract of land assessed for such improvement, or against the party or person owning the same, for the amount of such assessment with interest, and shall turn over same to the marshal of the Town of Watkinsville, who shall levy the same upon the adjoining real estate liable for such assessment, and after advertisement and other proceedings, as in case of sales for town taxes, the same shall be sold at public outcry to the highest bidder; and such sales shall vest an absolute title in the purchaser, subject to the lien of the remaining unpaid
installments with interest, and also subject to the rights of redemption as provided in sections 880, 1169, 1170, 1171 and 1172 of Park's Code of Georgia, provided that the defendant shall have the right to file an affidavit denying that the whole or any part of the amount for which said execution is due, and stating what amount be admitted to be due, shall be paid or collected before the affidavit is received, and the affidavit received for the balance. All affidavits shall set out in detail the reasons why the affiant claims the amount is not due, and, when received by the town marshal, shall be returned to the superior court of Oconee County, Georgia, and there be tried and the issue determined as in cases of illegality, subject to all the pains and penalties provided for in cases of illegality, for the delay, under the Code of Georgia. The failure of the mayor to publish said notice of maturity of any installment of said assessment and interest shall in no wise affect the validity of the assessment and interest and the execution issued therefor. Notice to property owner.Execution.Levy and sale.Affidavit of illegality.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that after the assessments are finally determined and fixed as hereinbefore provided for, suit may be instituted in the superior court of Oconee County by the mayor and council against the respective owners of the lots or parcels of land abutting upon said improvements. After setting out the facts in the petition, the prayer of the petition shall be that the court find and determine the validity of such ordinance or ordinances, and the question of whether or not the respective lots or parcels of land abutting upon said improvements shall be charged with the lien of said work in the manner provided by this Act. Validation of ordinances.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the mayor and council of said Town of Watkinsville shall have the right and power to construct, install, establish, erect, and maintain a system of waterworks, sewerage, and drainage in and for said town. Waterworks, sewerage, etc.

Sec. 17. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the mayor and council of said Town of Watkinsville
be and they are hereby authorized to issue bonds of said town under and in accordance with the constitution and laws of this State, in a sum not to exceed seven per centum of the assessed value of ll the taxable property in said town. Said bonds shall be issued in denominations of not less than fifty dollars and not more than one thousand dollars, and at such rate of interest, not to exceed six per cent. per annum, as the mayor and council may determine; said bonds to mature at such time, not exceeding thirty years, as said mayor and council may determine; the interest on said bonds to be paid annually, or at such less intervals, as said mayor and council may determine. Bond issue.

Sec. 18. That said bonds when so issued shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the clerk of council, and sealed with the corporate seal of said Town of Watkinsville, and shall be sold by the said mayor and council, in such manner as shall be determined by said mayor and council to be for the best interest of said town. Sale of bonds.

Sec. 19. Be it further enacted, that the money arising from the sale of said bonds shall be used solely for the purpose of constructing, installing, establishing, erecting, and maintaining a system of waterworks, sewerage, and drainage in and for the Town of Watkinsville. Proceeds of bonds.

Sec. 20. Be it further enacted, that before said bonds shall be issued, it shall be the duty of the mayor and council of said town to call an election of the qualified voters of said town, in accordance with sections 440 to 443, inclusive, of Park's Code of Georgia, to pass upon the question of the issuance of said bonds. At said election there shall be two kinds of ballots, one printed or written with the words For waterworks, sewerage, drainage, and bonds, and the other Against waterworks, sewerage, drainage, and bonds; and should two thirds of the ballots cast in said election by the qualified voters of said town, be for waterworks, sewerage, drainage and bonds, it shall be the duty of said mayor and council to issue said bonds and construct, erect, install, and establish said system of waterworks, sewerage,
and drainage, in and for said town; but should the result of said election show a failure of two thirds of the qualified voters of said town to vote for waterworks, sewerage, drainage, and bonds, then and in that event the said mayor and council, or their successors in office, are hereby authorized and empowered to again submit the questions to the qualified voters of said town in accordance with said sections 440 to 443 of the Code of Georgia, provided said election shall not be held within six months of the first election. Election as to bond issue.

Sec. 21. Be it further enacted, that the mayor and council of said Town of Watkinsville are hereby authorized and empowered to levy and collect annually a tax on all the taxable property in said town, for the purpose of paying the interest on said bonds, and also to create a sinking fund sufficient to pay off and redeem said bonds at maturity, as required by the laws of this State. Tax to pay bonds.

Sec. 22. Be it further enacted, that said mayor and council of said town are hereby authorized to lay watermains, pipes, sewerage, and drainage on, under and within the streets, lanes, and alleys and other public places of the Town of Watkinsville, and over and through such property within and without the Town of Watkinsville as the mayor and council of said town may acquire by lease, purchase, condemnation, or otherwise. Water-mains, sewerage, drainage.

Sec. 23. Be it further enacted, that when said waterworks shall have been constructed, the said mayor and council of the Town of Watkinsville shall have full and ample authority to prescribe the terms, rates, and conditions upon which said water shall be furnished to the inhabitants and residents of said town, whether upon a flat rate, or upon a meter system, either or both, and to provide and fix all rates, rules, and regulations governing said waterworks and water system. Regulation of water system; rates.

Sec. 24. Be it further enacted, that section 15 of the Act amending the charter of the Town of Watkinsville, approved August 29, 1891, be amended by adding after
the word that and before the word if in line one of said section the following words, to wit: Said mayor or the receiver, as the case may be, shall within ten days from the date of the closing of the tax returns for the current year inspect the tax returns, and it shall be the mayor's duty to call a meeting of the council for the purpose of examining all the returns of both real and personal property of each taxpayer, and if in the opinion of the mayor and council any taxpayer has omitted from his return any of his property that should be returned, or has failed to return any of his property at a just and fair valuation, the said mayor and council shall correct such returns and shall assess and fix the just and fair valuation to be placed on said property. It shall be the duty of said mayor and council to see that all taxable property within said town is assessed and returned at its just and fair valuation, and that valuations as between individual taxpayers are fairly and justly equalized, so that each taxpayer shall pay, as near as may be, only his proportionate share of taxes. When any such corrections, changes, and equalizations shall have been made by said mayor and council, it shall be the duty of said mayor to immediately give notice to any taxpayer of any changes made in his returns, which notice shall be served by the mayor or the marshal, either personally or by leaving same at his residence or place of business, or, in case of nonresidents of said town, by sending said notice through the United States mails to his last known place of address. Amendment of Sec. 15 of Act of 1891.Review of tax returns; changes in valuation.Equalization of valuations.Notice of change.

If any taxpayer is dissatisfied with the action of said mayor and council, he may, within ten days from the giving of said notice, give notice to said mayor and council that he demands an arbitration, giving at the same time the name of his arbitrator; the mayor and council shall name its arbitrator within three days thereafter, and if the two cannot agree, then the two arbitrators shall choose a third, and their award shall be final. The said arbitrators shall be residents of said town and shall render their decision within ten days from the date of the naming of the arbitrator
by said mayor and council, else the decision of said mayor and council shall stand affirmed and shall be binding in the premises. That the word if in line one of said section 15 and the word final in line ten of said section, and all other inclusive words (which includes the last six words in line one and all the words in lines two to ten, inclusive of said section), be stricken from said section; that when so amended said section 15 shall read as follows: Be it further enacted, that said mayor or the receiver, as the case may be, shall within ten days from the date of the closing of the tax returns for the current year inspect the tax returns, and it shall be the duty of the mayor to call a meeting of the council for the purpose of examining all the returns of both real and personal property of each taxpayer, and if in the opinion of the mayor and council any taxpayer has omitted from his return any of his property that should be returned, or has failed to return any of his property at a just and fair valuation, the said mayor and council shall correct such returns and shall assess and fix the just and fair valuation to be placed on said property. It shall be the duty of said mayor and council to see that all taxable property within said town is assessed and returned at its just and fair valuation and that valuations as between indivudual taxpayers are fairly and justly equalized, so that each taxpayer shall pay, as near as may be, only his proportionate share of taxes. When any such corrections, changes, and equalizations shall have been made by said mayor and council, it shall be the duty of said mayor to immediately give notice to any taxpayer of any changes made in his returns, which notice shall be served by the mayor or the marshal, either personally or by leaving same at his residence or place of business, or, in case of nonresidents of said town, by sending said notice through the United States mails to his last known place of address. Arbitration as to valuation.Section as amended.

If any taxpayer is dissatisfied with the action of said mayor and council, he may within ten days from the giving of said notice give notice to said mayor and council that he demands an arbitration, giving at the same time the
name of his arbitrator; the mayor and council shall name its arbitrator within three days thereafter, and if the two cannot agree, then the two arbitrators shall choose a third, and their award shall be final. The said arbitrators shall be residents of said town, and shall render their decision within ten days from the date of the naming of the arbitrator by said mayor and council; else the decision of said mayor and council shall stand affirmed and shall be binding in the premises; provided further that if any taxpayer in said town shall be dissatisfied with the returns of any other taxpayer as being too low, he shall have the right to complain to the mayor and council, setting forth the grounds of his complaint. The mayor shall then notify the person complained of; the matter of complaint shall then be settled by arbitration as above provided.
Sec. 25. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: WAYCROSS COMMISSION FORM OF GOVERNMENT ABOLISHED. WARDS, OFFICERS, ETC.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act to provide and establish a new charter for the City of Waycross in the County of Ware, approved August 17th, 1909, as amended by the several subsequent acts amendatory thereto, and especially as amended by the act approved August 16th, 1922; to provide for the division of said City of Waycross into wards, and to provide for the representation of said wards on the board of aldermen; to provide for a form of government in said city composed of a mayor and aldermen, in lieu of the present form of government by commissioners and a city manager; to declare the rights and powers of said government; to abolish the offices of commissioner
missioner and city manager as constituted under the present charter; to amend or repeal such sections of the city charter as amended, as may be deemed necessary to carry into effect the said mayor and aldermen form of government; to provide the time and manner of election of said mayor and aldermen and other officers and employees of the City of Waycross; to provide for an annual audit and the publication of the same; to prescribe the qualifications of the mayor and aldermen and other officers and employees of said city; to fix their compensation; to regulate the disposal of public utilities and franchises; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after the approval of this Act,

Section 1. The inhabitants of the City of Waycross, Georgia, as its limits now are or may be hereafter established, shall continue to be a body politic and corporate, to be known and designated as the City of Waycross, and the corporate existence, identity, territorial limits, and jurisdiction of the City of Waycross, both within and beyond the territorial limits of said city, with all the corporate rights, powers and privileges conferred, and all the duties, obligations, and liabilities imposed by law, shall be preserved to the said city, except as altered or amended by this Act, and, as such body politic, shall have perpetual succession, may sue and be sued, contract and be contracted with, have a corporate seal, and make, alter, and amend rules, regulations, by-laws, resolutions, and ordinances for its government and the exercise of its corporate powers, not in conflict with this Act, the constitution and laws of Georgia and the United States of America. General corporate powers.

Sec. 2. Said City of Waycross shall have and exercise all powers which it now possesses and enjoys, and not inconsistent with or in conflict with the powers herein expressed, and also all such general powers as may be possessed and enjoyed by cities, under the constitution and laws of Georgia.

Sec. 3. The said City of Waycross shall be divided into wards, six in number, and numbered and designated as First Ward, Second Ward, Third Ward, Fourth Ward, Fifth Ward, and Sixth Ward, respectively, of said city, according to the boundaries and limits herein provided. The boundaries of the said wards, and the territory embraced and included therein, respectively, shall be the same as existed under the charter of said city prior to the Act amending said charter and abolishing ward lines in said city, which Act was approved August 16, 1922, and are as follows: Ward One (1) shall include all of the territory within the city limits bounded on the southeast by the main line of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company from Waycross to Savannah; on the southwest by Oak Street from the western margin of State Street to the city limits, and by State Street from its intersection with Oak Street to its intersection with the east side of Plant Avenue. Ward Two (2) shall include all of the territory within the city limits bounded on the northeast by Oak Street, from its intersection with State Street to the city limits, and from State Street from its intersection with Oak Street to its intersection with the east side of Plant Avenue; on the southeast by the main line of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company from Waycross to Savannah, and on the south by Isabella Street from its intersection with the east side of Plant Avenue to the city limits. Ward Three (3) shall include all of the territory within the city limits bounded on the north by Isabella Street, and bounded on the southeast by the main line of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company from Savannah to Montgomery, Alabama, from the intersection of said right of way with the Gilmore and Isabella Streets crossing to the city limits; said last-named boundary consisting of one unbroken line, running northeast and southwest. Ward Four (4) shall include all of the territory within the city limits bounded on the northeast by the main line of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company from Savannah to Montgomery, from as far north as what is known as the Gilmore Street crossing on said main line to the city limits on the
south, on the east by Gilmore Street from said Gilmore Street crossing to the city limits on the south. Ward Five (5) shall include all of the territory within the city limits bounded on the east by Gilmore Street from the intersection of Gilmore Street with Reynolds Street south to the city limits, bounded on the north by Reynolds Street from its intersection with Gilmore Street east to the city limits. Ward Six (6) shall include all of the territory within the city limits bounded on the northwest by the main line of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company from Savannah to Montgomery, from the intersection of said main line on the north with the city limits to what is known as the Gilmore Street crossing of said main line, bounded on the west by Gilmore Street from its intersection with Reynolds Street to the Gilmore Street crossing of the Savannah main line of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company, bounded on the south by Reynolds Street from its intersection with Gilmore Street east to the city limits. Six wards.Boundaries of wards.See Act No. 82, post, p.

Sec. 4. The present form of government of the City of Waycross by a commission and city manager is hereby abolished, and such other offices existing under the present commissioner-city manager form of government as may be inconsistent with the provisions of this Act and otherwise provided for herein shall be abolished. Board of Education, the park and tree commission, the sinking-fund commission, and the office of city recorder, shall continue to exist, with the same powers and duties and with the same methods of election as provided by the present charter, except as they may be changed herein. Commission and city manager government abolished.

Sec. 5. The municipal government of the City of Waycross and its corporate powers shall be vested in and exercised by a mayor and board of aldermen, consisting of one alderman from each ward of the city as herein laid out, and also by officers, agents, and employees under their authority, except as otherwise provided herein. Said mayor and aldermen as a body shall be known as the city
council, and they shall be elected and shall hold office as hereinafter provided. Mayor and aldermen to be known as city council.

Sec. 6. The mayor and thre of the aldermen shall be elected at an annual election to be held on the first Saturday in January, 1931, and shall serve for a term of two years from the first Monday in January following the date of their election and until their successors shall have been duly elected and qualified. Three of the aldermen shall be elected at an annual election to be held on the first Saturday in January, 1931, and shall hold office for a term of one year from the first Monday in January following their election, and until their successors shall have been duly elected and qualified; and so on; an annual election being held on the first Saturday in January of each and every year, one year for the election of a mayor and three aldermen, to serve a term of two years, and the next year for the election of three aldermen, to serve a term of two years, as the case may be, to fill the places of those whose terms expire at such times. Election and terms of mayor and aldermen.

In the event the office of mayor or either of said aldermen shall become vacant by death, resignation, removal, or otherwise, more than six months prior to the expiration of the term for which he was elected, the said city council, shall by resolution order an election to fill such vacancy, and shall give at least ten days' notice thereof in one or more of the papers of general circulation published in said city, and the election shall be held in the same manner as other municipal elections; provided, however, that if any of said offices shall become vacant at any time within six months of the expiration of the term of said office, said city council shall have the right and power to fill said office for the remainder of the term by selection made by the city council without submitting same to the voters of the city. However, for the year beginning January 6th, 1930, and ending on the Monday after the first Saturday in January, 1931, Henry J. Carswell is hereby constituted and appointed mayor of the City of Waycross, W. W. Allen is hereby constituted and appointed alderman from
the First Ward, H. S. Redding is hereby constituted and appointed alderman from the Second Ward, S. T. Wright is hereby constituted and appointed alderman from the Third Ward, F. P. Howell is hereby constituted and appointed alderman from the Fourth Ward, A. M. Knight is hereby constituted and appointed alderman from the Fifth Ward, and C. A. LeCount is hereby constituted and appointed alderman from the Sixth Ward. No election shall be held in 1930 except to fill the places of those named above which for any reason may become vacant, and in that event such vacancy shall be filled as herein set out. Vacancy.Mayor and aldermen for 1930 named.

The mayor and council shall determine which three wards shall be represented by aldermen elected in 1931 for a term of one year, and which three wards shall be represented by aldermen elected in 1931 for a term of two years, and thereafter an election shall be held each year as provided hereinbefore and the terms of the mayor and each alderman so elected shall be for two years each.

For the purposes of this Act the following described territory within the City of Waycross is hereby taken from Ward Two in said city and added to Ward Three, so as to provide from the personnel of the present city commission of the City of Waycross, together with those aldermen appointed herein for a term of one year, a mayor, and an alderman from each ward of said city; that territory bounded on the south by Carswell Street, on the east by Nicholls Street, on the north by Roosevelt Street, and on the west by Izlar Street; said described territory to be included within the limits and boundaries of Ward Three within said city until January 1st, 1931, and then to be included within the limits and boundaries of Ward Two of said city as heretofore. Change of territory in Wards 2 and 3.

Also, for the purposes of this Act, the salary of the mayor for the year 1930, as fixed by the council, shall not exceed one thousand dollars, as the said mayor is appointed by the provisions of this Act from the personnel of the present city commission and not elected by the people. After the
year 1930 the salary of the mayor shall be fixed as provided in section eleven of this Act. Salary of mayor.

Sec. 7. The mayor of said city shall, at the time of his election, have been a resident of the City of Waycross for at least two years next preceding his election, shall be a qualified voter of said city, and shall be at least twenty-five years of age. Each alderman at the time of his election shall be a qualified voter of the City of Waycross, shall be at least twenty-five years of age, and shall have been a resident of the City of Waycross for at least two years next preceding his election, and must have been a resident of the ward from which he is so elected for at least twelve months next preceding his election. The mayor and each of the aldermen shall be elected by the entire vote of the city. No candidate shall expend or promise any money, employment, or other thing of value in order to secure a nomination or election to any of said offices. No candidate shall be guilty of any fraud, or a breach of the election laws of the State of Georgia and the City of Waycross, as they are at present or may hereafter be constituted. Qualifications of mayor and aldermen.Prohibited promises and expenditures of candidates.

Sec. 8. The mayor and aldermen or city council shall have full power and authority, except as herein otherwise provided, to exercise all of the powers conferred upon the city, and shall have and possess and shall exercise, subject to the terms and provisions of this Act, all the authority and powers, executive, administrative, legislative, and judicial, now had, possessed, and exercised by the commission and city manager under the existing charter, and may, subject to the provisions of this Act, by ordinances or resolutions, prescribe the manner in which any power of the city shall be exercised. Powers of mayor and aldermen.

Sec. 9. Before entering upon their duties of their respective offices, the mayor and aldermen shall take and subscribe the oath provided for in section eleven of the new charter of the City of Waycross, approved August 17, 1909. Oath.

Sec. 10. Neither the mayor nor any member of the board of aldermen shall be eligible for re-election to the same office after the expiration of two successive terms, unless one term shall have elapsed since the last term of such officer. Re-election.

Sec. 11. At their first regular meeting in January of each year, the city council shall fix the salaries to be paid the mayor and aldermen and all other officers and employees of said city, not otherwise expressly provided for, and the same shall not be changed during the year for which they are fixed. Provided, however, that the salary of the mayor shall not exceed three thousand dollars per year, and the salary of each alderman shall be three hundred dollars per year. All salaries, unless otherwise provided for herein, shall be paid monthly out of the general funds in the treasury of said City of Waycross. The salary of the mayor shall not be less than eighteen hundred dollars per year. Salaries.

Sec. 12. A majority of the aldermen shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, but in all cases a less number may adjourn from time to time, and may compel the attendance of the absentees. Any alderman shall have the right to call for the yeas and nays and have the same recorded on the minutes in all cases. The mayor shall have a vote, but no veto power. Quorum.

Sec. 13. The mayor of the city shall keep regular office hours at the city-hall morning and afternoon, for transaction of the city's business, and he shall give at least four hours of his time per day to the city's affairs. He shall be the presiding officer of the city council. He shall act as ex-officio member of the board of education and attend all meetings of said board. The mayor shall be recognized as the official head of the city by the courts for the purpose of serving civil process, and by the Governor for the purpose of military law. He shall also be the chief executive officer of the city government and shall see that all the laws, ordinances, orders, by-laws, resolutions, and regulations of the city council or of any department of the city
are properly executed and in force. He shall see that all officers of the city shall properly perform their duties, and shall recommend to the city council the removal of the heads of the departments or any other employee of the city, but shall be required to state in writing to the council the reason and causes for such recommendation. The mayor shall in all things exercise a general supervision over the affairs of the city and to recommend the adoption of such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient. He shall keep advised in reference to each of the departments of the city and the manner in which they are being operated, and shall see that each department is being honestly and efficiently conducted and without regard to politics or favoritism to any person or interest. The mayor shall make and execute all lawful contracts on behalf of the city with the approval of the council, except such as may otherwise be provided by law or ordinance. He shall act as purchasing agent, upon requisitions signed by the heads of the departments, but no contract, purchase, or obligation involving more than one hundred ($100.00) dollars shall be binding until and after approval by the council. He shall act as budget commissioner, and in conjunction with the city clerk shall prepare and submit to the council, prior to the beginning of the fiscal year, a budget of proposed expenditures for the ensuing year, showing in detail the amounts alloted to each department of the city government, the reason for such estimated expenditures, and also the estimated revenues for said year. He shall keep the council at all times [Illegible Text] advised as to the financial condition and the needs of the city, and shall make a full written report to the council on the first meeting in each month, showing the operations and expenditures of each department of the city government for the preceding month. In case of the absence, disqualification, or disability of the mayor, the mayor pro tem. shall discharge his functions, and if he, for the same reasons, cannot act, then another alderman shall be selected by the council to act temporarily, and such officer shall draw the mayor's salary during the time he discharges the duties of said office. Mayor's duties.Purchases and contracts.Budget.Financial reports.Mayor pro tem.

Sec. 14. The mayor and aldermen shall hold regular meetings of the city council at least twice a month, the time of meeting to be fixed by ordinance, for the consideration and transaction of such governmental, legislative, administrative, or corporate or municipal business or matters as may come before them; and they may also hold such special meetings from time to time as they may deem proper, such special meetings to be called by the mayor or mayor pro tem. or by the city clerk, upon the written request of any two (2) members of the board of aldermen. Notice of such special meetings shall be given each of the said officers who are in the city at the time, at least twelve hours before such meetings. And at such called or special meetings the council shall have the right and power to transact any business which they are legally authorized to transact at any regular meeting. All meetings of the council shall be public, and any citizen may have access to the minutes and records thereof at all reasonable times. The council may determine its own rules of procedure and shall keep a journal of general proceedings. All appointments, elections, and votes by the council shall be viva voce, and upon request of any alderman the votes of all aldermen shall be recorded upon the journal. Neither the mayor nor any alderman shall during his term of office be elected to any other position or office of trust or profit under the city government, except as changed or modified by the terms of this Act. All rules of procedure now in force with reference to the handling of business and the passage or ordinances by the commission under the present charter shall continue in force until changed or modified by the council. Meetings.

Sec. 15. At the first regular meeting in January of each year the mayor and aldermen or city council shall elect a mayor pro tem., clerk of council, city treasurer, city tax-collector, city attorney, chief of police, chief of the fire department, city health officer, city physician, superintendent of public works, superintendent of the waterworks, superintendent of sanitary department, and such other officers and employees, agents, and servants of the
City of Waycross as the city council shall consider expedient or who may be necessary for the proper handling and dispatch of the city's business. These officers and employees shall hold office for a term of one year and until their successors are elected and qualified. Any two or more of these offices, with the exception of the office of mayor pro tem. and city attorney, may be combined and held by one person. Their duties shall be prescribed by ordinances. On entering upon the discharge of their duties they shall each take an oath to faithfully and honestly perform the duties of their respective offices, and they shall each enter into bond, with good and sufficient security, which may be prescribed by the city council, for the faithful performance of their duties. The mayor and aldermen or city council may also from time to time, when in their judgment the necessity for same arises, appoint other officers and employees of said city, who shall be elected and hold office under the same terms and conditions herein set out. The mayor shall annually appoint standing committees of the city council, whose duties shall be fixed by ordinance. All officers, employees, and agents of the City of Waycross appointed or elected by the city council shall at all times be subject to the jurisdiction of the same and amenable to their discipline, and the city council shall have the power at any time to suspend, fine, or remove from office any of said persons from the office or positions held by them respectively, by a majority vote, unless otherwise expressly provided for. Such action shall in all instances follow the filing of written charges against the person complained of, and after a fair and impartial public hearing, at which both sides shall have an opportunity to be heard. Election of officers by city council.Duties of officers.Committees.

Sec. 16. The city clerk shall be at the head of the department of finance, as set out in paragraph (f) of section twenty of the Act amending the city charter of Waycross, approved August 16, 1922, and his duties shall be the same as prescribed therein. Clerk to be head of department of finance.

Sec. 17. The city council may be ordinance add any additional functions and duties to any of the above department
ments, and may create new and additional departments, and may combine any two of the departments above named and the duties and functions thereof, and shall make such rules and regulations in regard to such departments as shall be deemed wise and expedient, except as otherwise provided. Additional functions and duties of departments.

Sec. 18. The mayor shall be the purchasing agent of the city as hereinbefore set out, but he shall have the approval of the city council on the expenditure of all sums to the amount of one hundred dollars or more, and the mayor shall submit to the city council at the first regular meeting in each month an itemized list and statement of all contracts or purchases involving less than one hundred dollars, and shall transmit all vouchers, which shall be approved by him, to the council for their approval. In the capacity of purchasing agent the mayor shall conduct all sales of city property which the council may authorize by resolution to be sold. All purchases and sales shall conform to such additional regulations as the council may from time to time prescribe. No contract involving an expenditure of more than five hundred dollars shall be let save by competitive bid, after ten days advertisement in some newspaper of general circulation in said city, and as said council may further prescribe. No member of the city council or any other officer or employee of the city shall be directly or indirectly interested in any contract, job, work, or service with or for said city, nor in the profits or emoluments thereof, nor in the expenditure of any money on the part of the city, other than the fixed compensation of such officer or employee, and any contract with the city in which any such officer or employee is or becomes interested may be declared void by the council. Limitations as to expenditures.Purchases and sales.Prohibited interest of officers in contracts, etc.

Sec. 19. No person in the employ of the city shall take any part in any political campaign for officers of said city, nor work, contribute, or use any effort toward securing the nomination or election of any candidate for office in said city. Upon proof of the violation of these provisions such employee shall be removed from office by the council. Employees not to take part in political campaigns for city officers; penalty.

Sec. 20. All officers and employees of the City of Way-cross elected or appointed under the provisions of this Act shall be bona fide residents of said city, and shall have been residents of said city for at least twelve months next preceding their election or appointment. Eligibility of officers, etc.

Sec. 21. All administrative and judicial officers and departments of the city in existence upon the passage of this Act, unless otherwise provided herein, shall continue until otherwise provided by the city council. All laws and ordinances of the City of Waycross, and all rules and regulations regarding the administration of the affairs of the city, now in force and not inconsistent with the terms and provisions of this Act, shall be and remain of force and effect until changed by the city council. All vested rights of the city shall continue to be vested, and shall not in any manner be affected by the adoption of this Act. All contracts entered into by the city or for its benefit prior to the passage of this Act shall continue in full force and effect. Officers continued in office.Laws and contracts continued of force.

Sec. 22. No public utility owned by the city shall be sold, leased, or otherwise disposed of, unless authorized by a vote of two thirds of the registered voters of said city, voting at an election to be called for that purpose. Sale of public utilities.

Sec. 23. The books and records of the city and all of its departments shall be audited by a competent auditor or accountant at least once each twelve months, and the results of such audit shall be published in the official organ of said city. The council may in its discretion provide for such additional audits as they may see fit. The full report of all audits shall be placed on file in the office of city clerk, and open to public inspection at all times after completion. Auditing.

Sec. 24. Recall of the mayor or aldermen is hereby abolished, but the provisions for impeachment of such officers, contained in the new charter of the City of Way-cross, adopted August 17, 1909, shall remain in force. All provisions of the charter of the City of Waycross not repealed or changed by the provisions of this Act shall remain
in full force and effect, unless otherwise expressly provided for by special Act of the General Assembly passed at the 1929 session of said General Assembly. Provisions as to recall of mayor or aldermen repealed.Impeachment.

Sec. 25. The present commission of the City of Waycross is required to call an election for the election of the mayor and aldermen as provided for in this Act, and to declare the results of said election. Election of mayor, etc.

Sec. 26. If any section or part of a section of this Act shall for any reason be adjudged by any court of competent jurisdiction to be invalied or unconstitutional, the same shall not be held to invalidate or impair the validity of any other section or part of a section of this Act, but shall be confined in its operations to the section or part of a section directly involved in such suit or controversy in which judgment shall have been rendered. Invalidity of part of Act, not invalidate other part.
Sec. 27. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this Act be and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to provide a new charter for the City of Waycross, approved August 17, 1909, as subsequently amended; to reduce the city limits of said City of Waycross; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act, to take effect January first, nineteen hundred and thirty, the corporate limits of said City of Waycross shall be and the same are hereby reduced as follows:

Sec. 2. By removal from the said corporate limits of said city, and beyond said corporate limits as they shall be constituted after the passage of this Act, the following described tract of land, now within the corporate limits of said city. Commencing at a point where the line of the present city limits and Hampton Avenue in Deenwood, a subdivision of the said City of Waycross, intersect, and running thence easterly, or south of easterly, to the west side of the right of way of the Waycross and Southern Railroad Company; thence in a southerly direction along the right of way of said Waycross and Southern Railroad Company to the point where the said right of way of the Waycross and Southern Railway Company intersects with George Street, in Deenwood; thence along the east side of George Street in a northerly direction to Hampton Avenue, the point or place of beginning; all as shown by map or plat showing by blocks that part of the City of Waycross from the Waycross and Southern Railroad west to the city limits, as made June 6, 1929, by N. M. Pafford, county surveyor, and a copy of said plat being attached to this bill. Corporate limits.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after twelve o'clock midnight, December 31, 1929, the jurisdiction, authority, ordinances, rules, and regulations of the said City of Waycross shall not extend or apply to the said territory described in section two above.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: WAYCROSS RECORDER AND CITY ATTORNEY; SALARIES.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to provide and establish a new charter for the City of Waycross, approved August 17, 1909, and subsequently amended by various acts, especially the Acts approved August 16, 1913, and August 16, 1922, and by other amendatory acts; to provide that the offices of city recorder of the City of Waycross and city attorney of the City of Waycross shall be separate offices; to fix the compensation of the city recorder and the city attorney of said city; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that the Act to provide and establish a new charter for the City of Waycross, approved August 17, 1909, and the several acts amendatory thereto, including the Act approved August 16, 1913, creating the office of recorder, and the Act approved August 16, 1922, providing that the duties of city attorney may be conferred on the recorder, be and the same are hereby amended as follows:

Section 1. Be it enacted, that from and after the first day of January, 1930, the offices of city attorney and city recorder in the City of Waycross shall be separate and distinct offices, and the city recorder of the said city shall not be competent or eligible to hold the office of city attorney of said city during the term for which he was elected. Offices of recorder and city attorney separated.

Sec. 2. Be it enacted, that from and after the first day of January, 1930, the city recorder of the City of Waycross shall be paid a salary of one hundred and twenty-five dollars per month, from the general funds of said city. Salary of recorder.

Sec. 3. Be it enacted that from and after the first day of January, 1930, the city attorney of the City of Waycross shall be paid a salary of not less than one hundred ($100.00) dollars per month by the City of Waycross from
the general funds of said city, in the same manner that other salaries of city officers are paid. Salary of city attorney.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to provide and establish a new charter for the City of Waycross, in the County of Ware, approved August 17, 1909, as subsequently amended by the various acts amendatory thereto; to provide for the appointment of a board of tax-assessors for said city; to prescribe their qualifications; to define their duties and powers; to fix their compensation; to provide a system for returning property for taxation to the said city; to create the office of city marshal, provide for his election and compensation, and define his duties; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that;

Sec. 2. The new charter of the City of Waycross granted by an Act of the General Assembly approved August 17th, 1909, as amended by the Act approved August 16, 1922, and other amendatory Acts, be and the same is amended as follows: Acts amended.

Sec. 3. A board of tax-assessors is hereby created in and for said city, to consist of three members, a chairman and two other members, who shall be elected by the commission, city council, or other governing body of said city. The members of said board shall serve for a term of four years and until their successors are elected and qualified. Tax assessors.

Sec. 4. The members of said board of tax-assessors shall be residents of the City of Waycross, and shall have resided in said city at least two years before their election. They shall be at least thirty years of age at the time of their election, and shall be taxpayers and freeholders of the City of Waycross. The members of said board shall be elected by the commission or city council at their first regular meeting in January, 1930, and each four years thereafter, unless otherwise provided for in this Act. Any vacancy on said board shall be filled by the commission or city council at their first regular meeting after such vacancy occurs. Qualifications of tax-assessors.

Sec. 5. The said assessors shall respectively, before entering upon the discharge of their duties, take and subscribe before the clerk of the council of the City of Waycross, or the city clerk, the following oath, to wit: I,....., do solemnly swear that I will perform the duties incident to my membership of the board of tax-assessors of the City of Waycross, impartially and without favor to any person or persons, and that I will make a just and true return of all my actings and doings as a member of said board, to the best of my knowledge and belief; so help me God. Oath.

Sec. 6. Returns of all taxable property, within the city, both real and personal, and subject to taxation by said city, shall be made to the board of tax-assessors upon oath, upon the basis of its market value on the first day of February of each year. The board of tax-assessors or some member of said board shall convene and stay in session daily, at their office in the city-hall, from nine o'clock a. m. to five o'clock p. m. on week days, from the first day of February until the first day of April in each year, for the purpose of receiving returns of taxpayers, and all returns of taxable property shall be made to the chairman or some other member of said board. The time for receiving and requiring returns of all property, both real and personal, within the corporate limits of said city shall be from February
first to March fifteenth in each year, and all property not returned within that time shall be double taxed. Tax returns.

Said board of tax-assessors shall require all taxpayers or agents of owners, in making their returns, to designate the location of all real property by lot and block numbers, as well as by street and other boundaries and to distinguish between the value of lands and the value of buildings and other improvements thereon. Said board shall require all taxpayers returning unimproved as well as improved property, or either, to designate the acreage, and metes and bounds thereof in lineal feet, and they shall require all returns to designate separately each particular lot, piece, or parcel of land returned for assessment and taxation.

It shall be the duty of said board to see that all property, both real and personal, within the city limits of said city is returned and assessed for taxation, and said board is hereby empowered and required to return and assess all property not returned by the owner, or the agent or owner, as owner unknown, accompanying such return with a complete description of the property.

Sec. 7. It shall be the duty of the board of tax-assessors to scrutinize carefully each return of property, both real and personal, and to view the real or other property so returned, and determine and assess the value of all property within said corporate limits. If the said board shall find the property embraced in the return, or any portion of it, returned below its actual cash market value, said board shall assess the value thereof within thirty days from the reception of said return, and when the board of tax-assessors shall raise the valuation at which the taxpayer has returned his property, the said board shall give the taxpayer written notice of their assessment, giving him fifteen days in which to appear before said board and protest against the correctness and accuracy of their assessment. When there is a difference of opinion among the members of said board as to the valuation of property or the correctness or accuracy of any return, the valuation
determined on by a majority of said board shall be entered and signed by the members agreeing to such valuation, and reported as the assessment of said board. If any taxpayer, after appearing before said board, is still dissatisfied with their valuation and assessment, he may, within ten days from the date of said hearing, appeal their decision to the commission or city council or other governing body of said City of Waycross. Review of tax-returns.

Sec. 8. All persons commencing business in the said city after the time prescribed for making tax-returns shall return their stock in trade to the board of tax-assessors on call, and shall pay taxes thereon proportionate to the unexpired part of the calendar year, and likewise all buildings and other improvements completed after the time for making tax-returns shall be assessed and the taxes collected proportionate to the unexpired part of the calendar year; but nothing herein shall be construed so as to double tax any person or class of property, save as provided in section six above. Such taxes shall be collected in the same manner as other taxes by the City of Waycross. Returns after time prescribed for making them.Double taxation.

Sec. 9. The board of tax-assessors shall have authority to issue subpoenas for the attendance of witnesses, and to require the production by any person of all of his books, papers, and documents which in their judgment may throw any light upon the question of the existence or liability of property of any class for taxation. Said subpoenas shall be served by the city marshal or any police officer of said city. If any witness so subpoenaed shall fail or refuse to answer any question propounded to him, or shall fail or refuse to produce any books, papers, or documents required of him, such person shall be cited, by said board to appear before the recorder of the City of Waycross, who shall hear, in a summary way, the reasons or excuses of such person for such failure or refusal, and the recorder of the City of Waycross shall have authority to impose such punishment as for a contempt, as he may see proper, not to exceed a fine of one hundred dollars or imprisonment
in the city jail not to exceed thirty days, either or both in the discretion of the recorder. Authority of tax-assessors.

Sec. 10. The chairman of said board of tax-assessors shall be present at the office of said board in the city-hall during the time in which returns of taxable property are required and received, and the other members of said board shall also be present during that time, for the purpose of assisting in receiving such returns and eliciting the required information in regard to same. It shall be the purpose and endeavor of the board in receiving tax-returns to arrive at some satisfactory valuation or assessment, with the taxpayer, at the time of receiving such returns, but if this is not done, then they shall proceed as set out in section seven of this Act. After the time for receiving tax-returns in each year has expired, and after the board has assessed all property within the city, both returned and unreturned, for taxation, the chairman of said board shall maintain regular office-hours in the office of the board of tax-assessors in the city-hall, for the purpose of going over the tax information accumulated by said board, and going over and revising such tax systems or information pertaining to the assessment of taxes as may be in the possession of the City of Waycross. He shall endeavor to familiarize himself with the taxable values and property within the said city, and impart such information to the other members of the board, so that said board may at all times work for the best interests of said City of Waycross and its taxpayers and toward the equalization of its tax assessments. The other members of the board shall be called together from time to time by the chairman, to pass on such matters as he may wish to bring to their attention, and a meeting of the said board may be called at any time by any member thereof by giving notice in writing to the other members of said board twenty-four hours before such called meeting. The system of assessing or listing property for taxation, installed by the City of Waycross during 1928, shall be turned over to the said board, and said system shall be kept up by the said board
and used as an aid in assessing the property taxable in and by said city, and the valuations placed on property in and by said system shall be revised and equalized by the said board of tax-assessors as nearly and as rapidly as possible, and when this work is completed by said board, the listings and information shall be kept up to date, showing the changes in values, improvements, and ownership of the various classes of property in said city, and said valuations and assessments shall be preserved for the information and benefit of the successors in office of said board of tax-assessors. Duties of tax-assessors.

Sec. 11. The commission, city council, or other governing body of said city, shall provide the said board of tax-assessors with an office in the city-hall, on the main floor thereof, and said office shall be large enough to accommodate the said board and its helpers, and convenient of access and commodious for the public having business with said board. The supplies, stationery, etc., required by said board shall be furnished and paid for by the city in the same manner in which supplies for other departments of the city are provided, upon requisition signed by a majority of said board. Office of tax-assessors; supplies, etc.

Sec. 12. If any taxpayer of the City of Waycross, after his property has been assessed by the board of tax-assessors for taxation by said city, being dissatisfied with such assessment, appeals the decision of the board of tax-assessors to the city council or commission as provided for hereinbefore, and is still dissatisfied with the decision of the commission or city council on said appeal, then said taxpayer may demand that the question be submitted to arbitration. Whereupon it shall be the duty of the commission or city council, within ten days, to name one taxpayer of the City of Waycross, who is disinterested in the results of said question to be arbitrated, to represent the city; the tax-payer objecting to said decision shall name one taxpayer of the City of Waycross, who shall also be disinterested, to represent said taxpayer; the question of the valuation or assessment shall then be submitted to said arbitrators,
and their decision shall be entered upon the tax-books of said city as the assessment on the property in dispute for the current year. If the two arbitrators named as above are unable to agree, then the two arbitrators shall agree upon a third taxpayer of said city as a third member of said board of arbitration, and the decision of two of said three arbitrators shall be controlling. Appeal from assessment.Arbitration.

Sec. 13. The compensation of the members of the board of tax-assessors shall be fixed by the commission or city council at its first regular meeting in January of each year, and shall not be changed during the year for which it is so fixed. The compensation of the chairman of said board shall not be less than twelve hundred dollars per year, and the compensation of the other members of said board shall not be less than four hundred dollars per year each. Said salaries to be paid monthly out of the general funds in the treasury of said city, as salaries of other officers are paid. Pay of assessors.

Sec. 14. At their first regular meeting in January, 1930, and biennially thereafter, the commission, city council, or other governing body of said city shall elect a city marshal, who shall serve for a term of two years and until his successor is elected and qualified. However, for the term beginning January, 1930, and ending January, 1932, Thomas H. Miller is hereby appointed and constituted city marshal of said city, and the first election to fill the office of city marshal shall be held after the expiration of his term. The compensation of the city marshal shall be fixed by the commission or city council at the first regular meeting in January in each year, beginning in January, 1930, and shall not be less than eighteen hundred dollars per year, to be paid monthly out of the general funds in the treasury of said city, as other salaries are paid. The office of city marshal shall not be abolished by the city councilor or commission, and shall not be combined with any other office. The duties of city marshal shall be as set out in the new charter of the City of Waycross, approved August 17, 1909, except as otherwise provided for herein.
He shall be required to give bond in the sum of $10,000.00, in the same manner as the city clerk. He shall be charged with the duty of collecting all delinquent taxes due to the city that may be turned over to him by the city clerk and tax-collector, and shall account to the city clerk and tax-collector promptly for all monies collected by him. He shall be the special officer of the board of tax-assessors, and shall work in conjunction with said board in searching out and seeing that all property, both real and personal, subject to taxation by the city, is properly returned or assessed for taxation, in accordance with the rules, laws, and ordinances of said city. He shall also see that all persons, firms, or corporations subject to specific, occupation or license taxes shall pay the same promptly when due, and upon failure of any person so to do, the city marshal is empowered to summons them to appear before the recorder's court of said city, there to be dealt with as provided by law. The provisions of the city charter now in effect as to the collection of taxes, tax sales, transfer of executions, redemptions, and illegalities shall remain as they are now, unless otherwise provided for herein. Marshal.Pay of marshal.Collection of taxes.

Sec. 15. No member of the board of tax-assessors shall be removed from office by the commission or city council except for gross misfeasance or malfeasance in office. Such charges shall be preferred in writing by the taxpayer making same, upon oath, and in such case the commission or city council shall hear such charges at a public meeting, and shall hear testimony under oath, both in support and defense of such charges, and, if fully proven, the commission or city council shall remove from office the member of the said board against whom the charges are preferred, only upon a unanimous vote of all the members of the commission or city council. Removal of tax-assessors from office.

Sec. 16. The chairman and two other members of the board of tax-assessors shall be elected every four years by the commission, city council or governing body of said City of Waycross, as set out in section four of this Act, and any vacancies in said board shall be filled by election
in the same manner as soon as practicable after said vacancy occurs, but for the term beginning January, 1930, and ending January, 1934, W. W. Sharpe, Senior, is hereby constituted and appointed chairman of the board of tax-assessors of the City of Waycross, and Cary M. Sweat and Allen S. Morton are hereby constituted and appointed members of said board of tax-assessors of the City of Waycross, to serve for four years and until their successors are elected and qualified, so that there shall be no election of said board in January, 1930, unless one or more of the members herein appointed shall fail to qualify, when their places may be filled by the commission or city council. Election of tax-assessors.Assessors named.

Sec. 17. If any section or part of a section of this Act shall for any reason be adjudged by any court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or unconstitutional, the same shall not be held to invalidate or impair the validity of any other section or part of a section of this Act, but shall be confined in its operations to the section or part of a section directly involved in the controversy in which judgment shall have been rendered. Invalidity of part of Act not invalidate other part.
Sec. 18. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: WAYCROSS; WARDS; PERMANENT REGISTRATION OF VOTERS; ELECTIONS.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend the charter of the City of Waycross, approved August 17, 1909, as amended by the several subsequent acts, and especially the Act approved August 16, 1922; to divide the said City of Waycross into wards; to provide a permanent registration list for said city, and to provide and regulate the registration of voters in
said city; to prescribe and regulate the places and manner in which elections shall be held in said city; to provide a board of registrars, to define their duties and powers; to fix their compensation; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that on and after the passage and approval of this Act the existing charter of the City of Waycross be and the same is hereby amended, so that:

Sec. 2. The said City of Waycross shall be divided into six wards, said wards to be numbered one, two, three, four, five, and six respectively, the limits and boundaries of which shall be respectively as follows: Ward one (1) shall include all of the territory within the city limits bounded on the southeast by the main line of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company from Waycross to Savannah; on the southwest by Oak Street from the western margin of State Street to the city limits, and by State Street from its intersection with Oak Street to its intersection with the east side of Plant Avenue. Ward two (2) shall include all of the territory within the city limits bounded on the northeast by Oak Street, from its intersection with State Street to the city limits, and State Street from its intersection with Oak Street to its intersection with the east side of Plant Avenue; on the southeast by the main line of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company from Waycross to Savannah, and on the south by Isabella Street from its intersection with the east side of Plant Avenue to the city limits.
