And whereas the Georgia corporation known as Tate Mountain Estates, composed of representative citizens, is the owner of a large tract of mountain land in Pickens County at the Southern end of the Blue Ridge, and desires to honor the memory of General Oglethorpe by naming for him the highest mountain in the tract, heretofore known as Grassy Knob, or Grassy Mountain, overlooking the Piedmont
Plateau, 52 miles from Atlanta and visible from the top of the State Capitol;

And whereas the Honorable Sam Tate, president of that company, proposes to erect at his own expense, on the top of that mountain a shaft of native marble in memory of the founder of Georgia, and desires the sanction of the State and Federal Governments in changing the name of this great landmark to Mount Oglethorpe, as an eternal monument to the founder of Georgia;
And whereas the General Assembly deems this action appropriate and considers Mount Oglethorpe a fitting momument to the founder of our State; therefore be it

Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, that we sanction and confirm the naming of Mount Oglethorpe and commend the gentlemen composing Tate Mountain Estates for their wise and patriotic course in this matter, and request the Federal Government to confirm this action and change its record of the name of this great landmark to Mount Oglethorpe. Naming of Mount Oglethorpe.

Resolved further, that a committee of ten from the Senate and fifteen from the House, including their presiding officers, be appointed to represent the State of Georgia at the unveiling of the monument and the christening of Mount Oglethorpe, at a date to be fixed in the early fall; and we respectfully request his Excellency the Governor of Georgia to accompany said committee, and take suitable part in the exercises. Committee to represent State at unveiling of monument.

And whereas the owners of the tract wish to present to the National Government a site on the mountain top of suitable size for a beacon for airships and for an observatory or station for other departments of the government service, we commend that offer, recommend its acceptance by Congress, and request that a committee of its members be appointed to attend the unveiling of the monument and the christening of Mount Oglethorpe. Site for beacon for airships.
Be it resolved by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring:
That whereas the U. S. S. Olympia was the flagship of Admiral Dewey, at the historic battle of Manila Bay; and Preamble.
Whereas the Naval Board of Survey, has recommended that the Olympia be scrapped by the Navy Department, because it is now obsolete;

And whereas a prominent citizen of Savannah, Georgia, sent a telegram to the Honorable Chas. F. Adams, Secretary of the U. S. Navy, protesting against such action, and whereas the Honorable Chas. F. Adams, Secretary of Navy replied by telegram as follows: Disposal of Olympia has not yet been approved. Consideration is being given to preservation of Vessel as Naval Relic:

That since the Constitution or Old Ironsides is preserved at Boston Harbor and the Oregon preserved at Portland, Oregon; and whereas the people of Georgia are concious of a patriotic desire to preserve the U. S. S. Olympia as an historical and naval relic;
And whereas the harbor of the City of Savannah is of fresh water and could preserve the steel hull of the Olympia almost perpetually,

Therefore be it resolved by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, that a message be directed to the Secretary of the Navy, the Honorable Chas. F. Adams, protesting against the destruction of the historic and heroic Olympia, and requesting that should the vessel be preserved that the privilege be accorded to the State of Georgia, and that said vessel be preserved in the harbor of the City of Savannah, a Georgia port. Protest against destruction of Flagship Olympia, etc.

law.shorttitle: PEARSON, C. P.; SIMERLY, A. T.; IVEY, W. E.; DEARISO, R. L., RELIEVED AS SURETIES.
law.p: Whereas C. P. Pearson, A. T. Simerly, W. E. Ivey, and R. L. Deariso, all of Worth County, Georgia, did execute a certain bond for the appearance of Ellis West to the City Court of Sylvester, Georgia, in a case pending therein against said Ellis West; and Preamble.
Whereas, on March 2nd, 1927, said bond was forfeited; and

Whereas subsequently thereto, the said principal on said bond appeared, pleaded guilty, and was sentenced to pay a fine of one hundred ($100.00) dollars, or in default thereof to work in chain-gang of said county for twelve (12) months; and
Whereas said Ellis West paid said one hundred ($100.00) dollars, and was released and discharged under the terms of said sentence:

Be it resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, that the county authorities of Worth County, Georgia, be and they are hereby authorized to relieve said C. P. Pearson, A. T. Simerly, W. E. Ivey, and R. L. Deariso from any and all liability upon said bond forfeiture, and they are hereby authorized to cancel the execution which issued upon the same. Relief of C. P. Pearson, A. T. Simerly, W. E. Ivey, R. L. Deariso, as sureties.
Resolved by the Senate, the House of Representatives concurring, that Preamble.

Whereas October 11th, 1779, marks in American history the date of the heroic death of Brigadier-General Casimir Pulaski,
who on October 9th 1779, while fighting for the glorious cause of American liberty at the siege of Savannah, received wounds from which he died;

Whereas, on October the 11th, 1929, appropriate exercises will be held at Savannah, Georgia, in commemoration of the services which this great patriot and lover of liberty rendered to the American people in their struggle for freedom; and
Whereas the said October 11th, 1929, is the one hundred and fiftieth (150th) anniversary of the death of this brave soldier; and

Whereas many of the States of the United States of America have already by legislative enactment designated the said October 11th, 1929, as General Pulaski's Memorial Day, and have made due provision for the observance of said anniversary; and

Whereas above all States it is particularly fitting and appropriate that the State of Georgia should officially take cognizance of this anniversary and provide for a suitable commemoration of the same by appropriate patriotic exercises throughout the State, and otherwise officially participate therein;

Now, therefore, be it resolved by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, that there is hereby created the Georgia Pulaski Sesqui-centennial Commission, which shall consist of not less than fifteen (15) members, all to be appointed by his Excellency the Governor of this State, who shall be chairman of said commission. Georgia Pulaski Sesqui-centennial Commission created.

Be it further resolved, that it shall be the duty of said commission to call attention of the people of Georgia to this great event in the history of our State and Nation, and to invite our people to observe the said date of October 11th, 1929, as the 150th anniversary of the death of General Casimer Pulaski, Revolutionary War hero, by holding suitable exercises and ceremonies in the schools, churches, or other public places in the State of Georgia as may be deemed appropriate
in commemorating the death of this magnificent soldier. Duties and powers of commission.

Be it further resolved, that the said Georgia Pulaski Sesquicentennial Commission be and the same is hereby authorized and empowered to co-operate and participate in any special celebration undertaken in the State of Georgia from October 9th to October 11th, 1929, and to do such further and other acts in the premises as will bring about due recognition by the people of Georgia of the services which General Pulaski rendered to the cause of American Liberty.

Be it further resolved, that the Governor of this State shall officially proclaim October 11th, 1929, as Pulaski Day, and shall order the flag of this State to be displayed in an appropriate manner on all the public buildings in Georgia. Proclamation of October 11, 1929, as Pulaski Day.

Whereas Joseph D. Rhodes and Mrs. Louana Rhodes Bricker, as sole legatees and sole heirs at law of A. G. Rhodes, deceased, formerly a prominent and patriotic citizen of Fulton County, Georgia, have generously tendered to the State of Georgia a deed conveying fee-simple title to that real estate in the City of Atlanta and Fulton County and known as the Rhodes Home (said property being fully described in deed of conveyance), the consideration of said deed being their love for the State of Georgia and interest in the preservation of its records and historical documents and in the education and welfare of the citizens of Georgia, said property to be held by the State of Georgia forever in fee simple, conditioned only that said property shall be used by said State for historical as distinguished from ordinary business purposes, including the preservation of historical emblems, documents, and records of all kinds
bearing upon the history of our State and nation, and including also the housing of rare volumes, manuscripts, books, documents, trophies, pictures, souvenirs, relics, statuary, and works of art, pertaining to the history and development of the State of Georgia, which may be obtained from loans, gifts, or otherwise; and Preamble.A. G. Rhodes' home given to State by his heirs, to be used for historical purposes.
Whereas it is to the interest of the State of Georgia that said gift be accepted, and it being fitting that due appreciation thereof shall be recorded:
Therefore be it resolved by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia:

First. That the gift of said property be and the same is hereby accepted, and that the deed thereto be received and be recorded in the office of the clerk of the Superior Court of Fulton County. Acceptance of gift.

Second. Be it further resolved, that the General Assembly of the State of Georgia hereby gives expression of its high appreciation of the generosity of the said J. D. Rhodes and Mrs. Louana Rhodes Bricker and of the patriotic and public-spirited motives actuating them in making said gift. Expression of appreciation

Third. That the Department of Archives and History of the State of Georgia, now located in the State Capitol, shall be removed to and be located in the building so conveyed, which shall be the permanent home of said department and set aside to its exclusive use, and said department shall continue therein and shall be otherwise supported and operated in all respects as heretofore conducted and supported in the Capital Building of this State. Department of Archives and History to be removed to the building donated.See Appropriation Act, ante. p. 14.

law.shorttitle: RIDLEY, MRS. W. H., REPAYMENT TO.
law.p: Whereas W. H. Ridley did, on the 10th day of March, 1927, become bail for the appearance of one Gordon Bennett, at the March Term, 1927, of the City Court of Floyd County, Georgia, to abide the final order, judgment, and sentence of the court in said case, wherein said principal has been tried, convicted, and sentenced in said court for the offense of driving an automobile while intoxicated; Preamble.

Whereas said Gordon Bennett was required by said bond to appear in the City Court of Floyd County at the March term, 1927, of said court, said bond being in the sum of three hundred ($300.00) dollars, and when said case was called on April 4th said bond was forfeited by reason of the non-appearance of said Gordon Bennett;

And whereas a rule absolute was entered and an execution issued upon the rule absolute on the forfeiture of said bond for the principal sum of $300.00 and cost; and whereas the said Gordon Bennett was afterwards recaptured by the said W. H. Ridley, who paid the expenses of said recapture and the return of him back from North Carolina, at which place he was recaptured, and whereas the said Gordon Bennett was delivered over to the sheriff of Floyd County, and did serve his sentence in the chain-gang of said county;

And whereas W. H. Ridley did mortgage his home in order to pay said bond and cost, and did pay all cost of arresting and returning said Gordon Bennett to Floyd County, and whereas said W. H. Ridley afterwards ran away with another woman, leaving his wife with a heavy mortgage on their home; and
Whereas Mrs. W. H. Ridley did help to pay for the home, and now has several children to support, and is trying to pay off mortgage on home; therefore

Be it resolved by the House of Representatives, and the Senate concurring, that inasmuch as the purpose for which
said bond was made is fully accomplished, that the county authorities of Floyd County be and they are hereby authorized to pay to the said Mrs. W. H. Ridley the sum of three hundred ($300.00) dollars of the funds arising from fine and forfeitures of the City Court of Floyd County, to reimburse her for the sum so paid on account of said bond. Reimbursement of amount paid on forfeiture of bond.

law.shorttitle: RYALS, A. J., RELIEVED AS SURETY.
law.p: Whereas A. J. Ryals Sr. did, on the 1st day of December, 1925, become bail for the appearance of one C. D. Amerson, returnable to the December term, 1925, of the City Court of Macon, in a case charging him with the offense of violating the prohibition law, which said bond was forfeited in case No. 33005, by reason of the non-appearance of the said C. D. Amerson at the December term 1925 of said court; and Preamble.

Whereas a rule absolute was issued at the March term, 1926, and execution issued upon the rule absolute on the forfeiture of said bond for the principal sum of ($300.00) three hundred dollars and cost; and
Whereas the said C. D. Amerson was afterwards recaptured by the said A. J. Ryals Sr. and who paid the expenses of said recapture and a reward and return of him to Bibb County; and
Whereas the said C. D. Amerson was delivered over to the sheriff of Bibb County and incarcerated in the jail of said county; and
Whereas the said C. D. Amerson appeared in court at the March term, 1927, and on motion of the solicitor of said City Court of Macon said case was nolprossed:

Be it resolved by the House of Representatives, and Senate concurring, that inasmuch as the purpose for which the said
bond was made has been fully accomplished, that the said A. J. Ryals Sr. be released from all liability on said execution issued on said forfeiture; provided, however, the said A. J. Ryals Sr. should have first paid all the cost in forfeiting said bond. A. J. Ryals Sr. relieved as surety.

law.shorttitle: STRICKLAND, M.; DANIEL, A. E., RELIEVED AS SURETIES.
law.p: Whereas one Sam Cameron was bound over for trial to the City Court of LaGrange, with M. Strickland and A. E. Daniel as sureties on his bond for his appearance at said court, charging him with the offence of a misdemeanor; after rule nisi had been issued a rule absolute was taken at the June quarterly term, 1927, of said court, by the reason of the non-appearance of the said Sam Cameron; and whereas an execution issued upon the forfeiture of the said bond, for the sum of $300.00 and costs, and said execution was recorded on the general execution docket of Troup County, Georgia on June 20, 1927, on execution Docket 7, page 220, as No. 1092; and whereas the said sureties have apprehended the said Sam Cameron and have turned him over into the custody of the sheriff of Troup County, Georgia, who now has the said Sam Cameron in the common jail of Troup County, Georgia, awaiting trial; and whereas it would be mainfestly unfair and would work an unnecessary hardship on the said M. Strickland and A. E. Daniel: Preamble.

And now, therefore, be it resolved by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, that the said M. Strickland and A. E. Daniel as sureties on the bond aforesaid be and they are hereby relieved from any and all liability on said bond and the payment of said judgment based on the said bond, and that the clerk of the Superior Court of Troup County, Georgia, is hereby authorized and directed to
mark said execution satisfied and cancel the same of record on the execution dockets of said county, by authority of this resolution, upon the condition that all court costs accrued in the forfeiture proceeding be first paid to said clerk. M. Strickland, A. E. Daniel relieved as sureties.

law.shorttitle: UNFINISHED BUSINESS OF GENERAL ASSEMBLY; PERSONS AUTHORIZED TO REMAIN.
law.p: Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, that the speaker of the House of Representatives and his secretary, and the President of the Senate and his secretary, the Clerk of the House of Representatives, and the Secretary of the Senate be and are hereby authorized to remain at the Capitol nine days after the adjournment of the General Assembly, for the purpose of affixing their official signatures to all bills and resolutions passed previously to said adjournment; and that they be allowed their per diem for said time. Presiding officers, secretary, and clerk to stay 9 days after adjournment of General Assembly.

Resolved, that the chairman, respectively, of the Enrollment and Auditing Committees of the House and Senate, together with the members of the Senate Enrollment Committee and nine members of the House Enrollment Committee, to be designated by the Chairman thereof, and three members of the House Auditing Committee and two members of the Senate Auditing Committee to be designated by the chairman thereof, and the Chairman of the House Engrossing Committee and seven members of the House Committee to be designated by the Chairman thereof, and the Chairman and two members of the Senate Engrossing Committee to be designated by the Chairman thereof, be and they are hereby authorized to remain at the Capitol nine days after the adjournment of the General Assembly, for the purpose of bringing up the unfinished business of the session; and that they be allowed their per diem for said time. Certain committee members to remain.

Resolved further, that the postmistress of the House be and she is hereby authorized to remain at the Capitol nine days after the adjournment of the General Assembly, for the purpose of distributing and forwarding members' mail; and that she be allowed her per diem for said time. Postmistress.

Resolved further, that three porters of the House and two porters of the Senate be and they are hereby authorized to remain at the Capitol nine days after the adjournment of the General Assembly; and that they be allowed their per diem for said time. Porters.

law.shorttitle: WILSON, J. Q., RELIEVED AS SURETY.
law.p: Whereas J. Q. Wilson did become surety on two bonds of one hundred ($100.00) dollars each, for the appearance of Albert Jackson at the November term, 1924, Superior Court of Wilcox County, Georgia, in two cases pending against the said Albert Jackson, charged with the offense of a misdemeanor, which said bonds were forfeited by reason of nonappearance of said Albert Jackson at the April term, 1925, of said court; and Preamble.

Whereas a rule absolute was entered and an execution issued on July 13th, 1925, against the said J. Q. Wilson, surety, and said fi. fas. were recorded on July 16th, 1925, on the general execution docket, Wilcox County, Georgia; and

Whereas, on the 8th day of December 1925, the defendant Albert Jackson entered a plea of guilty in one case, the solicitor-general took an order nolprossing the other case on even date, December 8th; and
Whereas all cost in the said two cases have been paid, and bonds have served their purpose as required by law; therefore

Be it resolved by the Senate, and the House of Representatives concurring, that the said J. Q. Wilson be relieved from all liabilities of said bonds and the judgment of said court in the above-stated cases, and the clerk of the Superior Court of Wilcox County, Georgia, be and he is hereby instructed and directed to cancel said judgment of record. Relief of J. Q. Wilson as surety.

law.shorttitle: WILSON, J. Q., RELIEVED AS SURETY.
law.p: Whereas, J. Q. Wilson did, on the 25th day of March, 1924, become surety on a bond of ($300.00) three hundred dollars for the appearance of Mack English, at the July term, 1924, Superior Court, Wilcox County, Georgia, and charged with a misdemeanor; and Preamble.
Whereas said bond was forfeited on July 25th, 1924, for the reason of non-appearance of said Mack English, at the July term of Superior Court of Wilcox County, Georgia; and

Whereas a rule absolute was entered and an execution issued on July 28th, 1924, against J. Q. Wilson, surety, and said fi. fa. was recorded on the general execution docket of Wilcox County, Georgia, July 30th, 1924; and
Whereas J. Q. Wilson, surety on said bond, did, on the 30th day of December 1926, pay solicitor-general J. B. Wall the sum of three ($300.00) hundred dollars and all cost; and
Whereas said solicitor-general, J. B. Wall, died before said bond was cancelled of record; therefore

Be it resolved by the Senate, the House of Representatives concurring, that the said J. Q. Wilson, surety in the above-stated case, be relieved from all liability of said bond and the judgment of the court in said bond having been paid by said surety, and the clerk of the Superior Court, of
Wilcox County, Georgia, be and he is hereby instructed and directed to cancel said bond of record. Relief of J. Q. Wilson as surety.

law.shorttitle: WILSON, S. D., AND W. W., RELIEVED OF BOND.
law.p: A resolution for the relief of S. D. Wilson, principal, and W. W. Wilson, security, both of Campbell County, Georgia, on a bond forfeited in the Superior Court of Campbell County, Georgia, on August 14th, 1929. Preamble.

Whereas S. D. Wilson was tried and convicted for the offense of making whisky in Campbell County, Georgia, and said S. D. Wilson offered an alibi as his defense to said charge, but after conviction was sentenced to a term of six (6) months on the chain-gang of Campbell County; and

Whereas the said S. D. Wilson filed a motion for a new trial, and did give a bond with W. W. Wilson as security in the sum of two thousand ($2,000.00) to appear and answer the final judgment in said case; and

Whereas, after making said motion for new trial and entering into said bond, one Wilber Terry confessed that he and not the said S. D. Wilson was guilty of the crime for which the said S. D. Wilson was convicted, and the said Wilbur Terry exonerated the said S. D. Wilson from any connection or participation in said crime; and

Whereas his Excellency L. G. Hardman, Governor of Georgia, did, on the 13th day of August, 1929, grant to said S. D. Wilson a complete pardon from said sentence, and said pardon was placed in the mail, directed to said S. D. Wilson; and

Whereas, on August 14th, 1929, and before the evidence of said pardon had reached the said S. D. Wilson but after the same had been granted, said bond was forfeited in
Campbell Superior Court, and judgment was entered against the said S. D. Wilson as principal, and W. W. Wilson as surety, for the full amount of said bond:

Therefore be it resolved by the House Representatives, the Senate concurring, that the clerk of the Superior Court of Campbell County and the sheriff of Campbell County, Georgia, be and they are hereby directed to surrender up and cancel the execution issued upon such forfeiture of said bond, and the said S. D. Wilson and W. W. Wilson be and they are hereby relieved of the payment of the sum named in said bond. S. D. and W. W. Wilson relieved from bond.

law.shorttitle: WRIGHT, M. J., RELIEVED AS SURETY.
law.p: Whereas M. J. Wright of Collins, Georgia, did execute a certain bond for the appearance of Y. J. Boyd to City Court of Reidsville, in a case pending against said Y. J. Boyd; and Preamble.
Whereas on September 14, 1926 said bond was forfeited and
Whereas subsequent thereto the said principal on said bond was arrested and sentenced and served his said sentence:

Be it resolved by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, that the county authorities of Tattnall County, Georgia, be and they are hereby authorized to relieve the said M. J. Wright from any and all liability upon said bond forfeiture, and they are authorized to cancel the execution which issued upon the same. Relief of M. J. Wright as surety.

law.shorttitle: WRIGHT, WILLIAM A.; GRATITUDE FOR SERVICES.
law.p: Whereas on September 17th of this year, 1929, Honorable William Ambrose Wright will have completed fifty years of continuous service in the office of Comptroller-General of the State of Georgia, having been re-elected thereto by the people of the Commonwealth every second year since he first entered upon the duties of the office in 1879; and Preamble.

Whereas the soldier service of this chivalric son of the State in the armies of the Confederate States of America resulted in the loss of his right leg in the second battle of Manassas, August 30, 1862; and his private life has been impeccable and his public services to the State as its Comptroller-General for half a century have been vigilant, stainless, and invaluable; therefore

Be it resolved, the Senate and House concurring, that the highest appreciation and gratitude of the people of Georgia is hereby expressed and tendered to Honorable William Ambrose Wright, Comptroller-General, for his long, faithful, and distinguished services in an office of the most intimate trust and importance to his confiding fellow-citizens. Expression of appreciation to be tendered Comptroller-General Wright on fiftieth anniversary of his incumbency.

Resolved further, that a copy of these resolutions, suitably engrossed out of the contingent fund of the Executive Department, be signed by the Governor, attested and sealed by the Secretary of State, and be handed by the Governor and State department officials, the President of the Senate, and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, to Comptroller-General Wright upon the date of the fiftieth anniversary of his unbroken incumbency of his official station.

law.shorttitle: YALE UNIVERSITY AND ABRAHAM BALDWIN HONORED BY HOLIDAY.
law.p: Whereas, in this so-called materialistic age, this age of machinery, there are those who are still moved by a deep sense of appreciation and sentiment, and find occasion to pay tribute to those who have made the State great by contributing to its commercial, educational, and spiritual development; and Preamble.

Whereas the immigrants from Europe, the migration of citizens from other States of our own country, have made their notable contributions to the welfare and progress of Georgia; perhaps no single institution has done so much to advance Georgia to the forefront in things of permanent value as Yale University. The graduates of Yale University early fell in love with Georgia, and many came from year to year, not to find land upon which to settle, but to found schools, colleges, churches, and to become leaders in the secular professions and pursuitsto be governors, lawyers, teachers, statesmen; and Recognition of services rendered Georgia by Abraham Baldwin and other graduates of Yale University.

Whereas among the early graduates of Yale to settle in Georgia was that brilliant, staunch Puritan, Lyman Hall, who from the day of his arrival was prominent in the public life of the State. His intensely patriotic services to Georgia during the Revolutionary period are well known. He was a delegate to the Second Continental Congress, signed the Declaration of Independence, and was elected governor of Georgia. He was a loyal and typical Yale man greatly interested in religion and education; and

Whereas, as Governor, he urged the legislature to make provision for the endowment of seminaries of learning in the State, and in his first message to the legislature, July 8, 1783, said: Every encouragement ought to be given to introduce religion and learned clergy to perform divine worship in honor of God and to cultivate religion and virtue among our citizens. For this purpose it will be your wisdom to
lay an early foundation for endowing seminaries of learning; nor can you, I conceive, lay better than by a grant of land that may, as in other governments, hereafter, by lease or otherwise, raise a sufficient revenue to support such valuable institutions; and

Whereas the next legislature acted by granting, in the law laying out Washington and Franklin Counties, 40,000 acres of land to endow a college or seminary of learning. A board of trustees of seven men was named, and among these was ex-Governor Nathan Brownson, another eminent graduate of Yale University; and still another remarkable graduate of Yale University, Abraham Baldwin, whose life and service to Georgia have been rescued from oblivion by the late Doctor H. C. White, for more than fifty years professor of chemistry in the State University; and

Whereas Abraham, Baldwin came to Georgia from Yale University at the invitation of General Nathaniel Greene and Governor Lyman Hall, settled in Wilkes County, and later represented that county in the legislature. Afterwards he was elected to Congress and to the Senate. He was an active and an important contributor to the building of Georgia, one of the group of wise men who laid securely the foundations upon which was builded the present great republic; and

Whereas that illustrious Georgian, Richard Malcolm Johnston, said of him: He was the greatest man that ever lived in Georgia. In some respects he was superior to Jefferson. Justice has never been done to his great merits. He wrote the charter of the University of Georgia, a document that contains sentiments as lofty, as sublime and as inspiring as any found in the Declaration of Independence; as for example, It should be among the first objects of those looking towards the national prosperity to support and encourage the principles of morality and religion, and thus early to place youth under the forming hand of society, that by instruction they may be moulded to love of virtue and good order; and
Whereas Abraham Baldwin has the great honor of being the founder of the first of American State Universities and the first President of a State University; and

Whereas still another brilliant son of Yale came to Georgia to be the first active President of the University of Georgia, Josiah Meigs. He was given authority to select his own faculty, and of course selected Yale graduates; and
Whereas time will not permit to recite the contributions made by Yale graduates in other lines of activity, nor their full contributions to the educational system of Georgia; and

Whereas Yale University has done the University of Georgia the distinguished honor of accepting its invitation to send their football team to engage in a game which will dedicate the new stadium on October 12. It is such an unusual event for the Yale team to play at any field outside of New Haven, except Harvard or Princeton, that the University of Georgia has felt peculiarly complimented by their acceptance of its invitation, and are extremely anxious to make the occasion memorable in every way. Yale was prompted to accept the invitation because of its intimate kinship with Georgia; and Appreciation of attendance of Yale football team at dedication of State University Stadium, October 12.

Whereas Dr. George H. Nettleton, chairman of the athletic board of control, Yale University, states: With the founding and development of this university Yale has most intimate connections. In recognition of such close academic kinship and of the special interest of Yale graduates in the South, exceptional consideration was paid to exceptional circumstances. The determining factor is not accidental rivalry for inter-sectional athletic supremacy, but settled community of academic interests and friendly regard; and

Whereas, in recognition of the great services rendered the State of Georgia by its many illustrious graduates of Yale University: Lyman Hall, Nathan Brownson, Abraham Baldwin, Josiah Meigs, and others, and in appreciation of the coming of Yale University to dedicate the new stadium of one of her childrenthe State University:

Therefore be it resolved, by the General Assembly of Georgia, that Saturday, October 12, be and the same is hereby designated a legal holiday for the year 1929, as a courtesy to Yale and in honor of the founder of the first of American State Universities, to be known as Abraham Baldwin Day. October 12 designated as legal holiday for 1929, to be known as Abraham Baldwin Day.
